\[Page 1\]

Preface to the Fourth Volume
============================

As the foregoing sections of the fourth volume of the Mystik round off and conclude this part of the great edifice --- which, founded in the visible and tangible earth, carries that same tangibility over into the two invisible regions --- the work had therefore to be divided into three large departments. One comprises therein those very foundations laid safely and well‑fitted into earthly nature; and this part is the Physiology of Mysticism. The second is that part of the building which, upon this firm ground, rises into those regions which, in respect of root and origin, are indeed above the earth, but are yet in it insofar as they make themselves known and reveal themselves in earthly things; and this section will embrace the Theology of Mysticism, within the circuit of the militant Church. Finally the third part will sink into those regions which lie beneath earthly nature; and although grounded in Hell, yet, in rising, manifest and spread themselves upon the earth --- and here the Demonology of Mysticism will be expounded. The earlier volumes were devoted to the development of the first two; now the third too has found its own, so that this part of the building is closed, and we may set the bouquet on the height.

The work rises on the spot where until now the heap of shards of recent centuries had stood; just as, indeed, its model, the Cross, was raised upon the skull‑place of ancient times. The spot had seemed uncanny in these centuries; for spirits walked there that wandered in their affairs. Thus the site was designated by the police as the place where all filth should be deposited; and since the times produced much filth, and in the movement many pots were broken, the mass of what was brought in piled up mountain‑high; and people comforted themselves thus: the spirits would be well covered, and would lose the desire to stir under the weight. But spirits go through rock and through ruins; they were always on top, as the industrious carters brought more; the gravediggers could not succeed in banishing them by burial. Now in shards and rubble and rubbish the cornerstones cannot be laid durably. Therefore the place had to be cleansed beforehand, and when that was done, behold the whole foundation of the work stood revealed, already carried high above the earth; the diligent had only carted in the great quantity of rubbish because the fortress of enlightenment seemed too threatening. Rumour was set in circulation: there had once stood there counterfeit‑minting establishments which had to be buried. The inhabitants, who ought to have known better, permitted the fable and grew accustomed to approach the place only with caution, and fancied each night they still heard the hammer‑blows. The speaker of the present work, who has some respect for the scientific instinct of the schools of this age, but assigns nothing to their higher intentions and wholly rejects their truthfulness and credibility in such matters, was not deterred by this ban which learned timidity had laid upon the place; he fell upon it and began the work of clearing. Upon the found substructure he then continued to build; and, the stoutest hands of all times lending aid in the work, he in the course of a few years brought it to the point at which it now stands before the eye. Precisely the ill repute of the matter and the secret fear of spirits which surrounded the object kept the workmen from pressing forward. \[Page 2\]

Some would not look; others jeered at the folly of the treasure‑diggers; the third, the genuine workmen --- for they always go about in aprons and with the trowel --- cried: Let them dig, the uncritical ones, and, in the Roman‑Catholic sense, go in search of miracles; if they find none, they will rightly be laughed at; but if they do stumble on some, then they have only brought to light the proofs of the spuriousness of their Church! Thus the work proceeded publicly, undisturbed by the world; whereas the crush and crowding of the great market otherwise do not easily allow anything thorough to come to maturity, here the peace of God and the silence of solitude lingered: each matter could be treated with quiet composure, each could obtain its right, confused and led astray by no objection; and so the work gradually rose up to its ridge and now supports and protects itself, and let Nidhauger gnaw at its foundations in vain. For it is a bulwark of Catholicism which those who ought to defend it had abandoned and left to decay. Now it is newly fortified and well preserved; for it rests firm upon its rocky ground and can defy every attack.

As already said, the work is planned threefold: an earthly one, solid and well put together, each projection mutually securing the others; a supra‑earthly one, surveying and governing all; and an under‑earthly one, displaying its secret terrors beneath what is visible; the three covering, protecting, and corroborating one another. Three full, rounded, self‑contained disciplines --- indeed sciences --- are here established; each enjoys an actual foundation such as few others possess. With respect, first of all, to the physiology of mysticism, this foundation is similar to that which underlies the natural sciences. Here are the physicians and the naturalists who offer themselves as guarantors of the facts that belong to them; and if of the whole abundance of the natural riches only some things, and these not down to their innermost ground, are ascertained, this arises from the overarching, hard‑to‑access nature of the object, and induction here has at least the certainty of every medical science, and is daily strengthened by the advancing spiritualization of all physics.

The induction of hagiological mysticism appears incomparably better established. For the fact in question here springs from the soil of the most devout, God‑inspired, most blameless, most truth‑ful individuals; it is apprehended by them throughout in a penetrating, ethically purified and comprehensive spirit as far as possible; it is externally attested by witnesses who are in the most favorable position to discern it from the outside inward, even as they themselves are again discerned by it from the inside outward. They are therefore, as indeed by their vocation and position in general they are called to be, seekers after truth and proclaimers of truth. The ground of the attested --- the holiness of the individual producing the fact --- is further confirmed after that person's death in the miracles which he performs, and this guarantee is then certified by the authority of the Church, which thus likewise sanctions the innermost foundation of the attested truth. What other fact in the whole realm of science --- except perhaps the self‑consciousness guaranteed by the consciousness of God and of nature, which is the basis of all scientific certainty --- may be compared with the assurance of this historical fact? \[Page 3\]

In the demonology of mysticism this guarantee---the holiness of the one presenting the facts---indeed generally falls away; but in its place there now steps an ethical necessity which has just as firm a law as the physical one in natural phenomena, and thus affords to its products the same security as those. Error can in both cases lie only in the apprehension, and there again vouchsafe the same credible, practised witnesses who have borne testimony in the regions of that holy mysticism; and to these, strengthening their guarantee, are added the summoned physicians and the jurists. If, then, the certainty of this order of facts by no means attains that of the other, its guarantee nevertheless lies midway between that claimed by the physiologico‑mystical and that due to the hagiological. Thus matters stand with the facts in general; as to the particular selection made from the mass before us, we have already spoken concerning the first two disciplines; here we may only append to what has already been said the necessary remarks regarding the demonological.

First, as to possession: in order to bring the authenticity of the chosen examples---the ones valid in the higher domain---as close as possible, we have preferred those that occur frequently from the Gospels onward throughout the history of the saints. The atmosphere that surrounds a saint penetrates and overcomes the haze of falsehood and the darkness of the gloomy circle that has drawn itself around the possessed, and the same degree of certainty to which the whole life of the holy man lays claim extends likewise to this integrative moment of his. Secondly, those places where a remaining relic of such a saint--- a reliquary, for example---mediated intercourse with him, and where throngs of the afflicted gathered about such a site, have produced a rich practice in which a comparatively significant mass of facts has now accumulated.

We mention first the Camaldolese monastery of Valombrosa, half a day's journey from Florence. Saint Walbert, contemporary of Gregory VII and founder of the order, had there erected an oratory to the Blessed Virgin. In his life he had, when a dying monk was grievously terrified by a vision of a demon, driven it off with a cross which he took from the hand of the dying man. The monks preserved the cross there, and it soon served to test the possessed with it to determine whether they were truly demonic. Later the arm that had borne the crucifix to victory was also discovered; and from that time the Church of Our Lady at Valombrosa became a refuge for the possessed for all Tuscany; indeed, they came in swarms even as far as the borders of France. The healings increased, and since the year 1450 the occurrences had also found someone to record them in writing. \[Page 4\]

Responding to the urging of the physician Laurentius, who had been present on the spot, Hieronymus of Raggiolo, an active and very pious man, from what he there found, learned from credible old people, and saw with his own eyes, compiled eighteen books on the demonic healings. The confidence in which the holy place and its founder were held was so great that, as he reports in Book XVII, merely from the Getica region in Tuscany and the surrounding territories, every month---except in the depths of winter---three to four possessed persons, women and men, and people of every rank, came to seek deliverance; and hardly had they obtained it when they were again replaced by newcomers. The tomb of the holy Cajetanus in Naples was just as celebrated as he was helpful to those sick from the demon: hence he was visited even down to recent times by such persons, who filled everything around them with their howling and the lamentations of their oppressed spirits, and hung all the walls with stones, nails, tufts of hair and similar rubbish as trophies of the saint's victories. The relics of St. Ubaldus, who died in 1160, are buried in Gubbio, and from the hour of his death down to the most recent times the possessed were delivered at his grave; some even while they were climbing the mountain. The wondrous healings which there occurred up to the year 1519 have been written down by Stephen of Cremona, who also composed a book on the exorcism and personally practised it there, from his own eyewitness account and from what he heard from those present.

At the grave of Saint Leontius in Mur many were likewise freed; in Teinst in Belgium likewise at that of St. Amalberga, who died in 772; the Helfersberg in the Eichsfeld, where St. Boniface overthrew the image of Stuffo, and Charlemagne raised up the cross which Heizzo had borne in his battles against the Saxons, was likewise thereby famous in central Germany. At all these places a rich source of experience flowed; the temple annals show the holy malady in all its forms and aspects; and the only thing that can be objected to them is that they preserve merely the healings that occurred, and for the most part pass over in silence the cases of local incurability.

All these facts were attested by credible observers, but among them there is still a lack of such as have found this attestation also through the personality in which they manifested themselves. The mass of ordinary possessed persons is entangled by the predominance of a mendacious force; against it a single, but weakly self-assured personality reacts only feebly. To remedy this evil state, a hard-to-reconcile combination of holiness and possession had to be united in the same person; a combination which, precisely because of the inner contradiction, will occur only rarely. It is known that some of the ancient fathers in the desert were in such a way at once holy and possessed; but neither have they recorded reminiscences of their internal condition, nor have those who stood near them preserved any such records. \[Page 5\]

Among all the saints collected by the Bollandists the same is reported only of St. Eustochia in Padua; without, however, learning there any nearer circumstances concerning her. Bernardinus Seardonius, the canon there, spoke of her at greater length in his writing De antiquitate urbis Patavii (Basle, 1560), yet unsatisfactorily; and to learn more about her one must look about in her vitae, which on this side of the Alps are scarcely to be found anywhere. Her life, by Michael Aug\[?\], Abac\[?\], the Theatine, appeared in 1666; that by the Augustinian Giberti in Venice in 1672 and 1674; a third by Giuseppe Salio in the Venetian edition of 1739. Above all, good and beautiful, written in classical Italian, is the Vita, miracoli della beata Eustochia vergine padovana nata e professa dell'ordine benedettino nel monasterio di S. Prosdocimo di Padova, scritta dal P. Giulio Corr\[ado\] della Compagnia di Gesù. Rome, \[date illegible\]. Cesare has made an extract from it known in his Fiore di storia ecclesiastica (Turin, 1856). All these refer back to an earlier one by Baroccio, who was Bishop of Padua from 1488--1507, and finally all go back to a common source, the records of her confessor Saligario.

His contemporaries testify of him: Girolamo Saligario was a learned and devout priest of Padua, who not long after their death wrote the life of the departed in the form of an instruction for another nun, in a simple style. He was well informed about everything that occurred with her day by day; for she concealed nothing from him. All are unanimous that he was learned enough not to be easily deceived in matters of the spirit; sufficiently clever not to be taken in by appearances; possessed of adequate keenness to distinguish false virtue from true; and if no other testimony existed, his writing would speak for him. He declares that he has written with all truth and exactness, and he appeals each time to what he saw with his eyes and touched with his hands, mentioning only in passing other things that he had learned by hearsay. He knew, moreover, that he had unusual things to relate, and warns the nuns not to let themselves be led astray by them. (Italian:) "Di ciò non mi curo, perché io non parlo con increduli, né con eretici. Mi basta in questo la testimonianza della mia coscienza, et Dio sa, che in ciò, che scrivo non desidero che laude; ma la verità onorata, ed alle anime utilità." --- I care nothing for that, for I do not speak with unbelievers nor with heretics. The testimony of my conscience suffices me in this, and God knows that in what I write I desire neither praise nor glory, but the truth praised and the good of souls.

This manuscript was to be kept in the library of St. Prosdocimus in Padua, and consulting it there was one of the reasons that in the autumn of 1810 determined me to cross the Alps. But St. Prosdocimus had been suppressed under the French rule; the remains of the custodia had been taken to another female convent of the city; and it was possible that the books had been moved as well. But upon inquiry of the superior of the institution it turned out that none were there; and as to what had become of them for the fourth volume no information could be given. With further inquiry the cathedral library was indicated as the place to which the books had been delivered; and soon there everything that could possibly be found was put before the inquirer with friendly willingness. The following manuscripts were among them:

I: A parchment volume in small quarto from the year 1465 (8 Kal. Jun.), written in old Italian, under the title: Jesus Maria. Hieronimus s. P. Presbyter ad Eustochium monialem reclusam et ad ceteras sorores. In the beginning it says: "Dilecta filia, in me ha domandato et tu desidero de intendere alguna cosa utile del giudicio finale." --- "Beloved daughter, you have asked me and you desire to understand something useful about the final judgment." This desire, he then continues, is just, and in no way should its fulfilment be refused, and he cites in this matter the judgment of St. Bernard. He then proceeds in the first part to the workings of the malignant spirits, setting forth the experiences and thoughts of St. Anthony about them; he then expatiates on the diversi inganni del Demonio --- the various deceits of the Devil --- further on le arme de' Demoni --- the weapons of the Demons --- and on the weapons of prayer against demonic apparitions. Then he treats of the angels and the good spirits and their helpful activity. The second section then speaks at length of the Last Judgment, of Gog and Magog, of the Antichrist and the other apocalyptic apparatus. The third deals with the manner in which one should humble oneself before God's judgment in life, and with patience accept what He has decreed. The writing, although it does not further mention the Custodia by name, was evidently occasioned by her. She had died shortly before, and her fate had awakened much reflection in the convent; and the nuns could hardly understand how it had come about that so innocent, pure, indeed holy a person could be subject to such harsh dispensations; and the confessor of the convent now endeavours to explain the matter to them. The book is written in the plain language of the time, and one readily recognizes from it that the above-cited judgment of his contemporaries about its author was completely justified. At the end several leaves are torn away. \[Page 6\]

II: A parchment manuscript in another hand, in octavo, treating the temptations and how they are very useful and necessary for the salvation of man; again addressed to Eustochio and the nuns; often referring to her life but not relating it, and likewise defective at the end.

III: A third volume, continuing the same subject from the temptation, completing the begun theodicy, and also frequently referring to the Book of Job. It is a thick quarto volume, written on paper, addressed to the sisters Scholastica and Veronica, and at the end marked "1401 XIV. Calend. Novembr."; therefore, as perhaps also II, not by Saligario, who at that time was hardly still alive. Finally a fourth volume in folio on parchment, the Miracles of the blessed Eustochia, as they occur daily at her grave, containing the years 1472--1487, and authenticated with a notarial signature. Although Eustochia had given occasion for all these books; and although they more than once allude to her and to the life written about her, that life itself is not among them.

Now, since further investigation proved fruitless, and the condition of the manuscripts still extant, and the partial destruction they had suffered, could only have arisen from the vandalism to which they had been exposed at the suppression of the monastery, the obvious conclusion suggested itself: that this violence had not been content with a part of the thing sought, but had destroyed it altogether, and thereby cut off every further inquiry. Such were the circumstances when the reporter went over to Venice on other business. Soon the librarian of the seminary of Padua, H. Valentinelli --- whose helpful kindness in everything he must gratefully praise in the highest terms --- wrote to him: a copy of the manuscript in question had since been found in the episcopal chancery together with other related papers; and these had been opened, by higher permission, to the returning researcher. It was clear, since the bishops at various times had pursued her canonization, that these manuscripts had then, when the necessary apparatus was assembled, been deposited in the episcopal archive. On arriving on the spot His Episcopal Grace readily and obligingly opened access, and there was first found the hitherto thought‑lost life by Baroccio under the title: Vita della beata Eustochio composto in latino per il molto Rev. Padre Monsignor Pietro Baroccio, vescovo paduano et tradotta in volgare da Daniele Villa Doctorlegista Pad., et scritta di mia propria mano ad istanza della ven. Abadessa del Monast. de scto Prosdocimo, nel Anno 1541. 5. Apr. --- in six closely and very illegibly written quarto leaves; and another somewhat differing recension in seven folio leaves, again ascribed to Barozzo "homo dottissimo et de santa vita." Beside these was found: Catalogo de memorie antiche et moderne manuscr. et a stampa int. alla b. Eustochio nel Monasterio de S. Prosdocimo; and in it were entered all the manuscripts that we above recorded as being in the cathedral library, with the note that between Nos. 1 and 11 in this catalogue there had been included an octavo‑format one no longer extant, by the same author Girolamo Saligario, in which the life and precious death of Blessed Eustochio are dealt with. That manuscript was therefore lost; but of it there was, besides an instruction for the canonization process, an opinion by the Jesuit Butta Fanre on the subject, and the correspondence that had already been exchanged, a copy in small folio on paper in two parts under the title: Memorie della b. Eustochio paduana, scritte da Girolamo Saligario Sacerd. Pad. Confess. \[Page 7\]

This copy was taken faithfully from the ancient original manuscript that was preserved in the archive of the monastery of St. Prosdocimus. It is in the old Paduan dialect, which itself is sometimes difficult even for the present inhabitants to understand, but is otherwise written legibly; and at the end of the second part, which---weaker than the first---contains only 34 pages, the following note is entered: In fine del manoscritto leggesi 1477 septimo Idus Decembris; and a little lower: questo libro e del monasterio de s. Prosdoc. Padoa, 1418. One sees that Baroccio, the contemporary of the author, had already drawn from it, and later biographers have adhered to it. Only a few facts, which were nevertheless of the greatest importance for mysticism, they had overlooked. These were immediately extracted and are taken up further below in their proper place, in the third (and for the fourth) volume.

Thus the authenticity of the facts in the history of the possessions was pretty well provided for; it remained at once to procure equally reliable material for the matters of witchcraft and sorcery. Whoever has looked about even somewhat in this field knows how the matter stands throughout with respect to the experiential basis. Current literature is by no means lacking in such material; but it is as if the rabble itself, in cat form, had fallen upon it and roughed it up and thus entangled it so that no one is able to disentangle the snarled ball. Fabulous, legendary, natural and demonic elements run together in German matters in such a way that no one is able to separate them; the accounts may be true, but nothing has been done to demonstrate this truth externally. Even the records of the witch trials yield little; because of the slovenliness of the whole procedure---mostly only the back-and-forth talk of the excited populace, in part reporting oddities that are nowhere pursued and sifted thoroughly; then the unreliable confessions of those terrified to death on the rack, one miserable creature taking from the mouth of another; and so the same monotonous chatter repeats itself and leads to no result.

Not of much greater value are the contributions that England supplies us in this matter; there the entire form of process was directed to determining the persuasion of the jurors, which, being assumed in advance, did not require deeper probing. It was different, however, in France. That people---predominantly a measuring, counting and weighing people of understanding---has always directed a particular attention to form in all things, and has brought it everywhere to importance. The higher courts, the parliaments, have taken those processes in hand; they have never lacked wise, sensible, humane jurists, backed by the tradition of a legal experience of centuries; carelessness has not easily found its way into their sessions, and they have left no means untried to shed light on so complicated a matter and to motivate their judgments.

The clergy there have indeed allowed credence to the ground of the matter, but that very national spirit did not permit them to surrender to it blindly, shutting themselves against every objection of skepticism. Therefore they have at all times, with the same sobriety of mind which the national spirit now brings to the physical sciences, observed and experimented on the subject with the same keenness of intellect as is now customary, and have then deposited the results in authentic form. The physicians, too, have not lagged behind; one perceives throughout how doubt and the evidence of the senses contended in them, and how they at last recorded the findings conscientiously and in the best form. So we are thus offered here a material that has gone through a threefold examination by fully authorized and --- each in his own sphere --- distinguished observers, and under the stamp of these wardens has acquired complete credibility and guarantee. The inclination that moreover has always existed among this people to set down memorials about the lives of individuals has prompted several who were involved in the matter to leave us such writings of repentance or of renunciation; without doubt they are to be counted among first‑order documentary pieces, because they proceed from the most concerned and best‑informed. From there, then, we have consistently taken the facts that form the basis of this second part; they will speak for themselves, and if they err, they err in that error which clings to all human knowledge, and which even the threefold control is unable to separate.

A subject of this kind already contains in itself the impulse to arrange itself into determinate forms; as the elements of water in still air of their own accord unite into the snowflake. It is induction, namely, that seizes them, and according to a definite formal law of elective affinity joins them into a whole; a schematism which shows itself arranged, as it were, in radiations and sub‑radiations. The next question is: according to which formal law will this schematism be structured? Without doubt according to the same in which the human personality is held. For all these facts have appeared with reference to the human personality; it is the ground from which they have grown; all of them together, considered as a complex, are found bound up in it, in a regularity that governs all its manifestations. Since it itself appears divided into body and soul, and is again united in a third out of both into unity, and since this same basic structure repeats itself in all things subordinated to it; the law in which they are all connected with one another will likewise bind the facts that have sprung from them into a natural system. Thus induction in this book has proceeded through the domains of all three sciences. In the first volume it physiologically established the natural schematism of the human personality, and then carried this through the two other domains. Around it the formative impulse in the facts immediately began its play; a busy rushing about and confusion forthwith arose; for each one, unbidden, sought its place, and only after it had found the right place did it rest in it. Nothing artificial was done beforehand to prepare and insert them; they arranged themselves of their own accord, and now confirm and defend one another. In parallel fashion, in three domains the same play repeated itself; above it was only the brightly shining ethical and supra‑ethical light that prevailed, below the darkly shining sub‑ethical light; while in the middle the natural light to which these efflorescences refer. All three mutually reinforce one another, and only after formation succeeded above did it become possible to disentangle the amorphous error and confusion of the lower, and likewise to order them and circumscribe them with determinate lines. Thus the three circles --- the physical, the metaphysical, and the hypophysic (hypophysical) --- are rounded and well closed, and the three formal sciences native to them bear witness to one another; and now that each has found its place within them, it testifies also for itself and for its whole surroundings, and is in turn attested by them. In the whole extent of what has thus been ordered there is nothing that a sensible man ought to be ashamed to believe; yet a diligent closing of oneself against the evidence of truth, and the rejection of the guarantee of unimpeachable witnesses, would be a most shameful stubbornness. to the fourth volume.

The induction, having reached this point, nevertheless first encounters a new task which it must solve if it is to be completed otherwise. Order and its lawfulness, and in part observation itself, have hitherto been purely formal in character, and they therefore point back to an inner, substantive being that underlies them, and which must first be found, and from which the formal must first be derived and developed, before science can then fulfil itself. This substantial ground in all things is now of the nature of unity, which unfolds itself in the multiplicity of forms in every direction; in a law which, of mixed character---substantial and formal---appears bound in a third respect. These unities in the sciences must first of all be sought, and at the same time the laws of unfolding that inhere in them. In physiology the unity is the unity of nature, and the law the organic, in which life is contained. In hagiology the unity is God, and the law the norm in which he reveals himself to man in the realm of grace. In demonology the unity is sheltered in the personality of root‑evil, and the law of this unity makes itself known in the modality in which it manifests itself in the realm of the curse. To the previous analysis, therefore, a synthesis is now appended, and this is in the first circle indeed of a philosophical kind, but in the other two wholly theological. It cannot be avoided; for the analysis must precisely in it find the unity to which it belongs, so that it may be carried through; and this unity cannot justly unfold itself in relation to the given multiplicity, and thus complete the synthesis, without finding indicated in the analysis the focal points of its opening directions; so that both presuppose one another, and one becomes the control of the other. \[Page 8\]

If, therefore, in formal science it has been observation and the scientific mind that have guided induction, it is now---at least in two of the three circles---dogma and the Church that take over guidance and judgment in the synthesis. The Church has always been the great mistress of every synthesis; a work such as this remains at all times subject to her, so that she may examine whether the synthetic spirit at work in it has proceeded with care and rightly; and so great is the respect its author has acquired for that spirit of hers that, even if her judgment should not immediately appear convincing to him, he would nevertheless feel determined to assent to it without hesitation. The analysis in the book, however, stands or falls with this synthesis. A fourth discipline is still lacking to complete the whole scientific organism. In the first three it is the Logos made man who stands as the highest unity: first over physiology, as he by whose likeness nature was fashioned; over hagiology, as he in whom the divine and the human natures are united, and who now, assimilating to himself the personality of the holy one analogous to his humanity, draws it to himself and appropriates it; finally over demonology, as the power which fashioned the nature of the demon in its in‑itself good being, and even to that which is evil as the result of its perversion sets its bounds, limiting it in its inner, albeit abnormal, lawfulness (limited to the fourth volume), and permits and tolerates the connections of the same with mixed natures, and at will divides and separates them.

Beyond this unity, however, there lies still a higher one, that of the Trinity, into which the Logos himself enters as a moment, in the divine being. For it the whole creation has only the significance of a divine thought; hell hides in the abyss of its own being, and heaven has meaning only because it most perfectly expresses that thought. Demonology is thus here wholly bound and overcome by hagiology; and a higher physiology occupies it in divine physis. Through the Logos this higher unity is opened to the human spirit from afar and the way to it shown; and in it the analytical and the synthetic movements of thought likewise coalesce into one. This fourth, highest mystic therefore stands above the three others; she is in the One, the Second is about her, the Third is deep beneath her. She thus stands in secluded solitude for herself; the best of the Others touches only her outermost rim, and she is already in them through the Logos. The three therefore form a closed whole for themselves, and she again likewise, and yet again by no means entirely withdraws from those three. Therefore, now that the trilogy has come to its close, we regard the work as rounded and complete in itself, and we shall---after other necessary preliminary labours are ended, when it is granted us to return to the subject--- endeavour, following also the traces of that Higher, to apprehend them likewise in a comprehensive conception. In the meantime we hold the work closed and finished with the three disciplines: the other, its most general fundamentals, already contained in the introduction to Suso, could on the basis of that triad easily also have been completed by another, and even in recent times there has not been a lack of, in part, estimable preliminary studies. The completed work now submits itself to judgment, eluding no competent person, but closing itself to the weak-minded and prejudiced, and growing and prospering in the life that dwells in it.

Munich, at the equinox 1842. J. Görres.

Book IX. The Witch and Magic-Being
==================================

Section I. Transitions from Involuntary Possession to the Voluntary Attaching Oneself to the Evil
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

\[Page 9\]

The possessed person is for the most part, against his will and contrary to his intention, brought into intimate fellowship with the principle of evil that has produced his condition; and his endeavour is directed to the tearing asunder, as soon as possible, of the bond which mediates this intercourse. But just as in all that is human a twofold aspect of its being emerges---one in which he may be had, while in the other he has and seizes---so this doubleness will prove itself here also. If the boundless state of possession by a tyrannical power is also contrary to the individual will, and painful through its torments, the thought of self-possession and of intimacy with a power that now apparently honors the master and obeys him, while turning its baneful effect against others, flatters him on the other hand. Such a relation is therefore the reverse side of the other; and while the latter is formed by a sudden inroad, violent as a robbery, the former permits a free conclusion: the one who concludes, with a certain composure, yields himself to the intoxication, and now, after he has made an act of subjection, demands back from the power to which he has surrendered the surrendered thing, increased with usurious interest. The beginnings of such a relation are sometimes already to be found in the very tumult of a possession. \[Page 10\]

It has indeed sometimes happened that the possessed, either already by their own evil disposition or wearied by the torments they must endure, become in all things willing to the spirit that dwells in them and tyrannically masters them, and obey it; whereby the torment indeed ceases, but the consenting ones at once become companions and assistants in the commission of many misdeeds. Moreover, a variety of circumstances that occur in possessions point into a region where things that here proceed under the form of will‑less necessity were brought about by deliberate consideration; so that it gains the appearance as if possession itself were either the artificial work of deliberate contrivance, or at least, both in its origin and in its course, continued in a certain relation with the masters of the art.

Thus Peter Bernardi of Areia was violently possessed; he bit at noses and ears, and howled so that the hills and mountains around Valombrosa rang again. When the exorcism was applied, his spirit began to speak and recounted how he, bound by a charm, could not free himself until that charm placed under his threshold was removed. The monks, however, attached no credence to these words and continued with the invocation. The possessed then became entirely furious, and with a wild, burning eye cried out: "O cross! O torment! what must I endure; for what, you villains, all the praying, and the singing and toil! You well know what I said before." Some of those who had brought him into the monastery thought now that one must remove whatever might be found there; the monks, however, prevented anyone from proceeding to the work, so that it should not appear as if they had credited the devil, or that he had only departed after the removal of the charm. They therefore continued calmly and unconcerned with the exorcism; but he now tore himself away from the hands of those holding him, was thrown to the ground by the demon, and tormented as never before. This continued for a while; at last the demon, exhausted and unable to resist further, departed.

But it was worth the trouble, says Hieronymus, to hear what voices he uttered, even afterwards wandering about in the sanctuary; it would have seemed incredible to me were it not for the credible persons who, as eyewitnesses, gave me an account of everything. Such a clamor and tumult and trembling accompanied the departure that one thought the church and monastery were coming to ruin. Having returned to Florence, the people, disregarding the prohibition in the monastery, searched what lay beneath the threshold, and found a bundled, silk‑thread‑bound cloth, and in it a piece of the bone of a dead child, a woman's hair, the skin of a donkey's hide, with certain signs and characters written on it, all of which they immediately gave to the fire.

One sees that the ancient idea of magic and counter‑magic underlies this report. What the fingers of the dactyls, brooding mischief, had bound to the left side, the fingers of the right again loosened, preparing good fortune, and thus good and ill kept equal balance. So here it was words, formulas, and the relics of a child that had bound the possession; but the power of fire was to unravel the knotted thing as a counter‑charm. The Church, rightly, has not adopted this doctrine; she has not wished to regard the exorcism and her aid as merely a counterpart to witchcraft, lying on the same level with it; but rather as the higher thing, lying above magic and counter‑magic, because rooted in God; and in advancing unerringly along the appointed path she has broken the one and rendered the other unnecessary.

Similar things have at times occurred in other cases. A woman from Calcia was possessed on the eve of the Feast of Our Lady of the Snows. They took the sufferer to Valombrosa, and Hieronymus of Raggiolo himself exorcised her there; but her demon remained silent for a long time. Then a stranger monk, well versed in necromancy, happened to come by and begged to be allowed to speak something into the mouth (ear) of the possessed woman. He was permitted, and he delivered his speech. Immediately the demon looked at him threateningly and burst out with the words: "Hypocrite and flatterer, not a brother, but a corrupter! How dare you in this holy place, with evil art, force him whom God has not yet forced? You would rue it on the spot, if what you bear on your breast were your work." The monk answered: "I do not fear your threats!" The demon then formally challenged him, and the challenge ran to the Alps or elsewhere, wherever it pleased him; "you will not reach Perusium without having felt my power!" When the monk on his journey had come to the Perusinian lake, he sat down, weary, beneath an olive tree on the bank of the water. In a short while a black vapor and smoke rose from the waves, wrapped him completely in night and shape, and then lifted itself into the air. The monk died, probably of fright, in Perusium. (The word he had spoken into the woman's ear was probably the formula: Exi daemon quia Ephimolei tibi praecipiunt!) For, according to necromantic tradition, these words have the power, in distinguishing possession from falling sickness, to act healingly upon it. If the possessed person falls, having heard the formula, and drops senseless, but after some time rises again and relates what has just happened --- proclaiming things true and unknown --- then he ought to be freed; but if nothing of the kind occurs, then it is the falling sickness that is afflicting him. That, then, was the counter-charm the monk had probably intended to use, the application of which, however, turned out so badly for him because the demon did not acknowledge the power of the forces by which he sought to subdue it. \[Page 11\]

At other times it has been amulets to which the spell was tied, even if only in the belief of the bound person; after their removal the release then proceeded more easily. An old woman who was brought to Valombrosa was there severely tormented; at times, however, she would break out into jest and laughter, during which she would then recite the Creed and other chants, in the manner of priests not badly sang. At last the sorely pressed demon cries out from her: If what she hides beneath her dress is not taken away, I cannot go out. It is found, and all the monks saw it with their eyes; it was an amulet marked with various signs, letters and words in the corners, set in wax and bound about with ribbons. Among the words were also Gog and Magog, the Tetragrammaton, Adonai and Sabaoth. It was burned, and the demon came forth with a great noise. It was not Gog and Magog that held him bound; but in all probability it was her intention, which the woman, in the agitation of all her powers, had directed to it, and which now formed the knot by which she remained continually entangled and connected with her malady and its originator.

Again, too, the statements of the spirit compelled to speak sometimes concern connections that he had had with third parties, in the wake of which his relation to the possessed person has arisen; statements to which, of course, no more weight is to be given than the deponent deserves. Thus a girl from Città di Castello becomes possessed. At times she is perfectly quiet and calm, at other times she wants to kill herself with a sword, and she attacks others with nails and teeth. The demon, when questioned, finally declares: a priest had conceived love for the girl; but because she did not heed his importunities, he had conjured him to win the refractory one for him. But since even these arts wrought nothing, he, enraged, entered into her; yet he held her very well, so that he even himself went with her to church. Pressed to the attack, he demands that the priest who had bound him should first also loose him again. When his demand is refused, he at last departs.

Therefore the attempt at such sorcery itself is sometimes punished with possession. So it befell a woman who had yielded to the sorcery and was now brought possessed to St. Gandolph. The spirit, questioned, says: I am the demon, and by the evil art of this wretch conjured, I entered into her. So then, replies the priest, amid teeth‑gnashing, foaming and terrible voices, come forth again! The people await the result, and everything happens as he said.

Through these intimations, then, we are transported into a quite new field. In the foregoing domain the objective had everywhere become predominant; a gloomy power had, with tyrannical force, taken possession of man and made him, without his being able to resist, its slave. It had therefore seized him at that side of his being where he himself also grounds his objectivity; at that root of his existence which reaches into the multiplicity of existing things, whether spiritual or material, and through which he, as a member of the created whole, is incorporated into its totality, shares in its movements, lives in its life, co‑acts in its actions, and has his thoughts thought along and woven into the larger strokes and circuits of the world‑forces. This side is therefore, in its lower element, the life‑circle turned outward in two directions; this part has a share in the flowing source of all life; it is the complex of his deeper instincts, to which external activities and stimulations correspond. It is then the direction of his sphere of will, which, tending outward and downward, takes determinations from there, and conforms itself to the law and rhythm of necessity in order to find in the ever‑same a counter‑support on which it can exercise its higher autonomy. \[Page 12\]

At last there emerges that mode of thinking which, being bound to what is given, finds itself moved spiritually, like the atmosphere by the regular currents of the year, and the heat poured out into space by the contacts of light; and which in its turn again gives the spirit a firm, secure foundation that it is able to grasp and determine. This kind of possible grasping through all domains belongs to the natural constitution of man; it is that which is Nature in him itself, the one, together with his being, as a personality formed of two united into one, coherent side of his existence. \[Page 13\]

But when into this natural ground the ground of root-like Evil has entered, and this, behaving as Nature, in its own way has laid hold of this side of the human being, and in its own manner has nullified all regularity of the natural by boundless arbitrariness and distorted it to extremes, therefrom possession has arisen. The seizure of possession, however, has taken place in the ganglionic system, and indeed in that half of it which is turned away from the indwelling spirit, is more open to objective influences, and therefore carries the rhythm of life, regulated by the pulse of Nature, into all the stirrings of the inner life. We have followed and expounded the metamorphoses of Evil, which arose through the intrusion of Evil into intercourse with Nature, in earlier \[writings\] in their whole development. But now the other side of existence, the subjective, presents itself to our consideration --- that side in which man is himself in the midst of the flowing course of things; a particular concrete personality, endowed with freedom, and with consciousness mastering itself and, to a certain degree, also the outward. That outward side could be subdued and conquered; the evil principle could, if it is permitted, dwell in it as in its own property; the other side, however, which is surrounded by it, remained unconquerable --- it could not, because sheltered in God, be taken away by the Evil and destroyed. Only when the free assent of the Lord and Ruler has been given will it likewise be opened and made accessible to the approaching one. This assent must take place in the innermost centre of spiritual self-revelation; there where the self‑proper, from above strengthened intellectual light first illuminates for him the ways and the roads which natural necessity has made, and which the Evil has now opened to him even down into the abyss. The deed must then execute what the guiding reason has decided; so that the decision may gain real, plastic existence in life, and thereby become actual.

On this side of the demonic reciprocal relation between man and the primal ground of evil, therefore, there can be no question of any conquest and overpowering of the former by the latter; only of a deception and a covenant in its train can there be talk. Man must freely give himself over to the principle of Evil, and himself open the ways for it, so that it may penetrate to the innermost secret of his will and of his guiding powers of wisdom. He must thus come out to meet it from within, and seek the paths on which he, breaking through the enclosure that surrounds him, can reach the companion whose fellowship he desires. All mystical intercourse with objective powers, however, can occur only through the lower nature, withdrawn from clear consciousness, thus through the ganglionic system. In the fullness of possession the evil principle had, along the paths that lead from this system into the whole of Nature --- along the path of perdition --- entered into it, and life found itself entwined by it. But now the inner, free man comes toward him with full consciousness; he himself opens to him the gates of entrance, so that he may rule not only over the nature in him, but also over the inner, free, spiritual will. This opening could only happen from within, along those ways which lead from the determining, free man into the unfreely determined; those ways which the spirit, for example, must furnish in its mastery of the affections and passions, in the regulation of all involuntary movements, and in the disciplining of all that is only given in thought. The border-forts between the inner and the outer man therefore had to be opened first, and from them then also those which are erected as boundary-keepers of the outer against nature; only then could the admitted one take his triumphant entrance, and he is then the lord of him who has voluntarily given himself up to him as a subject on the condition that he receives back from the recipient, strengthened in might and force by the power of the bond, everything which he has delivered to him. Upon the conditions of the pact now rests the whole magic- and witchcraft-world in all its reality and its manifestations --- the counterpart of possession --- which we must now make the object of our closer investigation.

In the discussion of this object, with which the present book is filled, the manner in which the admission is effected will first be presented to the mind, and the sort by which the ways are prepared and the paths smoothed on which the hostile principle makes its entry, as well as the preliminaries that precede the homage. That will be the subject of the first section. If the subjugation has taken place, a new citizen is thereby settled in the realm of evil and has there obtained the indigenate; then the new relation develops peculiar connections throughout all regions of existence. For the admitted one has now stepped out of the ordinary order of nature, and has subordinated himself as a member to a supernatural one. There, in the realm of evil, his intercourse with his surroundings has become different, and he must conform himself to the changed relations and thus seek to find his way in the new environment. His whole being therefore undergoes a thorough alteration through all the moments of existence, and these changes we shall have to follow in the second division. But once full appropriation has taken place, the elective affinities to the like and the repulsions of the unlike have at the same time formed; for one and the same bond entwines the citizens of the same state, and separates them from the participants of other associations. Beside the hostile relation to the Church there therefore now exists also another, a certain concordance with the realm of the possessed, which in its relation of neighbouring places stands to the actual central realm of evil. Through this mutual situation and relation certain transitional bonds and communities are formed between the two, in which they mutually complete one another, and may first form a truly closed whole. These unions and separations of the two realms likewise deserve closer attention, and they shall be the subject of the third division of this book. Finally, the relation of this realm to Church and State --- what both have done to diminish and dissolve the hostile realm by strengthening and increasing themselves; how both have grasped and treated the whole phenomenon --- form the matter of a separate consideration, and the fourth division will deal with this.

### Chapter 1. First Origins of Demonic Sorcery

\[Page 14\]

In the craft of sorcery the reverse side of the mystical relation in which the saints stand to the Church and its founder is expressed. The first step toward holiness is the complete surrender of one's being to that Good which is lifted far above nature, and can therefore seize and fill nature precisely at its innermost and deepest point. With his whole nature thus turned toward It, the would‑be saint surrenders the free as well as the bound man within him: all the powers over which he can freely dispose, as well as those that in part have a hold on him, he gives up to the object of his affection; and that object will accept the offered gift, and take possession, one after another. \[Page 15\]

The first of these two surrenders and its acceptance must, according to the natural course of things and the nature of the act, be the first in order. For in the intercourse of the Godhead with men the approach of divine freedom to human freedom is by far the more preeminent and worthy; the relation of that absolutely free divinity to what in man is subject to necessity is, however, only of a second and deeper order. The man must therefore, in the innermost secret of his reason‑illumined will, have made the decision for that surrender, and the free offering must have been accepted, before, after preceding trials and purifications, the lower, vital man is also drawn into the mystical relation --- a stage which then reveals itself in ecstasy. A life led with clear consciousness thus stands in relation to this ecstasy, if not in a necessary, yet in a frequently occurring connection; one as a rule, though not always, leads to the other, and only rarely or hardly ever is the converse path observed. But with regard to the demonic realm it will be otherwise disposed.

The Good in God is altogether of a substantial nature, and of the kind of eternal Substance in itself, and therefore through itself and from itself. Evil, however, even down to its deepest root, is not of substantial kind, but only the inherence in a created substance, arising in it through its own fault. Drawn into the alternation of opposing contraries, it therefore does not stand, as the Good in God does, in a free relation to the creature that approaches it and seeks above all the Free in the Good as that which is most closely akin to it. Rather, even entangled in discord between created freedom and the bondage of the produced Evil, the action of the latter does not conduce to unity in concord, but must fall apart into the opposition of separated states. Under circumstances, then, the bound element in Evil, precisely in the power of the bond that extends through the whole corrupted creation, can throw itself upon the bound element in human nature, passing entirely by its free element; and in violently seizing that element, the state of possession will be brought about, a state which exists for itself and in no wise proceeds from a consent of the human will. But it can also, if the free nature voluntarily comes toward it --- having, of its own impulse, taken the decision to leave the communion of the holy and enter that of the unholy --- accept this surrender; and when a pact of give and take is concluded, there may also exist between the contracting parties a free compact for unfreedom. This pact is therefore altogether severed from the other; each has its own origin; one proceeds preeminently from the radically evil, the other from the human being; each unfolds in its own intervals; neither leads directly to the other, they rather seem to lead away from one another; yet both terminate in ecstasy, which, both in intention and end‑goal and in its whole succession, is distinct in each. The difference in origin, to which our attention here is directed, therefore remains fixed at the outset. \[Page 16\]

If possession has taken its own into an objective power, and thus appears as more than a suffering and a demonic passion of man, then magic must have had its adherents in an act arrived at by self-determination and pursued with perseverance, and so will appear as demonic action, and as a chain of such actions. Just as possession, regarded as a disease, has its origin in the lower systems and, in its development, continues upward into the higher and highest, so magic will take its origin from those highest, and we must from there pursue it into the lower and lowest.

The question is now: to what will it attach itself at that origin, and what circumstances will prepare the way for it? The doctrine prevailing in the social environment will begin this preparation; natural disposition will carry on the work thus begun; and the individual's own perversion of will will complete it at last.

#### 1. Origins in Doctrine

#### A. Manichaeism as The Social Basis of Magic

\[Page 17\]

Man is driven by his innermost nature to gather around himself the good, and, as one holds to another within him, to form fellowships and unions about it. Yet we see him in all his demonic associations turn his back on the good, and having taken evil as his center, to conclude a new covenant in it and about it, and thereby to renounce his most intimate impulse. But man never resolves upon something purely irrational; for the higher spiritual as well as ethical conscience demands an accounting of his deeds, and he must at least set before it apparent reasons and principles in order to veil his eccentric doings with a show of right and consequence. To the perverse resolution in which his exit from the natural order and his entrance into the unnatural is rooted, he must therefore give a theoretical foundation that, by reversing the relation, makes the unnatural into nature and so causes his work to appear as the simple consequence of a fundamental principle. To such beginnings Manichaeism has at all times supplied just such a foundation, as we have already touched upon in the historical development of magical practice, and which we must now further expound and demonstrate in detail.

The Church has at all times held fast as the simple ground of all truth the doctrine: that the Good alone is truly substantial; whereas Evil, not touching the substance of the eternally Good, has entered into the originally good-created substance by its own fault only as an accident, which is merely borne by the substantial thing in which it inheres and thereby attains its substantiality. Evil in all that is human therefore opposes every good, injures it and obstructs it in its manifestations; but as an inherence it is unable to assail the truly substantial at the core from outside; this remains unhurt in the midst of all evil, as a vessel does not defile the content it encloses. In the thoroughgoing division of all earthly things the Church therefore regards only the Good as law, norm, measure and rule, and the relations among goods alone possess a higher reality in themselves; Evil, acting in the accidental, is exception and excess, and is not an independent entity. So judging, although it is the irreconcilable opponent of evil, the Church may nevertheless be mild toward those who bear it, and thus oppose any violent rupture of human nature and human institutions. Therefore it also recognizes a higher, truly substantial mysticism, in which the good in man strives to reconcile more closely with the Eternal Good; this mysticism alone is essential to it, because, by drawing the being of things from the fullness out of which they have taken their origin, it really raises and increases them within itself. Every other mysticism is, to it, because it closes itself in the accidental, a mysticism of deceptive appearance; and that which turns toward evil must entirely lack all inner true reality in itself, even if not with itself; for it seeks to complete itself in a direction that can offer it nothing, but rather takes from it and binds what it really possesses from elsewhere. Opposed to this doctrine Manichaeism has built up its own.

As its first principle it bases the proposition: Evil is by no means an accident, but is of the same substantiality as the Good; for good and evil, though opposed in direction, are nevertheless both equally essential; because one has not arisen through defect, lapse, or fault of the other. The opposition that separates them therefore goes down into the innermost root of all existence, back into eternal substance, and even the Godhead finds itself divided in it. In the Christian form which the doctrine assumed in Christian times, therefore, all that exists is neither created by one God nor subject to him; but there are two consubstantial principles, the God of Light and the God of Darkness, the good and the evil principle, of which one, the Almighty God, alone created the invisible and incorporeal, while the other, Lucifer, from eternity called forth the visible and corporeal.1) Thus two natures stand existing, separated in their innermost substance according to their creators: a good one of the incorporeal things, a bad one of the corporeal things; and this deepest inward split, which therefore divides all created things, will recur in man as well; and he will belong, with the visible and bodily half of his being, to the evil nature and its creator, but with the inner, invisible half only to the good and its originator, who creates nothing perishable. Sin is therefore from the very beginning by no means a product of free will, and then propagated itself as original sin; it does not now repeat itself in any such free action: rather it is the work of the God of Darkness. There is no other work that he practices than this sin, and there can be no sin on earth that has not occurred in heaven; for Hell became Heaven at the moment when its ruler set himself up as God. There is therefore no repentance after committed sin, the evil of punishment is likewise not from the good God, and souls are not condemned on account of sin; there is therefore no eternal damnation or expiation in a place of purgation. For the good God only gives life, but in no way kills; only the Evil one kills and quickens bodies, and God, who bestows grace, likewise does not avenge the wrong by evil or good recompense; hence the right to punish in no way belongs to the true Church.

Since, then, Adam the first man was not from God, neither are new souls henceforth continually created and poured in by God for generation; for generation itself is from the Evil, and therefore marriage is reprehensible; reprehensible is the use of the flesh, as of the unclean, for the maintenance of life; and the resurrection of the body is inadmissible, because the body belongs to the evil principle. Thus, just as God and Nature and Man are incurably rent by the doctrine, so likewise are history and the whole historical course of things. \[Page 18\]

Ancient times before Christ were indeed in evil; Moses was of the Evil, and his law was not good as that of a prophet; the Father, the good God, did not speak to the old patriarchs, he did not lead Israel out of Egypt, nor command circumcision; the Old Testament is not from God at all; all this has been ordered by the prince of Darkness. No salvation can therefore proceed from him, and before the appearance of Christ there were no good men, and even the ancient fathers were not saved. But when Christ came, who was not God, but also not a true man, who took his body neither from heaven nor from the mother, who was not a true woman; who did not eat in the flesh and did not suffer on the cross in the flesh, did not truly die, did not rise from death, did not descend to the nether world, nor ascend into heaven; precisely because he had only a phantastic body, like John the Baptist, who was of the Evil: when this bringer and Saviour came, he indeed did not take upon himself our penal liability; but it became possible through him to work salvation, and the Holy Spirit can be given by the laying on of hands, but not by the baptism of John, which is null and without effect.

Null is also the sacrament of the altar, null confession and the anointing with oil. Into the true God-founded Church henceforth good and evil could not enter together; for evil separates and parts from it at once. The material, visible Church, however, cannot be of the good, because it appears as one mixed of good and evil, and the sinful life of the clerics necessarily stains its work. In the true Church, however, no bad priests and deacons should be found, and no evil person may assume episcopal dignity. It is not permitted to it to have separate private property; it may possess only a common fund. It must not persecute the wicked, it cannot excommunicate, cannot make its own constitutions; in it there should be prayed and sung only the Prayer of the Lord; the funeral office with its prayers, however, is of evil; from the Evil too is the application of any violence and the invocation of the punishing arm of justice on its part, because man is still capable of conversion. The swearing of oaths is, moreover, to be avoided in it; alms are to be given only to the good; only he who belongs to it can be saved, but that can by no means occur through mere faith.

If we consider the content of this doctrine more closely in its relation to our Church, then we perceive that both proceed from one and the same ground, the recognition of a twofold law in man, the law in the spirit and the law in the flesh. But the Church, in that she allows this double-law to be held as unavoidable, does by no means recognize in one half of it the law of the spiritual substance as such, and in the other that of the corporeal; rather, by referring one to the good principle and the other to the evil, she makes the dualism of the two insurmountable, and so transfers it into the eternal substance. The law of the flesh, on the contrary, is for her operative in both realms --- of spirit as well as of flesh, namely the fallen --- while the law of the spirit likewise has force in both, but as it proceeded from the hand of their Creator and insofar as, despite the Fall, it has been preserved in this condition. \[Page 19\]

Thus the dualism is confined to a historical sphere, to the domain of the accidental; but because the elements of the relation are of the nature of substantial accidents, in this doctrine the law of the spirit is not able by its own power to overcome the law of the flesh and to regain its lordship. Yet this may succeed for it with the aid of the higher Divine, which, by its immutability, is not touched by the opposition; and its endeavour is directed to, with mildness and forbearance enduring the inevitable in all that is human, to awaken the upward‑striving impulse and to equip it more and more, and thereby to draw down the descending salvation of redemption upon those who strive upward.

The other teaching, however, has entrenched the opposition by dividing it into the visible bodily things and the invisible spiritual things, and assigning both to the still higher of the two gods, of Light and of Darkness. The man who in the Church indeed lives in two natures, which are both the Lord's, and is only by his morbid perversion open to the temptations of the enemy, serves but one master; whereas in that teaching he stands under double lordship, belonging with his body to the powers of Darkness, but with his spirit turned toward the Lord of Light. He therefore of necessity belongs to two churches, and finds himself pressed to enter into a twofold fellowship; one of which tolerates no evil within itself, the other just as effectually casts out and keeps far from itself the good --- and now both meet in him, held in such close proximity only by the accidental bond of life. His attitude and his fate will now depend upon the relation into which the two principles have placed themselves. If these have divided themselves into the two hemispheres and sit peacefully side by side, then there will be peace also in him; with his body he has native status in the realm of Darkness and performs works of Darkness; with his spirit, however, he is an aborigine in the realm of Light and performs works of Light; and the two practices may, insofar as they can, tolerate one another. But if both powers are now at war, if one seeks to subdue the other, he is not permitted to remain neutral; and it then depends upon whither his being drives him with predominance. If the spirit, by the power of fate, is the stronger, then he turns toward the direction from which the stronger impulse comes; he joins the fighters of Light, becomes one of the Cathars who seek purity. But he must then above all fight the part of Lucifer in himself and strike it down to destruction, that he may be a worthy combatant; and is thus driven into a false, exuberant mysticism tending to self‑annihilation. Or he feels that, conversely, by that same power of fate, the flesh is stronger than the spirit; and in that case he enrolls himself among the dark hosts and fights their battles. In both cases he is in the service of an absolute and eternal Lord; there as here his contest, however, will every time be directed against the visible Church on earth; there because of its earthly faults, here because of the good that is in and about it.

As we have seen in the historical account, the false doctrine had long ravaged the East when the first traces of its transplanting to the West appeared at the beginning of the eleventh century in the castle of Montfort, in the diocese of Asti, and there found its martyrs. It then, during the two following centuries, spread further in secret, and by the beginning of the thirteenth had branched into fifteen different sects throughout the greater part of Italy and the whole Romance South, and had also contrived to force a way into the Germanic North. By the nature of the thing the tendency of their adherents in all these sects had to split in two directions, and the opposition again sought its reconciliation in a third, middle course.

Those who by temperament, orientation, and vocation had resolved in favor of the good principle pursued that direction with the whole one-sided, spiritualistic aloofness of the system --- devoting themselves to an asceticism which, according to circumstances, was severe and austere, or at least professing a stoical purity of morals that justified them in attacking the corruptions in the Church and in charging the Church itself as a work of darkness. They therefore formed the outward, conspicuous side of the sect, by which above all they won the confidence of the people; and so generally recognized was this strictness of morals as their salient characteristic that any such merciless, exaggerated severity was wont to be called "Patalia" (from the name of the sect Patalini), and in the conflict which Arnaldo, in Gregory's time, raised in Milan against the married, simoniacal priests, they called his beginning an unseemly, accursed Patalia.

He, however, against whom this harshness was directed, lost nothing by the matter; the corruption of the age made up to him, which Peter Damian summed up in a few words: shame has perished, honesty has vanished, religion has fallen, and, as it were, the whole host of saintly virtues has gone far away.

In the midst of this dissolution the adversary now found confessors in great numbers, who, supported by the system and fully justified by its principles, thought it better to adhere to him and to avow themselves for his cause. For, as every principle will not let men rest until they have realized it in the full development of all its consequences and moments, so under their hands the realm of darkness likewise grew into a perfect kingdom of Satan, to which they swore the oath of subjection, in which they then took upon themselves the apostolate, and which they sought to spread by missions.

When, meanwhile, those who held to the other side considered it advisable to come forward with their teaching, the interest of the cause they espoused and the invincibility of the shame bound to conscience drove the others back into the darkness and obscurity which they in truth served. While some strove openly, the others therefore withdrew behind the veil of secret associations, which celebrated their dark mysteries in woods and caves and on mountain heights. Both served extreme tendencies: for on the one hand they would not curb and govern the law of the flesh by the power of a higher might, but set themselves to deny it or to destroy it by their own self-sufficient might; on the other hand they were just as bent on annihilating and extirpating the law of the Spirit. \[Page 20\]

Against such extreme directions, however, the common healthy sense of mankind revolts everywhere, and leaves their prosecution only to the few who feel the vocation for it within themselves. The church of naked light and that of darkness therefore formed only minorities in the midst of the sect; the great mass sought a moderate middle which would permit it to live and let live. On the higher road of the Church, through the higher middle, that could not be attained; the system opposed it, for it was wholly at variance with it. Nothing remained, then, but to gain, within the same system, by a reciprocal tempering of the two extremes, a kind of mechanical middle in the balance of the tendencies which, while it kept off the inconveniences of the extremes, measured out a life in calm worldly prudence, and prepared for itself a more comfortable modus vivendi that indeed sacrifices to evil but nevertheless knows how to increase its enjoyments from the spiritual realms.

Such a middle, presenting itself in many gradations, was joined, in this pervasive heresy of the Middle Ages, by the decidedly largest majority of its adherents, especially of the higher ranks; while the far smaller number placed itself only on the two extreme points, and the one party accepted the half-year polar day as its portion, the others the equally long night.

Among these various orders of the false teachers we must here follow, with preference, the night-spirits; although these, bound up in the common system with those who regarded themselves toward the light, were again closely connected with them, and even externally in their organizations hung together. If they wished, then, to carry on their missionary works successfully, they must above all know how to surround themselves with the alluring shimmer of the miraculous, and the promising charm of great powers over which they claimed authority. They probably found this enchantment in the magical arts and traditions which they had brought from the East, and in the exercise of which they everywhere appeared as possessors of great secrets. We have already, on the occasion of the sect that worked in the north of Germany, cited what was believed there of their gift for miracles. Cæsarius has adduced another example concerning this, which clearly expresses the opinion of the time about miraculous power, and its relation to the ecclesiastical. \[Page 21\]

At the time, he says, when the heresy of the Albigenses first began to make itself known, some of the evil sort, strengthened by the power of the devil, wrought certain wonders and signs which not only confirmed the heretics but also seduced many faithful. They walked, among other feats, upon the water, and did not sink. When a priest, honest in faith and religious disposition, perceived this, and reflected that true signs could not stand with a false doctrine, he carried the Body of the Lord in a pyx to the river where these people were performing their powers before the people, and spoke aloud in the hearing of all present: I adjure you, Satan, by Him whom I hold here in my hands, that you cease, on this river, to exercise such conjuring to the corruption of these people! After these words, when the false teachers went on, as before, to walk upon the waves, the priest, thereby agitated, cast the Body of the Lord into the flood. Wonderful power of the Lord over the elements! The moment the Sacrament touched the waves, the illusion of the deceit gave way; the false partisans, like lead sinking to the abyss, drowned, while the pyx was taken away by angels. The priest, seeing all this, rejoiced indeed at the miracle, but he was pained by the loss of the Sacrament; he spent the whole night in prayer and sighing, and found in the morning the lost thing with the pyx upon the altar. This was told to us at the same time. \[Page 22\]

The reporter cites no guarantor, no place, and no name; he therefore took it from legend, which however expresses the opinion of the time. The same appears in another account preserved by his contemporary Cantipratanus. When M. Conrad preached in Germany against the heretics, where he also suffered the martyr's death, one of them, as I heard from Brother Conrad, the Dominican provincial in Germany, being led astray by demons, sought to win over a brother of the same order to the heresy. But when he perceived the brother's violent resistance he said to him: "You are very stubborn in your faith, of which, however, you know only some things from Scripture; but if you were to give me your belief, I would by actual sight show you Christ, his mother, and the saints themselves." The brother suspected a deception of the demon, but, because he wished to try what was true in the matter, he said: "I would with good reason give you belief if you could accomplish that." The heretic rejoiced at this, and set a day for the meeting; the brother, however, took the Sacrament of the Body of Christ secretly under his cloak with him. The heretic now led the brother into the cave of a mountain, into a spacious, light-filled palace. As they entered the interior of the castle they saw thrones set there as of the purest gold, upon which sat a light-encircled king and a queen arrayed in serene beauty; at her side were chairs of the elders, who, like patriarchs and apostles, surrounded her in the midst of the angels; everything shone so that it seemed anything but demonic. When the introducer beheld them, he fell on his face and worshipped them. The brother, however, stood unmoved, astonished at the spectacle before his eyes. Then the heretic turned to him and said: "Why do you not worship the Son of God whom you see before you? Come forward, and, paying him homage, receive from his mouth the mysteries of our faith!"
