The brother then came nearer, drew out the pyx, and offered it to the queen who sat on the throne, saying: "Are you indeed the queen and mother of Christ? See there your son! If you acknowledge him, then I will acknowledge you as his mother." At these words the whole phantom vanished, and after the fading of the brightness so dense a darkness spread that the brother with his guide scarcely found the way out. The heretic, however, terrified by the marvelous guile of the demon, returned to the faith.

Even more fully is the narrative preserved for us in the form in which Picus of Mirandola gives it. In the Rhaetian Alps, about twelve years earlier, there was a pious priest who, being summoned to administer the sacrament of the Eucharist to a sick man and the road being long, mounted a horse and, after hanging the pyx with the sacrament about his neck, rode on his way. After riding for a while someone met him who invited him to dismount from the horse so that, in his company, he might witness a wonderful spectacle. The parish priest, out of curiosity, imprudently followed the invitation, and had hardly alighted from his horse when he felt himself borne through the air with his companion. After a short while they stood on the summit of an exceedingly high mountain, in a wide, exceedingly lovely plain, bordered by the noblest trees and enclosed by dreadful rocks. Beneath the trees they found ring-dances winding and divers sorts of games, tables laden with costly foods; they heard sounds and songs full of every loveliness; whatever could delight the mind and gladden the heart was present there in abundance. \[Page 23\]

The simple, good clergyman, astonished at the unexpected sight, and, from wonder, daring neither to speak nor to move, stood there as if stunned and out of his senses. Then the companion who had brought him said: would he not venerate the queen present, and visit her with a gift? She sat on a high throne, dressed in royal adornment; all those present approached her, two or four at a time and in perfect order prostrating themselves before her, and paying her homage while presenting gifts. The clergyman, when he thus perceived her in the radiance of her glory, surrounded by many, believed: it was the Mother of the Lord, the Queen of Heaven and Earth; and he had no inkling that anything demonic was hidden behind her. Considering to himself what he should present to her as a gift, he thought: he could bring her nothing dearer or more pleasing than the body of her Son. So he went up to her, and, as he fell at her feet, he took the little case with the Sacrament, which he had hung about his neck, and laid it in the woman's lap. Wonderful! Everything vanished at once. The man, struck by this, now recognized how he had been ensnared by false signs and wonders; and when he found himself abandoned in the gloom of dense forests, he cried to God for help with trembling, that He would deliver him from such dangers. After having wandered for a long time astray and about in the woods, he at last found a shepherd who informed him that he was some hundred miles from the place where he had wished to carry the Eucharist. Having returned to his place of residence, he reported the matter to the magistrate. The incident took place, however, under the reign of Emperor Maximilian.

The old relation of heathenism to Christianity---now transferred to that of heresy to the true faith---lies at the root of all these tales, and one sees, for example, that earlier one about the old Frisian king Radbod, who led his convert to the glorious Valhalla, but which, under the sign of the Christian cross, vanished, clearly shining through.

If such tales, in their individual circumstances, also appear as products of lively imagination, yet a higher basis of truth nevertheless lies in them, and a higher power has allied itself with the poetic in its formative work; so that a fundamental idea, in its comprehensive and general truth, governs and sustains the contingence of the circumstances. Such an idea, precisely because it is universal, also belongs to the universal power of the human spirit; and has in many cases tested itself as such on facts and experiences which, while mutually explaining and correcting one another, finally resulted in the confirmation and guarantee of the common idea; which therefore has always remained behind, after the experiences long since have fallen prey to oblivion; and in which the legend now, freely operating according to circumstances, again consistently develops the particular. \[Page 24\]

This idea here is the conviction of the magical powers of the heretics, as formerly of those of heathenism; powers which, before the force of truth that, if need be, pours forth miracles from the Church, can never endure. The miraculous gift of the false doctrine, however, manifests itself here by deceitfully clothing evil with borrowed splendor, making it appear as something good; a deception which then dissolves at the approach of truth. It can also make itself known in another way, by letting this evil consist in its terror and dreadfulness, yet presenting it as a power that, though fearsome, is bound to it. From this mode there then sprang another class of tales, which extends from the invocations of the demon in front of the circle of the necromancer to the necromancer's relations with it; a root of legend that has burst forth in many shoots and that connects itself with the historical in manifold entanglements. \[Page 25\]

Caesarius thus relates: a knight, who could not be convinced of the reality of demons, had urgently entreated a cleric, who was very proficient in necromancy, that he would show him some. This man, after having strongly admonished him, at last --- once he had obtained a safeguard for every contingency --- led him at noon to a crossroads. There he drew a circle around him with his sword, and then warned him: that in his absence he should not make the sign of the cross, give or promise anything to the demanding spirits, nor by terror or encouragement be induced to bring even a limb of his body out of the circle, because otherwise he would be dead; after this he went away. The knight sat for a while in the circle, when he perceived the inundation of many waters coming toward him; he heard the roaring of furious winds, then the grunting of many swine; but none of this could frighten him. Soon, however, he saw in the nearby wood a dreadful shape, like the shadow of a man, coming toward him over the trees, and understood that it was the Devil. The figure stopped at the circle, and asked him what he wanted. It was to be compared to a great, exceedingly black man, clad in garments of the same color, and so hideous that the knight could not bear to look at it. Meanwhile he said to the coming one: You come to me at the right time, for I have asked to see you. --- For what? --- I have heard much of you. --- What have you heard? --- Much evil, little good! --- The Black (one) replied: Often people judge without cause; I have injured no one without being provoked; therefore ask your master, who is my friend, whether I have ever done him any harm; I do what pleases him, and he commands me in all things. The knight, however: Where were you when I called you? The answer: I was as far beyond the sea as the distance from here to the sea; therefore it will be fair that you reward me somewhat for my trouble. Now he first demands his cloak; on his refusal then the belt, then a sheep from the flock, lastly the cock of his yard, that it should crow for him. But when he refused him everything, he stretched his arm toward him; so that the knight, shrieking, recoiled; whereupon the master ran up and made the specter disappear. Another man, who allowed the same master to show him the demon, was not so fortunate. He let himself be terrified, was drawn out of the circle, and so treated that he died on the third day. In a third tale it is Swabian and Bavarian students who make the attempt in Toledo. Before the circle the spirits appear in the form of armed bands of warriors, who play at war and with lances and swords try to frighten them from their security. Then they change into beautiful girls, who practice all the arts of seduction to lure them out. They all, however, remain steadfast except one, who is enticed to put a finger into the ring which one of these sirens offers him; he is therefore pulled out and disappears. The students, especially the Bavarians, a fierce people, threaten the master with death if he does not return the stolen man. Appalled by this, he convenes a council of the demons about the case; in which they agree to give the stolen man back. The idea underlying these narratives is as follows. Just as the Church of the Lord recognizes possessions and hauntings among its people for the cleansing of those possessed, whereby in clairvoyance the possessor or the one sitting upon them is seen; so the church of darkness, for the initiation and advancement of its own, likewise has these states, and they are produced by the black art. \[Page 26\]

The Church of Light, in such cases, keeps the inhabitants of its realm enclosed within a circle which the besieging or even bodily-invading spirit does not dare to cross; unless human freedom itself should break over the circle, or pay it homage, even with the smallest part of its own. Likewise, in that other relation, the black art keeps its own people confined within the circle drawn by the tip of the sword; it determines the limits of the atmosphere that surrounds the man, which the spirit of darkness does not dare to penetrate; authority therefore comes to it from within, just as from within, by the sign of the cross, in the mighty ban of the Church, the whole work is undone.

Legend, in carrying out this idea, pays no heed to whether in particular cases fraud and scenic arts have co-operated; for the deception lies along the whole line of the enterprise. Cæsarius, however, has at the same time given those accounts as historical. He names as the master of the magic the cleric Philipp, who in those times was much in demand; he knew him personally, and this Philipp, a few years before Cæsarius wrote, as was believed, had been killed at the instigation of his friend and master. In the first case he names the knight Heinrich, born at Castle Faltenstein, cupbearer of Cæsarius of our order and at that time abbot of Prüm, from whose mouth he learned the course of events. Since that adventure, after the loss of his natural colour, he had always remained pale, and he, too, had died not long before. In the second case the same Philipp had taken part, and the house of the slain man had been confiscated by Walram of Luxemburg. The third story had been told him by his fellow-member of the order, Gedschalt of Volmunstein, and he had questioned that Philipp about it, who claimed to have experienced it during his stay in Toledo.

Here, then, some ground of truth must be hidden, and Weyer, where in his book De praestigiis daemonum (Book II) he speaks of certain magical writings, leads us on their trail. He reports, namely from them: the prescription is that, when the circle is drawn, the neophyte must walk in it in a continual whirl from east to west, until, seized by dizziness, he falls down; whereupon ecstasy then seizes the prostrate man, and one will appear to him who gives him further enlightenment. That is the old practice, as we have shown, of the shamans in Siberia; that of the North American Indians in their forests, who, with a rope twisted about the neck, whirl themselves round a post, everything relying on a technical maneuver that produces vertigo. The skilled practitioner then becomes clairvoyant, and along demonic paths demonic powers meet him.

The traditional secret was in subsequent times lost, and only the legendary remained. Thus there existed traditions of demonic arts in this Church, which were applied especially at initiations. The principle, in whose name the initiation took place, had to present itself, whether plastically and spiritually to the waking man, or pictorially to the clairvoyant, to the perception; and here the form of the goat, which had already played that important role in the ancient service of the Mendesians, offered itself in both cases as the most suitable. We have earlier cited, from the older times, individual facts that point to such practices. That, however, the thing itself was not altogether lost in later centuries is proved by the following remarkable story, which Brognoli, as an informed witness, has preserved for us in his writings.

##### The Story of The Unrepentant Magician

\[Page 27\]

About the middle of the seventeenth century there lived in northern Italy a man versed in both laws and devoted to the study of philosophy; moreover, endowed with a penetrating keenness of mind, and therefore eager to penetrate into the deeper mysteries of things. He had given himself up, by constant association, to learned but unbelieving people, magicians, and men of similar ilk, who initiated him into their arts and doctrines and infected him with their evil habits. He, who now wished to put into practice what he had learned theoretically, in order thereby to satisfy his desires --- which he could not accomplish without demonic help --- allowed himself to be carried away by them to give himself over to him who granted them and to his service, and in turn to seduce others to that service. The relationship had already continued for a good number of years, when one night he was so badly mistreated and almost strangled by him to whom he had given himself, that --- since even his mother had pleaded to God in prayer for that reason --- against his will he resolved to return to God and to call for His help.

Partly on the advice of his elders, partly through the encouragement of Father Carolus von Belitri, Vicar of the Holy Office in Tarvis, finally determined, he betook himself, as to a safe place, to the house of the Office with that vicar, as to a friend. He was now to go there to confession, and for that purpose a pious and discerning theologian was chosen; who, finding him by no means sufficiently prepared, took every pains to bring out what was still lacking by his exhortation and to examine his conscience in a fitting manner. But behold, at that moment his evil spirit again began to seize upon all his senses, and repeatedly to call out from his mouth: I, I am Satan; I, I am this man's lord and owner; he, he may not and cannot make his confession, and I will never permit it. By virtue of the pact which he has concluded with me, he is bound to me and belongs to me; he has solemnly promised me to obey me in all things, never to make a proper confession, nor ever to forsake me. The clergyman was at first frightened by this speech, but then, strengthened in the Lord, he asked the speaker what he wanted here. Thereupon the instigator of all evil answered: This man is the worst scoundrel, who has long consorted with unbelievers, still possesses many of their books, and is always ready for every evil; since he therefore does not commit as much evil as his baseness and wickedness prompt him to, I remain here to watch over him. Thus and the like said the crafty guardian who had plunged him into the abyss of all vices, and who now vaunted himself to be guarding him against greater evil. But when the priest ceased to speak of things that concerned his soul's salvation and turned to indifferent matters, the voice likewise at once ceased to speak through him, and did not hinder him in the use of his senses and faculties. Yet when another time the priest exhorted him with exorcisms not to hinder his confession any longer, the man burst into a furious laugh, and, with face, mouth, and fists, attacked the exorcist, mocking and scoffing at him, so that he appeared utterly mad. If the clergyman desisted a second time, he likewise ceased his rages and his laughter and his taunts, and addressed him seriously and with mature consideration, like a learned and prudent man; asserting at the same time that he from the bottom of his heart cursed all wrongdoing. \[Page 28\]

But as soon as, with his mouth --- the man who spoke these words --- he would renounce these misdeeds, confess them sacramentally in confession, or would name the companions and co‑sinners of his vices, he immediately felt his heart bound and pressed; whereupon he then burst forth with the greatest violence and vehemence, and was driven to laughter and ridicule by a power which he could not resist. He confessed that it inwardly determined and carried him away to despise, to deride and to abase the priest who advised him to do penance; and nothing then appeared to him more pleasing and delightful than to hold all religious people and clerics, all clerical ordinations, offices, usages and ceremonies in contempt, to mock them and to trample them underfoot. This did not happen merely once, but whenever he was appointed to any act that could be useful to his soul; especially when, being persuaded by the priest, he was to renounce his errors before the Vicar of the Inquisition. Then he at once broke out into the most violent derisive laughter, and although he strove to drive away force with force, and to write while kneeling and to produce good acts, nothing came of it; he was suddenly overcome by the demon, upset the inkwell, and fled, wrenching himself away with great fury. \[Page 29\]

Who can resist referring all this to the evil spirit, which, supported by many years of bad habit, applied every means to assert its right over this its adherent. Not that it possessed him in his body, tormenting and afflicting him like the possessed, without extending its power to their souls. Rather it was, as with all sorcerers and evildoers, always present to him merely as the owner of his soul as well as of his body, and acted according to the circumstances; now in his body binding his heart, contracting it, expanding it, and exciting in it many often opposite passions; then again moving his throat, mouth, tongue, eyes, lips and the other members of the body in many ways; and alternately affecting his internal sensitive powers by diverse objects, as seemed advantageous to it, so that it might hold him forever in its subjection.

Now I, relates Father Brognoli, in the same year, coming from Rome to Bergamo, lodged in a place only a little distance from the city, which that magician inhabited; I was urged by the venerable father‑provincial of that reformed province and by the clergyman of whom I have just spoken to take under my charge the aforesaid jurist, whom the clerical exorcists declared to be possessed by the demon, but whom the physicians pronounced insane. When he was brought to me, I first began to speak with him alone about many matters, and I recognized from his speech and answers soon that he was not foolish and out of his senses, as the physicians said, but of very sound understanding, learned, quick of spirit and sharp‑witted. Now, however, in the presence of that clergyman and of a noble jurist, his friend, I began to invoke the demon with exorcisms. But the one being exorcised was not, as commonly happens with the possessed, tormented by the exorcisms; instead he burst into laughter and threatened me with his fists. When I had seen this, and remembered the pact that he had concluded with the demon, and how he had already served him for eight years and been devoted to the magical being, I judged it necessary to employ other means.

Therefore, partly urged by himself, partly appointed by the entreaties of his friend, the other legally trained man, as well as by the clerics, to take him more closely under my supervision; I went to the place where he himself lived, had from the Father Inquisitor the necessary authority over him transferred to me, and then, after invoking divine help, in the monastery there, in the presence of our reverend provincial, of a Father Definitor, and of the companion of that man, commanded in the name of our Lord the demon: that they in no way hinder the external or internal faculties and abilities of the person, and that they answer all my questions freely and without obstruction. \[Page 30\]

I then asked him for what reason he had turned to our Order, and had especially summoned me, and what he required of me. He answered: So that I might learn whether I am bound by a maleficium, or possessed, or suffer from some other illness. For I feel my heart bound and compressed toward a young man, so that I can scarcely draw breath; and yet I will not break forth into love toward him; but that, I suppose, comes from a maleficium. If therefore you bring out that the evil has its origin in this; then I beg that by your remedies you will restore my health.

When from this speech I perceived that he was not moved for the love of God, nor out of sorrow for having offended Him; but, like another Antiochus, willing to give way to the demon in order to avert the scourge from his body, I said to him: I assure you with all the certainty that a servant of Christ and of the Church can have, that if you are struck by a maleficium you shall be healed, on the following three conditions: First, you must obey me in all things that I shall command you, spirituallly or bodily. Secondly, you must reveal to me all the thoughts, words and deeds of your life, as far as possible, and especially from the time onward when you engaged with unbelievers and consorted with demons, up to this hour. Thirdly, you must give ear to the reasons and authorities which I adduce to persuade you of the evangelical truth; and if anything occurs to you in opposition, you must communicate it to me, so that I may resolve your doubts. He promised solemnly in the presence of the clerics and the legally trained man to fulfil all this.

So that he might not again break into his laughter and mock me, I commanded him on the spot to make the following retractation: "I, N. N., have learned that whenever I would undertake any act conducive to my healing, I am compelled with the utmost force to laughter, and thus forced to reject all remedies useful to my body and soul. Therefore I declare here on my knees before God, my Creator and Redeemer, and before you, my spiritual father, with all my heart and with my whole soul and with all my strength: that if from this moment I laugh, or perform any act which is meant to express scorn and contempt, I do then laugh Beelzebub, the prince of the demons (so he called him to whom he had devoted himself), to scorn and derision, as do all his adherents; because they, out of pride, have abandoned their God, and, yielding themselves to eternal punishment, have forgotten Him." \[Page 31\]

"I will likewise laugh for joy that God, in the infinite fullness of his mercy and goodness, has forgiven me all my sins, which, whenever I laugh, I every time from my whole heart denounce; for they are insults against my God, Creator and Redeemer, whom I must love above all. Therefore, you devils, having tempted, moved, and driven me to laughter at your pleasure; yet it shall, according to my intention, always be to scorn you, and to the salvation of my soul!"

After all this had thus been arranged among us, the laughter was suddenly turned to sorrow. From then on, when things holy were spoken of, he never laughed again; rather he seemed seized by the deepest pain and the blackest melancholy. Wherefore I begged the others to leave us, so that I remained alone with him, and then questioned him about everything he had done and what had happened to him: about the pact he had concluded with the demon; about the confession he had made to him; his promises, accomplices; about the books of the heretics; his master Hämmerlein; about his presence at the Sabbath, and all that there is done there by the sorcerers, the lords and demons; the pleasures and the magnificences that he had obtained from the demon; finally, about everything that had occurred during the eight years that he had served him --- all of which he told me, albeit with some difficulty.

He said how, a year earlier, before he had bound himself to the demon, he had had much intercourse with magicians and malefactors, among whom there had been Lutherans, Calvinists, Anabaptists, Manichaeans, but for the most part atheists; and how he then set himself to the study of their books and teachings. Then first he came to renounce God; and now he found himself prepared to perform everything necessary for the demonic confession. As to the initiation, he reported that it had proceeded thus: the act took place in the year 1638, in a cave of the Genoese mountains, to which he had traveled with nine other magicians, in the company of all the heretics with whom he had then been staying in a certain city on account of his studies.

When they arrived at the appointed place they had found the demon there in human shape, sitting upon a stone; with fire-spraying eyes, a goat's beard, horns, clawed hands, ox-like feet; with a hoarser, thinner, but terrible voice. At his sight they all fell down with their burning pitch-torches, which they carried in their hands, and paid him homage by kissing his hindparts. Then the first magician rose from their circle and, while the others remained on their knees, addressed the seated one, setting forth how he brought a new novice to him --- a learned doctor of both laws, likewise well-instructed theologian, whom he presented here and begged him to receive among his own.

The Prince of Darkness, pleased thereat, answered that the neophyte should present his wishes. He replied: "My wish is that you show me a treasure and the way to raise it; also that you use no deception or other trick upon me, but provide me with true gold and silver. Then you should teach me the art of going and walking invisibly to wherever my lust and desire strive. Furthermore, the demons that I call should not refuse to comply with my wishes, and should bring me everywhere I wish with the greatest speed, and perform everything that I demand of them." \[Page 32\]

The demon then said: All this is easy, if he first renounce God and firmly believe that there is no other God than him, the demon; renounce the remaining articles of faith, the sacraments and sacramentals; all his life hold religious and clerical persons in contempt and deride them; regard all clerical rites as null, never go to confession, and consider that confession itself as an invention of the priests to deceive the simple. The novice promised to observe all of this exactly, except the first. "That there is no other God but the demon" contradicts my reason, which bids me the contrary, he said. Then the most distinguished of the magi, who among them was regarded as a kind of bishop, took the mediation upon himself, addressing the newcomer with the words: If you will not immediately believe as I do that there is no god but the demon, then at least believe: there are two gods, one, the Creator of the invisible and spiritual things; the other, the demon, founder of all corporeal and visible things. The novice answered: I can readily give my belief to that.

Thus were now the Lord, the Holy Virgin, the sum of all articles of faith, sacraments, clerical rites and ceremonies abjured; and to the demon, after repeated kisses, fidelity was pledged, the confession made; and over all this a written bond was drawn up and sealed by the magician's own hand. He then received from the prince of demons a Martinet or Martinell assigned to him, so that it should be at his hand everywhere. This one, in company with the Martinelli of the other magi, brought before them a splendid carriage drawn by four white camels; which the whole magical society mounted, and was then borne with the greatest speed before sunset to the city which they inhabited. He told all this not jokingly, but in full seriousness; adding that he had earlier communicated it to the reverend inquisitor, before whose tribunal he had appeared, indeed with his mouth but not with his heart: all in accordance with what Petrus of Abano left in his writings. Moreover he said he was ready to abjure all these errors from full conviction.

He then went on to say: he had been led by the demons to England, France, Germany, and had in Trento, Bergamo, Briren, Verona and in many other cities, together with other sorcerers, attended the gatherings, and again related this all in earnest. Fully in his senses he also told me: We magi and necromancers, when we do not wish to go to such nocturnal assemblies ourselves, then our art teaches us to draw certain necromantic circles, by murmuring a few words, to summon certain demons, and to offer certain adorations to their chief; then we are relieved of being present there and of the labors connected with it, and the demon appears on our behalf. Thus I myself have often acted, by making the circles in my room and adding the rest; yet at other times I have also attended the Sabbath in nearly all the cities of the Venetian territory. \[Page 33\]

The women, however, and the magi of low rank, since they do not possess the higher knowledge, are obliged to appear at every assembly, unless they can produce a sufficient, truly excusing cause. At the third hour of the night the Martinelli assemble; then their protégés must also be present. Those who come too late or not at all are, wherever they are, struck with illnesses, and are tormented not only during the night of the celebration but also for the following days in body and soul: so that everything they undertake comes to nothing in their hands, until they swear an oath to be more attentive in future.

In order not to be recognized, the more distinguished and wealthy persons in particular appear covered with a mask, a net, or a veil, which he confirmed by repeated testimony. They would also, for the same reason, not appear under their own proper names. Instead they are called by the names of their native towns, or even of foreign places, with the addition of another place-name, e.g. Brescia of Venice, Palatiolum of Milan, when several belonged to the same place.

What is told of the pitch-torches at these festivals, of the offerings that each brings, &c. he confirmed all from experience; and, asked what he himself sacrificed, he answered: the blood of menstruating women, which the witches of his place supplied to him, and which seemed to be especially pleasing to the demon. He added: the commanding demon of the city where he lives is called Beelzebub; and he has 20,000 demons disposed to every sort of evil under his rule. To himself, however, by virtue of his magical insight, full dominion over the demons had been granted at his will; and he could, by a ring or by some other instrument, bind them and use them for his purposes; but he would neither be used nor forced by them. For all who truly possess magic could, by the power of that art, summon the demons, tame them, make them do their will, and enclose them in rings, vessels, and the like. \[Page 34\]

When I, says Brognoli, exposed to him the folly of this fancy, he replied one day that he would give me a proof of his power, and by his necromantic circles summon the 30,000 demons that served him. I, for my part, answered: I will for that purpose on the following day, with God's help, preserve myself in the power of Him and of the name of Jesus, to whom sufficient authority and efficacy have been given to put all demons to flight. At that time he lived in the house of the Inquisition, directly beneath the sitting-room of the Inquisitor, Carlo of Velitri. On the following night the latter, as well as one of his friends from the laity, in the room where the magician was alone, heard much speech of the demons; it seemed to come from a great assembled multitude, in which all cried out confusedly, raged in fury, blasphemed God, and boasted how they would do me to death; which they twice attempted that night, yet each time were driven off from my cell by a fear that came over them. By this noise and the shouting which they raised, the Inquisitor and his companion were filled with great terror; and both dared not go to the door of the room in which the magician lived, until I came, and, trusting in divine help, entered the room, and thereby impressed upon him the powerlessness and weakness of the demons. The same was also attested to me by his grown brother, who told me how he had very often heard the voices of many speakers, although the sick man had been alone in the room or in the stable of his house, who, under loud laughter, blasphemed God; which each time caused him the greatest fright.

The same man, a serious person, also solemnly declared that the brother was heard on almost every night uttering dreadful blasphemies against God, and mocking and deriding Him; which he himself, when I afterwards asked him about it, admitted, adding that he cast them forth in his inward wrath, roused by the violent passion that filled his heart against that young man, and from which he could only free himself by such outbursts. All of that then led directly to atheism, to which several of the magicians with whom he associated daily, according to his own statement, professed themselves.

All this and his whole remaining behaviour left little hope of his deliverance. I had appointed a day on which he should come to Mass and make the beginning of a sacramental confession. He promised everything; but the demon produced a stiffness and numbness in his body, so that it seemed to him as if it were cold, hard and earthbound; so that he could not stir himself from his bed. After two days I visited him, reproaching him for not having come at the appointed hour. He replied, "Excuse me, for I cannot rise from the bed nor move from the spot; yet I am content and satisfied and feel no sort of pain." When I thereupon commanded the demon not to hinder him, he rose immediately and went to our cloister. But when he wished to confess his sins, there was not the smallest sign of sorrow or inwardness to be perceived in him; which occurred repeatedly over the course of the month. He several times appeared ready to make his confession, and said, "My offences grieve me in my heart," although he was not in a state to show any outward contrition. But hardly had he knelt down when it seemed as if the whole act he performed were entirely empty and altogether irrational; and he said he was aware of no mortal sin. After scarcely begun questioning he already stood up, saying, "I remember no transgression at all." \[Page 35\]

Often, when I sought by wholesome exhortations to prepare him for confession, he immediately broke off the conversation and went away, as if someone had urgently summoned him; which he also did frequently with the Inquisitor. When I reminded him to accuse himself of diabolical magic, the invocation of spirits, and other such crimes, he answered: he could not accuse himself of that, because it was an excellent, holy thing worthy of no reproach; he had a pure conscience, unstained by any crime, nor defiled by any vice; and all that he undertook was permitted and right and holy. If, therefore, he had formed a purpose of repentance, the matter was always turned by the demon to the contrary; because his purpose never aimed at God, but at the removal of the bodily evil with which he felt afflicted.

He told me this often in the words: "I do not want you to cleanse my conscience by confession; for we magicians and necromancers are all sure of our salvation, and do not need confession; because contrition is sufficient for us, as Peter of Abano teaches us in his writings. I therefore ask only that you free me from the maleficium, should such a thing have struck me." Thus he referred everything solely to his bodily health, and no desire arose in him to attend to his spiritual health in order to cure himself of the illness that kept him down. After I had dealt with him for a month he was, for the time being, dismissed home by the Inquisitor. With the increase of this illness he, despairing of any cure, wished to put an end to his own life.

Since he could not leave the bed on which he lay, he incessantly called to those present: Give me a sword or a dagger, with which I can quickly remove myself from the world! Why do I delay any longer? I need only a rope to hang myself. So wills my patron, to whom I have given and devoted myself wholly and entirely; to whom, with body and soul, by virtue of the concluded covenant from which I cannot free myself, I belong! He often made similar speeches, and would have carried them into effect had not someone kept watch over him day and night, as a worthy priest who saw him often at that time testified to me.

In the year 1667, nineteen years later, when his book was to be printed in Venice, Brognoli asked another priest, who was his countryman, whether he was still alive; and this man replied: I believe so, but I have not seen him for a long time; for years now he has lain bound in chains, naked, covered all over with hair, and entirely without sense. For one day, when he, with some of his companions, outside the city, was performing his necromantic circles to summon the demons, and in some respect erred against his art, the spirits rose up against him and beat him with cudgels all over his body, and especially upon the head, so that he was scarcely carried away half dead by his companions; from those blows he afterwards entirely lost the use of his reason, and became more senseless than an animal. Thus had happened to him what I had often foretold him, when I begged and entreated him to return to sound reason.

If one considers more closely this horrid mixture of madness, possession and bewitchment, of hellish humor and mockery and irony, one clearly sees the threads of evil deceit, of wicked infernal arts, and of wild, unbridled passions shining through, out of which a demonically impious deed has woven together this tragic story. \[Page 36\]

It falls into the last times of the Thirty Years' War, in which a dreadful barbarization seized upon almost the whole of European society and brought forth the utmost of vileness and abomination, whose miasmas were then carried about everywhere by the undisciplined armies. It was then also this learned doctor of both laws, and thoroughly instructed theologian, whom the pestilential influence seized, and whom they wove into their mysteries in that cave near Genoa. His associates were sorcerers and malefactors, Manichaeans, Anabaptists, Protestants, but above all atheists. Among these, without doubt, all those higher-order questions that moved the times had been discussed, and had led, by divided paths, out into uncertainty.

Protestantism had first awakened doubt, and carried it through all degrees to heathen pantheism, and finally to self-destruction in atheism. The Anabaptists on their part had pointed to mystical routes in order to attain truth in these matters; the malefactors boasted of a practice founded in a world other than the Christian; the Manichaeans promised to unlock this night-covered world, and so the journey to the Genoese cave was undertaken. That the Manichaeans were the ones who played the principal role in the abjuration of the Christian God and the subsequent admission into the fellowship of the evil prince is already shown by the indications of an ordered hierarchy that shine forth from the whole act. There were nine magicians, that is, Manichaeans, who were present at the rite, carrying pitch torches in their hands. Their hidden chief appears in the cave in human form, but wearing the mask of the Goat of Mendes.

They fall down before him, in the usual fashion paying him homage with the kiss a posteriori. Only the first among them, their bishop, then rises from the midst of those kneeling and brings the novice forward. The Manicheans, as they spread themselves in Italy, had united and ordered themselves under a fully developed hierarchy. From the trial of their adherents which the Inquisition held at the end of the thirteenth century in Ferrara it appears that the sect had bishops in all the principal places --- through the Ferrara, Mantua, Verona, Bergamo, Vicenza districts as far as Romandiola --- several of whom are named, as well as visitators, quaestors and messengers. By the zeal of the Inquisition and the crusades in France the league was broken at the beginning of the fourteenth century, but not exterminated. The ruins withdrew from the light of day and withdrew into the darkness that in any case had been their element; and we still see them so late, in the old holy ninefold of their heads, in that cave, a secret Carbonaria, assembling for recruitment.

Before the seat of the Master the question of the terms of the pact is now discussed. The desire of the one to be received concerns treasures, invisibility, the serviceability of demons at his command. The Master of the Rock agrees, on his part, on the condition that the initiate renounce God and His Church, and firmly believe that there is no other god than him, the demon. This touched directly upon that question earlier debated among the Genoese. "The exclusive godhood of the demon contradicts my reason," replies the novice, refusing to make such a profession. In truth this doctrine could hardly have pleased Manichaeism, because it rested on the denial of all that is spiritual, and would soon have to threaten even Satan himself in his existence. The chief magician, who was regarded as a bishop among the others, therefore stepped forward as mediator; and although he himself professed that doctrine, he permitted the novice to hold to it at his pleasure so long as he seriously acknowledged the duality of the divine being: one invisible who created spiritual things, and another who created the visible, corporeal things. \[Page 37\]

Both, however, are Manichaean doctrine, as Pfellus found in the last half of the eleventh century among the Euchites or Enthusiasts, a Manichaean sect in Thrace. According to his account these took a Father and two Sons as principles. They left the government of the super-world to the Father; of the sons, the younger had the dominion of the heavenly, the elder that of the underworld. In accordance with this threefold principle they themselves again divided into three parts. Some paid divine veneration to both sons at once, because they were, although often not in agreement, nevertheless children of the same father and would once more be received into grace. Others worshipped the younger only as lord of the higher region, without, however, refusing the older his honor, which they did not withhold for fear of harm from his power. Those among them who attained to the highest godlessness entirely renounced the service of that heavenly one and turned all their veneration to the elder, whom they called Satanaki and the firstborn, alienated from the Father, and acknowledged as the author of plants, animals and all composite bodies, together with all corruption and degeneration. To honor him especially highly, they impute to the heavenly all injustice: he envies his brother and persecutes him, who governs the earthly well, with the bitterest hatred, arousing earthquakes, hailstorms and famine; wherefore they, among all other imprecations, also utter that shameful anathema against him. \[Page 38\]

This Satanaki was also present at the initiation in the cave; how much of that was capricious and how much derived from traditionally transmitted, magically visionary practice cannot be determined from the account. Psellus likewise relates: the demons promised gold, possessions and honours, all of which they were in fact unable to provide. To the initiated they often presented many phantasms and fiery displays of light, which they dared to call theoptia or divine visions; and to obtain these they were obliged to undergo every shameful and abominable thing. He then speaks of the solid and liquid excrements of mankind, which they were bound to taste, because that made the demons favourably disposed toward them. He then explains their secret sacrifice. On the evening of the day on which we celebrate our Lord's Passion they would be brought into a house; there, with lights extinguished, all would intermingle without distinction. After the lapse of nine months they would then meet again in the same place. Four days after the birth the children would be taken from their mothers, all their blood drained off, and they would be burned alive on a pyre; the blood was then mixed with the ashes, and with that they contaminated food and drink, and that was their communion. They believe that thereby the symbols impressed on our soul are driven out and obliterated, so that the demons can gain access to it.1) All their deeds and endeavours are indeed directed to making the demons visible to them.

Later he also speaks of some among them who possessed a prophetic spirit. One of these, speaking of him in an assembly of his own people, once said: "Know that a man will be sent against us who will persecute our faith and abolish its customs! He will, like many others, put me also in chains; yet, however much he may toil, it will not succeed in bringing me hence bound to Byzantium." He described me at that time down to the very countenance, clothing and everything; and that at a time when I had not even passed the suburbs of Byzantium. When I had indeed captured him and asked him whence he had his gift of prophecy, at first he would not answer; but finally, forced to speak, he said that he had learned his arts from a wandering Libyan. This man, he related, led him at night to a mountain, made him taste of an herb, then spat into his mouth, anointed his eyes with an ointment, and caused him to see a multitude of demons, among whom he perceived one that flew toward him in the shape of a raven and entered through his mouth into his entrails. From that time until the present day he could look into the future, as often and in all matters as pleased his demon. Only on the days of the Cross and of the Passion, and on the day of the Resurrection, does he never, even if I wish it, reveal anything to me. But when one of the men struck one of them on the mouth, he said to him, "You will pay dearly for this one blow!" and, turning to me, "but you will suffer much misfortune in your body! For the demons whose service you have overthrown are very hostile to you, and have brought upon you dangers which you will not escape unless a power higher than theirs frees you from them." And all came to pass as he had foretold, and I narrowly met death in the many dangers that surrounded me, from which, contrary to expectation, the Redeemer delivered me.

The ways of the Abomination --- on which, in the deep Orient, they knew how to prepare the sacrament of Hell, under sin and homicide, and the bread of the abyss which, whoever has tasted it, attaches him to the nether-realm and, as we heard elsewhere, never lets him recover --- these ways had also been opened in the peninsula of the West; the deep had foamed its venom into the food, and the unhappy Manichaean had sat at its table. Now the trunk of the good, which springs up in man, had not, as if struck by frost, cast off its green leafy adornment; the axe had not cut away its branches and shortened the trunk itself down to the ground: the stump left behind would then still have been able to put forth new shoots. No --- the last root of what was better had been torn up, the last living germ killed; the higher symbols were all extinguished, and to the dreadful night of death that had now fallen the demons had free access; and the seed of evil, buried down in the depths, could now develop freely.

He was not possessed, now, in the manner in which possession is commonly understood --- an involuntary entanglement with the hostile power, therefore bound merely in the body; rather the soul had surrendered itself in full deliberation, and from it the body was then occupied with its full knowledge and will. The bird of darkness had flown down through his opened mouth into the depths of his heart, and there, finding already the culpable inclination for that youth, had fastened itself to it and made it the center of his whole being. Thus it was he himself who had committed the evil deed, while his suspicion clung continually to others; just as he, thinking himself the possessor of the demons, became possessed by them. Precisely because a reversal of his whole being had taken place, no notion of his condition remained to him; because no object, not even God, was present to him by which, through comparison, he might find his bearings. The ground of his condition appeared to him good and right, for he believed himself to be perfectly oriented; he was certain of his salvation in it. Only a small flaw disturbed his happiness --- the supposed enchantment with the youth, to which he endeavored to attach all the contradictions into which his perverse state had entangled him with the proper order of things. When, at night, one abyss within him called to another, and a hundred voices spoke blasphemies and vented their despair, then he found in their fury a relief for his flaming passion, and believed that it merely poured itself out there. The bondage of his body when the physician approached him, the grim mocking laugh that burst from him, and the grief that possessed him --- it was all, as he knew, the consequence of his own doing; his caprice, however, had only surrendered to vicissitudes; another power, which continued itself alone in his will, had made the choice.

This power had bound him with fetters of necessity, and this necessity was not the expression of a power that binds in love under the law of order; but of a violence, hating and destroying in the division of lawlessness, that compelled him to all evil. Thus he was the true canon of a condition that will hereafter meet us more often; a condition that united him intimately with everything that in any way created evil on earth. \[Page 39\]

He therefore attended all the Sabbaths of the brethren, but with the unboundness of a high magnate of the realm, coming and going according to his pleasure, as it pleased him. It was therefore no wonder that Brognoli's efforts failed on an honorable man in whom reason had become counter-reason, conscience an uncertainty, the whole spirit a mere madness. His end, in which, it is to be believed, his comrades took part, was therefore also --- with the complete extinguishing of the last spark of intellect --- the outbreak of a raging beast, which vented itself upon its chain.

#### B. Effects of Judaism on the Art of Witchcraft

The Jews, scattered in the midst of Christendom, and having for so many centuries penetrated and in part overgrown it, necessarily had to exert a historical influence in every sphere, despite the hatred long heaped upon them; and thus even that which here demands our attention could least escape their influence. Talmud and Kabbalah had effected the construction and development of a twofold realm of spirits: opposite the paradise, which rises in seven steps, each placed under the ward of an angel, they had deepened a hell, fashioned pyramidally in Dantesque fashion, pierced by seven streams of fire, and guarded by just as many angels of destruction.

Above all these Satanim or Opponents, Schedim or Desolators, Seirim or Terribles --- the sum of all dark powers --- was to them S'maäl, Satan par excellence; whose Schechina, or feminine part, is called Lilith or the serpent; and all of them together sought only to spread ruin everywhere and to restore the state of Chaos. Samael, the alien god, was a servant of the Most Blessed; but since he has made himself a god, the Most Blessed will in time sweep away the fallen and entirely destroy the impious servant. \[Page 40\]

Just as there are degrees on the holy side, so also on the unclean; and as there man and woman are contained as one there, so also here; and Samael's consort was the serpent; and from the day when this evil serpent, who is the death of the world, persuaded Adam, she obtained dominion over him, until the King Mashiach comes. For by the poison which she hurled upon him, Satan has gained a permanent assault upon man. Great therefore is the power permitted to Satan by God over the world; the Satanim dwell with man and beside him, and mock him; and their purpose is to do him harm, and they pursue his blood.

Not only does Satan draw to himself those who voluntarily surrender to him; he also persecutes the pious, and disturbs their well-being by the Ruach Thesaṣṣith, the spirit of confusion or possession. The man in whom such an evil spirit has entered does everything he does and says by the inspiration of the evil spirit that is in him. Thus it was also with the serpent in the case of Eve: all that she did and spoke came from Samael. In the city of Ferrara a Jewish woman was thus possessed; she fell into a stupor, and a voice issued from her throat while her lips were without movement, and the voice spoke. In the time of Luria there was a widow into whom a Ruach had entered, and it inflicted extraordinary torments upon her. People went to her, spoke with her, and received answers to what they asked. The relatives of the woman came to Loriah, and begged him that he would drive the Ruach out of the woman. Loriah sent his pupil R. Chaim Vital, and gave him certain holy names with him, and told him what intention he was to observe in the matter. He also commanded him that he should pronounce over the Ruach the small and great ban, and should by force drive it out. When R. Chaim came to the woman, she turned her face away from him. R. Chaim said: Why do you turn away? The Ruach answered: I cannot look you in the face. Then R. Vital commanded that it must turn around, which immediately happened. He now asked the spirit: who are you? whereupon it related its former criminal life. It said it had formerly been a Jew, and had already been wandering in the world for twenty‑five years, incessantly pursued by three angels of destruction. Vital further asked: who gave it permission to enter the woman? The Ruach said: I was in the house when the woman rose in the morning and wanted to strike a fire. When the tinder would not catch, she became angry and threw the tinderbox out of her hands in rage and said: "Go to Satan!" From this word "Satan" I obtained permission to enter her. Although the woman sinned through the sin of unbelief, and did not believe in the Exodus from Egypt, yet the Ruach had no opportunity to enter her until she, in anger, mentioned the name "Satan."

As the good service is directed toward purification and sanctification and the restoration of the original harmony, so opposed to it is an evil service, directed to the unclean and dark --- the discord of that harmony. This demonic service reaches its height when a person, with full will, delivers his soul in a formal covenant to Satan; keeps a personal intercourse with him and his followers; at appointed times delights himself with them by dances, orgies and other excesses; and now he and Satan serve one another mutually. For it is known that all sorcerers and sorceresses make a covenant with the Shed, and deliver their soul to it.

##### Specific Tales of Jewish Sorcery

\[Page 41\]

In the magic books of Ashnidat we find that those who wish to practise sorcery should stand by a burning light, or in a place where the Kliphath can see the man's shadow. They should say words ordered for that sorcery, and call the Unclean by their unclean names; and should appoint their shadow for those whom they have called; and should declare that they submit themselves to their will for their service. Such a man goes forth from the dominion of God, and yields his spirit to the unclean side. And by the magic words which he utters, when he invites the unclean spirits to his shadow, two Ruchin appear; and they arrange themselves in his shadow, in the form of men, and are contained therein, and communicate to him matters in order to do evil, sometimes also to perform good. Thus is the order of the evil side: one prepares a table for them, with food and drink and magical works, and makes smoke before the table. Then all the unclean Ruchin assemble, and make known what the sorcerers desire.

All kinds of witchcraft in the world are connected and proceed from the ancient serpent, which is the unclean spirit; therefore all the witchcrafts of the world are called serpent‑arts. Some sorcerers also transform themselves into the shape of animals and harm people; or traverse great distances in a short time. With them one also makes use of darker means, especially salves made from certain herbs and oils.

There are also women who have made a pact with the Shedim, and at certain times meet with them, dance with them, and attend those spirits which appear to them as bucks. In many states such women are put to death; for although their crime consists in no external, but only in an internal, imaginative act, the death-penalty is nevertheless just, because they have wholly surrendered themselves to Satan.

It also happens, that when a man dreams, female Ruchin come to him, excite themselves with him, solicit themselves from him, and afterwards bear children. In the same way male Ruchin come to women and impregnate them, so that they beget Ruchin. Great also is the power of the evil eye. For it rules over a thing which takes place with pomp and noise, even when it is brought about by a miracle. The Ruchin do not all belong, however, to the more wicked orders; there are also elemental spirits, namely such as consist of the element of fire, invisible but inclined to good, the salamanders of the Middle Ages; others formed of fire and air, the sylphs of that order, likewise invisible, and wise and good. The third class consists of fire, air and water, at times perceptible to the senses, their life being of a plant-like kind, the undines of the middle period; finally the fourth order, in which a substance of earth is added, visible and of a more mineral nature, belonging with the foregoing to the side of Samael. They all dwell in the upper, inner circles of the elements, and know the near future; their food is the incense with which they are fumigated; according to the fineness of their elemental body is also the degree of their spiritual rank.

From all these citations, which reach down from the beginning of the 17th century to the older times of the Zohar, it follows how, besides possessions, also the whole witch- and sorcery-craft, the entire visionary and operative black magic, the incubus and the succubus, and likewise natural magic, were perfectly well known to the Jews; and that all these black arts, entirely analogous to those that prevailed in Christianity, developed themselves --- which of course proceeds from the commonness of the root, but also testifies to the continuing contact of both.

##### False Jewish Messiahs and the Demonic Influences

\[Page 42\]

The people of the Jews have, by temperament, been a mystical people before many others; and this temperament has likewise decisively helped their reputation as the chosen people in ancient times. Such a bent made it possible to lead this people out of bondage into a conquered fatherland, and to hold them there for so many centuries, bound under theocratic forms; and the whole history of this realm, and even its fall into death and horror, amid the turmoil of every passion, bears witness to this mystical, full-blooded vein which runs through its otherwise harshness and obstinacy. But even after the judgment had come, and the nation was scattered, this side of their tribal character did not fade; and it especially manifested itself whenever their hope for a coming Redeemer moved their whole mind in its inmost depths. When that "son of the star," Bar Chochéba, for the first time awakened and deceived that hope in them, the enthusiasm for their new king burst forth into bright flames, which could only be extinguished by a bloodbath worse than that which Titus had wrought among them.

In the year 432 that other Moses appeared on the island of Crete and proclaimed that he had been sent to earth a second time in order to lead Israel again into the land of their fathers, on dry feet through the divided waves of the sea. The people, seized by enthusiasm, abandoned their trades, gave away their property, and followed their leader to the seashore; and there, at his command, without wavering in their faith, crowds from the heights cast themselves into the sea and were swallowed by the waves. The survivors explained the calamity that had befallen them by saying that it had been a ruach from the dark side, one of the demons of Samael, that had seduced them.

It was just the same with all the others; and when, at the beginning of the seventeenth century, Sabbatai Zevi in the Orient proclaimed himself the son of David and the long-expected Redeemer, Nathan of Gaza --- who had become clairvoyant, pronouncing past things of which he could not have known by natural means; who saw visions and prophesied of the future --- declared him such. Soon prophets and prophetesses rose up in Samaria, Adrianople, Thessalonica, Constantinople and many other places: men, women, youths and girls, even children, were seized by the prophetic spirit. They fell suddenly to the ground as if epileptic, had violent convulsions, and in that state uttered, both in Hebrew and in Aramaic --- languages of which they had previously not understood a word --- wonderful and extraordinary things, both long past and yet to come. Every such prophecy concluded with the words: "Sabbatai Zevi is the true Messiah, from the house of David, to whom crown and kingdom are given!" \[Page 43\]

Even the opponent Pechina, whom he had encountered and to whom he foretold that he would yet live to see his own daughters bear children for him, had to witness the fulfillment of the word. For when that man once returned to his house, he found his two daughters festively adorned, and they spoke in the two languages which they had never understood, about the new Messiah. Also Moses Servil, a highly respected, sensible man who had been his renounced enemy, suddenly found himself driven to exhort the people to repentance because the redemption of Israel through Sabbatai was near; and at the same time he was given the gift of reading every person's committed sins from their brow. In the end all this enthusiasm found itself sadly betrayed, when the Messiah converted to Islam.

This impetuous, inflammable people --- which, once kindled, burns long afterward --- had now, after it had misconceived its historical vocation and missed the solution of the problem assigned to it, the fate of seeing itself given over to the captivity of the nations for a third time; this time, so that it, to use the expression of Pope Innocent III, as "the living witness of the true Christian faith" he led his life among them. In Germany they were regarded as chamber-servants of the realm, over whom the emperor exercised authority; likewise in the other kingdoms of the Christian West. The powerful vassals in every case had parcelled the unhappy people out among themselves, and, treating them as serfs and, by the strict letter of the law, stripping them of all personal, property and contractual rights, had added them to their domains. Though the popes, especially in earlier times --- Innocent II and III, Alexander III and Gregory IX --- urged leniency; though the bishops sheltered them against inhuman violences; and the synods regulated their relations with Christians: they served hard bondage, and each year hatred would sharpen anew against them when the observance of the days of suffering recurred, and the people, prone to merriment, allowed themselves blasphemies against the mysteries, or sometimes even ascribed them to the Jews.

##### Jewish Treachery

As compensation to the oppressed, the riches of Christendom were allotted to them; even the church treasures were not excepted; the day was to come when the consecrated gold would be handed over into their hands by its keepers. The fulfillment of this promise was bound up with the magnetic attraction that exists between metal and genuine avarice, and with the sober cunning and industry of this class of people. Thus they always succeeded in getting hold of the largest portion of the circulating money supply, and they continued to practise usury with it at the enormous interest rates customary for the time and country. The joy in ever-increasing possessions made the lot of the oppressed easier. The mighty, for whose account they in part lent and acquired, protected them; but the people, who felt themselves doubly drained by lords and by servants, burned more and more with fury against the arts of usury; moreover with envy and ill will against the rising prosperity of the ever-multiplying foreigners, who, like parasitic plants, entwined and sucked away the native stock. \[Page 44\]

Over generations the storm slowly gathered, single outbreaks from time to time announced the approaching catastrophe; at last, when the Crusades put the people into the deepest inner agitation, the whirlwind burst forth with fury. Like lightning the persecution suddenly fell upon the people devoted to destruction; in France, Spain, England, Italy, up the Rhine, down the Danube, in Bohemia and Hungary, the masses rose against the unfortunate as if by common agreement; and robbery, arson and murder raged against them everywhere. In English York, somewhat later, about five hundred of them who had fled to the castle were slaughtered --- their wives and children --- and were burned with the fortress; the petty nobility around, who owed them money, caused all the writs in the cathedral to go up in smoke, a burnt offering to the Lord. \[Page 45\]

They were driven away everywhere, but compassion and their gold soon opened the gates to them again; Louis VII in France tolerated them anew, and Peter the Venerable, who had been abbot of Cluny from 1120 (sic) and was a man of note in his time, who knew the Talmud well and had had the Koran translated in Spain, could urge this king to employ their riches against the power of the Saracens. "What I say to you, O King, concerning the Jews," says the abbot, "is well known to all. Not by diligent tilling of the soil, not by lawful service in war, not by any honourable and useful occupation do they fill their barns with fruits, their cellars with wine, their sacks with money, their chests with gold and silver; but solely from that which they win from Christians by deceit, which they buy from thieves at a bad price." If a robber breaks into a Christian church anywhere, if he brazenly carries off candlesticks, jugs, censers, even the holy cross or the consecrated chalices; then he avoids the Christians, seeks out the Jews, and, enjoying accursed security with them, he not only has his den of thieves in their midst, but sells what was stolen from the holy Church to the synagogue of Satan. The vessels that contained the Body and the Blood of Christ he hands over to those who killed that Body and shed His blood; who then, when He walked among mortals, did Him every outrage, and now, seated in the Majesty of the Godhead, do not cease to persecute Him with their blasphemies. Even those holy vessels themselves, which they preserve, as formerly the Chaldeans preserved theirs, remain therefore --- though they themselves have no feeling --- not free from reproach; and they are, as I have often heard from trustworthy men, put to a use which is already a horror to imagine, and an abomination to speak of.

But that is not enough! So that such dishonorable theft and the Jewish fence might be secured, an old, truly demonic law, issued by Christian princes, has prevailed: that if a church utensil, and what is worse, a holy vessel, is found in the possession of a Jew, he shall not be bound to return the church theft, nor to betray the unworthy robber.

Those were burning words, words of reproach for the powerful of the time who, like William II of England, accepted gold from Jewish fathers to deter by threats and persuasions their sons who wished to become Christians; flaming words which, kindling in every heart, explain --- if they never justify --- the barbarity with which passion then acted in that age. The Talmud tells the people of Israel: the shooting lights that fall nightly from the stars are the tears which Elohim twice daily weeps over the captivity of His people; every morning, for the same reason, He roars like a lion, stamping the firmament with His feet. Like a turtledove He utters a cry of lament each day, rocking His head and crying, "Woe! woe upon me! that I have made my house a wilderness, broken and burned my temple, and scattered my sons among the nations." A people that in this way carried all its pride into its humiliation, and laid its sorrow in the bosom of its God, must deeply rage over the ill‑treatment and the scorn it endured, and a violent reaction must kindle in the sulphur‑fields of its passion. Defenceless and long unaccustomed to courage, as the Jews had grown in their servility, this reaction could not rise openly, eye for eye, against their persecutors; it was forced to choose secret ways in order to strike more safely. Hence, from that time forth, the legends of poisoning wells and running waters; the legends of sacrament‑theft, to assuage wrath against the substitute of the Crucified; and finally, in order to wound those hateful oppressors in the depths of their hearts, the seizing of their children to make of them victims of vengeance.

The oldest example of such a robbery appears to be that of the boy William of Norwich, whom the English Jews in the year 1144, in the ninth year of King Stephen, thus abducted and cruelly put to death in Passion Week; to which the French, following this precedent, in the year 1171 likewise sacrificed a boy at Easter in Blois, and were therefore delivered to the fire by Count Theobald; and in the year 1179, when those of Paris crucified the boy Richard of Pontoise. In the year 1181 news again came over from England: the Jews had treated the boy Robert at St. Edmund in just the same way as in 1160 under Henry with the one from Gloucester; the great uprising of 1180 was the consequence of this.

In all these cases, however, there was no formal investigation; the murdered were venerated by the people as saints, and the miracles performed by their relics served as a guarantee for everything that legend told --- a guarantee which was not in all cases irrefragable, since the people brought their own excitement into the matter; and this excitement probably sometimes even produced miracles at human remains, about which the Inquisition later had to pronounce the sentence of condemnation.

The courtiers now told, at the coronation of Philip Augustus, to the young king in their levity: in his father's time the Jews in Paris had every year sacrificed a boy --- as in this case Robert of Pontoise --- to the derision of the Christians; and they were thereupon arrested throughout France, their Christian creditors were released from every debt, and then they were all expelled from the realm, and their movable goods awarded to the king; a decree which, however, was revoked in 1108, because it was felt with regret that one had killed the hen that laid the golden eggs. The Jews, on their side, answered this harshness at Brienne by accusing a Christian of homicide and by taking a bankrupt peasant --- whom the local countess had delivered to them --- and crowning him with thorns, beating him through the town with sticks, and then hanging him; for which 82 of them had to make atonement by death by fire.

From then on the boy-murders recur throughout the whole course of the thirteenth century. When Henry III in England had driven the Jews by his exactions to the utmost, so that they themselves asked to emigrate with their goods, their bitterness produced in the year 1255 the outrage at Lincoln. They had, as the chronicles of the country relate, abducted the nine-year-old boy Hugh from his children's play into the house of Jopinus, there starved and scourged him for 26 days, cut open the wings of his nose, cut off his upper lip, and smashed in his teeth; then stuck him all over the body with needles, and finally killed him with a lance-wound. The body had been drawn up from a well; numerous miracles had strengthened the suspicion against the Jews, who were arrested. John of Lessinan conducted the trial, and since their chief rabbi Jopinus had been promised his life, he confessed everything. He was nevertheless dragged to death behind a horse; 18 suffered the same death later in London, and the remaining 60 escaped the same fate only through the intercession of the Dominicans and Richard, the king's brother. \[Page 46\]

On the Rhine, in the year 1287 at Oberwesel, they seized the fourteen‑year‑old youth Werner while he was carrying earth out of the cellar of one of their houses; they had hanged him with his head downward in order to get possession of the Host that he had taken before his work. When that, however, did not succeed, they put him to death after various torments and cast him far from the place into the fields. Although Emperor Rudolph, and through him the Archbishop of Mainz, took the Jews under their protection, the nobility of Swabia --- already inflamed by another murder which they had committed in 1271 on a seven‑year‑old girl at Pforzheim --- rose up mightily against them, and several thousands lost their lives. Earlier, already in 1256, Emperor Frederick II had ordered a formal inquiry into the repeated accusations of murder, but it had led to no result.

Mahometanism, in its essence a Judaism driven up to the highest abstraction, stripped of the abandoned Messiah‑idea, had from its origin exhibited certain sympathetic relations to Judaism. Jews had cooperated with Nestorian heretics in the composition of the Koran; Jews had already before the Prophet founded realms among the Ishmaelites, and the Prophet had only reluctantly renounced the idea of winning them over amicably, and only against his will subdued them by force of arms. In Spain, since the conquest by the Saracens, they were continually accused of collusion with the enemy of Christendom. In the year 1321 letters were said to have been found in France in which the King of Granada reported to the Jew Samson that he had loaded three pack animals with riches and poisons to poison the waters with them, and had sworn to them as reward to carry them back into the Promised Land. When, then, in 1348 the great death began throughout Europe, and only the Jews were spared, this suspicion seemed to be confirmed; and a terrible persecution again burst forth against those who, it was thought, had sworn the death of Christendom.

When later in Spain the realm of Islam came to an end, the Jews were again involved in its fall. After the middle of the century it became notorious that in Hispalis there had been opened a Jewish propaganda directed against Christians; and in secret assemblies, in the midst of apostates, terrible blasphemies were uttered. Two inquisitors were therefore sent there in 1482 to investigate the matter. To their edict, which allowed forty days for the apostates to return, 17,000 of them yielded; the others were sought out, and had either to pay with their lives or, confined in sacks, to do penance. But when Granada fell; when fears of the contagion spreading among the people grew ever stronger; when Jews in the town of La Guardia were accused of having stolen the Sacrament of the Eucharist and committed sacrilege upon it; when they were said to have nailed a stolen child to a cross --- then, in the year 1492, the edict went forth that all Jews must leave Spain within three months under penalty of death; their goods they might sell and take with them. An enormous terror fell upon them, and by the hundred thousands they went over to Africa, Greece, Romania, Egypt and Babylonia; others fled to Portugal, France, Italy, Germany; many perished in shipwreck or at the hands of pirates: it was a calamity greater than that which they suffered in the time of Titus and Hadrian, and it even stirred the compassion of Christians toward them.

In the century that ran from 1394, when Charles VI likewise again drove them out of France, to this catastrophe, we again find the child‑murders reappearing with force, and now by means of judicial inquiry taking on a more documentary character. Outstanding among them, above many others, is the story of the boy Simon, who was born in Trento in the year 1472 of poor parents, and in the year 1475 found his death at the hands of the Jews. At the instigation of the old Moses, who was reputed to be a seer, knowing the day and hour of the Messiah's coming, their elders---Tobias, Angelus and Samuel, in whose house the synagogue was---had resolved to sacrifice a Christian boy at the Easter festival. But since their servants refused the plotted seizure of such a one, Tobias at last undertook it himself, his medical profession giving him the best opportunity to execute the commission. The boy was brought in, hidden for a time in the synagogue, and on the appointed day was most cruelly murdered. The corpse was concealed by the murderers for some time, because the elders searched everywhere for the child with armed men; and finally, as the danger pressed all too near upon the awakened suspicion, it was thrown into the nearby flowing water, and the discovery was then reported to the authorities.

The bishop ordered the most exacting inquiry; the Schultheiß Johannes and the prefect Jacob de Sporo were appointed as judges; they summoned Archangelus Baldin of Trento, Math(eus) Tiberinus of Brescia, Chr(istus) de Fatis of Turlach, as physicians and surgeons, to report on the condition of the corpse and its wounds, and the report sharpened the grounds for suspicion. The Jews were brought in; they chose the most eminent jurists at the University of Padua as their defenders; their statements contradicted one another, torture finally forced the full confession which---being found to agree completely with the circumstances (one had, for example, also discovered the hidden flask containing the collected blood)---now resulted in the judicial condemnation of the proved perpetrators, the expulsion of the Jews from Trento, and the transformation of the synagogue into a chapel of the miracle‑working murdered one. All this is reported by the physician M. Tiberinus in an authentic letter to the senate and citizens of Brescia. The deed had taken place on the night of 23 March; the sentence was executed on 21 June; in the three months between the rumor ran through all Italy. \[Page 47\]

On 22 April the Doge of Venice, P. Mocenigo, issued a mandate; it was believed that the rumor of a boy murdered by the Jews had been invented only for certain purposes; he, however, wished that the Jews should dwell undisturbed and secure in his lands; he therefore forbade any change in their condition, and prohibited preachers and other persons from stirring up the people against them.
