That was without doubt worthy, just and sensible; but when meanwhile the trial had taken its course and led to the result above mentioned, then a second decree of 12 August of the same year revoked that judgment, permitted the carrying about of the images of the martyr, allowed preachers to treat the deed from the pulpit, but even then forbade them to incite the people against the Jews; because those who were not guilty could not be struck by the punishment. \[Page 48\]

In September the magistrate of Trento wrote a letter to Venice --- still to be found in the archive of St. Franciscus de Vinea --- in which he reports the affair in complete agreement with Tiberianus, and among other things says: "how the judges, although they were deeply moved by the murder, and well recognized the deceit and guile of the Jews, their cunning, their hatred against the Church, and the corrupting power of their gold, nevertheless dealt with them so moderately, with such gravity and such leniency, that whoever runs through the records will rather complain of excessive indulgence and tenderness than of severity. Torture, it is true, finally wrested the truth from them; but after Tobias had first confessed, all, as with one mouth, confirmed the matter with regard to place, time, circumstances, and those who had been present. It is moreover not the first time that such things have occurred." 1) These and the immediately following, still entirely unedited documents are taken from the work: De Cultu sancti Simonis pueri Tridentini, et martyris apud veteres in --- (title in the Crela sacra) sive de episcopis utriusque Ritus graeci et latini in Insula Venet. 1755. In the appendix five shorter writings of the author Flaminius Cornelins, senator in Venice. The first document p. 63. 2) Ibid. p. 67. Görres, chrihl. Mystie. 1v. 2. 5

Since time immemorial the same thing, it says, has occurred in Speyer on the Rhine, likewise in Dortmund in Westphalia, in Maastricht in the duchy of Guelders. In the place Dutsch, between Cologne and Aachen, two boys were likewise sacrificed; two others in the town of Penigen in Swabia; in Upper Bavaria in Amberg one; in the Palatinate at Alzey another; in Endingen in the margraviate of Baden two, whose parents were also murdered; recently moreover the whole of Christendom has learned what occurred in Sicily." 3) As the multiplying miracles in the meantime further spread the cult of the murdered boy, a breve of Pope Sixtus IV of 10 October 1475 forbade this beatification until the proper inquiry before the papal throne, to which the decision alone belongs, should take place; at the same time taking the Jews under the protection of the Church; and the Doge had commanded that this breve be obeyed in his territory. Several cardinals and other prelates were then appointed commissioners for the examination of the process records; and after these had thoroughly examined the whole business, on 20 June 1478 the entire legal procedure was completely approved as irreproachable; and the veneration was then permitted, although no breve concerning it remains.

Five years had hardly passed since this murder-story in the neighboring Trentine territory, when the Senate of Venice had occasion, in its own jurisdiction at Portubuffaleto in the province of Friuli, to learn by experience that the tales which formerly circulated among the people about such matters were by no means unfounded. The Jews Servadeus and Moyses had set about Jakob, the son of Simon of Cologne, and another of the same name: to procure for them, at Easter time, a boy; and they had, following the suggestion, in Treviso found Sebastian Novello of Bergamo, a seven-year-old poor child, and persuaded him to follow them to Portubuffaleto; where then, on Maundy Thursday, they all together killed him. The perpetrators were brought to Venice, the trial was conducted in all lawful form, and the condemned were then burned on the Piazza San Marco, between the two columns. 5) According to others, five years later, on 5 April 1485, in Marostica, in the territory of Vicenza, the boy Lorenz suffered the same death; and the Jews were on that account expelled forever from that territory. \[Page 49\]

News came then from the Orient that they had bought a Christian slave from the sea‑robbers in Pontus and crucified him; and in Crete the syndic Gradonicus had reported that the people there, in derision, had crucified lambs. (1) About the same time, in the year 1486, according to the chronicles in Regensburg, six children were sacrificed in that manner. In the year 1540 the four‑year‑old boy Michael, according to Rader's Bavaria sancta III. B., was slaughtered at Easter in Heitingen; while in the year 1579 it was reported from Lithuania how a boy Sinnat and a girl Elisabeth, both seven years old, in the village Punie lost their lives at the hands of the Jew Joachim Sinerlovicz, with the consent of others.

In the year 1650, still, at Cadana in Bohemia on 11 March, the four‑year‑old boy Matthias was killed, to whom Ferdinand III caused a monument to be erected. Since then the matter was lost sight of until it reappeared in our days in Damascus --- a welcome opportunity for the newspapers and journals to chatter over the subject with their accustomed shallowness and vapidity, making use of the usual phrasemongering, and then to dismiss it as finally disposed of. But these murder‑stories had so deeply impressed themselves on the popular consciousness that they became the subject of popular song; and the strain beginning:

"The rain rins doun through Mirry‑land toune, Sae dois it doune the Pa: Sae dois the lads of Mirry‑land toune; Duhan they play at the ba' . . ."

is a relic of that popular poetry, in which "Mirryland toune" is very likely Milan, and "the Pa" denotes the Po.

In all these mutually provoking outbreaks of fury --- the wolf‑like rage of Christians against the Jews, and the hyena‑like reactions of the latter against the former --- the paw of the tearing beast that sleeps in the breast of man was only made visible; Hell had, by its breath, exhaled nothing but horrors, and the demonic had visibly entered the world. The imagination of the peoples, kept in constant excitement by the oft‑dreamed and sometimes palpable nearness of the outrage, accustomed itself not to recoil before the most monstrous; and, thus poisoned at its inmost root, brooded further upon the abominations with which it had become familiar. In this way blasphemies practised against all that is holy, the atrocious mistreatments of the plundered sacred things, the murderous deeds against children carried out under the most revolting circumstances, penetrated even into the Sabbath --- things that occur all too often to be other than rooted in the morbid condition of imagination of an infected age. \[Page 50\]

To the frequently recurring tales of poisoned wells were then joined those of the power of poison‑brewers extended also over the other elements, of weather‑making, and of the devastation of the vegetable world. One knows what power the Jews have ascribed to the Schem‑Hamphoraſch: it not only unlocks the word of man, but makes below the voice of animals intelligible, above the speech of ministering angels and the demons of the abyss; it makes the world of thought accessible and opens the view into the future. He who knew how to bind the Word could create a new world; Moses worked his wonders by it, the prophets prophesied by it, even Jesus --- who learned it from Jehoshua in Egypt --- brought forth wondrous things by it. It embraced not only, like the name Jehova, God's essence within itself, but at the same time also his omnipotence, omniscience, truth, righteousness, and mercy; it was written at the entrance of the Temple of Jerusalem on the stone that Jacob had anointed with oil; but in the burning of the Temple in the time of the Romans it was lost together with the stone; and the later Jews devised substitutes for it, and their legend has much to praise about what their rabbis effected with them. It is the symbol of the higher mysticism and prophetic gift as it existed in earlier Israel, but it retreated with the first captivity, and with the beginning of Christianity it was wholly lost; whereupon deceitful human contrivances and wicked witchcraft took its place.

##### Jewish Magic

All branches of the demonic arts have flourished merrily among the Jews: the interpreters of dreams, rabdomancy, casting lots and interpreting signs, the Iyur, astrology, amulets, the teraphim and necromancy. Everything at all times found its cultivation among them, and even today in the Orient Jewish women prepare love potions for the wives of the harem. The legend of the Jewish Faust accordingly runs through all the centuries of the modern era. The rabbi J. Scheda already boasts in the Sohar how much artistic skill he learned from a demon, a circumstance from which he also obtained his name. The Jew Sedechias, who lived in the time of Louis the Pious, had --- the chroniclers tell --- set himself the task of convincing people of the existence of the elementary spirits, as the Kabbalists interpreted them. He therefore commanded them to show themselves visibly. They did so in all their splendor, and one saw in the air a wonderful spectacle. Beings in human form showed themselves, arranged as if in battle order, now moving in good formation, now standing quietly under arms, or encamped beneath splendid pavilions. Sometimes they had embarked in air-ships of wondrous construction, and the fleet then sailed, driven by gentle winds, through the blue. \[Page 51\]

That was the same phenomenon that one has so often seen elsewhere, e.g. in the Scottish Highlands. Thus Walker relates, for example: In the year 1686, during the months of June and July, a large number of people were assembled at the Croftfoord ferry, two miles below Lanark, on the Clyde; they saw trees and the ground covered with caps, hats, swords and weapons. Armed men marched in order down to the water's edge; one troop met another; they passed through one another, crossed, then sat down and vanished, and others then took their places. I myself went three afternoons in succession, and as far as I could see there were among the assembled two who saw, always one who did not see; and although I myself saw nothing, all those who were in my position could not fail to perceive the fear and terror of the seers. Beside me stood one who said: "A pack of damned herren and sorcerers, who have the second sight; the devil rides them, that I see!" At once, however, a complete change came over all the features of his face, and such fear and trembling seized him as any one of the women I saw there; and the exclamation followed: "O all of you who see nothing, judge not; for I tell you, it is all true, and manifest to all who are not stone-blind!" The seers described meanwhile the appearance of the pieces of ordnance, their length and their caliber; the sword-hilts, whether they were narrow or triangular, or furnished with Highland tanged blades, likewise the points of the black or blue caps. And all who saw such things beheld, wherever they might look, everywhere a cap and a sword in the way. I have hitherto tried in vain to discover a foundation for this latter circumstance.

What occurred here in Scotland is the same as what happened a thousand years earlier in France; only that here the cabalist Sedechias was on the scene, who explained to the seers their visions out of the elemental spirits of Jewish doctrine; and the people at once connected the matter with Magonia and the air-ships of that mythical land, which, with Lombardic sorcerer‑poisons, ruined his crops. This same Sedechias, moreover, was the Jewish Faust of the Carolingian era, and Trithemius relates of him that he threw a man into the air, cut him into pieces, and then restored him whole and sound; also that, before all the spectators, he swallowed a cart of hay with horse and man. At the end of the 13th century the Rabbi Fechiel, a great cabalist of his time, was summoned to the French court. The Jews revered him as a saint, but the Parisians shunned him as a magician. It was said that he worked every night by the light of an inextinguishable lamp; the people gathered at his house to disturb his sorcery. Then he struck with a large hammer upon a nail; immediately the earth opened and swallowed the intruders. --- This expresses the popular notion of the Jews' magical powers, which remained the same in the centuries that followed. Rabbi Chanina had, he said, bought from an elderly man a toad for eighty florins in two silver vessels, from which he learned the law of Moses, the seventy languages of the peoples, as well as the languages of birds and four‑footed beasts. J. Karro had made use of a spirit for the study of the Mishnah. Rabbi Elias of Worms, Isaac Hünerfänger, Rabbi Levi of Moravia, Naphtali Lohen of Frankfurt, and others were later called great sorcerers; in the guise of a boy, of an eagle, of a raven the spirit had initiated them into the secret science. Often, therefore, the Jews in large numbers were suspected of sorcery; that Chanina was accordingly burned alive; in Ascalon, on one day, eighty Jewish women were hanged by Simeon ben Sehetah for magical poisoning; Thuringia likewise expelled the Jews precisely on the accusation of witchcraft.

Since the Kabbalah enjoyed such great repute, it was natural that the Jews gave themselves to it with all zeal; but, moreover, the persecution they suffered in that period had to lead them over to their demonic side. If they succeeded in gaining allies in the realm of spirits, they could then easily put an end to the oppressive supremacy of the Christians, and take vengeance for the outrages which they had to endure from them; not to speak of the hidden treasures over which such princes of spirits presided. According to the tradition of the Sohar, the eagle had already brought to King Solomon the two fallen angels who dwelt below in the deep abyss practising sorcery, and taught it to everyone who desired it; and he had learned many hidden things from them. Sacrifices offered to Samael that he should not accuse the chosen people before God on the Day of Atonement were, in any case, already customary. (3) The disposition to every form of ecstasy was, as we have seen, likewise highly developed in that people; their dispersion over all parts of the world brought them into contact with every centre of the art of magic, especially among the Saracens, and above all in the northwest of Africa, among the Moroccans.

The wound of suffered evils burned without ceasing; the perpetration of so many crimes in reaction made them fear nothing; shall we then wonder that the black art in that time found numerous practitioners among this people, and that the literature of magic books is especially attached to the Jews? The Jews, however, were then the general leaseholders of the princes: their revenues, customs and taxes passed through Jewish hands; they were the money-changers from whom all the powerful borrowed; often officials, in order to give weight to their business, and in conducting it protected by special rights. Early already they had also appropriated the medical profession to themselves, and while this profession sharpened its gaze into the nature of things, it also increased their influence on Christian society. \[Page 52\]

Under circumstances black-artists and alchemists for themselves --- whatever they were, both against and at times also for the Christians, who in any case were already standing on a well-known foundation in their doctrine of spirits --- and thus Judaism likewise furnished a well-spun thread to the web of sorcery of those times; as also the weavers themselves placed the Jewish mark in the note attached to the loom.

#### C. The Arrival of the Gypsies

About the year 1417, in the time of Emperor Sigismund, a people of about 3,000 souls migrated into Moldavia; there settling near Szesava, and soon strengthened by those who followed, spreading over Wallachia, Transylvania and Hungary; and the king soon granted them, in written letters, the right to settle around the royal towns and on the royal domains. They called themselves Zincalo, contracted in the plural to Cales, "black men," or Chai, also Romano; at times also Sinti, thereby pointing to India, from whence they had immigrated. This account found confirmation in the language they spoke, the Romany, which takes its foundation from the Samserida and has appropriated many Persian, Slavic and modern Greek roots; which then led the English to search in India for the tribe from which this people had been derived; in consequence of which they recognized, among the native aborigines in the North-Indian mountains, the sought-for root. The strangers, for their part, declared at that time: at first they had migrated from Little Egypt or Chali, where they had previously lived, until, being granted to an enemy of God, they were driven back.

They were thence driven away. For a Pharaoh of the land had, it is said, overcome all the peoples of the world, and finally, in his pride, challenged God himself and his heavenly host to battle. God, however, refusing the challenge, to punish him opened a wide cave in the side of a mountain, and a storm-wind then blew the Pharaoh with his host into that abyss, which thereupon closed over them. Whoever now on St. John's night approaches the mountain, hears the king with his army ever singing and sounding. But since the Pharaoh had thus vanished, all the kings and peoples who had previously obeyed his realm rose up against it; and easily conquered the defenceless people, drove out the vanquished, and scattered them over the whole world. \[Page 53\]

They were therefore also driven out, and they called themselves on that account Chat, the people of Chal; or in Hungary Pharaoh Nepet, people of the Pharaoh. Thus they belonged to the raging host, and were in the retinue of the overbearing Ashen‑king Sesostris; but when God overthrew the proud and shut him up in the Egyptian Horus‑mountain, when his rule overthrew the old heathenism, then they were expelled, and the old Tannhäuser went to Rome to obtain from the Pope absolution for his sins. They were therefore driven from their old dwelling-place as the consequence of a religious struggle; and if one considers that some dim notions of the transmigration of souls remained to them amid their religious indifference --- a doctrine which is found only in Buddhism --- then the great wars of the Buddhists with the Brahmins may easily have been the occasion of their expulsion.

From their original Indian homeland they then probably passed over Persia, where Ferdoussi already mentions them in the eleventh century; and then into Little Egypt, probably the Delta, later settling among the pictish and they may perhaps have traversed Asia along the same route which in primeval times the Indians followed, who, according to the Chronicle of Eusebius, migrated into the Nile‑land. There they still live under the name of the Ghaste, and from there have spread through North Africa; Leo the African seems to mention them under the name Zingari, as plunderers of the caravans from Agades to Bornu; and the Dar‑Buschi‑Fals or fortune‑tellers in Morocco, who speak their own language distinct from the Shilha and from Arabic, probably likewise belong to their root. \[Page 54\]

In the same way, as they passed through Asia, hordes were left everywhere; and while there the whole manners and customs of certain tribes, the Luri for example, recall them, swarms of them perhaps turned northwards via Astrakhan and spread into Russia. From Egypt the flights of these migratory birds then set out over Syria and Asia Minor on their migration to the third part. Crossing the Bosphorus, they first spread in the Byzantine realm; the whole Hæmus range from Abydos to Philippopolis gained from them the name Tschenghe Balkan; and from there they filled Bulgaria, probably incorporating from their contact with the local peoples Greek, Slavic and Wallachian roots into their language. After they had obtained a safe‑conduct from Emperor Sigismund in Hungary, and thus traversed all Germany to the North Sea, a division actually went via Bohemia and Switzerland in the year 1422 to Rome, to obtain the same from the Pope for the whole of Christendom. Since they, it seems, were at least not refused, they were thenceforth regarded as those on whom the Pope himself had imposed a seven‑year pilgrimage as penance; they were therefore spared and honored as poor itinerants, and from there spread over all the lands of Europe, as far as Spain; where they are called by all the peoples through whose lands they gradually passed the names Moors, Little Egyptians, Bohemians and Germans, and are traced back to Tatars, Persians, Cilicians and Nubians.

A wild, coarse people --- thus these Gypsies appeared to the chroniclers of that time, setting out for booty and carrion like birds of prey; and in this they were akin to the race of pleasure‑seekers, in that they direct all their thoughts only to the next moment and live wholly in it. They therefore at all times showed themselves restless, frivolous and mobile even in their mien, in all their doings as inconstant as air and water; with great cowardice yet, according to the circumstances, madly daring, cringing before every superiority, cruel and vengeful toward the weak, treacherous besides, and hot‑tempered, quarrelsome, vain and boastful beyond measure; besides this inclined to idleness, gluttony and every kind of sensual indulgence. Much cleverness, spirit and ability, however, are ascribed to them; above all, however, directed toward, by cunning craftiness, outwitting and injuring all those who are not of their blood, and whom they pursue with inherited hatred to deadly effect. Musical talent in particular is not uncommon among them; a certain skill too in the few trades they practise, for example iron‑smithing; but even greater deceitfulness in wheeling and dealing in horses and in every form of theft.

Thus these tribes, who on their arrival called themselves by an equally Egyptian word, Roma --- in their tongue "house‑fathers" --- were distinguished from all other peoples by the peculiar, fixed and gleaming light of their eyes; and so they have remained unchanged to this hour during the four centuries since their immigration. Their ephemeral existence, decided in the bare instant and drifting along carelessly with it, never allowed a serious religious idea to arise in them; without faith, without rites and without tradition they everywhere conformed to the religion of the country in which they lived, without further incurring the trouble of observing its practices. The same is true of their conjuring art. When, on their arrival, they wandered through Europe and were still received hospitably --- in and about the barns and sheds, in the neighbourhood of combustible materials they frequently kindled fires, and nothing burned there but the material placed into it --- they ascribed this to the peculiar natural power of the "fire‑root," which grows in Little Egypt on a high mountain, and of which they yearly obtained a large quantity from there. That was one of the elements of this art which they had brought from the Orient; others they picked up on the roads along which they travelled; and just as their language in this way adopted many foreign roots, so these magical roots were gathered into the stock of their knowledge and skill.

When, on these flights and journeys of theirs, the lodestone (magnet ironstone) came before them, their childish imagination saw in it a symbol of their thievish instinct, of sexual attraction, and of the faculty for smelling out hidden treasures; and it so took possession of them that they ascribed to it --- which they call Bar‑Lachi --- all miraculous powers, and believed of one who possessed such a talisman that he had nothing to fear from steel and lead, water and fire; that death had no power over him, that it made him invisible to his pursuers, and that it was excellently suited for love‑potions. They likewise ascribed very similar properties to the Gospels, when Berrow spread a translation of them into their language among them, which they at once carried with them on their thieving expeditions as a protecting charm. "All that our people truly believe they have learned from you," an old gypsy said to Grellmann; and indeed the charms they have to staunch blood, and those which they use every morning to make themselves secure, are not in their own tongue but in the German language. In like manner the acquaintance with the evil eye came to them on the road, in which they place great trust. That misfortune dwells in a house where an unbaptized child is found, but that good fortune attaches to every day that begins with passing through the parish church --- such opinions already prove by their very content a Christian origin. \[Page 55\]

Only their palm-reading from the hand, which is bound up with the piercing eye of their women, but otherwise rests on no deeper foundation in their nature, seems to be their own work. La Baht is the name of this art, which has made them famous throughout the world, and which, in the hands of girls, reads the future lover, in those of women the children, and in those of the older the impending rich inheritances. Hokkano Baro, however, the great Psiff, is said by the power of the spell to compel the earth-spirits to give up long-buried treasures; that magnet, fashioned against a piece of steel forged from the hook of the high court (the gallows), likewise cooperates; and thus this Cuenta or art appears so refined that, in the words of one of the initiated, even the Beugui Lango, the lame devil or Asmodeus, would not know what to add.

From what has been set forth here one can easily judge what is to be thought of the view of those who hold the whole witchcraft business to be a work of the fraudulent Cuenta of this people. If one of the initiated of the covenant leads the neophyte into the dark wood under the oak, and brings her a handsome demon; but he refuses the ugly woman because the procuress has pledged to bring him a young and beautiful one; if other accounts speak of riders who, clad in black and on black steeds, meet the women, beg for their favor, and, after they have willingly renounced all the saints, then pay them with a coin that afterward turns into shards;---if we read such things frequently in the protocols, then all this certainly sounds very human, in its generic character, but in manner gypsy-like. \[Page 56\]

The people's propensity for cunning fraud, which manifests itself especially in the arts of horse-cheating; their inclination to lust --- these things show through everywhere in such occurrences. Indeed nothing can resemble the Sabbath more than the spectacle presented by a horde of gypsies when they encamp by night in the forest gloom around their fires, and, the flames contending with the torn tree-shadows, they cast a singular illumination over the scene; when men and women there spread out their plunder, dance their dances, and gorge themselves on the fallen cattle, while their chiefs maintain a sort of etiquette. The effect must have been particularly significant in earlier times, when the nature of the people was still unknown, and rural women of the neighborhood were brought into this circle and, by prestidigitation they had seen on their travels, were made serviceable to the purposes of the craft. It cannot be denied that such things may often have happened; but to suppose that in the countless cases where witchcraft showed itself there were always gypsies present to set the machinery in motion would be a foolish assumption, and would never accord with the unstable, fugitive spirit of this people. Among the manifold causes that produced this historical phenomenon, this cause has therefore probably also occasionally played a part; by no means, however, in any way, not even remotely, an exclusive effect.

Very unlike the Jews, their traveling companions over the earth, the gypsies' unsettled mind never seriously delved into the abysses of the magical arts; only what was serviceable to them on their travels have they known how cleverly to grasp and, according to their purposes, to make use of. The outward trappings of the whole discipline, its showman-like aspect, they accordingly appropriated; and whereas what the Jews contributed toward the whole direction was mostly calculated for the higher ranks, they on their part played to the lower orders, the rural folk in particular.

The outward appearances of the Sabbath may therefore well have been taken from them: the light-effects of their encampments in forest solitude; the unboundness and the glaring contrasts that arise between wild nature and acquaintance with the polishes of modern life; the licentiousness that their way of life brings with it: all of this may so often have impressed itself on the actuality of the imagination that it at last recurred again in the visions of the Sabbath. The suspicion of child‑stealing soon arose against them, to which another, also cannibalistic appetite was soon added; no wonder, then, that this suspicion fastened also on the uncleanliness of their kitchens, and that the eating of children on the Sabbath now ran rife. They dance the same lascivious dance in which the Egyptian women likewise excel, and which, according to Swinburne, is called Maquendoy in Spain; it is, as we are taught by explicit testimony, a prototype of the Sabbath dances.

Amulets and magical roots, too, have already played their part in the whole mischief. Their women cook love‑potions from the root of the good baron (la raiz del buen Baron); their men have thrown the Drau, a powder or the like, into the herds so that the cattle fall ill, and afterwards, when called, they may heal them again, or so that the fallen beasts may become their prey. k) When their women make people ill with the evil eye (querelar nasula); when the Moors in Africa, from the Dar‑Buschi‑Fal belief, think they know how to transform a white man into a negro; when they themselves generally boast of the art of witchcraft --- it remains uncertain whether, in these matters, they comported themselves as teachers or as apprentices; probably they were both within their circle, and thus contributed their share to the further spread of this practice.

### Chapter 2. Natural Disposition for Witchcraft and Sorcery

\[Page 57\]

The human being is born into history; each individual contributes to shaping it in their own part, but is, in turn, shaped by it. Witchcraft is thus also a historical product, and we have, in the preceding, considered and explained the historical influences that contributed to its emergence. But the indirect historical influence presupposes a direct effect; nothing can exist in history that was not previously or simultaneously present in the individuals, who only receive from it what they have previously invested in it. The second moment, on which all sorcery is based, is thus this autonomous quality, which conditions all historical phenomena through the individual. The self of the personality is twofold, composed of body and soul. The consideration of this moment will have two aspects: insofar as it takes its starting point from the physical and its inherent bound life, and then is directed to transition to the free-spirited. The present section shall therefore serve the investigation of the physical disposition and the temporal and spatial conditions associated with it; the following section, however, shall take as its task the consideration of the spiritual and what is connected with it.

#### A. The Obsession with Magic and Sorcery

When the exodus into history first began, the earth, with all its earthly directions and tendencies, was assigned as stage and racecourse to those who were journeying forth; but the demonic world had its provident care concealed at the very moment when the higher world of spirits withdrew from the fallen: both were to draw near to the wanderers in their continued influence only under the covering of earthly conditions and of powers limited by the earthly; and help or temptation, so that the scales should not be too unequal, were to come to them only in the binding and guise of the earthly medium. \[Page 58\]

This is the ordinary course of the world; the abysses over which man walks are closed and sealed in the bosom of the deep; upward the bound gaze may well reach into the spaces of the stars, but not beyond these into the spirit-depths. Thus, being dependent on that which is like himself, he must above all see to it that he does not fall through his own fault; the assaults from below will then be powerless against the upright man, because the higher protection binds them back from him. But if we see that individuals or whole masses turn aside from the path and knock at the closed gate in order to seek help from the monstrous shadows of the abyss, then something in them must have become disturbed and displaced from the ordinary order of things; a darkly falling shade must have dimmed and clouded the cheerfulness of life in them; so that between the darknesses of those nocturnal realms and their own inner ones a certain sympathy exists, and in it powers awaken which stand in a certain rapport with those of the abyss. If this overshadowing first occurs in the bodily, it will, having become habitual, form a morbid disposition that turns away from the ordinary toward the unusual; an idiosyncrasy that takes pleasure in bitterness, a delight in what is not pleasurable, and ultimately even a liking for evil. This disposition, however, will take root as a disease in life and in its organs; and preferably in the central organ of that life, in the ganglionic system, and in it slowly develop into a craving of its own.

When, in the first of these mystical books, we spoke of the organic inner structure of the body and of the currents that connect all these subdivisions among themselves, we also treated of the articulation of this ganglionic system, and it there divided itself for us into a threefold group of organs. The first, its head part, is connected to the distributions of the sympathetic system which, issuing from its upper cervical nodes, run along the carotids and vertebrals, join with them in the vascular circle, and from there, as the peculiar center of a distinct and yet in the general circulation opening system, lay its vessels through the whole brain. Its second or trunk part is formed by the 24--30 ganglia connected by their commissures, which run down along the vertebral column as a second sympathetic spinal cord, and with their nerve outgoings supply the vessels of the whole torso. Its third division finally presses together into the visceral part, the brain of the lower belly, and the so‑called semilunar ganglia gather together. Around it are arranged: stomach, liver, spleen, pancreas, kidneys, testicles and the intestinal canal downward; lungs and thymus with the pharynx and windpipe. Through the diaphragm this lower brain sends its capillary vessels to all the organs, and with a peripheral, branched ganglion it serves the fecal excretions; while the two encircling \[ganglia\] supply the respective accompanying secretory parts.

As these viscera are therefore divided into twelve organs, so the corresponding brain will likewise divide into twelve ganglia which, connected among themselves by commissures, form a cooperating mass; so much so that each for itself, and yet all together, supplies each of the named organs with its nerve outflow. The highest organization of the system in the head is thus formed circularly and crown‑like in its central ground; the lowest in the depths of the viscera, from the plurality of separate centers, plastically united into a compact central mass; while the connecting middle one, the subordinate central ganglia from above downward, binds them together into a descending line and into a strand. Now in life there is nowhere dead rest and rigid torpor; everywhere there is current and motion: and everywhere an overwhelming flow must, in a compelling way, hold the individual within its bounds. Accordingly, in the whole system such a flowing current will circulate without interruption; and this will appear divided according to a threefold modality. In the head the current will, in its innermost ground, close upon itself in a circle; as most currents in the brain-system indeed proceed in a ring. The current within the viscera will, to and from a contracted centre, take place massively along three mutually perpendicular axes. The third, finally, will run straight down along the spinal column, descending from the first to the second and from the second again rising to the first; thus alternately lowering and raising itself, sinking the upper into the lower, and, in turn, raising the lower toward the upper. All three then unite in one and the same great current, which corresponds to the circulation of the blood down in the depths.

Each ganglion in this great circle then completes its subordinate circle, in which it, from its centre, governs its peripheral expansion through its nerves. All such subordinate vortices of separate activities that thus form are again encompassed by the three larger vortices --- the wreath-like, the plastically operative one about the formative axes, and the penetrating, up-and-down oscillating one --- and in health all are kept enclosed within their boundaries; the equalization of the threefoldly different movements of life itself, however, is entrusted to the implanted conservative power of life itself. Just as the heart is charged with the regulation of the entire circular movement of the blood, so the heart-ganglion also seems placed as guardian over the equilibration of these different movements.

This ganglion is therefore placed in the very midst of them all, where they appear drawn closest together at their innermost starting-points; near at half the distance of the vascular wreath from the celiac ganglion, and three nervous radiations bind it to both and at the same time to the third intermediate member which links them. The whole system is again submitted to the higher systems, and if affected in its members these will in turn draw those affections into their own, and its currents will play over into theirs. Thus there will be an intercourse between the visceral ganglia and that part of the spinal cord and brain which serves life; another between the middle sympathetic system and that which, of the two, operates in voluntary movement; and the third system, finally, with the head insofar as it performs intellectual functions.

From such diversely held streams, poured forth through the manifold articulations of the life-system, the great movement of life is assembled; and everything that happens and occurs within its circle appears in its origin to be determined thereby. The alternation between sleep and waking appears especially brought about by the perpendicular ascending-and-descending; and when, in the first state, the lowest circling has become dominant --- when life has entwined everything into its natural unity --- then this closedness becomes a point of passage into another state. When we spoke of somnambulism, we distinguished two kinds of waking of the system: in one it reaches over into the external physical world and perceives and acts and performs its functions; while in the other it opens itself to the world of spirits. \[Page 59\]

From the first waking-world into the second, and from this back into the former, the transition, however, passes through the state of sleep; and we have furthermore explained how the gradual inward awakening of the system --- advancing by the threefold order of sympathetic movement --- marks the steps and degrees of magnetic elevation up to clairvoyance. But the matter can also be considered from another point of view. Although the whole movement of life appears of earthly character, the part of this movement in the circumference of the skull nevertheless expresses the solar element in it; the other, in the region of the lower entrails, the lunar; and only in the middle sphere does the properly kernel-like earthly show itself distinctly. If now the slight overturning of the life-movement in general --- from outward waking into the inner, in general toward the side of nature --- constitutes the predisposition to magnetically somnambulistic states, then this lightness, when especially attached to the upper mode of motion in the head, will establish a predisposition to a sunlike life-magnetism; whereas, when lying upon the lower mode in the entrails, it will evoke a moonlike magnetic disposition.

The Sun is the lamp of day, radiating light and warmth, the two greatest goods of nature; the prophets of the old service of nature, whose inner being had opened itself to the power of the luminary, recognized themselves as children of Helios, descendants of the radiant Apollo; and, mindful of their inspiration by him, they described the path that his prophetic ray takes from the pit of the heart to the oracle-speaking mouth. The Moon, however, is the lamp of night; what she conceals in her womb she partly unveils with her borrowed light; coolness and moisture are the media in which her effect most gladly reveals itself. Those, then, in whom the lowest vital movement has the impulse to sink into the nocturnal seclusion of this luminary, called themselves children of the Moon, proclaiming prophecy under its influences. The mild Sun, however, becomes an angry one when, by excess, she makes her gifts destructive; and the beneficent Artemis becomes grim when her blessings are in the same way transformed into poisons. The Helios-seers of the first order are thus likewise changed, and the benefactors become corrupters; while those inspired by Artemis, now thrown into frenzy by the Angry One, go about as the helpers of Hecate in nocturnal gloom.

As the mild Sun, now bountiful in giving, is, in her anger, kindling, enflaming and consuming --- her nature therefore pointing to the masculine, as in the choleric temperament --- the Moon, on the other hand, in her good mood is receiving, fostering, preserving, and in gentle light begetting; but in her dark aspect she unleashes every nocturnal horror, stiffening and binding all life. In this effect of hers she thus behaves as feminine, as in the melancholic temperament alternatingly; so will it also be with the double chorus of those inspired by them. The sun-mania, in which the Helios-servants shine forth radiantly and again burn scorching in grim fire, will predominantly be the affair of the male sex, and have the choleric temperament as its organic basis. The moon-mania, which, like the Moon in her phases, alternates between light and shadow and thus between sorrow and joy, will be found chiefly in the female sex and will attach itself to the alternation of the melancholic temperament. \[Page 60\]

What here in the circle of nature acts as a closed system is introduced into the cacodæmonic or agathodæmonic circles; when, as there, the system, instead of manifesting in outwardness, awakens into the inwardness of physical nature, it opens into the inwardness of the spirit-world; and now, in place of the forces of nature, evil or good spirits set themselves into rapport with it. The transition, initiated by various intermediate stages, already appears clearly in magnetic somnambulism; when the lower life, ceasing to play with the forces of nature, is lost in the deeper circles of the spirit-kingdom that are akin to it; and now the double nature of all human drives, divided into good and evil, successively or simultaneously---attracting the homogeneous in these circles and repelling the heterogeneous---falls into states which outwardly bear all the signs of a higher ecstasy and then also those of an incipient possession. The same was already the case in ancient times with their nature-enthusiasts; and while, in the better mysteries that guided and initiated them, a higher, ennobling ray shone in, the worse ones in their abominations assumed altogether a demonic character. The demonic, then, breaking into these natural states, finds in them a predisposition that favors such an intrusion; just as the better, when promoted by them, finds its access facilitated.

Now sun and moon, and thus likewise sun-sickness and moon-sickness, do not, in life, behave at all exclusively as salutary and harmful in the physical, and still less as good and evil in the ethical; yet they do present themselves to the intruding intelligences in different ways. The moonlike, in space bound twice---by the earth and by the sun---has therefore the condition of being bound as one of its essential characteristics, and can accordingly be more readily mastered by the objectively evil as well as by the good. The sunlike in the regions, however, being predominantly binding and only subordinately bound, adapts itself less readily to being bound---just as in double stars it only, as an exception, associates with a similar body; whereas the planetary cannot exist without such an ordering. Moon-sickness is thus more easily mastered because it is already in itself divided into phases of light and darkness, and so more readily divides itself into those of good and evil and, at last, becomes aligned with one or the other; whereas sun-sickness, not so easily dissolved, offers greater resistance to the power of the objective.

The lower visceral life, to which the one (i.e. moon-sickness) is tied, is thereby---like the lower, night-covered nature---by it brought nearer to the spiritual under-realm; while the system to which the other (i.e. sun-sickness) adheres, being more remote from these regions, approaches the higher physical; so that even the spiritual can, at least with less strong separation, more readily break through. For the same reason that in the physical domain lunar floods and ebbs are greater than the analogous solar movements of the element, there were in ancient times more enthusiastic moon-women than sun-seers; more Thessalian enchantresses than male sorcerers; and in later times more female seers than male---and therefore also more witches and sorceresses than sorcerers. The reason lies, plainly expressed, in the natural relations of the sexes, in the melancholic and choleric temperaments in which their difference stands out most sharply; and thus it comes about that this difference of physical constitution, according to sexual difference, has likewise been impressed upon the realm of witchcraft: the witch-nature being especially attached to moon-sickness, where possession found a fertile soil; while the natural substratum of the male magical nature preferred to take root in a sun-sick disposition. Notwithstanding the full moral freedom of the sexes --- to which therefore also the entirely equal accountability attaches --- nature nevertheless disposes, once choice has been made, the execution more toward the form of one or the other side, and the modality is then again conditioned by the course taken.

#### B. Sidereal Influences on the Natural Constitution and Epidemic Outbreaks

\[Page 61\]

In the nature-belief of antiquity it was especially the sun and the moon that stirred the drives in the realm of instincts tending inward and upward; they were the queen about whom the swarming flights of bees assembled. The sun, the great light of day, was also, in the outward vivification, the root of the works which, with prudence, are accomplished by day; just as the small light of night exerted its influence upon the plastic works of the nocturnal world. Clearly delineated natural beings, and acting as such in these reflective states, they were, on the other hand, mystical powers in the unconscious, naturally ecstatic states, awakening and stimulating those states by their effect; and since above all women most frequently and most easily fell into these states, it was, beside Apollo Helios, especially Luna --- the one most closely turned toward them --- who exercised this mystical power above all, and gathered them about her in the stirrings and movements which she produced in them. She was indeed the Lilith of the Hebrews, the lady of darkness; the Artemis of the deeper Orient, the Alilat of the Arabs and the Melitta of the Assyrians; the two-horned Psḫat or Bubastis of the Egyptians; Diana, formerly Jana, the mother of hidden life, and as Trivia the goddess of the ways who leads her retinue over forests and mountains, thus the Norse Holda riding over the heights; the Lydian girls danced and rode for her on Tmolus, and the Spartan maidens performed the Carga before her. She was, over the whole earth, the mistress of female life; she ruled all the waters of life that flood within it; and in her was represented the great heart of nature, through which she pulsed all things, and from which she then first poured herself into the individual human heart, and thereby ever kept it in general union with the centre of nature. Beside her was then that Helios, the source of all the higher nerve-spirits, so to speak the sensorium and common nervous centre of the all; leaning more toward men, among whom especially the kings were regarded as sun-born. They were mystically illumined from above, so that they might again radiate what they had received, as human Heliads, upon their subjects, and in higher states move the nervous systems just as that All-Mother moved the vascular tissue, in manifold stirrings.

In that nature-belief, however, the contradiction of good and evil also referred back to the hidden grounds of the all, and communicated itself to all beings that arose from its depths. Both were branches of the same life inherent in the unity of nature, which in them was only split in different directions, and could, possibly, also restore itself again out of them. Thus wrath lay alongside mildness, dread was joined with friendliness, life with death, suspicion easily allied itself with goodness, and cheerfulness was united with horror. The same Helios who awakens the whole earth to activity with his rain of light also sends forth the poisoned arrows of pestilences. The goddess of the night, the leader of her retinue over the heights of heaven and through the depths of the earth --- as the moon is always divided between light and shadow, so she separates herself into the mildly shining Berecynthia, who traverses the Maenalon, and the dreadful Hecate of the dark nether realm, attired with all its terrors; as also Ceres, giver of the harvest, the earth-mother opened to the light, who bore the subterranean daughter and queen of the shadow-realm, Persephone. \[Page 62\]

This division continued also among the daughters of the earth, magnetically linked with them in choirs; and just as day and night, summer and winter, sowing and harvest ever alternate upon this many‑cleft earth, so too is the life of the earthly drawn into these alternations; and to the ritual choirs of the Destroyer there always succeed those of the Builder, and the round dance thus ever passes its turn down into the depth, and rises again to the height. The mysteries which the sex therefore celebrated for life and the fruitful nature‑deities were thus split about midnight, according to day‑night and night‑day; for that which is to germinate must first perish and be buried that it may attain to resurrection. The secrets of destruction in all generation, spiritual as well as physical, therefore formed the subject of one half‑chorus; generation amid all destruction the subject of the other, and both made themselves known in everything in which, in the realm of appearance, the two directions were revealed.

Thus the women's choirs which, in the Romance South even in the first Christian times, were gathered about the Night‑Queen, their mistress, plainly reflect the nature of their leader. They held, under her presidency, these their assemblies in nocturnal leisure, to consult about the fates of the night‑realms; the mistress's ministerials were chosen there, offences were punished, and fostering deeds were richly rewarded there; at the banquet the mistress then shone mild and gracious through the nightly coolness. When the following, led by her, set out at the turn of the year in the great procession through the dwellings of men, then it was the play of Diana and of the good mothers that took place; it is the good and wise women who move in it; indeed they are also called the good things. Men open to them kitchen and cellar, and they taste of the offerings thus presented without diminishing them; and in return give yearly fertility and blessing and prosperity. For Abundantia or Satia is the name of their mistress, and where she goes the fullness of good things springs up at her footsteps. But if she turns to the other side, she becomes the Wrathful, the Fury‑burned, the Perfidious and the Harm‑doing: then her retinue likewise turns; the dark nocturnal side appears, the earth is smitten with barrenness, the house with misfortune, the children wither and life fades.

At the moon‑table, which stands beside the sun‑table of the ancient Ethiopians, the gentle goddess had given drink and food to the needy; now the hating one pours forth the poison of Colchian‑Thessalian witchcraft. Now the monsters of the old night spread their dark brew over the timorous. Even beauty is transformed into a ravening beast. Lamia, the daughter of the ancient Bel and of Libya, in the land of terror Africa, wins the favour of the Olympian, and he brings her to Italy, where the city named after her is built. Juno kills, in jealous anger, all her offspring, and she in envy and rage again slays all the births of other women. Now the Lamiae, the dread of children, go forth; they who may transform themselves into any thing --- into birds, dogs, mice, even flies --- inclined alike to sensual pleasure and to cruelty, and kindling beforehand into heat those who would consume them. The daughter of that first Lamia, however, was the African clairvoyant Sibyl, the old Saga, from sagire, to see sharply; the ancestress of all those who, probing the mysteries of the nether realm, bring them to light; while the striges of the Latins circle about the cradles, and suck the blood of sleepers, and rend their entrails. \[Page 63\]

To these terrors, which have been raised up from the south, others move against them whose origin is in the north. In the realm of Holda the same division holds, as we have already seen; if she is kindly disposed, then her host likewise brightens. They help the Mistress spin the threads out of which, over meadow and field, vegetation weaves itself; they help her preserve the children in the deep well and bring them forth into the daylight; they fill the jugs with mead and wine. But if the purpose of the goddess is perverted into malignity, then the fair ones about her are likewise transformed into monsters; the thread on the distaff becomes confused and tangled, the fruit is smitten with drought and blight; storms rage through the once-still air; the midwives become child‑stealers and practice child‑devouring; hunger and want take the place of riches.

Now Christianity came into the world and put into general force a previously prepared doctrine. The idea of the Godhead was held to be the absolutely Good, altogether incompatible with any kind of Evil and incapable of being stained by any touch. In connection with sin, however, the origins of this Evil were laid in the will of the rational creature; which will, according as it kept itself freely in the likeness of God or in apostasy received the evil into itself, was divided in two directions --- taking between them the irrational, and therefore also in its irresponsibility only by communication capable of evil but not of sinning, the physical nature, --- and assigning to it above and below the mixed human nature capable both of apostasy and of union. Before this doctrine the powers that had earlier assumed the masks of natural forms, as the Egyptian gods assumed animal shapes, were compelled to unmask. If they had previously passed themselves off as gods whose essence manifested itself in them in good and evil, they must now appear as demonic powers that, by fraudulent usurpation of the essence of the Godhead, had practised robbery against God. With them fell now all their worshipers and confessors whom they had found among men, and in whose associations their falsely divine natures had incarnated themselves in good and evil, down to the same level of reprobation; it was the Evil, therefore, which had thus taken shape in grievous deceit, in the uprising of the creature against its Creator; and therefore it had to fall into dissolution to make room for a better formation.

##### Christianity Against Nature Beliefs

\[Page 64\]

A strikingly significant hint of how this relationship was thought of from the beginning of the modern period into the later Middle Ages is found in the life of St. Taurinus, the bishop of Corbeil, in the earliest period of Christianity there. He bound in the year of Diana the demon who there played the Night‑Goddess. The spirit, because he rendered willing obedience to the saint, is not sent to Hell: rather his punishment is allotted to him in the very region where he had previously ruled. Henceforth he must appear in manifold forms without doing harm to anyone; by the people about there called Gobelin from that time until now (the Life was written in the middle of the twelfth century). The folk had had manifold experiences of the doings of the so‑called kobolds; the ambiguous, good‑naturedly malicious mixed nature, the helpfulness of these beings combined with teasing wilfulness and evil craft in these ghostlike natures, had awakened their reflection; and the question about their origin and their relations had been repeatedly raised. The introduction of Christianity at last set this inquiry on a track: the holy man had driven away the old mistress of the night, and she had yielded to his exorcism without resistance. The natural power, referred back to the spirit dwelling in it, now becomes a ghostly apparition which, where it formerly exercised dominion, has now sunk to servitude; and for a small dwarf's wage helps to carry on the household affairs.

Now the canon attributed to the Synod of Ancyra also speaks of the criminal women who, having turned back to Satan and, through the deceits of the demons, been led into delusion, rode in troops on beasts, in the retinue of the heathen Diana, through the stillness of the night, across wide distances, on certain nights called to the service of the mistress. For there are now demons transformed into women who formerly rode with the once well-named mistress, but who now take the likenesses (larvae) of neighboring women who meanwhile sleep in their beds, as St. Germanus made proof. The company of night-women is now, even where it brings good, a confederacy of witch-women, which, abusing good for evil ends, robs the Creator of his honor and turns it over to the fallen spirits. Holda, in whose service they rode northward, has become a she-fiend; a name with which the language likewise names the Devil. Her company have shared in the same transformation; the white Alrune has become a treacherous enchantress, the old Asine a Here. They now go through the houses, light funeral candles, and know only how to steal children who, at their banquets, at the command of the mistress, are either torn apart and eaten, or---out of a sudden fit of pity---are carried back to the cradle; they torment the sleepers in every way and practise every sort of evil. \[Page 65\]

Through the Greek lands the Gellones now pass, they who enter through closed doors and suddenly destroy the children;---as such a one, in Byzantium, according to the account of his mother, often carried the newborn Emperor Maurice out of the room, but was unable to harm him. In Italy the old Matres and Matronae have become Mascae; the old fairies or fates, for whom the Neapolitan women set out the tables so that they kept the children and kept the house pure, are deceiving phantoms; and these gather in bands around the dethroned mistress, called Queen Mab in Ireland, in Brescia also la Donna del Ginco, in the so‑called Tregendas, to the lordly place. For, says Bartholomew de Spina, from the confessions of those who ride we know officially that they, before anointing themselves at night, first wait for the noise of the mistress as she passes with the great throng of those rejoicing; only then do they anoint themselves in order to join the throng, until they all arrive at the appointed place. This place is above all for Italy the walnut‑tree of Benevento, there where the old Lombard tree with the golden dragon stood; in France la croce d'el Pastiecio, in other countries other \[places\]: everywhere, however, they are those spots where the old pagan mysteries of the gods were celebrated at the feet of their images and in the surrounding groves.

The Herodias who takes the place of Diana, and who under the name Radodese long was the terror of children in the Venetian region, and who in Ferrara also bears the name of the Sibyl, thence conducts her following beyond the sea to the Jordan. This happens twice in every week, and all their striving is directed to the single aim that they might but once touch the waters of the stream; to her, who already is mistress of one third of the earth's circle, it would---if she succeeded in that---fall to possess the whole world. But the river draws back before her, and would sooner dry up than permit the touch. All this is perfectly fabulous, and only wishes to assert: that if the unholy could force itself upon the holy by violence, nothing thereafter would be able to resist its power. But that can never succeed, and so the mistress each time abandons the useless, yet ever-repeated task; and all the more becomes enraged, so that everyone must flee from her wrath.

Thus, at the turning-point of history the whole doctrine was reversed; humanity was to be torn from the bonds of nature, and to enter a higher, serene kingdom of God. But these bonds held fast; for in that part of it which belonged to the earth the higher, guiding consciousness had grown dim, taken root, and had grown up with it. With all instincts and dark drives the ancient belief in Nature was confirmed; the sun acted in it, the moisture of the earth greened in it. When the seed sprang up in the fields, and the groves about the temples put forth leaves, then the enthusiasm for Nature rose also inwardly; and the night-veiled realm within man germinated, greened, blossomed with the kingdoms of nature. \[Page 66\]

Most closely bound in this union with Nature was the tilling population; and in their midst, again most strongly, the sex of women, in whom the root of human growth sinks into the earth. One knows with what tenacious attachment the old rural folk clung to their belief in Nature; so that, in opposition to the new doctrine, it was branded with the name of paganism. Even in Italy, the centre of Christianity, it was able only slowly and gradually to take root again in that portion of the population. In the fourth century the more mobile cities had for the most part turned away from it; the countryside, however, especially in the mountains, had remained entirely heathen; and Bishops Gaudentius of Brescia and St. Massinus of Turin therefore bitterly reproach the possessors that they allowed their castalds to persist in the old heathenism. At Monte Cassino Benedict still found an Apollo temple where the people offered sacrifices in the very solitude of the forest. That old Lombard tree near Benevento stood down to the end of the seventh century, an object of veneration, untouched; until at length the holy Barbatus, bishop of the place, one day took an axe and hurried out with an escort to the sacrilege that called itself arbor sanctiva, and having felled it at the root he heaped earth about it, so that no one might find even a trace of it.

By no means, however, was the matter thereby settled in those relatively early centuries. Even at the end of the fifteenth \[century\] the inhabitants of Arezzo still highly honoured a spring over which, from the times of paganism, an altar had been erected in the darkness of the wood; whither the people, according to old custom, went on pilgrimage as to an oracle of Apollo, to obtain answers to secret questions or healing of the ills that afflicted them. Here, too, it was the holy Bernardino who finally destroyed the ancient belief in Nature. One day he preached on the subject, then exhorted his hearers to accompany him in the work of destruction; and at once, provided with axes and other tools and accompanied by the people, he went to the spring, stopped its flowing source with stones, and overturned the altar, so that thenceforth the memory of the thing perished.

How much the councils and synods in France, Spain, and Germany had to contend with similar matters is known from their acts and decrees. Especially in the latter country it was again the mountain people, and the tilling tribes of the Saxon lowlands, who most stubbornly held to the old ways; and this returned with force as soon as even a cloud of heresy passed over the sunlit mirror of the new doctrine.

Thus in Frisia, in the time of Emperor Lothar, the teaching of Arins and Sabellius had spread; immediately the old natural faith of the Æsir-doctrine reappeared. The country became full of cries: on that hill the old elves' dwelling had opened; they, whom one also used to call witte wywen, the wise women, in the vernacular. Their house was an underground cave; from it one heard first a dull murmur, then an immense lamenting and weeping of people; then again children's cries, and alternately music and notes of joy. Night-wanderers and cattle-herds were carried off, mothers with their infants were seized; and therefore the women in childbirth and their children were kept under strict guard, lest they should thus fall into the hands of the elves. Saint Odulphus had to instruct the people against these deceptions; and they vanished only when the people had been newly confirmed in the faith. \[Page 67\]

From then on we see, at every any significant change of religion in the countries, similar appearances break out, as it were epidemically. Thus everywhere the old inclinations had remained behind, but their objects had been taken away; a great upheaval had cast down into the abyss those things which had formerly been objects of the people's veneration; no wonder that it was difficult and slow to accommodate itself to the change. Indeed other affections presented themselves, in part at the same localities; but even where people gradually resolved to accept them, the old recollection still long continued to work; and the new comers still had to contend late with the remnants of earlier habit, and to share the worship with the expelled. But when, in the course of time, they gradually carried off the victory, and the godless worship of the powers of nature was really regarded as robbery against God and as demonic worship, the dim transitional period, which had lasted many centuries, had prepared the way: that which otherwise in itself contradicts human nature was led over to the veneration and service of the evil principle as such; and when Manichaeism set itself up as the representative of this principle, it everywhere found in men's minds a basis to which its otherwise paradoxical teaching could attach itself. \[Page 68\]

The memories and echoes of the old paganism thus cooperated with the errors of later times; the darknesses of the ages that had sunk backward into a glooming past; the darkness of nights, of forests; the spiritual obscurities and the moral cloudings: they all flowed together into one abyss. In its midst the idea of a Satan's realm on earth now developed, which was to have its right, its law and constitution, form and aspect alongside the kingdom of God; in it the old, inexpiable claims of matter against ensoulment, of the flesh against the spirit, were to be represented; and the old, irreconcilable struggle of both powers was to be continued until the end. Into this strife there entered, however, the material counterpart, with the whole real weight of its palpable corporeality. What human nature enclosed in itself of such dark, bodily forces and appetites, in opposition to the rule which the spirit at all times --- and in the new doctrine more than ever --- had assumed, found itself disposed to take part where, as it seemed, the contest was for its emancipation. This had to happen most decisively again among the lower classes of the people, where all these vigorous, fleshly instincts had been preserved most solidly; and where the higher light, on the whole, had still made itself a way most sparingly.

In this domain, then, it will again be chiefly the farmers, shepherds, and seafarers --- those who in their daily intercourse with physical nature also strengthen and exercise most the forces most closely akin to it --- who will be preferentially inclined to that side. Again those whose seats lie in the high and middle mountains, those whose dwellings are in marshes and swamps, remote from the great currents of intellectual intercourse; those who, settled in the spirit of the seashore, by the barrenness of the land were driven over to the moving wave; --- once they had been won to that cause, these would again be its most natural and stalwart allies in the service of the Nether-Realm. Finally, men and women again, according to their different temperaments, will be disposed to that side: women, by virtue of their constitution more closely related to Nature, and the closer union in which their powers stand; by the greater mobility of their whole being for external impressions; by the changeable inconstancy of their will comparable to the element of water; by the forward play of the powers of imagination, and by a tougher, more enduring passion --- will incline most to this side. Thus even way of life, locality, and sex must operate together with historical memories to realize the idea of Evil as such in a large fellowship on earth, and to make it the guiding principle within them.

#### C. The Endemic Influence According to Earthly Localities

From what has been said it now becomes intelligible why witchcraft and sorcery, in their whole diffusion, are bound, just as they prefer certain times, likewise to particular localities. That they belong, according to time, to the periods of transition --- both of the natural faith and of the spiritual --- and in the latter from one form to another, has been made clear above. That spatially they attach with equal preference to those conditions where the natural still manifests the most persistence and most powerfully plays over into the higher life, will likewise be evident, even on only a superficial survey of the existing relations. History shows that in all places and in every situation where the old paganism was longest preserved; where, for the same reason, perhaps later the Manichaean heresy struck its deepest roots; --- there subsequently the greatest development of witchcraft and sorcery was attained. \[Page 69\]

The great mountain-parallel that runs from east to west through the old world will indicate to us the line of its progress. In the west, therefore, France and Italy will especially attract our attention. As to France, Alphonsus Spina already names in his Fortalitium, at the beginning of the fifteenth century, Gascony and the Dauphiné, "ubi nimium abundant tales perversae mulieres"; and Alphonsus Tostado about the same time adds the neighboring Spain: thus, from the Dauphiné through the whole of the Basque country, even into the Spanish mountains, witchcraft has spread to a great extent. It is therefore the inhabitants of the Pyrenees and the Alps who have done most in this direction; to which Lorraine must also be added, where Rémy found great material. The Basques, however, are already known as the most tenacious adherents of custom, habitual way of life, homeliness, old manners and former conviction; and in this sense they are the only ones among the present Southern Europeans --- although a small people --- who have preserved their old language unchanged; and their most ancient forefathers would be able to make themselves understood with them in it, and to find their way among their customs. \[Page 70\]

From the midst of that people of French allegiance, from the little district of Labourt, the charge of a generally spread witchcraft and sorcery was now in many ways brought against Henry IV; and in the year 1609 he appointed a commission consisting of President Espagnet, Councillor of State, and the councillor at the Parliament of Bordeaux, De Lancre, to carry out the inquiry on the spot and to bring the guilty to trial; subject to any oppositions and appeals that might be lodged. They remained four months in the country, and soon convinced themselves that the accusation was not groundless. The great number of the proofs filled them with dread, and the strangest facts came to their knowledge. Their arrival, moreover, had produced a panic terror throughout the whole country. Everyone fled by water and by land; pilgrimages to Montserrat and to St. Jacob were used as a pretext; Upper and Lower Navarre and all the Spanish frontier provinces filled with fugitives; and the Spanish inquisitors stationed themselves on the border to turn the runaways back. The investigation proceeded in the meantime, and its results De Lancre summarized in a book which he gave the title: Tableau de l'inconstance des mauvais anges et démons, où il est amplement traité des Sorciers et de la Sorcellerie. Paris, 1613. In the first book, Discourses II and III, he speaks of the character and circumstances of the country and people in the following manner.

\"The land of Labourt is an office composed of twenty-seven parishes, with a population of about 30,000 souls, without trade or industry. The inhabitants live along the sea, stretching inward into the mountains; and speak, like their neighbours, the peculiar Basque tongue. The country is therefore at once a mountain-land and a frontier-land of three kingdoms: France, Spain, and Navarre; the meeting-place of three languages, and likewise belonging to two dioceses, and likewise divided between land and sea. The sea, however, makes them rustic, coarse and ill-mannered; the spirit as well as the prosperity of those who give themselves to it is tied to rigging and to movable pennons, and thus movable like the wind; millet, which the mountains produce for them, and fish, which the sea provides, compose their food; the sky meanwhile is their covering, and the sails are their tablecloth. They are so accustomed to see the inconstant element in tumult and storm that they fear and dread nothing so much as its calm and its stillness, entrusting all their welfare to its waves, which rock them up and down day and night. Hence it comes that the nature of the sea imparts itself to their manners, their intercourse, their speech, and even to their faith; which likewise does not leave them even when they again set foot on land. They are then always as if striking in waves---hasty, choleric; at the slightest whim that passes through their heads they throw themselves upon you and set a dagger to your throat.

The land, moreover, would not deny them its produce, were it not that they have turned their inclination preferentially to the ocean and to the sea, that lawless, untamed element, the navigation of which is a veritable and plain despair. Now consequently their soil has become meagre, barren and poor to them; and they themselves are also sluggish and idle when they have returned from their voyages; and their idleness leads them, before they have grown old, to a beggarly state which presses heavily upon them again; because, as immediate neighbours of the Spaniards, they feel an extraordinary amount of their pride and presumption within themselves. They have moreover not even a secure harbour in their country, and must, when they arrive from Terre-Neuve, Canada, or the two Indies, put in at St. Sebastian or Fontarabie; where they are under Spanish authority, which makes them yet more dependent.\" \[Page 71\]

These privations kill in them the love of their fatherland, and their long absences on their sea-voyages moreover stifle their love for wife and child, who have been left behind alone with the old people, and make them indifferent and cold. Even if their wives wish for their return, on account of the small earnings they have made; yet it is only the winter season that brings them home; in which, since they pursue no trade at all, they consume what has been earned in the inns, without giving any of it to their families; whereupon in the spring they sail out again as poor as they were before, and frequently --- meeting with misfortune --- do not return. They do not even properly know their wives at all, because they live with them only half the year; and as to their children, the custom they have of taking wives on trial for several years before they actually marry them is also detrimental to their relationship with those women.

As for the women, they in turn live in a like, or even more distressing, condition with regard to the men, whose company they enjoy only half the time, and whom, divided by expectation, doubt, and uncertainty, they regard only half as their husbands. They are no support to them or to their families, and treat them only temporarily as their wives; whereby many, upon the husbands' return, are forced to let it happen that the mothers choose another father for their children. Just as the Indians of Hispaniola inhale the vapor of a certain herb called cohoba, which confuses their minds; and when they have taken it, slipping their hands between their knees and hanging down their heads, remain for a time in ecstasy; whereupon, rising, they tell wondrous tales of their false gods, which they call Cemis --- just as our people do when they come from the Sabbath --- so do these women behave with petun or nicotiana, which each plants in her garden, however small it may be; and whose vapor they use to clear their brains and to somewhat stave off hunger.

Now I do not know whether this vapor stupefies them as that plant stupefies the Indians; but I do know that it makes their breath and whole body so foul-smelling that no creature not accustomed to it can endure the stench. They, however, practise this fumigation four times a day, and thus, accustomed to this smell and to the sea-smell of the men, they dread no other. Formerly, as girls enjoying the freedom of the mountains, already reminded by the manner of their head-dress of the nudities of paganism, they have, in the close relations of the sexes, too often listened to temptation for those other demons to frighten them. Neither they nor the men, moreover, have been raised in the fear of God. Even their priests have in part given themselves to the service of Satan, and have even profaned their churches. For we have judicially established that the Sabbath has been kept in the church of the Holy Spirit on Mount Rhune, and in the church of Dourdar. \[Page 72\]
