Thus, instead of promoting the congregation and bringing it to a better path through churchly aid, they rather lead it astray; by repeating at night everything that they practise in the church by day in the service of evil. The women again take their part in this; for they have free access to the churches under the name of the Benedictines, who undertake the outward household, decorate the altar, keep the linen in order, and exercise similar duties. One such woman must already be in the church before daybreak, just as the last must be there in the evening to clear away the altars and extinguish the lights; which, in a land of such loose morals, can give occasion to many things that do not respect the sanctity of the place.

From all this is explained whence the great spread of witchcraft in this country comes. The men are light and agile, both in body and in mind; decisive and hasty in all their actions, ever with their foot in the air; inclined more to revenge and homicide than to theft --- for I have never seen one of them condemned as a thief at the parlement. Yet, since they are poor and needy, and too proud to go begging, they find themselves all too ready to yield to the devil's deceptions. The women, for their part, given over to idleness because they have little to keep them at home or to manage, and eaten up with deadly boredom, likewise readily surrender themselves to his promises; when he blinds their senses and holds out to them pleasures and marvels which would be their portion in his orgies and at his Sabbaths, and displays to them all his pomp and all his glory, so that they believe an earthly paradise will be their lot, into which only the most chosen and select will be admitted. Satan's greatest exertion is directed against the poor children, who, regarding the churches as true houses of God and the pastors as their protectors, fly into them as into asylums; these \[places\] are profaned, and the pastors themselves are found in part infected by the evil. Yet no other refuge remains to them, and one sees them sleeping in troops in the houses of God; and it seems to them that the devil has no power over them to tear them away from there and bring them into his accursed assemblies.

From that point the evil, spreading further westward, overspread the whole Spanish peninsula. About the same time that the French commission was at work in Labourd, striving by fire to cauterize out the cancer, the Inquisition in Spain did not remain idle and joined in the efforts. In November 1610 there took place an auto-da-fé at Logroño in Castile, which was solemnly held over those found guilty; a report of this act was printed at that very place, from which de Lancre gives a detailed account. Fifty-three persons were brought forward; twenty-one men and women went as penitents bareheaded, with a candle in the hand and a rope about the neck. The same number, with paper mitres on their heads as a sign that they had been expiated, followed them. Then the bones of five deceased persons, with their effigies, were carried, and six others closed the procession last, wearing the habit of Saint Benedict and the mitre on their heads, indicating that they had once before been released by the Inquisition. The five effigies with the bones, and the six who went last --- among whom Maria de Rocaya, distinguished above all as a mistress of witchcraft, stood out --- were handed over to the secular arm and burned in the fire. \[Page 73\]

Among the others were especially twelve sorcerers and sorceresses who had been tried; others were charged with different crimes. Of these, twenty-four were subjected to various corporal punishments; eighteen others, who acknowledged that they had associated with witches all their lives and begged for mercy with tears in their eyes because they wished to return to the faith, were received as penitent and actually reconciled. They were from Navarre and the neighboring Spanish towns, and in part connected with the refugees from the French Basque country. As in this instance, so has the Inquisition throughout Spain --- the land of the ancient Priscillianists --- acted. Another focal point for France falls in the Alps, namely in the Dauphiné and the neighboring districts.

"The Dauphiné," Michelet says in his survey of the French tribes, \"lies like a fortress under the lee of the Alps, and its inhabitants are called Francieur by the Provençals, by which they mean that with them begins a series of Gallic tribes different from themselves; a series which thence runs through the lowlands of the Bresse, over the ridges of the Franche-Comté, and through Lorraine as far as Belgium. A vigorous spirit of resistance and opposition marks these provinces, and a stock of severe, analytical minds has arisen from them. A lively and free simplicity, in the manner of all mountain-people, which appeals to everyone, characterizes these Dauphinois; their women, in turn, are likewise distinguished by a manly, vigorous spirit. Old age is highly honoured among them; for their dead a funeral feast is held each November, and everyone is presented with his share of the funeral food, made of eggs and flour. Each year the land sends forth not only swarms of masons, water-carriers, teamsters, chimney-sweepers into the neighbouring provinces, but also hordes of schoolmasters descend into the surrounding plain to offer their services in the lower elements of learning to those eager to be taught. \[Page 74\]

The inhabitants of the lowland appear less noble, given over to demagogy, and inclined to satire.\" While the sea-facing Provence, and still more the inward-closed Languedoc, in their Iberian blood more inclined to pure, crude Manichaeism, which broke out in the Albigenses and drew its demonic nature from that source: in that other tribal grouping rationalism will predominate, and the dark streams will flow more for that reason. But rationalism, in the spirit of that opposition, tears itself away from the tribe of original tradition; grounding doctrine on free understanding itself, and morality on arbitrariness of the will. Thus the boni homines of the Middle Ages descended with the bands of wanderers from those heights --- westward into the lowlands of the Rhône; and eastward the Waldenses poured into their valleys. Such teaching is of course averse to all spirit-beings, but only insofar as tradition is rooted in them; if, however, it lends a hand to the preservation of its own existence, it by no means casts them off.

While, therefore, the misunderstanding of personal freedom in that land of the Allobroges through the fourteenth century was driven on to Turlupinism in the societas paupertatis and to the disorder of the Beguards with their saying, ubi spiritus Domini, ibi libertas, Calvinism founded its school of prophets on the heights of the Dauphiné. From there that school then spread further into the Cévennes, the connecting link of the Alps with the Pyrenees; taking root in the kindred popular spirit of the inhabitants there, and in the excitement which the revocation of the Edict of Nantes had aroused in them. All the symptoms of ecstasy in the course of the Cévennes war manifested themselves en masse in those mountains, and testify to a predisposition to clairvoyance among these peoples.

And as now the phenomena of heresy and sorcery likewise rest upon the same basis, so they too have there attached themselves to it; on the one hand, in one cluster rooted in Manichaean doctrine and a licentious life; on the other hand, in a second cluster based on intellectual, rationalistic pride and the bold defiance of the mountain peoples. Thus it spread over Burgundy and the county palatine, on the one side toward Savoy, on the other as far as Lorraine. Thus Remy at the end of the fifteenth century found the evil generally widespread there among a bold people, partly living solitary in the mountain forests, and, as his folk-songs prove, thoughtful and inwardly given to mourning, besides poor and meager; so that he felt called, within fifteen years, to hold nine hundred trials.

From there it spread down the Moselle into the Trier region, and by the Meuse over into Belgium and Flanders, where in 1459 a similar slaughter had occurred. The rest of France had by no means remained untouched; the plague was so widespread, or the suspicion so keen, that Crespet (de odio satanæ), in the time of Francis I, on the testimony of those involved, could set the number of those entangled in sorcery throughout all France at at least 100,000.

Parliamentary councillor Florimond de Remond, however, relates in chapter 7 of his Antichrist: vice is so common that the prisons, like the time of the judges, did not suffice; and horror seized them at the dreadful things they had to learn in the interrogations. Understandably, the confused spirit that moved this land also opened an outlet into England. The accusation in 1303 in Rome against an English bishop, that he had concluded a pact with the Evil One and, in the usual way, rendered to him feudal homage, shows that this had already occurred early. The teachings of Langham of Kent, Wycliffe and others showed that the heresies, in rationalistic as well as dualistic form, had likewise forced an entrance, and that those aberrations had thus also penetrated. \[Page 75\]

The religious agitation which, in the wake of the Reformation, seized the minds in this country as in Scotland, soon likewise loosened here the predisposition to the second sight, wherever it was found among the people. Patrick Walker, who wrote under Charles II, relates: that time was marked by wonderful visions in lonely, desolate places. In 1668 and the years about then those assembled at such places, when the Gospel was preached to them there, had the vision of pitched tents, about which men and women were gathered, and from which voices were heard.

Especially on the first night, when John Dickson preached east of Glasgow, the people, as they made their way to the spot, saw, off the road, such a vision; and a voice came from the tent which loudly cried: "This is the eternal Gospel; hold fast to it and confess yourselves to it, and then it will never be taken from you!" When they went up to it, everything was vanished. Others, who came along another road, heard in a sweet voice the 93rd Psalm begin to be sung; so that they stood still until the singers had finished. Still others, who had stayed at home in various places, heard the 44th Psalm and the 46th; so that, when the first returned, they received them with the words: "Where have you been so long? the place of the sermon was so near; for we heard the Psalm sung, and can tell you of the sermon." John Blackadder questioned many honest people about this, and they all attested to the truth of the matter. Likewise at Craigmad in Stirlingshire, where A. Stirling heard the 121st Psalm, and saw a white horse with a red saddle among the singing people; and in Darmead, where the 59th Psalm sounded. The people were at that time so excited that they believed of the bishops of the High Church: they had claws on their feet, and cast no shadows; the soldiery that pursued them wore impenetrable armor, and rode on horses which, like foxes, could climb the rocks; the justices of the peace, however, were believed to be seen in great intimacy with the demon. All these regions, moreover, were in the time of James also the scenes of witchcraft; the records and the parliamentary acts in England from 1541 to 1682, where the three last witches in Exeter at the gallows expiated, as in Sutherland 1722, give testimony to that.

Those two French stocks, the Pyrenean and the Alpine, have meanwhile, from their own soil, certainly modified and increased the evil; yet they by no means called it forth from their own ground: rather it came to them, with the general migration of history from east to west, from neighboring Italy. There, as we have seen, Manichaean and rationalistic heresies had earlier spread in the towns and in the countryside; to these the demonic disorder afterwards attached itself. In the continuation of the French Alps there dwells also an Italian people, comparable to the Iberian Basques and to the Gallic Dauphinois; full of stubborn spirit and courageous mettle, who, e.g. the people of Como, Bergamo, Brescia, etc., make among the best soldiers. Bernard Retegno, whom Pope Julius II in 1505 appointed as inquisitor, found records of the Inquisition concerning witchcraft in the diocese of Como that went back to 1350. So great was the zeal of the local inquisitors for the extirpation of the evil, that Spina relates: the number of those who annually fell under the investigation of the local inquisitor and his eight to ten vicars amounts to a thousand, and that in single campaigns as many as a hundred of them were burned. \[Page 76\]

In the nearby county of Burbia the bewitched had eaten children; the Inquisitor Cumanns was called upon by one of the inhabitants, who had thus lost his child, to intervene; as a result of the process he instituted, in the year 1485 forty-one of them were delivered to the fire; the others fled across into Tyrol. Camonica, the open spring-valley of the Oglio above Lake Iseo, is inhabited by a robust people, mostly composed of shepherds. According to Thevet all are mighty sorcerers who occupy themselves with incantations, and practise everything by the power of the simple means furnished by the vegetation of their mountains and valleys.

Theodor von Folengo in his Orlandino, first canto, stanza 12, mentions this magic-cry of the local people, which has been preserved down to our times. Around 1517 an inquisitor took note of it; the consequence was that many made satisfaction in the flames. The same bold spirit which may perhaps have led some from natural magic into the demonic would not, however, brook a procedure that, in turn, confused one of these magics with the other without distinction. The people took up arms, and appealed from the Inquisition to the court of the bishop. The bishop summoned the jurist Alciatus, as seems to appear from his writings, to report; the government in Venice intervened; the Council of Ten annulled the proceedings of the ecclesiastical court and ordered a review, whereupon the people quieted down.

A similar forcible self-help seems to be the outcome of an earlier incident in the diocese of Como, related by Bernardus Comensis. He tells, namely: When about fifty years earlier, that is about 1460, Bartholomew de Homate was inquisitor there, Lorenzo of Concoretio was podestà, and Johannes de Fasseto was notary, and they were inquiring into heresy at the Comacine place Mandrisio; one day the podestà wished to satisfy himself whether the heretics really and in bodily person went to the Sabbath, or only in imagination. He therefore arranged with one of the initiated that she should lead him to such a spectacle, and so on a Thursday he went, with the notary and a third man who had been summoned, to the spot pointed out by that woman. The three there saw many persons gathered round the demon, who had assumed human form, and how a great lord sat among them. At first, as Prieras adds to his version of the report, the master of the chair took no notice of the intruding strangers. After the meeting ended, however, he gave a sign, and then suddenly those present fell upon the spectators and beat them with cudgels so that all three died within fourteen days. The matter, Bernard adds, is still in many persons' remembrance in Como. That in these valleys the whole activity was likewise connected with the heresies, and that action against the evil, when it was shown by an impartial and dispassionate inquiry, had the mass of the people on its side, is shown by the following remarkable account which Giussano has preserved for us in the Life of Saint Borromeo. \[Page 77\]

The valley of Mesolcina, which belongs to Graubünden, was, at the time of this archbishop, besides the heresies and other evils already recounted, also filled with those who practiced malefices and witchcraft with the help of the demon, to whom the abandoned wholly surrendered themselves, and who now committed great and intolerable wicked deeds. By their sorceries and malignities they harmed both people and beasts; for they not only brought various sicknesses upon adults and children, but even sentenced them to death: and it happened that people and whole herds threw themselves down from the mountains; which caused the populace great distress and harm, all the more because they could find no remedy. In that year 1583 the communities therefore assembled the common council of the valley to discuss measures by which the evil might be remedied; and those assembled resolved to take refuge with the archbishop and to beg him that he would grant them counsel and assistance in this matter. They therefore sent some of the principal persons of the valley to Milan to lay the commission before him, and they were received by him very kindly; and, rejoicing that God was opening the way for him to be active in the service of these communities, he kindly promised them his assistance; and he offered to go personally into the valley in order better to learn of the situation and to take precautions for what was necessary. With this he dismissed them comforted.

He then considered the importance of this affair very maturely and cautiously, and judged it necessary first to send a judge under the name of an Inquisitor, who would, within the bounds of justice, initiate the inquiry against the malefices and witchcraft. For this task he chose Francesco Borsatto, a famous Mantuan jurist who had shortly before put on the clerical habit; and, drawn by the public reputation of the archbishop, had come to Milan to receive the holy orders from his hand and to learn in his school the practice of ecclesiastical discipline. Borsatto carried out the necessary investigations with great prudence and agility. He found almost the entire region infected by witchcraft; and, what is worse, he discovered that the provost of this valley himself, who resided in the collegiate church of Rovereto, was as it were the head and leader, after he had transformed himself from a shepherd into a ravening wolf. He therefore instructed the judicial processes, and conducted them with so much humanity and goodwill that he won all hearts, and was then able to dispose of all things according to his judgment.

These wise efforts proved very useful for the visit the Cardinal wished to make there, and served as the best preparation for greater matters. But since the Holy Man knew with what caution one must proceed, how fiercely one must contend with the infernal enemy, and what difficulty commonly presents itself in the destruction of evil diabolical arts, and still more of damned heresies, he deemed it necessary, after having in accordance with his custom first taken refuge in prayer, to choose some men distinguished by kindness and learning to assist him in various functions in his undertaking. Among these were Father Francesco Pignarola, a Milanese noble and very celebrated preacher, who afterwards became Bishop of Asti; Father Achilla Gagliardi of the Society of Jesus, a man of great authority and experience and an exceedingly learned theologian; and lastly Bernardino Morra, his general auditor, who was afterwards made Bishop of Aversa by Clement VIII, after he had in the most honorable manner endured many hardships for the Church. \[Page 78\]

After he had put all these matters in order, he left Milan at the beginning of November and went to settle in Rovereto, the chief town of the valley, where he was received with jubilation by the people there, from which he drew great hope for blessed fruits. When Borsatto had finished the instruction of the processes, he reported to the bishop. Since the latter now knew that people of that sort are very hard to advise, on account of the special friendship and the close contracts into which they had entered with the devil, he therefore tried, with great patience (supported in this by his subordinates), every means so that the bound ones might see their grievous errors, renounce the devil and his false arts, and turn their hearts to God. His efforts were not in vain; for he converted a sufficient number of them; at one time he was able to obtain more than 150 abjurations, who then confessed to him and received communion. Eleven old witch-women, the leaders of the others, who had wholly given themselves over to the devil, and who perhaps no longer deserved God's mercy on account of the exceedingly grave offenses they had committed against Him, remained hardened in their sin; and since all effort with them was in vain, they were delivered over to the secular arm and punished with death by fire.

The same obduracy was shown by the provost of Rovereto, who was the head of that wicked sect; and however much the cardinal and his subordinates labored, they could never soften that seduced heart to a true recognition of its faults. Therefore, out of obedience to the holy canons, they found themselves compelled to proceed, by public act, to his degradation, an act accompanied by the cardinal's tears and deepest sorrow; in which he also delivered a sermon to the people lamenting the offender in person, and expressed his oral regret that he was compelled by the command of the law to an act so far removed from his mercy and clemency. "You see, my sons," thus began the sermon, "the decision of the holy Church against her servants who have made themselves unworthy of ecclesiastical service;" and he then went on to show how unwillingly the Church, as the mildest of mothers, has recourse to such decisions. It cannot be told what care he took for the conversion of the heretics as well as for cleansing the people of their superstition; for he had spent much time in making these persons receptive of the truth. Even with the lowliest he showed the utmost patience, although some proved themselves most obstinate and gave him exceedingly unseemly answers. He did not, however, act as if he felt it, but persisted in his long-suffering and zeal to gain their souls for God. In this way he reformed that entire valley and brought it into a wholesome condition; a result that seemed more wonderful than natural.

The whole Italian chain of the Alps was thus, just as much as the French, infected by the same evil; and while this, in the direction of the Apennines, spread southward over all Italy as far as the walnut-tree of Benevento and beyond to Sicily, it likewise overspread all Germany to the north. In the Bernese territory, toward the end of the fifteenth century, according to the testimony of Nider, witchcraft was very common; and Peter of Bern, a secular judge, raged against it. The cited examples all belong to French Switzerland and the diocese of Lausanne; into these regions the evil had penetrated from Savoy, where the Inquisition at the same time found itself much engaged. \[Page 79\]

But the German Switzerland was at the same time also seized by it, and Nider mentions an entire succession of reputed sorcerers in that region who, judging by their names, were of Teutonic stock. At the beginning of the fifteenth century there was, namely, a certain Scaf or Schaf notorious as such, who boasted that he could, in order to escape the hands of his enemies, turn himself into a mouse; nevertheless he was killed by them by an unexpected assault. His pupil and the inheritor of his secrets was a certain Hoppo, who is also known to Sprenger, and who in his turn initiated, in the third generation, one called Stadelein, whom that Peter in turn burned. They boasted of making weather, of shifting grain, of smothering children; they could render men and cattle barren, strike the horses under their riders with madness; ride through the air, repel their pursuers with stench, disclose hidden things, see into the distance, and foretell the future. The authors of the Hexenhammer, Sprenger and Institor, likewise found much work in German Switzerland, and from there, by way of Basel and Strasbourg, traced the tracks that led to the Lower Rhine; whereupon Kalteisen pursued them further into Belgium and Holland. In East Franconia the evil showed itself at various intervals, and from 1627--29 the flames consumed 158, among them 14 curates and five canons. To Austria and Bohemia the Lollardy had already, at the beginning of the 14th century, carried over its Manichaeism, to which a century later the Hussite rationalism was added; no wonder, then, that the demonic practice went over with it and now infected the whole North, which had already been prepared from the Netherlands by the Stadingher; and in Friesland, Mecklenburg, East Prussia, everywhere now, in the midst of the Protestant lands, the funeral pyres flared up. The plague penetrated even into the Scandinavian mountains; after it had earlier run its course in the region of Elffdale and the fire there had set its bounds, it broke out suddenly in 1669 and so in Mohra and the surrounding places, and the inhabitants begged the government for measures against the same, in order to restore the peace. A commission of clergy and laymen was sent there, and this, after it had examined all witnesses and taken statements, found that in the village of Mohra there were 70 witches who had seduced about 300 children. Of those, on voluntary confession, 23 were \[condemned\], of these 15 were sentenced to death; 36 children had to run with birches, 20 with rods in their hands, for three Sundays in succession stand in the church doors --- a punishment to which those 36 likewise had to submit for an entire year.

Ethnographically determined nodes, in which the threads of the web of witchcraft spreading over the earth are entangled, are not to be mistaken throughout all this; and these points fall near those germ-centres to which the confluences in the forms of paganism attached themselves, and to which afterwards the newer heresy again established definite relations. The Orient is therefore also the first original point of radiation; and as the Alps pass into the Hæmus, and this into the Taurus and the Caucasus, so to the Alpine tribes the first germs of Manichaeism came from the Balkan peoples, and these in turn from the Taurus mountains and Lesser Armenia --- which finally run together in the cave of Manes, and the older Mithraic peoples of the yet deeper East converge. \[Page 80\]

The mysteries of demonic service have followed this guidance; other currents in other channels have joined them: and blood and temperament, and direction of thought, and circumstances in history have here and there taken them up preferentially, and the fire has run on in the innermost marrow of things, in the tinder that presented itself to it, and thus this solfatara in history has been formed. History has therefore taken them up here and there in preference, and the fire has continued in the very core of things, in the tinder that was offered to it, and thus this solfatara in history has been developed.

#### D. Morbid Intensification of the Predisposition From Within

If the predisposition is present in individuals at the outset, it then easily increases from within through subjective affections, and mysterious states develop in which the decision whether they were really formed in this way, or objectively introduced from without by an injurious influence, is subject to great difficulty. A remarkable story that occurred at the beginning of the 17th century in Danish Zealand at once places us in the midst of this mode of operation and the question connected with it. The mistress of the house in which the affair took place wrote down the report of it; and Brunsmann, rector of the school of Herlof, later published it and supplemented it from the judicial records of the town of Køge, near Copenhagen. The events occurred between 1609 and 1614, but the publication was first made in Danish in 1674, while a daughter of the household was still alive. Later the book also appeared in Latin under the title: \[Enarratio Cagiensis?\] sive admirabilis historia de horrenda cacodæmonis tentatione, quacum in urbe Coagio \[a most honest and most reputable family\] for some years was afflicted. Second Latin edition, enlarged and corrected, Leiden. Leipzig, 1695.

The affair created a great sensation on its appearance, and Becker in his Bezauberte Welt explained it in his shallow manner; on the spot no one thought otherwise than that the narrative, as the woman had written it down, was perfectly true; and Brunsmann, in the second edition, repelled the suspicion of any fraud having occurred with proper scorn. \[Page 81\]

"The demon," Anna begins her account, "called malum domesticum, first made himself felt when I once went to bed in the evening with my husband. We heard under our heads a sound like the cooing of a hen calling her chicks. Startled, we rose and told the matter to our friends the next day; who then advised that it was due to snakes and other natural causes." We therefore examined the bed, pillows, and straw sack most carefully, but found nothing. Soon afterwards one evening, when I went from the room into the cellar, I saw a toad on long thin legs as if coming from the door; but when, frightened, I called the household together, we found nothing. The following night my youngest child gave a terrible scream, and when the maid lighted a lamp to look after him, she herself went pale and said: the demon had attacked her; she therefore fell ill from that time on, so that we had to hire another maid for her service for half a year. My little eight-year-old daughter then suddenly ran, frightened and crying, to her father: she dared not sleep in the children's room, for at nightfall there always came a strong man, in a silk garment, with a mustache and frightful eyes, before whom she was terribly afraid. We scolded her for her timidity, and she had to go to bed. But when her father had left her, she broke out into great weeping and screaming; we hastened to her, and found her deathly pale. She then became ill, and caused food and drink to be expelled again through her lips; yet she afterwards recovered.

Soon after my husband had to travel to Germany, and two weeks after his departure a great terror came upon our house. A young man, called Jakob, a nephew of my husband, began to be beset with fear by the spirit of temptation. For when he went to bed at evening he began to lament and to cry, and said he could not sleep in his room because of the demon and the ghosts. So we made his bed in ours; but when he lay down there he began again to bewail himself; and when we ran to him his whole bed trembled; and the boy's eyelids were so widely torn apart that they could not be closed or brought together by anyone; his mouth, however, was so tightly shut that no one could open it. After he at last came to himself and began to speak, we asked him how he was. He answered: God knows it; to me it is unknown. At last sleep came over him, so that he rested the remainder of the night, and slept until the tenth hour on the following day. On rising, however, he looked so corpse-pale and emaciated that it was a terror to all. That evening, as he stood at the table during supper, I said to him: Take something to eat, Jakob! Lie down, and commend yourself to God's protection, so that you do not again behave as on that accursed night, whereby we all were thrown into terror, and finally must leave the house! As I spoke these words, the doors of the chamber and the kitchen were torn open of themselves, and so violently that they struck against the walls; the youth, however, was torn from the room into the hall, where he was raised two ells high into the air, hanging suspended; without anyone present who supported him or held him aloft. His arms were stretched up, his eyes wide open, his mouth drawn together, his chin twitched up and down as if it were about to be torn off. \[Page 82\]

We tried with all our strength, grasping him by hands and feet, to pull the one hovering down; but the limbs hung so motionless that we could not even shift him or move him from the spot. We therefore all, kneeling in the hall, called to God that He would remember His mercy. Then the youth was released and set again upon the ground. But his mouth was still closed so that he could not speak, until we made him vomit with a silver spoon. Then he sighed, and his tongue was loosened, and his speech restored; and when we asked him how he was, he said: I hope that, with God's help, I will now grow better; for when you called to God on your knees, he went away, and moved from the well to the wood-pile. When I asked, "Who has gone?" he answered, "Satan." When I further asked whether he had then bound himself to Satan, he burst into tears and said, "You do me a great wrong, mother, in holding me capable of such a crime; my years have not taught me such things!"

While he spoke thus, a great noise was heard in the entry-hall, and a monstrous voice was heard, which however no one understood. The young man said: it is the voice of Satan, who speaks with him. At that moment a great fire flared up in the entry-hall, running about here and there. The young man said: Satan had spat the fire from his throat. We then took him into the room and read to him from God's Word until two o'clock after midnight, whereupon sleep at last came upon him, which lasted until the eleventh hour the next morning. He was, however, soon assailed again, and the terrors in our house increased day by day; all the more because I kept the matter secret until my husband's return. Of him Satan said: he had dogged him for fourteen years, but on account of the great man (so he used to call God), whose assistance he invokes day and night, I could do nothing against him; instead of him you are now delivered to me! The young man wept as he told this, and lamented that he had ever set foot in Denmark; for he was a German, and his temptation by Satan grew worse and worse thereafter.

At times he crucified him, bowing his head and crossing his feet one over the other, as Christ is represented on the cross: then no one could bend him, or move him from the spot, or alter his stance and appearance; he turned the whites of his eyes outward as if he were dead. At last my blessed husband returned home, and was informed of what had occurred. He caused prayers to be said for us in the town and the neighboring churches. He appointed the three successive Sundays as days of penance for the whole household, on which none, neither man nor beast, should eat or drink anything.

On the first of those days it was as if Satan would force in the windows, and the young man wailed that he would carry him off through the open window; the Evil One also appeared to some as a raven, to others as a goose. --- For a month the afflicted one had not slept soundly; now he began to enjoy some rest and awoke cheerful; likewise nothing had occurred in the house during the whole night, and the awakened man related that during the night his angels had told him he would get better. Yet he announced at eleven in the evening the return of the Evil One, who indeed appeared and remained with him until Easter. \[Page 83\]

No place in our house was in the meantime free of spectres; to some of the household he appeared in the likeness of Mr. Johannes Knuse of Karslund, or of H. Mathias in Herfögle; to others in that of a merchant, a dog, or a pig. The face and hands of some swelled so that they were no longer recognizable. Our children cried out and lamented at his appearing. One, only two years old, tore at his hair and pointed with his finger to the spot, crying, "There! there he is!" Jacob usually felt his approach in advance, and then urged us to remove the boys. The maid of our neighbour I. Mejer had once also come here with her master's boy; Jacob had warned her, but she had refused to heed the warning; her face and hand swelled up so that she was no longer recognizable. We had taken in a poor woman in the evening; but the enemy, appearing in the form of a local burgher, so frightened her that she could not compose herself. \[Page 84\]

A little white puppy lay in our parlor; it was lifted by the head and struck against the floor, though no one was visible who could have held it. It then hid itself under the bench, and was drawn out from beneath it by the head, and, resisting with its hindquarters, was dragged along the floor. The next morning it was frantic, tried to bite everyone who came to visit us; and we were obliged to kill it. When at last the time came in which the tormented young man was to be freed, he rose in bed and wrestled with Satan, using God's Word for the conflict; he recited many prayers that the neighbors we had summoned listened to; finally he lifted his hands to heaven and cried out: Now be God praised, who has delivered me from Satan! Then, turning to the other side, he extended his hand to someone we did not know and said: Hail to you, angel who standest at the right hand of God; forsake me now never, whether I travel by water or by land! He spoke other such words, reached out his hand again after kissing it; then wrapped himself in his blanket so that we saw nothing but the crown of his head; and we heard him, like a small boy with a clear voice, sing: Glory to God in the highest and peace on earth to men of good will. Now he rose up, and was completely well again; before, without our help he could do nothing, so bent and contracted was he, and he could not straighten himself up; henceforth he felt nothing more of all that affliction, and we were joyful and all thanked God.

But God, in his unfathomable counsels, sought to visit us even more harshly. My husband now began to be assailed day and night, harder than anyone can imagine; namely from eleven o'clock in the morning and evening until two o'clock after noon and after midnight. It began when I had stayed at home from the Sunday service because of a boy's illness; thereupon such a terror seized us all that we altogether fell upon benches and chairs, or upon the floor. We came to ourselves again, and after we had prayed the evil vanished again. The maids and the children, however, again saw apparitions; and my husband, who had already been sorrowful for three weeks, became all the more downcast when he learned of it. Once, when I adjured him by God to at least tell how he was, he collapsed; and when he came to himself again he said: God, who is always gracious and merciful to those who call on him, may he also be mindful of me and of ours, and bring us help! So sorely am I pressed by Satan day and night that heaven and earth seem to lie upon me with their weight. You will not long have me with you further as a husband, and my children will soon be orphans. From that time on he was harried more and more fiercely; according to his account something lay upon him daily at that hour like a sack of fruit; and at times swellings, as large as hen's eggs, would break out at his side. I again had prayers held in the churches, and also drove by carriage out to Mr. Johannes in the parish of Norderup to solicit his assistance. But when, on my return, I entered a wood the carriage became so heavy that the horses could scarcely move it; the trees crashed about us, something as high as a tower rose up before us, and a dreadful voice was heard which we could not understand. When I, having come home, went to bed and, my right hand bowed over my head, fell asleep, it was as if a mouse were gnawing my finger. However I cried and for a quarter of an hour tried to pull the finger to me, I could not; the finger seemed dislocated to me, and although nothing could be seen on it, yet I could not move it for a whole month. \[Page 85\]

On the following night, when I lay in bed with my husband, a heat seized us, as if the bed were standing in flames; so that we could not sleep. But when we rose the next morning, there lay on the lower sheet, from the pillow to the feet, a hanging of filth, two and two as masses united in a link of the chain, as if they had been strung on a thread, and so numerous that one could scarcely see the sheet beneath them. Our neighbors looked on this in amazement. Ingeburg, the wife of Mejer, who had come over, heard a loud laugh but saw no one. When she, frightened, withdrew again, my husband fainted. We brought him to bed, and sat in the front room until the ninth hour; but when I then wished to go to bed, he was no longer in it, and at last we found him in a small room, weeping and lamenting. This continued until it finally ended as the whole affair had begun: in my husband's head-pillow, into which the spirit had thrown itself, and from whose lower side, when it was removed, it had torn a piece out of the covering so that the feathers flew about the whole room. My husband was then freed.

When we gave thanks to God for this deliverance in the churches, our nine-year-old son fell ill. Yet we could not fathom his sickness; he said something living ran through his body, gnawing at him here and there. We tried baths and other remedies, but he grew worse. A surgeon we consulted likewise could give no explanation, and directed us to a woman versed in healing who at that time visited our town. She said the boy was possessed, and that nothing would help but prayer. Meanwhile, as the boy lay in his willow-woven bed, the bed together with him was lifted two ells into the air and was moved hither and thither. When I therefore called my husband, the boy had meantime been pulled out of the bed and stood on his head, his feet turned upward and his hands outstretched; so that we could hardly get him back into bed. Something continued to run through him; his body sometimes swelled horribly, his tongue was thrust out of his mouth, and then again was wound up like a cloth, while blood pressed through his lips. His limbs were drawn so together that four strong men were not enough to pull them apart. He grunted like a pig, clucked like a cock, and howled like a dog. At times it carried the boy onto the beams of our room, or on a pile of wood, and left him there; so that he did not know where he was and wept bitterly. It also threw him over the wall into the gateway of our neighbor Mejer. Sometimes it drew his eyes and cheeks so far back into his head that they were no longer visible. The boy became rigid like a log, and we set him up in this condition against the wall, where he then stood motionless like a statue; so that even the most hard-hearted were moved to tears at the sight of him.

Once, when I myself was at the evening sermon on a Sunday, it ill-treated my mother, who had stayed at home; the spirit, taking my likeness, pulled her shoes from her feet and struck her with them. She therefore received me on my return home weeping and with bitter reproaches. Although women the next day assured her to the contrary, she could scarcely be persuaded until the spirit, speaking from the boy's mouth, told my husband about it, adding: Had the Great One permitted it, I would have treated her so that the whole town would have wept for her. When we in the evening prayed the 46th Psalm, he neighed like a horse to it; he spat upon my husband's face so that it ran into his beard. He placed bare knives upon my breast; but when I said he should strike in the name of Jesus, the knives fell to the floor. He said to my husband: Be not too hasty, you will not drive me from here until those who brought me here receive their deserved reward! That is the will of the great man; even if I am a liar, he at times compels me to tell the truth. I would wish the time were already come when I could leave the house. When my husband asked when that time would come, he answered: Only that great man knows, not I.

My husband, after having borne so much himself and for his family, was now delivered from all misery; he himself passed to the other life, and left me alone, entangled in combat with the raging enemy, who would not cease to speak from the boy's mouth. The affliction continued for two years after my husband's death. Magister Glostrup held prayers for us in the church, often came to our house, spoke with Satan, and reproved him harshly. He also tried to speak with him in Latin; but the reply was: he would not burden his head with Latin. At last God would not permit him to continue his persecutions; he had to desist, and our house became as free from spectres as it had been before --- for which may the holy Name of God be praised, who does not abandon His own in their distress. I have written this down as a memorial of what happened in our house, and it contains, so help me God! the pure truth.

This is also known to M. N. Glostrup, then our pastor, now Bishop of Opfloe; likewise to P. von Duebrodere, Bartolo Foannis; to Peter Mann in Ferse, to the pastor Jakob in Nordrup, Caspar in Roeschild, Lorenz in Liemarch, Nicolaus in Vallensby --- several of whom still live, others are already dead. Magister Nicolaus had the boy in his house for half a year; the boy afterwards recovered, once the authors of our misfortune had expiated their guilt, and lived until the year 1620, when the great mortality carried him off.

One might, on reading this account, imagine that every member of that worthy family went mad in turn; but it would not be proper to attribute the participation of all the named pastors to the influenza as well. The censor of the book, Fan Berharod, who, after reading it, believes it will help to confirm Scripture's teaching about demons, likewise must not have escaped the contagion. Then there are the two burgomasters of the town, father and son, and the senator Pomeyer, who officially and before God declare to the author Brunsmann that there is no reason to suspect fraud in what is contained in the woman's report; that they have had the truth of the matter confirmed by their predecessors, and that it also appears as such in their records, which they have placed at his disposal; they too must be regarded as having suffered from the same malady.

The circle of this strange mental disorder grows still wider when one reads the extracts Brunsmann has made from these records. The householder Barscher had taken suspicion of the authors of the mischief in his house, and this suspicion had fallen upon Johanna Thomana, with whom he had formerly been in business relations --- relations he broke off when she was accused, by Christina Capserin (who had been executed for witchcraft), of being implicated. Her grievance had been increased when he had pre-purchased a house on which she had bid. For this reason he had taken an advocate, and by him caused the suit to be prosecuted before the town council. The investigation was instituted and carried out; on 8 June 1612 sixteen judges of guilt were appointed at the Ting of Køge, who are named in the records. They were charged to pronounce only such judgment as, according to the laws, they could justify before God and men. From 8 June until the 3rd... \[Page 86\]

The trial lasted through August, during which the lay judges, their hands laid upon the Holy Scripture, declared: As we desire---may God and His holy Word prosper us for good and for salvation---so in this matter we could find nothing otherwise than that Johanna Thomana had been the cause of the mistreatment of the servant in the service of the merchant Johannes, who is reported as possessed; and we can see and discern nothing else than that she is in truth guilty of diabolical sorcery. She confessed, and was executed on 11 September. One sees that the lay judges had judged according to their conscience; and one must believe that they had previously verified all the factual circumstances that underlay the case. Whether, however, they judged rightly in attributing the evil --- that is, the objective influences --- absolutely to that cause, is another question which we shall consider later in general.

In general there are many and various complications into which a person falls when the disposition for night-visions, which sleeps within him, is awakened and, by a particular un-favorableness of the providences of his life, comes to full development and makes him a suitable instrument to receive inspirations from below. We shall cite only one example of such a talent of a negative character which, as one easily sees, with some cultivation could readily have been brought to considerable virtuosity. In a neighboring region, where at a famous pilgrimage-site all sorts of human afflictions converge, and where, therefore, exorcism is also practised as a remedy for one kind of them, the contemporary exorcist made the following experience, which he roughly set down in manuscript in the following words; and which, by the uncanny intervention of spirits into that disposition, may furnish an immediate transition into the next consideration.

In Holy Week, 1836, three brothers of Protestant confession came from Rheinbischofsheim in the Grand Duchy of Baden --- Jakob, David and Friedrich --- bearing a letter from a Catholic parish priest from the Lower-Rhine Alsace, who recommended them for exorcistic treatment because they, their younger sister, and their whole household were continually tormented by evil spirits. From the conversations I had with the three young men in consequence, roughly the following emerged. Descended from common peasant parents and occupied from youth with agricultural work, they had always been healthy and strong. The eldest, Jakob, learned the smith's trade; the second, David, entered service in the army; the third, Friedrich, always remained at home. While Jakob was still abroad, David was one time seized by a very strange condition: he felt as if blown upon by a wind, and such a compression arose on his chest that he began to spit up blood. He was medically treated and was sent to the hospital in Karlsruhe; but all remedies applied were in vain, and he finally received his discharge. Arrived at home, his condition was not at all better, and at the same time extremely strange things happened in the house and in the stable. At the same time Jakob, while abroad, had begun to perceive what was going on in the paternal home; and now the younger brother Friedrich soon also began to be tormented, just like David; and also a younger sister, though not to the same degree as the brothers. In the house there were intermittent rumblings and bangs in a dreadful manner, and in the stable the cattle perished in an unnatural way. When the brothers went across the fields or drove with the cart, stones were often thrown at them from the air. Sometimes, they said, a thunderstorm suddenly stood up in the clearest sky; and on several occasions an unknown animal walked ahead of them and then, at a certain spot, suddenly vanished. \[Page 87\]

Physically Jacob suffered little, but he was a kind of visionary, and saw, as he said, the fiends coming. A moment later the brothers would be as if smitten by a breath, and feel an inner motion that increased to the point of hemorrhage; yet so that, when the attack had passed, they felt their strength restored, as if they had never lacked anything. Often it seemed to them as if they were beaten by invisible but still palpable hands; often as if they were pierced through the belly. They ascribed these things neither to the devil nor to actual spectres, but to wicked people. The seer insisted that he had positively recognized the apparitions as persons still living and even related to them; and the strangest stories were adduced in proof.

They had at the outset sought diverse medical help, but found none anywhere; what wonder, since they sought to drive out sorcery by sorcery, and went to those who were reputed to practice such arts. These assisted them on several occasions by sympathetic means, but only for a short time; because, as they alleged, the helpers were better paid by the others. What opinion I should draw from all these accounts as to the real ground of the matter I did not know. I regarded the two younger brothers, David and Friedrich, as hysterical; for their condition, especially that of the latter, pointed to a high degree of suffering. They otherwise appeared to be anything but timid, superstitious people; so that, since I noted they were Protestants --- among whom such things, especially in that district, occur even more than among Catholics --- I was inclined to ascribe the whole affair to a play of the imagination; yet on the other hand their calm narration, their ingenuous answers to embarrassing questions which I put to them, utterly disabused me of that view.

After I had at last deliberated, and after I had to some extent explained to them the meaning of the church benediction, I gave this to them repeatedly once or twice a day. They testified that they felt easier, indeed they seemed entirely free from their plague. I therefore dismissed them in Easter week with a letter to the pastor who had sent them to me; in which I begged him, in consideration of my ignorance concerning the true nature of the affair, to make on the spot inquiries into the relations of the family, into the circumstances of the people among whom they had been raised, and in general into everything that might throw light on the matter; also himself, notwithstanding the general prohibition of exorcism, at least to employ the exorcismum probativum.

At the beginning of June the brothers, to my no small astonishment, returned a second time and brought with them a letter from the pastor, who wrote that he himself had gone to their parental house in Bischofsheim; that he had there examined and investigated all the circumstances, but had discovered nothing significant as to the cause of the matter. He had had the brothers examined by physicians, and these, as the enclosed certificates showed, had detected no bodily disease. Twice he had written to the Vicar General for permission to perform the exorcism; but the latter had only answered evasively. He had now blessed the house, and it had indeed been freed from all haunting; the half-dead cattle were now well too; only the three brothers continued to be tormented, and he therefore repeatedly begged me to apply the exorcism. The medical testimonies ran as follows --- first, that of Dr. Kühn: the three brothers had, several years before, suffered from pulmonary hemorrhage and had been treated by him; but the prescribed remedies had been without effect, because the causes of the ailment could not be sufficiently ascertained. \[Page 88\]

Secondly, that of the physician Humann in Herrlisheim, who declared that he had examined the brothers stethoscopically, but had found nothing in them that pointed to an organic defect of the sick person, or to a physiological disturbance of the functions of her body as a whole. The brothers, once they reached me, now assured me that when they had left here on their earlier departure they had remained free of all attacks for two days; upon which, however, the evil had returned, and they were again as before in distress. During their previous absence everything at home had been topsy-turvy; there had been terrible noise, and all the cattle in the stable had seemed as if they were about to die. The distraught father had at once run to the Catholic pastor for help; but since he was prevented from assisting personally he had given him blessed palms; and when these were burned in the stable the animals immediately became healthy and rose up well.

The pastor had afterwards come and blessed the house again, whereupon nothing adverse had occurred since. Only they themselves suffered from the old malady, and begged me piteously to help them, since they firmly believed I could. I had therefore to return to the work, whether I wished to or not, which weighed on me greatly because of the obscurity of the whole affair. I had them tell their stories again, I asked fresh questions, I had them set their answers down in writing; but I could come to no foundation, any more than the first time. Their accounts partly confirmed what had been stated earlier, and partly added new details.

I have again forgotten many things; I will therefore set down only some of what I have written from Jakob before me. He wrote: when he was yet away in foreign parts, a man often came to his workshop by day and by night who showed him how matters stood at home; he always demanded that Jakob should throw money to him, and he would show him what he could do. If Jakob then wished to leave, he could not stir from the spot; nevertheless he was not otherwise prevented from working. The matter soon took a worse turn: the visitors became more numerous; they planned all sorts of things with him, and forced him to swear at night; he often had to carry coffins, was himself laid into them, or had to dig up corpses. They crucified him; but when it was over it appeared that it had been nothing.

Naked women appeared, carried out all manner of mischief with the others, sat on his face, etc., whereupon he then had actual pollutions. They would also have carried him off, it was to him as if he went out through his own eyes, and they led him to games and debauchery. They showed him how they had poisoned the well-water at home, and promised that if he married one of them they would make it right again. Thus it went on as in madness, and when the apparitions presently threatened to devour him, shot at him with pistols, beat him, tore one another's hair, then again came driving up with carriages and horses; another time a man loaded with golden and silver chains would appear and two golden rings would be placed about his arms; when they then rode with him into the clouds, climbed Mount Sinai, gave him nine golden keys, made three garments, set up a white bed before him; meanwhile again firing cannons, making music, launching an assault on Paradise, and desolating and destroying all things --- who could be wise after all that? He complained that these phantasms appeared to him almost every night; whereupon, every time, certain afflictions befell the other brothers. \[Page 89\]

He also wrote much about this, from which, however, likewise nothing rational could be drawn; the assertion remained steadfast: the principal persons were close relatives; among others, the father's sister, a notorious woman, with her equally notorious daughter. It was precisely this latter who was to marry Jakob --- but he did not want her. Even their own pastor was said to have been among the fiends. The thought occurred to me: since that notorious aunt had christened all three of them, perhaps the first cause of the evil had been laid then; and for that reason I renewed with them the baptismal vows. I continued to pray with them, instructed them about the churchly benediction, and pronounced it over them.

At last I resolved also to speak the exorcism contra maleficia over them. I can cite nothing remarkable of its striking effects; for the fact that Friedrich once or twice perspired under it, so that the sweat fell in drops, could well be explained by his suffering state. They likewise assured me this time: after each prayer over them they felt lighter, but it would come back again anew every day; it already brought relief when they were even only in the convent. They always thought: if I took it to the highest degree, it would surely be better, it would be altogether well. Almost three weeks thus passed, but no thorough help had been attained; the people's money ran out, and by their long absence from home the accumulating tasks demanded their presence ever more urgently; I could not and would not detain them for a single moment with empty promises. I therefore dismissed them with a letter to the pastor, in which I communicated to him everything that had occurred, and how I had never found a sure sign of a demonic influence. That the exorcism had remained without effect might well be due to the fact that the young people lived outside communion with the church; this defect could indeed have been supplied by my faith and my trust; but since that is only a divine gift which God bestows on whom He will, no one could accuse me on account of the lack of success. A magnetic treatment by a reliable and religious physician might perhaps be advisable in this case; the pastor himself might also, after careful consideration of all the circumstances, privately, and without telling the people what was going on, apply the exorcism.

They went away with this advice, and the narrator, when he wrote this down, had heard nothing further of them since. One must regret that this story could only be observed so incompletely and with so many gaps; for, had it been followed on the spot with attentive eyes for the requisite time, it would have afforded a profound insight into the nature of a most wondrous condition. As it stands, it appears as a popular, and, as one can hardly doubt, sincere report on the modalities of a disposition as it often occurs in witchcraft; and although it lacks sharpness of observation and the investigation of all the circumstances that occurred, it nevertheless, intelligible to a physiological tact, affords many revelations.

It becomes clear from this account: the house of these people, with everything that was bound to it in some relation, has been transferred out of the natural state in which it previously was into a counter-natural one; in which other laws than those of ordinary life prevail. In the midst of this new condition stand, to begin with, the three brothers, who had previously been healthy and strong, but are now reduced to a hectic appearance; and to them the younger sister attaches herself in the first instance. All are united to one another in a physiological bond, and within it stand in reciprocal interaction. \[Page 90\]

In this association --- and thus also drawn into the shared suffering --- is also the household's stock of cattle; which, so to speak placed at the circumference of the sphere of action, nevertheless, according to the testimony of the pastor, takes part in everything that occurs within it. Within the house itself things happen that wholly belong to the domain of haunting, and, however one may explain them, they show that this domain has been pushed to the border of two spheres. At the apex of the solidaristic connection stands the first-born; against his will he has become clairvoyant, farsighted and foreseeing; he therefore sees through the whole relationship that attaches itself to him as the members to the head.

Immediately beneath him stand the two brothers, again placed like members to the central organ; they are not seeing themselves, but when he becomes seeing they appear affected; they are, in relation to his knowledge of their condition, as if breathed upon, and are at once seized by an illness in which this knowledge becomes real in them. Congestions of the lungs appear which end in bleeding from the lungs; whereby, after the termination of the attack, as in all maladies of this kind, the powers rapidly restore themselves. The younger sister is also, though less deeply, drawn into this relation of action and reaction; the cattle, as if struck by the outermost emanations, give notice of their participation by rapid falling ill and recovery; and the haunting stirs itself each time as well, and seems to form the medium in which all those effects occur.

Yet the first impulse of the movement by no means proceeds from the centre of the association, and the knowledge of the deed is not realised by the deed alone; rather this realisation also comes to it from elsewhere. Even the clairvoyance Jacob possesses is not entirely his own; there is a man who comes to him and shows him things as they occur. He finds himself bound and held by its power, although it does not prevent his work. It seeks to master him, and employs against him alternately terror and bribery. Desire too it makes its ally; involuntary sympathy it is able to extract from him, only the accession of the will is lacking; and yet all this likewise shows, as the crucifixion does, finally as a haunting.

Opposed to the household association there thus stands another association, which actually effects the realisation, and this association is of demonic nature, its head being that objective apparition; for even the church's actio in distans opposes it and hinders its effect. The members who belong to this counter-association stand in a certain relation to the house itself; it is the ill-famed woman who took the brothers through baptism; it is the pastor who baptized them; it is the woman's daughter who suggests marriage to the seer, and who draws him out with her own eyes, as she had previously bound him, and leads him to play and feasting.

From this counter-association, then, issues the realisation of what is seen; it is the hostile demonic principle that works in it, and it is by no means strictly necessary that its members be aware of the particulars of the matter. They need only, perhaps by their moral demeanour, stand to that principle in an ethically sympathetic relation of some depth: and this principle can, by virtue of the will-less natural force that lives in them, make use of them as instruments to exercise its effects through them; as the like may happen through any natural mischief. Just as this kind of evil, exercised by the haunt-spirits in the frightful manifestations, nakedly comes to light; so, in those fable-like ghostly proceedings, the haunting has only entered into these persons and has personified itself in them. Thus the whole points only to an order of things higher and more intensified than that in which the foregoing phenomena stood. \[Page 91\]

There have occurred there the spooky (spukhaften) events, without their actual inner cause having come into view. Here this perception, as clairvoyance bound to the disposition, found itself appended. Now the thus-perceived world presses upon the seer, so that he who hitherto has behaved passively will now also put his will into it, and truly unite himself with it. He resists with all his might, but give such a disposition likewise the perverse will that meets the impulse, and one will fully understand that a tacit or express compact may come to pass. Merely for this reason, because the episode marks a moment of the advance on the path of deepening into the region of night, we have inserted it here, notwithstanding the fragmentary and obscure character in which it has remained for want of keen observation. If the natural disposition is lacking, then it will, in the further advance along the road of evil, be artificially evoked by those natural stimuli of which we have spoken in detail elsewhere.

Nature also has its orgasm, which first manifests itself in the plant kingdom. When the spring sun in that kingdom awakens the sleeping natural impulse, and this then, overflowing through the plant's veins, raises the swelling green toward the warming star, until finally in the blossom the driving force pours itself into fertilization; then those juices and compounds are mixed and boiled out in which the orgasm that produced them rests enclosed, and which, when brought into a higher organization, imprint in it the same quiet natural frenzy that begot them. This intoxication, which in the lower nature expresses itself plastically, becomes in the higher, nervous nature a sensory image which, arising from the sea of senses ordered in the circles of dizziness, opens the murky prospect into higher regions; and, if oft repeated, at last produces in organs thus frequently carried away into intoxication the facility even, in the absence of the exciting agent, of setting themselves from within into that drunken state. That these states, when evoked to evil ends, are directed immediately to the ultimate object of all these ends, and that the Sabbath with all its appurtenances then always stands at that goal, we have already learned from the manifold statements of those who were in such a case. Those, however, were mostly women, and indeed such as belonged to the lower ranks, where self-deceptions of the grossest kind might be suspected. Therefore, in order to supplement what has been said above, the experience made by a man who belonged to the higher ranks, as Prierias has preserved it, cannot be passed over here.

After the author in the first book had established the possibility of demonic influence in an Aristotelian fashion, and the reality by means of the Malleus, he relates at the beginning of the second book: A marvelous event was wont, as experienced by himself, to be told by a resident of Piacenza; who, if he has not recently died, still belongs as a Benedictine monk to the congregation of St. Justina, and there bears the name Jerome. This man, then still worldly, had a love affair with a girl whom he had won with the help of a sorceress; in return for this the sorceress had him promise to attend the Sabbath. She contrived it, however, in such a way that he kept his promise. Naked, he anointed himself between the hand and the arm with a certain salve which she had given him, making at the same time a certain sign which she had taught him. The same was done by the teacher and by the girl whom he had already abused. \[Page 92\]

All three were at once lifted up and carried away through an opening in the roof; and he, as it seemed to him, was sitting on a swift horse. Thus they reached the walnut tree of Benevento, and indeed with such speed that the quickly cleft air sounded about them with a sharp noise. Beneath the tree thousands were gathered; a scant light illuminated the scene, and they amused themselves in many ways. After the merriment had ended the witness returned by the same way home, and on the journey he saw many rivers and places, among which he especially noted Venice, which he had never before seen; and later, when he visited it, he recognized again what he had seen in that vision, which also occurred to him with other places. Having returned home, he was---after he had indulged in the pleasure with the girl---horrified at what he had done; and either kindly by nature, or because God had mercy on him, he confessed everything that had happened to the bishop or his vicar, and returned to the Church; who then received him into that order in which he probably even now leads a pious life. Whoever wishes to have full certainty in this matter may turn to Brother Andreas of Genoa, a man of great learning and pious conduct of life; I cite him here as a still-living witness. From this example it becomes clear how everywhere the rinculum must join to sin's clairvoyance in order to impress upon the condition the character of the demonic.

The free, conscious will, in its downward aspect, has two sides in us. With one it is directed toward all that is unconscious in our life, and through this toward the bodily. This unconscious in us, subject to the law of necessity, leads us, if we follow this necessity back to its very source, out of ourselves and over into external nature, which is wholly obedient to its law. If we then proceed further within it, following the direction of this law, we are finally driven toward the innermost unity at the center of this nature; which receives this law from a higher power above, and binds all that is its own downward in it. The will is, in everything that it must accept as inevitable, likewise bound in its expression by this unity; and what is allotted and apportioned to us has obtained its measure from there. \[Page 93\]

The same will, however, just as it is set toward God by all that has remained good and uninjured in us, is with its second, downward-going side directed toward that which has entered into us as corruption. In this corruption clings that moral fatality to which everyone succumbs who gives himself up to sin; so that, bound in it, he delivers himself over to that servitude which every sin exercises over the one who has become its servant. If we follow where the bonds of this servitude lead us, we are likewise led out of ourselves into an objective world of evil; and in tracing the traces of the inner connection in this realm we are finally driven toward its innermost concrete unity, in which all the radiations of that ethical necessity converge as in a focal point; a unity which we are accustomed to designate as the root-like evil by the name of Satan. Now if the unconscious in the individual becomes conscious and clairvoyant through temperament and the development of life, or through art, then it comes, freed from what binds it in ordinary life, into closer intercourse with outward nature; the roots in which it connects with her become sensorially potent; but it is thereby by no means demonic. Only when that other side of the will, which descends into corruption, joins to it---when this corruption sharpens in that somnambulistic loosening, and the clairvoyant faculty is made to gravitate toward that other center---only then does the demonic appear.

Every sinful thing which, adding itself to the mass, increases the fund of perdition, then acts as a means of appropriation and as a band that strengthens the pull of the radical evil; so that the operation of the same, in ever-accelerated motion, grows as it approaches. To the loosening which Nature has effected in somnambulism there then attaches that other spiritual factor which effects the ethically nocturnal influence; the entanglement becomes ever deeper, and the encompassing ever more narrow. To the feudal tie into which man at first places himself with the evil principle succeeds the relation of that principle's absolute autocracy in him, under which the lost one has sunk down into unconditional bondage.

### Chapter 3. The Meeting and Confrontation of Humanity and Evil

In the foregoing we have surveyed the ways which, from the evil side, lead up to the threshold of the spirit-realm. Now the question presents itself: How is the enclosure that surrounds man broken from without inward; or how is the barrier which shuts off that realm overthrown from within, so that the two realms may have closer intercourse with one another? Demonic asceticism has already answered this question for us in general; we need now only demonstrate the particular application of what was there said.

#### A. The Approach of The Spirits. Again the Kobolds

\[Page 94\]

Two modes there presented themselves to us in which intercourse between the two realms can be mediated: namely, either the invisible realm presses into the visible, or the latter intrudes into the former. We found the first beginnings of their mutual approach where the region of night, as it were with its outermost hem and limbus, passes in a kind of half-shadow into the region of light; and the depth, overflowing as if in jest and caprice, mingles itself in a coquettish, ironic, at times humorous fashion with the play of life. It is the region of poltergeists and kobolds, of the Norse tricksters and the folletti of the Italians, who here produce the arabesques of this half-dreamlike realism. These beings may in part be what they appear to be --- the demonic and harmless plays of a middle world lying between light and darkness, in which the jesting wit that lies in things, and reaches down into the seriousness of nature, tries itself out in burlesques --- Bambocciades that make sport of the respectability of life's prose; but something else may lie at the bottom of it. All wit in itself is already of twofold nature, and the corrosive fire of sarcasm shows how far down one of its veins draws; and the wittiest of the old Norse gods, Loki, is also the most malicious --- his name already expresses the consuming blaze of his demonic temperament. The harmless may therefore be only a mask to conceal this temperament; and then these will-o'-the-wisp forms will furnish the most suitable agents for linking day and darkness. All experienced and discerning exorcists therefore warn against the deceptions of this errant and confused world of hauntings, and forbid entering into any confidential relationship with its ambiguity. Stephan Colett has allotted a whole section of his writing to this subject. "I speak here," he says, "of those spirits commonly called in Italy folletti or household spirits, and whose familiarity one must shun as one must shun that of the evil one. They begin this familiarity with teasing: small things from the domestic circle are stolen, especially such as belong to the one to whom they have attached themselves, and are then mostly returned to him; so that everything seems to be an innocent game. But it is precisely against the playing, flattering spirits that one must guard oneself most. To some they appear visibly, in various forms, by day or by night, or only at certain times; to others they never show themselves." Mostly, when they make themselves manifest, they are of small stature, hop about in the corners of the room, laugh, make a racket, steal to the beds, and pull the coverings off the sleepers. Such beings do not wish to possess the person they pursue; they only press themselves upon him for intimacy, most eagerly upon women in the bloom of life. They are wont to promise them something, express love for them, bring them now this, now that, and are then most commonly visible in the shape of a handsome youth. At first the person suspects no guile or deceit; but woe! if she is thus pursued and does not immediately put the adversary to flight --- as happened to the one of whom I am now about to tell.

Not long ago a country girl came to me with her father, who told me how the evil spirit had insinuated himself into her confidence in such a fashion. He had appeared to the girl more than once in the guise of an ugly man, and had then followed her as she fled. At times he stole something from her, especially bread which she either had with her or had laid elsewhere. Whenever the bread portions --- the people were poor --- were set down, it was always the portion that fell to the girl, and no other, that was taken, and most often the stolen thing was brought back as if in jest. The same happened with other things that belonged to her. But the girl was ashamed of this game, and so were her parents; for they mistrusted the outcome. They therefore soon came to me and earnestly begged that I free them from this burden. I instructed the good girl, in the presence of her father, in all that was necessary; then I commanded in the name of Jesus that the demon should no longer show himself, should steal nothing more from her, nor otherwise be troublesome. And so it happened, and the girl still lives today unmolested by all demonic temptation. All of this are not dreams, for those awake do not dream; nor phantasms, which do not as a rule occur to persons of full understanding. \[Page 95\]

The attaching (or attaching itself to the young) was also observed in many other instances, in the two cases of which M. speaks in the following words. I recall the following incident in Bologna. A certain citizen, who had much to do in his house with spirits, so that he had to consult theologians, and the matter itself came to the ears of the local bishop. Whatever one did, one could not get rid of the pest. He was, as people believed, in love with a girl of the house; followed her wherever she went; played a thousand tricks and jests around her; and whenever her mistress, in whose service she stood, did her any harm by deeds or words, he immediately caused some mischief in the house.
