But if the spiritual, being undisciplined and let loose, after the higher light in it has gone out, glows in a dark flame, has descended into and become fixed in the mere bestial impulse, and in its narrow containment is kindled to madness, and then moves downward where it feels the hearth of that flame, and unites itself with the principle of the depths to fornication --- then the curse will flow in this connection. The birth will indeed also be a spiritual one, but sin in it has become merely flesh, and appears throughout the whole brood of vices, only specifically graded according to family likeness. As those virtues there are poured in as graces, so here these vices will transfuse themselves as temptations; and the whole action will mean nothing more than the begetting-act of these vices in their living ground; just as that higher mystical symbolism would indicate the conception of those graces. For virtue and vice, if they are to dwell vivified in man, must have a principle of life in him; this was implanted for evil at the first transgression in the germ, and is then bequeathed to the following as hereditary guilt.

Since the Sabbath is a popular festival in these mystical regions, it is understood that all accounts coming thence to this side are in every respect popular in character, and occupy themselves exclusively with the grossly fleshly act in its kind. De Lancre adduces circumstantial statements made before the commission on this point; of these we will here cite only the general and instructive, passing over the particular, repulsive and obscene.

He reports among other things that the girls and women of Labourd, instead of blushing over the damned affair and bewailing their offense, had told the court all the circumstances and the filthiest detail with such shamelessness and pleasure that one saw how they took a pride in it, and found a special gratification in the telling, because they preferred the filthy caresses of the demon to anything else. They did not redden in the least, whatever slippery and unclean question was put to them; so that our interpreter in Basque, who was a priest, felt more shame in translating our questions to them than they did in answering them --- and these were girls of thirteen to fourteen years, answering quicker than one could ask. That, however, applied only to the girls who had known nothing else than that school; and in their ignorance they may have believed they had to do with a god, and therefore told everything outright. Among them there were indeed also some who could be brought to loathing of the vice; and who then, as far as they were able, strove to free themselves from Satan.

The old Hauber-women, however, took care not to disclose the matter; and if they were pressed sharply about it, they endured everything as if they had the best of causes to keep. One must be thankful to the one from whom Maria Dindarte of Sare testified: that she had, when Satan took liberties with her, begged him first to give her another shape; which he also granted her. This remainder of shame, which, it would seem, is ineradicably implanted in man, and even in these scenes of prostitution is not entirely displaced, showed itself also in that, whereas everything else otherwise happened openly, the affair was hidden from the children present by a thick cloud which rose between Satan and them. \[Page 145\]

At the assembly it was, moreover, just as on earth: the most beautiful and the youngest were considered the most valuable; the most distinguished sat in splendid dress at the side of the master of the chair, and were regarded as the queens of the Sabbath. When therefore the meal and the dance were over, he took them, or whoever else pleased him best, aside; brought them, according to the testimony of sixteen-year-old Margarethe von Sare, to a silken bed; and then did with them as he pleased --- the more unnatural and hateful to God, the better. In every pleasure, especially in those unbridled ones, there lies a sting and a barb; that likewise took hold of them in this case and pressed.

In the statements it is expressed in a very graphic manner. All confess, as Remy also assures us, that nothing colder and more unpleasant could be imagined than such deeds; and Nicolea Morelia affirmed that whenever she was separated from such wretched dealings she had to lie down and rest, as if she had grown weary from prolonged driving and hunting. They all complained that, completely against their will, they had to have dealings with the spirits; and it did not help them, however much they might struggle. Moreover the spirits were jealous; none would tolerate another courting their own. Nicolea Morelia's husband testified in this connection that when she became of age, and there was much ghostly activity about her, she was consequently often and severely beaten by her own family.

Unmarried persons were not readily chosen, because otherwise the opportunity to commit adultery on the side would be lacking; they were therefore kept for later. Just as everyone had to give themselves up to their master, so were they dependent on one another in him. Jeanette d'Abadie testified that she had seen men and women mingle without distinction at the Sabbath. The Devil gave, she said, the watchword, assigning each person to another who most violated nature and custom: the daughter to the father, the son to the mother, the sister to the brother, the baptized child to the godparent, the confiding penitent to the confessor --- without any distinction of age or status. That had happened to her herself countless times; she, who outside the Sabbath never incurred a misstep, there, since her thirteenth year, at Satan's command did everything he ordered without hesitation, because the responsibility then fell on him. It was a continual filth in which all wallowed; and it is understandable that here a kind of virtual practice of all that a certain class of books sets forth theoretically appears.

Besides, according to the same witness's testimony the same was true here as in intercourse with the demon; the fundamental motive in all of it was simply depravity; and Remy records Petron, the shepherd of Dalheim, as confessing: whenever he embraced the Abrahele, he immediately became rigid in all his limbs --- a testimony that fully makes clear the nervous, convulsive state in which the participants found themselves. Since the act takes place in a manner contrary to the order of nature, no natural offspring can proceed from it. That same Jeanette also stated explicitly that from those unions, whether with the master or with the other persons present at the Sabbath, no one ever became pregnant; a statement to which, however, others objected. On closer inspection it soon appears that either popular interpretation and interpolation has crept in, or that this phenomenon of demonic, magnetic elective affinity plays itself out only from conception to birth. \[Page 146\]

The first occurs with that belief which is expressed most clearly in a statement by Remy, where it says: one calls the children that spring from such debauchery "children of Adam." They wept day and night, were heavy as lead, sucked dry, misshapen, always hungry and emaciated, and nothing thrived on them, even if five nurses took them to suckle. Those are the so-called Kiel-kröpfe, children afflicted with rickets or cretinism; a natural evil whose cause Bolk believed to be found in such demoniacal relations. Proceeding from the principle that all evil has come into the world through evil, this opinion --- which, as is well known, Luther also cherished --- forgot that once such an evil exists it reproduces itself according to laws of necessity, and in its separate appearances by no means always needs a special causality through whose perverse action it arose. In this way, it seems, that delusion was formed which, to the misfortune that pressed upon these helpless creatures, now also added the evils of mankind's loathing; this, in turn, was alleviated among the people by the belief that the misfortune was derived from the house through them. Many of these unfortunates have nevertheless become victims of this delusion; for it was then customary in Lorraine that midwives quietly got rid of them.

The other mode reveals itself in what is recorded elsewhere in many confessions about the so-called elves or evil things. These were worm-like or entozoic formations which many of the arrested women confessed to having received on such occasions; and which, after they had carried them in an apparently regular pregnancy, finally came to light, whereupon they were buried in the earth. That the impulse toward the same, indeed an even more intensive inflammation --- which externally ignites in nymphomania --- excites in the organs a process that, immediately entering the rhythm prevailing there, runs through all the forms and symptoms of a pregnancy without any bodily foetus being present, is easily understood from what has been adduced earlier, and such a process has its analogue in the domain of nature. This pregnancy will then be able to advance in the realm of vision just as it had its beginning there; and in the same way it will there also be brought to an end.

What such women under these circumstances thus declared about themselves was taken from the history of the course of this spiritual pregnancy; it was the vice of unnatural debauchery that had become alive in them because it had implanted itself in the ground of their inner life. That which had been conceived within them had passed through its stages, with all the symptoms of an ordinary pregnancy; but it falls into their inner life, drawing the outer only into compassion. The process must end in a delivery which, however, because the fruit was conceived in the intus-(inward) reception and therefore takes place in the inner world, becomes visible to the outer world only in vision; hence the accounts run to a burial of the thing born. It is moreover not necessary, not even probable, that the whole occurrence remained without any external envelope. The dreadful inflammation of the forces must also have brought about a volcanic burning of the organ; and these organic processes in it, as in the possessed the inflammatory condition of the entrails, give rise to --- Görres, chridl. Monte. 1v. v. 15 --- whose extent and nature we are not able to measure. It is an unholy disease that has seized the individual in this region, and can now form concretions of the kind of hydatids which perhaps arise in the closely closed chambers of the brain, and in which the temporal evil both finds its course and finally its crisis.

#### C. The Witch Physiognomy and the Witch Stench

\[Page 147\]

A life that thus passes its days in abominations of every kind will also outwardly express the inner tornness in a corresponding distortion, which is expressed in the popular saying: "ugly as a hag!" To this first belongs what popular belief has preserved concerning the characteristic features of witch-physiognomy. The traits of this portrait must have been taken from such specimens as had brought that matter to virtuosity; and were then, given the hardness of the human heart, found and applied everywhere where age, poverty, misery, ill-treatment, in prison and on the rack, among old unhappy women who either did not at all or only very superficially partake, produced similar, and accordingly interpretable, features.

A canonical example of the first kind, however, seems to have been that Necato of de Lancre, of whom he tells us much and whom he thus describes. She, whose name already anagrammatically and hieroglyphically pointed to her fate and her kind, had set aside the nature of her sex in order to make a man of her, or rather a hermaphrodite. For she had altogether the expression, the speech and the bearing of a man; indeed of an exceedingly rude, dark-hued and sun-tanned one, like a forest-devil or savage who never left the woodlands and the open fields. She was bearded like a satyr, had small, deep-set, wild eyes, with an expression of ferocity like a wild cat; at the same time so flashing and dreadful that the children and maidens whom she brought to the Sabbath, and whom we confronted with her, could not endure her gaze; although she, out of consideration for us and in view of the justice, made every effort to moderate it, and by taming that natural savageness to move it toward some mildness. One believed one could plainly discern in her that she was accustomed to rest her eye upon that fearful object, after whose model she had adopted her raging and dreadful expression.

Another consequence of the inner dissolution is the smell which those initiated into these mysteries emit from their mouths and whole bodies; which thereupon communicates itself to their clothes, and transfers a pestilential stench onto all who come near them, and fills the houses, the air and all neighboring places so that it endures for a long time. In these words Brognoli has described the condition of the demoniacs; and the testimony of all exorcists agrees with this result. Not only is the whole body infected with this stench; every single secretion from the mucous membranes, the kidneys, &c., is marked by the same infection. Opposite the odor of holiness on the good side therefore stands, in full truth, the stench of unholiness; which proclaims itself so decisively that the elders accordingly called them the Foetentes, and the Gascons called them the Fetilléres. Just as the sweet scent of the saints tends to increase with every holy action they perform, so the stench of the unholy will increase and decrease with the degree of depravity to which they have sunk; and with each manifestation of them will only be concentrated.

We have ascribed that sweet scent to the production of an ethereal oil which develops in the simplified life-process, under the influence of a higher illumination, like the aromas in a blossom. The foul smell must therefore likewise be ascribed to the production of a putrid and inflammable animal oil, which is generated in the depressed life in the flames that burn through it; as the sharp and caustic or stupefying juices are produced under the sun's burning in poisonous plants. \[Page 148\]

Sharpened emanations tend already in ordinary life to accompany every deviation from moral harmony, which is immediately met by a corresponding natural dissonance; for the sharpened sense of the saints testifies to this, who, as we have seen, have smelled the sins of those who approached them, particularly the sins of the flesh; whereas the expression "stinking pride" seems to render this vice intelligible to the common understanding. A habitual intimacy with evil will therefore also render such a production permanent, and will thereby increase it both qualitatively and quantitatively so that no specially heightened sense is needed to perceive its presence; rather it forces itself upon ordinary powers of perception.

While, therefore, to the saints a conservative power is given which remains dominant even through frailty and sickness, and preserves in them the sweet odour even in conditions which otherwise unavoidably are associated with foul smell, yea even preserves them uncorrupted after death; in the demonic a destructive principle seizes, piercing even through their health: so that their healthy body already, like a cancerous ulcer, is foul-smelling, and, at death, rapid and swift dissolution and putrefaction follow. This is already hinted at in life by the uncleanness into which they must be brought; for the statements of many in their interrogations ran as follows: the unclean spirit does not allow them to wash themselves in the morning. It was therefore even believed that daily washing of the hands, and commending oneself to God's protection before going out, gave security against witchcraft; and Mugeta von Essem warned her husband earnestly about this, even before her burning at Remy.

### Chapter 2. Personal States of the Psychical, Middleman in Witch and Sorcery-Being

The transition into this region is effected, from the sphere of life, by the systems of voluntary movement in the torso of man. This torso is indeed built up from below by life, and is maintained by life in its existence; but it is destined chiefly to serve the psychical man as carrier, and as an organ to be borne and ruled by him. In the ordinary relations of reciprocal subordination it now rests firmly upon the support of the earth; and the column about which it is gathered is upheld by the rooted lower extremities, though it is also moved from place to place. But if the relation is annulled by the inwardly supporting (principle) obtaining predominance over the outwardly supported, then the dynamic in the organ becomes preponderantly powerful over the outwardly heavy, material; it withdraws into itself, and, concentrating more deeply, it masters the externally downward-drawing forces more and more.

In contrast to the common centre of gravity of these forces, another such point is found for the totality of the opposing fighters; and in the conflict of both points, on the one hand the position of the first is drawn more upward, and on the other hand the sum of the forces set upon walking and moving is outweighed by that of the winged, and, in the midst of the increased mobility, the possibility of flight movement may develop. Thus it must be the case in every inward-turning (process), whether its final aim be directed toward height or toward the abyss; the opposite modality will only appear with the externalization, where in the latter case the inwardly supporting is bound by the outwardly supported, and the whole act appears more in the character of a mere lower natural performance. An analogue of this will show itself in external nature, where with the earth's gravity a higher or deeper gravity, in the sun- or moon-gravity, connects, and now the union or counter-effect of these moments alone determines the total effect. \[Page 149\]

This total effect will then manifest themselves in the flood and ebb of the sea, and in the flood the earth-element, freed from earthly gravity, will rise in ascent; not only, however, where the other acting moments intervene at the zenith, vertically and in opposition, upon terrestrial gravity; but also at the point diametrically opposite, where they, though apparently confirming it, reinforce their effect by their own. If, therefore, the evil spirit has become the center of attraction for the spirits turned toward him, then the effect of this spirit-gravitation will also become visible in the realm of the physical in man; he will in part be unchained from it, as is the one who has surrendered himself to the Lord. But if the latter gains release from that power, so that it may be the expression of his higher, inward liberation, then the other is only torn away from his natural bent in order to sink into a more shameful servitude. Just as the Kabbalists call the bearer or organ of a power its chariot, so the Elijah-chariot of the mystics is the higher power, while the fiery chariot of the demonic is the lower --- Satan, who carries them over into his realm.

#### A. The Witches' Ride

The demonic, in organic life, by the nature of the process taking place there, predisposed to a specific lightness, and therefore belonging to the family of night-birds, are further driven in this direction by the distribution of forces in the organ of motion; so that they, too, like the possessed, do not lack the flight-membrane of the inner man, whose swing the outer must then follow. This character will therefore be characteristic for the whole class, and whatever in any way touches this region will already appear tinged with it. It has accordingly been remarked that even children who once took part in the Sabbath have already acquired this tendency to become buoyant.

Remy gives a clear example properly attested by witnesses, which we will cite from him here on account of its singularity. Franziska Haquart, who stood before the court in the year 1587, had, when her daughter Fana was only seven years old, given her over to the unclean spirit, so that he would thereafter leave her untroubled. She immediately reported this to the judge, and the daughter's testimony agreed with the mother's statement. On account of her youth she was released, while the mother had to atone with fire. A respectable matron thereupon took the child in hand and urged her to the fear of God, to bring her back from the godless condition. It succeeded so well that at last people entirely came to believe that it had been altogether accomplished. \[Page 150\]

Then it happened that, one night when she lay in bed between two maids, she was suddenly borne aloft, as if the spirit would take her with it. How likely --- it would indeed have actually happened --- had not the maids prevented it by their cry: "Lord Jesus, help!" When the spirit thus saw his work disturbed, he left his prey hanging up among the beams, and departed. The maids did not invent this; the whole neighborhood attested to what had occurred. For at the cry for help from the maids everyone hastened in and had seen how everything was arranged. The stiffness in which the little maid was found, her pitiable condition, and the fact that for eight whole days she took no food, remaining continually awake and silent, proved that no deceit had crept in. The very rigidity in which the child was found testifies that her condition had been nervous; that in the seizure she had spasmed locally, and was then borne aloft as far as the space permitted. What of demonical in the matter there may have been remained behind from the former direction which the mother had given the child, and was therefore accidental. The Bishop of Pamplona, Pr. von Sandoval, relates in his History of Charles V, on the occasion of a witch-trial that was held before the royal council in Navarre, the following fact. He wished to satisfy himself by personal inspection as to the cause of the circumstances there occurring, and therefore promised clemency to an old witch, from among the others, if she would perform her sorcery in his presence. The old woman accepted the proposal and asked for her ointment-box, which had been taken from her; and then she, in the company of the commissioner and many other persons, climbed up a tower. There she placed herself at a window and, with the ointment, rubbed her flat hand, her loins, the joints of the elbow, the underside of the arm, the shoulder and the left side. Then she called with a loud voice: "Art thou present?" Everyone present then heard a voice in the air say: "Yes, here I am!" The witch then began to descend the tower, head downwards, using her hands and feet in the fashion of lizards. When she had thus reached about the middle of the height, she took flight into the air; and the eyes of those present followed her until the horizon hid the flyer. All remained full of astonishment at what they had seen, and the commissioner caused it to be announced that a considerable sum of money would be given to whoever should bring the escaped woman back. After two days the shepherds brought in the one found. The commissioner asked her why she had not flown farther away in order to escape the inquiries of those searching for her. She answered that her master had only undertaken to conduct her three hours' distance, and had then left her in the field where the shepherds found her. Llorente relates in his History of the Inquisition the course of this affair, which ended with whipping and several years' imprisonment for the 150 participants involved. \[Page 151\]

The example of the Indian brahmin, who, according to the testimony of many English witnesses, sat suspended in the air upon a staff, appears akin to this fact. Where such occurrences take place, therefore, it is not absolutely necessary to infer demonic agency; other natural forces may also intervene in such cases. Thus Rémy relates from his records: Once, in the German Vosges, near Huncaria, a violent storm arose with thunder and lightning; the shepherds, for protection against the tempest, had withdrawn with their cattle into the woods. There they suddenly saw two peasants hanging high up in the tree-tops, and their minds were so stunned and distraught that one could clearly see they had not climbed there intentionally but had arrived by some accident. The state of their clothing, covered with dirt as if they had been dragged over stick and stone, meanwhile aroused the suspicion that demonic force had placed them in the trees; and this seemed to be confirmed when, after they had sat there for a while and no one was watching them, they came down and vanished. Afterwards arrested, they freely confessed what the shepherds had asserted of them.

Likewise, once in Bellmont during a storm two men --- a certain Rothar and another called Amantius --- fell from a cloud onto a roof. The first had expressed great concern in that position about how they might come safely to the ground; the other, however, had replied laughingly, "Be calm, fool! for he who has us in his power can do still more." And indeed they were seized by a whirl and forthwith brought down to the earth uninjured; whereby the whole house trembled so that it seemed shaken to its foundations. The inhabitants were all unanimous in their testimony as to the circumstances and the day on which it happened.

Again, Cunin, a magistrate of Roncas, in December 1586 had been attending to business out on the meadow; and since the sky proved very stormy, he set out in haste for home. Suddenly a lightning strike had uprooted six oaks around him, and a seventh, which had remained standing, was torn and riven as if by claws. As he now hurried home all the more, having only lost his hat, he saw on the top of the oak a woman who seemed to have been set down there from the cloud. He recognized her, and called to her: Are you the ill-famed Margaretha Warma, upon whom, as I now see, suspicion of witchcraft has not been groundless; how then have you come here? She answered: Conceal what you have now seen; no smallest ill shall from me befall you and yours in the future! Cunin swore to his statement before the judge, and Warma confirmed it by her confession, without the use of torture, and at the last moment.

Del Rio relates a fourth case as equally beyond doubt. He was at Calais in 1587, when Archduke Albert took the town; on the bridge toward Boulogne, where the enemy lay, the Walloon outposts were posted. Two of them saw in the evening, under a clear sky, a blackish cloud approach; and heard confused voices issue from it, without being able to distinguish anything. Because they mistrusted the matter, one fired his arquebus; and then a drunken, naked, rather stout woman of middle age, wounded, fell from the cloud at their feet, who acted foolishly and could hardly say anything but: Are enemies or allies about here? \[Page 152\]

In those first cases there are sworn judicial attestations; Del Rio appeals to many eyewitnesses; there must have been some basis of truth in the facts. Natural explanations, on the other hand, must be admitted as long as they are not found to be insufficient. Storm and bad weather were, except in the last case, always involved. It is contrary to natural instinct that people should have sought shelter on trees and roofs for the purpose of shooting at them; but it is possible that they were perhaps whirled up by a waterspout, which would have produced their bewildered state of mind and, because of the violence of the occurrence, led them themselves to believe that it had been the work of the devil. If this interpretation is rejected by the circumstances, then that which arises from becoming suspended in magnetic states comes into play; and only when the person's previous life also accords with it will the assumption of demonic influence be justified.

If the impulse to hover seizes simultaneously many who are connected in demonic rapport, and if these impulses are all directed to the same distant goal, to the place of the Sabbath, then thereby the excursion will be formed; and the next question must now arise: are the participants in this excursion bodily and physical, in real locomotive movement, to that place, or are they present there only outwardly in appearance and in a spiritual manner; that is, are they present in the one place without being at the same time present at the other, distant place? Some have accepted both kinds of presence, and in order to prove the reality of the former have repeatedly adduced facts which, as invented out of the air, can be dismissed; rather, a more exact inquiry is required. The two most important \[cases\] to us here must be those that Fr. Bartholomew de Spina has set forth in his book. An eminent physician of Ferrara, who in that city is especially devoted to the care of the poor sick, called Sozinus Bentius, has in the last days told me the following with the most sincere truthfulness.

He said that three years ago he had been in the country to look after his estates, and there he had by chance fallen into a conversation with his farmer about the witches. The physician had maintained that all that is told about them is mere imagination; especially, he said, if one believes that they physically set out on the ride. The farmer, however (who is still living and is called Thomasinus Pollastros, born indeed in the district of Mirandula, but now residing in that neighborhood in the place called Clavica Malaguzzi), answered that he knew a peasant who lived nearby and who himself, with his own eyes, by night had seen men and women in great numbers who danced and gave themselves up to all manner of lusts. The doctor was astonished at this remark and begged his bailiff to bring that peasant to him. He came, and, when asked about the matter, gave the following account. \[Page 153\]

One night, when I had risen three hours before dawn in order to bring my oxen and my cart to my tenant to assist him in some business, and had thereby come to that plain to which he pointed with his hand because it lay near, I saw from afar many fires in different places, like great lights; and between them a great multitude of men and women who as it were quarrelled among themselves, or else danced together. But when I came nearer I beheld, in the bright light which the fires shed around them, more than six thousand people; and there were tables set up at which many sat and made merry with food and drink; several danced and practised various games; others took out things about which it is indecorous to speak at greater length. Among the crowd I saw some men and women already known to me, and I spoke with several. But after an hour all rose at a certain signal, hurried away, and vanished as if in a mist.

On this testimony the physician changed his opinion, and held that what he had formerly declared to be delusion was not only possible but really did occur. The same author reports: Brother Paulus of Caspan of his order assured him that a priest, J. Ant. von Palavisinis, an honorable man who lives at Caspani in the Veltlin, had told him the following. When, before dawn, he rises as usual to perform divine service or to attend to other business, it has often happened to him that he has seen a great number of men and women in a neighboring plain running about with lights as if in play, and he has recognized them as witches and sorcerers in their assembly.

In both accounts the persons, the place, the time and the occasion are exactly specified; the witnesses who give them are not suspect, and they have taken down what was told; one must believe that they saw what they testify they saw. Yet their testimony by no means proves that the company seen was actually present at that place. One has, namely, neglected to verify whether the seers did not possess the second sight, and whether the Sabbath observed was not seen in a vision. The vision of the tenant of Glenarz and of a son at Inverness on the Gairan bridge has arisen from this source. The seers have, in the very content of the vision, seen an actual rider on the road whose horse the teamsters seemed to urge on with bayonets. Just as these saw an army, so could his Italian seers behold a revel without its being spatially present at that time. The statements of witnesses in judicial inquiries that they saw dancers under the trees as they passed by can in part be interpreted in the same way.

As is well known, the circles in the grass around trees, chestnuts for example, in which not a single herb ever grows, have been regarded as witch-circles. Various natural explanations of this phenomenon have been sought, among others the supposition of masonry existing beneath them. But at least this explanation Strozzi Cicogna has found to be invalid. At Castelnuovo in the Vicentino such a circle was found. Strozzi had excavations made; one found nothing but earth, like in the places beside it. \[Page 154\]

Many other narratives circulate concerning such gatherings, said to have been held truly and bodily, remote from human intercourse, into which eyewitnesses accidentally stumbled. Besides the fact that in these reports it is never clearly shown whether what was seen was not either merely too corporeal, or not rather a vision, all these accounts lack the external authenticity that would be required to admit them as testimonial evidence. There is the peasant from the Sabine country, near Rome, whom his wife persuaded to anoint himself. He is at once led under the walnut tree near Benevento, where he finds many gathered who eat and drink and make merry. He does as the others; but since the unsalted dishes do not please his taste, he repeatedly asks for salt. He finally receives what he demanded, and then says: "Praise be to God, now that this salt has come." Immediately everything falls apart, the spell vanishes, and the man is left alone. He must painfully beg his way home; he then accuses his wife along with others whom he had seen there; they confess and are all burned. Grillandus, who relates the story in the first book of his work De sortilegiis, gives no names and adduces no witnesses; but even if the matter were best investigated on that side, it would not prove what it sets out to prove. For the peasant had been anointed, and thus was subject to all the enchantments that commonly accompany that condition.

The women who rode out used to put the men at their sides to sleep by applying the salve, so as not to be disturbed by them in their proceedings. Bertranda, the barber's wife in Forbach, confessed that on such occasions she, with her anointed right hand, plucked at her companion's ear, whereupon he then fell asleep. Exactly the same thing occurs in the trial of the witch of Loches in Bodin, who calls it a matter still quite fresh in memory. She and her husband are transported from Loches to the heaths of Bordeaux, fifteen days' journey away. The husband says: "My God, where are we?" Immediately everything scatters; there is a trial, and the woman confesses everything without coercion. Thus in the year 1525 a girl from the duchy of Spoleto, thirteen years old, is led in by a witch; the girl, amazed at all she sees, cries out: "Blessed God, what is this?" Everything has vanished; in the morning a peasant finds her in the field.

Torquemada, in the third book of his work, relates: a sorcerer persuades a man to ride with him, and the latter consents. He then takes him by the hand, and they fly through the air very far off. There they find the Sabbath assembled. But the newcomer loses patience and cries out: "God --- what a great noise!" Immediately a whirlwind and a storm break in, and everything is scattered. It takes him three years before he comes back to his native place. The generality and indefiniteness with which these narratives are framed proves that they rest upon popular legend. This legendary character appears still more plainly in what William of Newburgh relates of an incident that happened, when he was still a boy, in the province of Deir, not far from his birthplace. \[Page 155\]

From a place near the eastern sea, where the river Vispe is situated, a peasant had gone to visit his friend in the neighbouring village and returned late at night in a not entirely sober frame of mind. From the nearest hill, not far from the road --- the one I have often seen --- he heard the voice of a merry company. He wondered who could make such a noise so late at night; and when he saw a door in the side of the hill, he went in to look. He found there a large, brightly lit chamber, and many men and women sitting as at a feast. One of the serving attendants, when he saw him standing in the doorway, brought him a cup, which he took; but, because he hesitated to drink, he poured out its contents; then he tucked the cup away and withdrew. Thereupon there arose an uproar inside on account of the cup; the guests pursued him, but he escaped them thanks to the excellence of his horse, and reached his home safely. The cup, of unknown material, unusual colour and peculiar shape, came to the elder Henry, King of England; then to David, the brother of the Queen, and long preserved in the Scottish treasury. A few years ago, as the legend says, it was handed over to King Henry II, who wished to see it, by the Scottish William. The hill in this tale is the old Benusberg, into which the Wild Host rides every year; the cup, however, is the Oldenburg drinking-horn which Count Otto won in the hunt from the maiden who, emerging from the Osen- or Asen-mountain, offered it to him filled with a draught which he poured out; the horn, spurring his horse, he carried away. The Teutonic legend, transplanted to England, there received only local colouring. \[Page 156\]

But this legend takes another turn again in an inquiry conducted by Remy, where it appears as if it were a historical happening. In Lützen, at the foot of the Vosges, in May of the year 1580, the neighbours celebrated a kind of carnival; and Claudius Chotey had returned at night to the place Wisembach. He had already half climbed the mountain that lay between the two places; then, in an otherwise clear, calmer air, he was seized by a vortex and now looked about him, astonished at what might be happening around him. There, at a place apart on the edge of the cliff, he saw six masked women dancing around a table set with many silver and gold vessels, flinging their heads about like the possessed; with them, on a black ox, sat a man who watched their revels. When he stood there, to look at the matter more closely, all was lost to his eyes. He went forward, and when he had already come over the crest of the mountain, he saw those women following him, still silently swaying their heads. Before them was the one with the dark face who made at him a clawing look; but he defended himself against her with his sword, so that the assailant fled. The women in the meantime returned with their leader a third time, and Chotey, now bolder, went nearer and recognised Desiderius Garete, to whom he then gave his word that he would keep secret what he had seen. Another vortex or mist seized him again and brought him to a distant place, from which he at last reached his home. He had reported it to the magistrate. The same had, however, nearly in the same words been told to the magistrate by Barbelina Careta, one of the women, adding: Desiderius had purchased the witness's silence with much wheat and two grown calves; and it was not true, as he had said, that they had attacked him because he had come too near the table, but because he had attempted to steal a cup.

One sees that a private carnival-night lay at the root of the whole scene; it was held in the darkness of the forest, and night and wine did the rest. This is also confirmed by the third form of the tale, as told by Joachim Kämmerer of Bamberg. A butcher was walking through a little wood at night; there he hears a noise and a dancing, goes up to it --- and the dancers vanish. He now sees silver goblets standing there, takes them, and brings them to the authorities. They thereupon arrest, as witches, those whose marks were upon the goblets, together with others who had been denounced, and execute them all together. That they, says Lerchheimer of Steinfelden (who tells the story), were witches is to be inferred from the fact that they had accused others whom the devil, in a dream --- as if they had been together there --- had shown to them. They had lain at home and slept; meanwhile the devil kept watch, and carried the goblets from their benches to that place. Who would willingly keep a feast and dance by night in the rough, dark wood, in the wind, in cold and rain? Their goblets were found there, therefore they had been there. \[Page 157\]

By the same line of reasoning it once happened that, in a distinguished city in Germany, the authorities were deceived so far as to hang an innocent locksmith because his lock-picks had been found at a place where money had been stolen from a chest. But another had taken his lock-picks and used them, which he afterwards confessed. Yes, some --- those who ought to admonish judges to fairness and leniency --- are so perverse toward the poor man: when the husband testifies about his wife that she was on that night, the very night she is said to have been at the dance and to have been seen there, never out of bed and lying on his side, then they say and argue: in the bed lay a specter, but the true body had been outside. Dear sirs, why do you not invert this and interpret it --- not to the devil's discredit, but for the good of man --- so that the true body lay in bed and the false one was outside? Is it not a principle with you that, in doubtful matters, one should always prefer the milder to the harsher? --- One must say there is good and sound common sense in these words. Meanwhile many of the accused themselves had voluntarily sworn: they had left their child's pillows in the bed in their place; others a broom, a scarecrow, or even their own spirit as a succubus.

The age that entertained such an excess of belief that the ordinary, prosaic world thereby stood in danger of disappearing in the same way as the invisible world is in danger now through present unbelief, accepted this account without the smallest doubt. What Binsfeld, an upright and very reliable man, relates from the Trier records may well demonstrate the possibility of such real abductions; but it does not suffice to establish the reality of such assemblies. He adduces, first, a noteworthy example of an invisible child-abduction to prove the power of imperceptible forces in the matter. The wife of Johann Eysenkopf, a burgher of Wilmar, called Margaretha, had borne a little boy named Conrad. A spirit often stole him from the cradle, before and after her laying-out \[i.e. the funeral-like rite?\] --- from the feast of the Resurrection to that of the Departure of the Apostles --- and carried him to other places. Once he laid him in the mother's bed, another time he hid him beneath the steps of the cellar-stair; at times he carried him to the loft or to the privy. But so that no harm should befall the child in these happenings, he always placed cloths under him which he had likewise secretly stolen from the parents.

Once, when the mother destroyed such a bed as the spirit had prepared in the bathing-room, her face and hands swelled up, as far as they were not covered by her clothes, and her skin peeled off. At times the spirit would also rock the little boy, and he always cried when his mother had put him into the cradle, but was perfectly calm when the spirit had carried him to another place. The dean of the place, W. Lyndner, wrote to Binsfeld for remedy, and the latter advised the use of sacramentals. They were applied, and the older people also undertook a pilgrimage, whereupon the matter subsided for a time. But soon the consecrated objects were found torn away, and the invisible one began his game again. All that was told had, at the dean's request, been authentically recorded by the local notary. \[Page 158\]

One sees that here again one of those spectral apparitions was at work. Binsfeld then relates further. On 22 September 1589 the peasant Michael from Longen, in the Amt of Pfalzel, was executed for witchcraft; he confessed among other things that he had been led at Christmas to the Sabbath at the cross of Longwich, on this side of the Moselle, but had only arrived there after the dispersal of the assembly. Thereupon he cried out, "Lord God, it is already over!" In the same instant he had fallen down into the field, and about eleven o'clock at night had gone to the Moselle, put himself into a boat across the stream, and gone to bed. In the year 1591, on 4 May, Martin of Corlingen was burned there; he confessed that twice, on the return from the Sabbath, he had been thrown into the bushes near Pellingen because he had said, "O God, how did we come to be here?" Once, he said, when during the dearth he had bought a sack of wheat in the town, he had been carried over the wall together with the purchase. Anna Meisenbein of Cologne had gone to the assembly on the Hetzenrodter heath; after its conclusion she quarrelled with her daughter and beat her in the presence of her son. The mother, the daughter, and the son had all given this account in complete agreement.

One sees that these statements are entirely authentic; the people express their full conviction. But in order to draw from them a decisive conclusion as to the tangible reality of the occurrences, it would first have to be determined whether what they report as having followed the Sabbath actually happened in such objective reality, or whether they did not experience it only in vision, perhaps in a lesser degree of the same. Thus, after everything is carefully considered, among the facts adduced for bodily excursions there is not a single one that has been clearly and incontrovertibly established as proof of what it purports to prove. Only a few related cases: for example, where the servant of a woman in Oostbruck, in the reed-swamp, was found with his feet dislocated, whom his wife had thrown down during Ascension; she, being taken in and examined by Judge J. Culemberg of Utrecht, confessed the matter without evasion. This and some similar occurrences seem to indicate that in rare cases, as a consequence of a specific lightness (a levity) occurring in demonic states, just as in ecstatic ones, such sorties may indeed take place. But the circumstance that such things have, on the whole, only rarely occurred among ecstatic persons; and still more, that there is not a single example on record in which a number of them ever assembled together in such a way, for instance to celebrate a communal act of worship; ought to have made contemporaries cautious and to have restrained their judgment: since it is by no means credible that the devil and his prestidigations should be allowed a wider scope than the Lord permits Himself to take. Thus the only generally admissible supposition remaining is that the excursion took place in the vision. Whoever has entered into the state of ecstasy finds himself transferred into a region more interior than that in which he was situated under natural conditions. In the latter case his spiritual inwardness is, throughout the extent of his bodily outwardness, present everywhere; and it accomplishes his will, with more or less freedom, throughout that whole sphere. \[Page 159\]

In the other case another sphere, surrounding that outwardness, is drawn into his domain, and is as it were embodied and subjectivized; and he rules, within this circumference that has fallen to him, as he formerly ruled in his body; if not absolutely, yet with respect to certain powers. If therefore he directs his intention to a certain point which lies within the sphere that has thus newly grown for him, then he will be spiritually present at that place; and since for that he does not need to separate himself from the body in order to get to the spot, because the object rather comes to him, he will also feel this body as present just there, and in spiritual optics all around him everything will appear perfectly as if he had truly gone to the place in person. The body meanwhile remains fixed and petrified at its place; for it has, in its outward relations, become an object, like one among the others that surround the personality.

But with that very thing the awakening of the inner spirituality is purchased; and this now begins, upon the basis of personal and impersonal outwardness, the interplay of higher forces which govern space and are not governed by it. This, as we have seen before, has been the case in many ways in the higher ecstasy, where the spirit, torn away from itself, enters into the inwardness of the Lord. It will happen just the same in demonic ecstasy, where the spirit indeed has been pressed down beneath itself, but in the abyss of the same finds, though negative exponents, in an imitative reproduction of the ascending positives --- which rise one above another upwards, but downwards in the others are reflected not as in their image and likeness, but in the full opposite, the non-image and the un-likeness. In this distorted un-imageness everything that issues from the new relation --- thus being and present-being at a distance --- is now effected. In the higher ecstasy this being is not merely truth; rather, because it occurs in the root of all truth, it is root-truly true, from which all ordinary truth is first derived. Here, however, because it occurs in falsehood, it is in falsehood, but with the full semblance of truth; and because it clings to a concrete reality, it intrudes with all its evidential force. The personality thus altered, or rather depressed, will therefore fancy itself present at the place of its intention, and will be spiritually truly present.

If several such personalities, bound by the same rapport to a ruling centre, are also united in their intentions, for example directed toward the same locality, then they will likewise find themselves transported toward that place; and as the directions of their striving converge on the same point, they will assemble about it in a circle which people are accustomed to call the Sabbath, or also the Synagogue, and which they reach by the outing --- the act of putting oneself out of oneself and of transferring oneself thither. \[Page 160\]

The critical days of the Sabbath are well known to the initiated; they therefore urge one another not to miss the gathering, and are also sometimes admonished by their spirits. In earlier times much is also said of the noise of the procession which, led by its queen, swept past the houses of the laggards and reminded them to join. They anoint themselves when they still require it, or when it pleases them so to do; but those who have attained greater practice need it in no way --- as many examples shown in the arrested, and many witness statements, attest. The ointment was rubbed on the naked body, sometimes also applied to the clothes, which nevertheless appeared no less clean and neat on the Sabbath. Maria d'--- of Handaye had testified against Mariacho de Moleres: when they wished to set out, she had anointed her hands, loins and knees with a thick, greenish water, and the witness then, seizing her, led her away. One sees that each must either have been in that same state of ecstasy, or the anointing itself must already have belonged to her. Occasionally already a very lively desire is sufficient to produce the rapture.

Catharina de Landalde, thirty years old, from the parish of Ustaritz, confessed that when she sat in the evening by the fire such a desire came upon her to go to the Sabbath that she had never felt so violent and irresistible a longing for anything as at that time. She then always went there on foot, without any sleep, dreams, or illusions having been produced in her, nor could any doubt arise in her about the reality of what she had seen. It is readily seen that in her a favourable disposition had been well formed by long practice; only an instantaneous, scarcely perceptible passage through the sleep-state was required, and she awoke inwardly with such clearness of what was seen that, as she with equal swiftness passed into the waking state, the memory of what had been seen, likewise without visible transition, attached itself to the circle of ideas of the new sphere. \[Page 161\]

The going on foot, as it showed itself in her, is moreover the one and first type of outing. Maria de Ralde, twenty-eight years old, confessed that she sometimes, in the company of all her neighbours, went to the Sabbath on foot. They then advanced so swiftly as if they had flown, and in a moment arrived at the place. Each time, when she thus found herself united with her companions, she felt a marvellous contentment; for the devil binds the will of those who have been in the assembly only once or twice so firmly that no other desire or longing easily comes to equal it. Other accounts by such persons, who in this way went to the Sabbath or returned from it leading children by the hand, confirmed this information. They were conscious of all the circumstances of their going, which people they met, whom they called upon; and all together affirmed the full reality and corporality of the perceptions they had experienced. But this was not only the case in the Basque country, but elsewhere as well. The Lotharingian women of Pangra likewise asserted that they always went on foot; only when they came to a body of water did the spirit carry them across. If Satan was present there, he as a rule appears as the guide of the travelling witch-women. He summons them or has them summoned at the appointed hour; those who happen to be asleep are inwardly awakened, and then behold the leader in the form of a horse, ass, ox, pig, poodle or billy-goat, and sometimes of a bird, which takes them upon its back. At times even that is unnecessary; any object to which the vision can attach itself---a stick or broom, a spindle-distaff, a pitchfork, anointed or unanointed---already suffices. Sometimes they imagine themselves winged and skim over wide countries. Sometimes only the crown of the head is anointed; children taken by the armpits must sit in front and are carried in that way. Occasionally several of those bound in closer fellowship mount the same pack-beast, and it then proceeds with the cry: "Up on and nowhere!" into the air; most beloved is it in the smoke of the element which, among all, by its nature rises upward from their hearth; sometimes, however, it also goes from some crossroads to which they repair. If meanwhile rain falls, the cry among the Welsh---"Haut la coude Quillet!"---causes the beast with its tail to shield the carried ones from all wetting. The crowing of the night watch and the early morning messenger is exceedingly hateful to the riders; nothing can be more hostile and vexatious to them than his cry when it rings in the ears of those prepared for the ride. Likewise hostile to them are the ringing of bells, and the utterance of the name "Jesu" likewise breaks the charm. Yet the outing must by no means be regarded as effortless; for those led in it grow so weary as if they had traversed a long, rough road on foot; and Barbara Ragel often had to keep her bed for three days after such a journey, and could not stand on her feet.

#### B. The Sabbath as the Court of the Witchly Retinue

\[Page 162\]

The Sabbath is as a rule held upon the mountain which is visible at the greatest distance round about in the district. There is appointed, there, a desolate heath without access, path or dwelling in the neighbourhood, preferably not far from a lake or running water, as the place of meeting. More spacious must these places be for the larger assemblies; in the Basque country the largest was on Mount Rhune and was called Aquelarre, the billy-goat slope. Closer assemblies are held in narrower and more secret places. Often they are open spaces near towns, by large buildings or churches, near the main gate, opposite the high altar when the church is built in the centre. Sometimes they are solitary churches and chapels, in the neighbourhood of which the meeting is held; sometimes even within them, as in the Blessed Spirit Chapel on the Rhune, or in the church of Dordach according to judicial testimony. Sometimes they are old masonry, the ruins of fallen castles scattered on the heights; remote churchyards, or otherwise conspicuous objects, as in the Basque country the so-called Portuguese Chapel at St. Jean de Luz, which serves as a beacon to the ships. A regular order is observed in the selection of all these places. The most private gatherings, at which only the nearest confederates are present, are held in the houses about their centre; often, as the investigation showed, to spite the courts, in the very buildings inhabited by the judges.

Those for whole parishes are celebrated in their vicinity, so that a single parish will often have several; and after the conclusion of one at a given place, the participants will often move on to another in order to begin a second, to which other participants then join themselves. Provincial assemblies for entire provinces are then gathered on prominent mountains, whence comrades assemble from the wide district. (1) The Master of the Chair insists that every comrade remain steadfast to his own fellowship. A girl who lived in St. Pée was, according to the testimony of fifteen witnesses, never seen at the Sabbath there; she had to move over to Sare, the place of her birth. (2)

At times it is some other object which attracts the general attention of an entire region, and then becomes the common point of attraction for the whole neighbourhood. Such is, from Lombard times, the famous walnut-tree of Benevento, around which the bona societas of Italy gathered for their games; and thus many old thunder-oaks will have become sabbath-oaks. One sees that any object, conspicuous enough that the intent of many can be directed toward it, is fit for this purpose; best when it belongs to the church, because the curse is wont to cling to the blessing. Therefore the whole arrangement of the infernal Sabbath is modelled on the ecclesiastical one. Just as the churchly order rises from the household meeting to the brotherhoods in chapels and oratories; just as the populace of a town and district collect into parishes, and these into deaneries, which again are gathered into a bishop's diocese: so is the anti-church society subdivided in the same sequence of stages, united in likewise increasingly prominent meeting-places.

Therefore the times on which these gatherings fall are appointed in the order of the ecclesiastical festival calendar; as the old Bacchic orgies probably submitted to the phases of the moon and their conjunction with the positions of the sun. As the Turks celebrate Friday, the Jews the Sabbath, the Christians the Sunday, so these above all have chosen Thursday; and the Sabbath then falls about midnight, from eleven o'clock until one or two, preferably on stormy nights. Sometimes, however, the night from Friday to Saturday is appointed. So in France; in Castile, according to the statements of those from Logroño, three days---Monday, Wednesday and Friday---are set aside for it. The smaller gatherings, however, are held on almost every night; on Sundays rarely, because it is believed that the sorcery loses its power on that day. Midnight is not, however, absolutely exclusive; the Spaniards already went at nine o'clock in the evening, stayed until midnight, and vanished at the first crowing of the cock. Catharina von Naguille even testified that she had been there at broad daylight, because after a night watch in the church she fell asleep at eleven in the morning. All these small festivities which they held in parishes at individual places they nevertheless call merely "merriments" (esbats), celebrated on the spot. But four times a year, at Easter and at the other great church festivals, the great procession to the Bockshaide is undertaken, in mockery of their service; which, according to the records, was already held in Labourd in the year 1567. (k) The most solemn of all nights, however, was that of St. John the Baptist, about the summer solstice; above all others a night of the greatest dissolution and licentiousness.

Blokula was the name of the place of the Sabbath among the Norse in Mohra and in Elfdale. It was a beautiful pasture; so large that no end of it could be seen. A spacious house had before it a smaller enclosed pasture, to which a large painted gate led; there they let the animals on which they had ridden walk. The human shapes that served for this, however, lay sleeping, leaning against the wall by the door. In a large room of this house stood a long table at which they took their meals. Adjoining this room was another chamber in which stood some finely dressed beds. One sees it is a Swedish country-house, as magnificent as the imagination of simple folk could conceive; elsewhere there is sometimes talk also of gardens and palaces. All those, then, who, directed by their inner intention, meet together in the same space --- just as they, in the exalted sense, behold the whole spatiality, with all its circumstances, rocks and waters and trees, and, on awakening from their rapture, are able to give exact account of all the circumstances --- so they also recognize one another, insofar as they stand in relation to one another. Therefore the reports about the frequency of the Sabbaths all agree in large numbers streaming together there. Even at the festivals of a lower order Katharina Kuffa, from Vellen on the Moselle, counted more than many assembled, and indeed far more women than men. At the larger gatherings it was once estimated --- on the heath of Hunderalse near Handaye --- that the number of those present exceeded 12,000. So many people streamed in from all quarters that one who had been there testified in court that so many had crowded together there as there are stars shining in the sky. Janua von Banno in Lorraine, however, said that, on account of the multitude of those present, it astonished mankind. \[Page 163\]

One sees that demonic vision, as it plunges deeper into the abysses of things, embraces not only great masses of outward objects but also distinguishes them down to the most particular; it is therefore by no means necessarily unclear and confused. More women, however, are present than men; because more of the weaker, more mobile sex, disposed in degeneration toward sensuality and revengefulness, incline to these ways --- for the same reason why, in the Fall, woman fell first. A part of those present appear open and unveiled; others are wrapped in veils and to the rest indistinguishable; as some interpret this, to make the assembled mob believe that there were mighty and rich people in their midst. In truth, however, it is the same symbolic mode of expression that is found with those endowed with the second sight. Those who are only imperfectly in the bond, or who have entered it only with reservation, appear veiled; because the sense is closed to them. The same symbolism also appears in the frequent metamorphoses of form which prevail at the Sabbath. To the inner sense only the innermost in every thing stands and remains; the outward, as the accidental, is subject, in great mobility, to facile change.

Jeannette of Belloc, twenty-four years old, who had been present at the Sabbath since early youth, related: it is there like at a fair. Many walked about in human shapes; others were transformed into dogs, cats, asses, horses, pigs. Yet she added that she had never been able to learn the manner of this transformation, and had only seen all those animals running about there; they could also, at will, make themselves very small, and again as tall as houses.

Jeannette d'Abadie, however, testified how she had been present when this one and that one were transformed into a wolf, a dog, etc.; how they washed their hands in a water which they had kept in a pot with them. They would then at pleasure resume their former shape; and all this not only on the Sabbath, but on the way to it and everywhere. They thereupon vanished so that one saw only a shimmer of them. Both witnesses agreed: there is a constant coming and going; some flew up into the air; others still higher heavenward, while others settled lower down on the land. Some plunged into kindled fires like rockets or lightning; they also went in crowds to do this, and on return related how they had been in Newfoundland within the past two or three hours; how they had sat upon the mast of this or that ship, but could not step aboard because it had been blessed; instead, there they raised a storm in the rigging. They had seen all their own beyond, and which of their relations, who were notoriously in America, had been in their company.

One sees: it is a host encampment of mythical fowl, to which the power of metamorphosis has been given. The Sabbath likewise has its herds and its shepherdly order; those are formed by toads, while boys and young girls make the shepherds who tend them. In the Parsee doctrine they are the devouring kharfesters: snakes, scorpions, and toads, created by Ahriman, the principle of Evil. The shape, kind, and nature of these animals are so fashioned that the disgust with which they fill men appears to him as a warning of a treachery lurking within, which the first two are also completely justified in by the poison they brew. The toad, for its part, since it also seems to possess the entire apparatus for that purpose, has at all times kept suspicion awake against itself. \[Page 164\]

Abbe Rousseau relates in the tenth section of his Remed Secretorum how he had kept one of these animals enclosed in a glass, with the intention of letting it die in its prison, as he had already done with some others. Once, after watching for a while the most strenuous efforts the toad made to get out, it suddenly turned upon him, rose up, swelling itself in an extraordinary way, lifted itself up on its legs to a great height; and then blew, without moving from its place, around itself. The enraged creature looked at him with eyes that, imperceptibly, seemed to become quite red and fiery, so that in that very moment a weakness came over him which made him swoon. A cold sweat ensued, and a flux set in, both of the bowels and of the urine; and his condition was such that his people thought him dead and lost.

The account proves, if not with certainty the physical harmfulness of the animal, at least the injurious effect produced by the deeply rooted belief in its poisonous nature. Thus it will be the most apt symbol in the northern countries to express the inward-closed, poison-swollen, treachery-breeding power of Evil and of witchcraft. Just as doves and other birds, lambs, hares, stags comported themselves tamely toward the saints, so the toad will in particular be the beast of the monsters. It will furnish a suitable ingredient in the poison-kitchen, and appear as the most fitting form into which the witch herself is metamorphosed, or in which the evil spirit hides itself. Therefore the toad has always played a large role in the witchcraft realm. Peter Grey of Toulouse already relates: an unhappy priest from the diocese of Soissons had asked a witch in what manner he might most effectually take revenge on his enemies, and she had advised him: to baptize a toad under the name of John, and then cause it to eat a consecrated host. After that he was to tear it apart, and might prepare from it a poison that would bring death to all his enemies; which indeed happened. The affair was discovered, and she was handed over to the flames. That took place in the year 1460. Therefore it is these creatures that form the flock of the Sabbath. There they are herded by children at a brook, to whom a white rod is given for the purpose. The animals are clothed in red or white velvet, have a small bell at the neck, and sometimes on the feet; and witnesses testified that they had seen the daughter of the Lady of Martibelsarena dancing at the Sabbath with four such animals; she carried one so clothed on her left shoulder, an unclothed one on the right, and two similar ones on her fists, like a huntsman his hawks. \[Page 165\]

They dance before their masters on the Sabbath, and present their complaints when they have not been well kept. That is the idyll of the Sabbath; they are the little lambs of the local Pegnitz-shepherds. "I too have been in Arcadia," his initiates can attest; and naive innocence still maintains, in the midst of a debauched life, its right, lavishing all its tenderness on the most unlovely of all animals. But not only those bound together in the same principle recognize one another in the vision, and all that in nature belongs to their circle; they also peer into the realms of spirits, to whose powers they are attached, and the depths of those realms are opened to their exalted eye.

Yet this glance into its home is not granted to the evil eye alone; the good eye is likewise not denied sight of the regions where ruin has taken up its dwelling; and we shall do well, with it, first to inquire what it beholds of them and of their circles, before we allow the demonic apparitions to pass over us. Herbert, a contemporary of St. Bernard --- round whom a whole world of visions disclosed itself --- tells us something like this of a friend of his youth, the hermit Dominicus. He had formerly lived in the Cistercian monastery Carrezeda near León, and was then dismissed by the abbot into solitude, dwelling near that city in a mountain cave, practising the strictest continence; almost shut off from all intercourse with the world, devoting himself to contemplation; burning with love of God, and in a wonderful way endowed with the gift of tears.

Once he sat at the entrance of his cave, his gaze turned toward heaven, attentively following the light of a sunbeam to its source. Suddenly he perceived the shape of a burning dragon, which, descending in that very ray, in a violent plunge threw itself toward his face as if to devour it. Terrified by the apparition, he crouched inward; called on the Lord, and made the sign of the cross against the assailant. Driven off, it was yet able to do nothing against him, but it flew constantly about him and would not leave him. He then shut his eyes and covered his face with his garments; but that availed him nothing, for he saw the figure with closed eyelids as though with them open; and this penetrating, subtle being could not be repelled by clothing. When he saw, therefore, that he could not escape the sight, he opened his eyes again, and let them behold that whose attack he could not prevent. Then other demons likewise came to light in serpent form and other animal shapes, in hordes, and filled the dwelling from top to bottom.

Among them there was so great a diversity of dimensions, such variation in their properties, and such ugliness in their forms that it cannot be described, and many of them were fire-colored. They swarmed about him like bees, flared up like fire in a thorn-bush, dashing at him with angry movements and attacking him with blows. But although they appeared fiery, they by no means had the power to burn. For though they flew around him in a circle, and, sweeping past him at the swiftest speed, often struck his face, they did indeed press upon him in every way, but never harmed him with fire. When he then again went out somewhat before the door, to breathe somewhat from the oppression; there also appeared to him whole heaps of demons, in great swarms traversing the air, and filling everything from the earth to the heaven. These too were so manifoldly graded, so terrible through their extraordinary appearance, so gruesome through their ugliness: that human senses could not endure such a confluence of monsters, had not the power of Heaven assisted them. \[Page 166\]

He shared with me at that time the observation: these impure spirits had not laid aside the spiritual forms in which they always appeared to him in the air before the sign of the cross; but rather those into which they had fantastically transformed themselves. From then on, until the day of writing it down, the man of God saw these visions daily while awake; both in daylight and in the nocturnal darkness, with closed eyes just as with open. But the terror and the distress which he had at first entirely vanished; so that in the end he made no more of them than if they were flies or other vermin. For the light-spirits also visited him, and filled him with their consolations; however, about their forms he never, out of discretion, spoke to me.

These perceptions found themselves confirmed by others, from a monk of Clairvaux, whom Herbert does not name, because he was still alive at the time; who however had spent 40 years there in all holiness, and among other gifts also had such a lively inner eye: that with it, at a dying fellow brother, he saw the soul going out like a smoke from the censer, which then, when it had fully risen, remained hovering for a time in a round-clumped little cloud, transparent and about the size of a bushel, four to five ells above the corpse; until the brothers who had hurried there completed the funeral rites.

This one now, as often as he looked up into the air with a sharper gaze, likewise beheld, with his bodily eyes, in broad daylight swarms of demons roaming everywhere; in such numbers that their count could not be estimated. They appeared in manifold forms; one of these misshapen ones however was predominant. According to their bodily outlines they seemed to be monstrous men, of giant stature, black as Moors, nimble as serpents, wild as lions. They had thick heads, misshapen bellies, and were besides crooked and hunchbacked, with long and thin necks; while arms and legs likewise stretched themselves beyond all measure in length. When they halted somewhere in the air, then he could distinctly distinguish their forms, limb by limb; but if they roamed about in it with agile movement, then he saw nothing of them but mere larval shadows and tangles of whirlwinds.

On bright days, when the sun in its full power shines through the airs, then he was accustomed to see these visions the best, and to distinguish them the most clearly. When however he once also spent deep into the night in prayer, suddenly the hairs of his body began, in night terror, to bristle; and he saw masses of these demons crowding through the doors, and filling the whole house; so that piled up everywhere, they struck at the one praying. He made use of the sign of the cross and the angelic salutation, and thereby drove all the boisterous guests out of his oratory. In the following night he heard them again striking violently against the wall; and when he looked up, he saw in the window One, winged like a griffin or ostrich, standing, threatening him with its assault, which he however drove away in the same manner.

These views of spiritually sensitive men are presented here, as one easily recognizes, with the same fidelity, simplicity, and the same color and physiognomy of truthfulness, as the reports of a naturalist who has perhaps sharpened his senses through an especially light-strong microscope; and now recounts to us his observations made on the winged infusoria of the air, which he has discovered. One does not see why one should grant belief only to his report alone, and not also make the others the object of closer investigation; since nothing stands in the way except the unusualness of the matter. \[Page 167\]

Those now who have seen these appearances had their intention originally not directed toward them; it was much more turned away from them by them; they had with all the power of their will armed from Above opposed themselves to the approaching ones, and so they had had to seize flight before them. But the demonic ones have now sunk this their intention entirely into them; they are devoted to them with all their affects, and lure them toward themselves. Before these, therefore, they do not flee; they, winged as they are, carry off the ones sunk into them well themselves with them, lending them their own wings, to those nodal points on earth where the demonic entwines itself with the natural, and in the meshes of the great net the threads of the one cross through those of the other.

This out come in the spirit, it is the sally forth; the place to which it goes is the site of the Sabbath: that nodal point which the fleeing shadows circle, where the settling, permanent ones have already chosen their seat. To them the ones striving into this realm are led by those messengers, and admitted to the community of the settlers. Their companionship they will now likewise behold in the spirit; according to the measure of the type which appears implanted in human nature, and in whose forms it must grasp the ideas offering themselves; the good ones in beautiful, inner harmony, the fallen ones in distortion and in dissonance. Let us see what the judicial testimonies about these types report to us: varying, as is comprehensible, in the apprehension of them, according to the turbidity or clarity of the beholding.

Maria de Ralde, who since her tenth year had visited the Sabbath, but for five years had given up the abomination, testified: she had there seen the Satan for the first time in the form of a tree stump, without feet. He seemed to sit on a chair, with something that looked like a human face, but as if covered with darkness. From there downward she saw him more clearly, in the form of a man, either of red or black color. Usually it is a stone that stands in the middle of the place, on which the one whom they call the Lord or also the Master sits.

Beside that tree-like form, like an old cypress or oak struck by lightning, and dried up from the top downward, it is now especially the form of the goat that he loves to assume. But if he appears in human form, then he presents himself in the form of a tall, black man, red and flaming like a fire that bursts from the oven, whose forms appear only halfway; with a broken, inarticulate, but commanding, noisy and terrible voice; often done in such a way that it is hard to distinguish whether it is man, animal, or tree trunk. He sits in a chair, apparently gilded, but glowing; the queen of the Sabbath, whom he has taken for himself from the initiates, in all splendor and glory at his side. Everything around, persons and things, appears in a false nothing; all forms in the enormous, gigantic or dwarfed and shifted. Jeanette d'Abadie saw him with six, sometimes eight horns, a long tail, and a double face. Sometimes there are two of them present: a Grand Master Leonard, and a smaller one, whom the Basques called Master Jean Mullin, and whom the former, in his absence, substituted in his place. \[Page 168\]

The prisoners from Logroño saw him sitting on a black chair, so terrible and abominable that it cannot be described. He had a crown of black horns, among which three were very large, like those of a goat, the others smaller; two at the neck, one on the forehead, which illuminated the entire Sabbath with a light stronger than that of the moon, weaker than sunlight. His hair was disheveled, his face is pale and distorted.
