He has round, large, wide-open eyes, glowing with it and terrible to behold; a goatee beard, the form of the neck and the rest of the body ill-shaped, half human, half goat; hands and feet shaped humanly; the fingers of the hands all of equal length, tapering to a point and clawed; the feet like goose feet, with a donkey's tail besides. On the Sabbath he appears under a kind of throne canopy, of poor cloth, but fitted out in strange forms. His voice is terrible, but without resonance; when he speaks, it is as if a mule were braying; his tone inarticulate, biting and hard to understand. He maintains, however, always great gravity and haughtiness, combined with the bearing of a melancholic person who is always bored.

One sees that our poets, who in recent times have greatly endeavored to depict for us the personality of the King of the nocturnal realms, have devised nothing more striking in form and bearing than these women from the common folk have beheld. There must well be a ground of truth underlying their visions on both sides, which they have only further elaborated; and which then again other youths strive to express as mimetically as possible in their bearing. Beside this Master, however, there are still many other demons of every order present in the lodge; and indeed, as one who belonged to the higher ones testified, more in number than humans. They undertake manifold tasks, set the tables, procure all necessities, consort with men and women as succubi and incubi, serve as cupbearers, assist at the sacrifice, transform themselves into animals, manage the musical exercises at the Sabbath, and as attendants are often assigned to the women in the form of toads. Many of the latter had closely observed these their spirits, and said of them: they had a dark, black face, deep eyes sparkling like flames; a wide, deep, always foul-smelling maw, exhaling like a sulfurous vapor; rough, hairy hands with sharp claws; feet with cloven hooves, and in their shape always without proportion, either too small or too large, and otherwise without all measure.

Aleria Belhora of Blamweiler saw them sometimes without a head, sometimes with only one foot. These spirits, although according to another account they know many languages, yet always speak in the vernacular; and from it are also taken the names which they bear: Misfortune, Torment, Featherbrush etc. in German; among the Romance speakers, however: maistre persil, Solybois, Verdelet, Sautebuisson. But their voice too has something artificially made about it; three witnesses compared it to a sound coming forth from a barrel or a broken pot, small, soft, lisping. They are at the beginning quite kind and pious, and accustom one well to the like. To Mallot his one advises: to abstain from gluttony, unchastity and every wrong; he should always keep God before his eyes, give alms, fast twice a week, and not forget his daily prayer.

These figures are true goiters, begotten by the spirit as incubus with these women. He has impregnated her inner sense, and the female nature has then surrendered the material for the development of the germ; and since evil and falsehood can only incorporate themselves in disharmony, disproportion, distortion of all relations; so these acephalous beings, monstrosities, elves and evil things have emerged, in the sharpest consequential justice of the visionary formative nature.

#### C. The Homage Paid to the Master and the Round Dance Around Him

\[Page 169\]

If the Sabbath in the relation first described was a cookshop of the evil principle and the Venus mountain, whither the inflamed life pressed to enter as a guest with the food master, and to intoxicate itself in lust from his beaker; then the scene now passes over into the throne room of the imperial palace. The emperor, or his plenipotentiary, sits crowned on a golden seat, the chosen empress at his side; and the estates of the realm appear, to present their homage and to obtain investiture. But here the contradiction that lies in the whole relation steps forth most glaringly, and manifests itself in the sharpest irony. On the throne sits a goat or a goatish figure; for the inner essence will not and cannot hide itself. Just as the good fragrance in such an atmosphere yields place to the stench, so every beauty to ugliness. Where the immoderate holds sway, there can be no question of measured bearing, dignity and majesty; the opposite of all that is therefore demanded there by the circumstances. The homage will thus also be, in its forms, a sarcastic parody of all submission to the higher; nevertheless, it will express the surrender into the blindest servitude. The act of homage is fulfilled as the homage-payers kiss the posterior and anterior parts of the goat.

The face of man is held upright, his eye drinks in the light, his ear the sound-ether; while his mouth inhales the air, and in the exhaled air inscribes the thought in the word. Extremely characteristic is it that the goat-figure of the evil spirit is assigned a second face, turned downward; initiated into the night-realms of the depths; closely connected with all the excretory organs that open downward, and with all the paths through which life purifies itself in the refuse. On the middle of this face the kiss is pressed; and the kisser thereby pledges himself to eternal servitude under the absolutism of evil.

All who newly enter the circle---whether as children introduced into it by their mothers and relatives; whether already grown and led up for the first time by an earlier initiate---must begin by performing this homage. It repeats itself with all of them in every great celebration, which opens with this hand-kiss and only admits the most intimate to the kiss of the mouth. Every one who enters approaches the chair with fear and trembling, falls at the master's feet, and embraces his hips with humility; or all kneel before him with their backs turned to him, hands clasped together behind, and remain in this position until he bids them rise.

All who have performed the homage in such a manner have unanimously confessed: that once they have surrendered themselves to the devil, there is no more separation from him, and that their apostasy is punished with severe penalty; wherefore none of them ever dares to escape his tyranny. He indeed promises in all things the opposite of the Sermon on the Mount of the Savior: riches to the poor, joy to the sorrowful, power to the weak, beauty to the ugly, knowledge to the ignorant. But---and herein the falsehood of the matter steps forth most sharply---experience shows that there is nothing more wretched, more comfortless, more hateful, more ignorant, more tormented than those who have thus given themselves into his servitude. Never has one of them become more beautiful than she was before, or more insightful and lovable. \[Page 170\]

The money that he gives is an ideal one; it has validity only in the inner world; it is not even paper money, only a fabricated golden shimmer, like a will-o'-the-wisp hovering around a rotting plant, a moss, a shard, which in the real world immediately fades and vanishes. Not always does it seem permitted to them, on the other hand, to close their spiritual balance in the same coin; for there are some among them appointed to collect the penalties; who, for common or personal advantage---as is evident from the records---also exact them with sober courage. The rich in general buy off their offenses with an ox or a sheep, which is then offered up in the form of a sacrifice. Thus Desiderius Foucant, at St. Deodat, annually during the dog days on Mount Hupella in the Vosges, offered something of the sort to his spirit, though it had to be black. The poor give young chickens; some also their hair, small birds, money made of leather; and if they have nothing at all, then perhaps a straw, or whatever else the spirit provides; it is then already enough if they only willingly submit themselves to the Fendallasten. If one refuses, then it is scolded and beaten, falls into weakness, its children die, and its livelihood fails.

It is a common complaint that the Master always seeks pretexts to punish them mercilessly for disobedience or other faults; so that no peace is ever to be found with him. One is beaten to the point of death because he appeared late or not at all at the assembly. Another is kept suspended over the Moselle for so long, and threatened with drowning, until he promises that he will bewitch and kill another. Others must atone with severe strokes because they have caused no harm; often so harshly that they can scarcely breathe; for the disciplinarian has iron hands. At times they are scratched, of which Rosa Gerardina showed the marks. Often they are struck with illness; one must ruin her own livestock because she spared others; indeed, a third must carry out the imposed task---since she cannot execute it on the neighbor---on her own ten-year-old daughter. For that is their law and their way; and if several have drawn his retribution upon themselves, then the lot decides between them. Everywhere, therefore, the harshest and most burdensome servitude; and in this realm of the imagination, as they now customarily call it, the ironclad consequence reigns with oppressive tyranny. Therefore a woman from Biarritz, in the Basque country, forty years old, let herself out in streams of tears before the judges concerning the Sabbath: those are to be deemed fortunate who have never seen the Sabbath, or wished to see it, and who have never beheld with their eyes the Lou Peccat, as she called the Devil in Gascon. \[Page 171\]

He who binds himself to the Lord seeks to escape the dominion of fatality, whose tyranny has entered into him through sin, so that he may regain the freedom of the children of God. But he who holds to evil must stake the freedom that has still remained to him from that fall; and to the fatality that previously had only partially bound him in its chains, he will now entirely fall into serfdom. The realm of the Sabbath is therefore a realm of the most unlimited and absolute despotism, in a scope such as even the Orient does not know; more so even than the realm of Nimrod, the great hunter from the land of the Cushites. The well-ordered state seeks, through the power of the united good in men, to curb and master the evil that dwells in them; but this state, fashioned in the image and likeness of Hell, unites the evil in the bond of its center, in order thereby to bind and suppress the good; so that it is tolerated at most only as a means to lead to an evil end.

From a semblance of the freedom of the companions can therefore never be spoken in it; they must blindly surrender themselves to the perverse ruling will as tools; and this one, armed with them, rules and governs in this armament according to its pleasure. The despot on the throne is therefore the unconditional lord over the body and soul of his servants. Of both sexes, as evil is, the entire companionship of the Sabbath fills his harem, and he has set his favorites in it as kings and queens of the day; his chancellor with the staff watches over the order of the assembly; all the forces of the assembled are reined and bridled to him, and he directs them like the rider the horse that he has mounted. As now the heavenly bodies, one higher than the other, all however ultimately obey gravity; as the spirits of evil, opposite those of the good, stand ordered in their hierarchies; so it is also in the arrangement of the children of the night on their Mayfields.

The number nine rules in these hierarchies, and so it will also be the ruling one in these assemblies. Johannes de Vaulr von Stablo, questioned in his interrogations about how many lodges there were in the vicinity, named nine of them: Stablo, Hufalise, Trer, Tasgine, Cher, Malmedy, Salm, Valle; each had again designated various places where they might assemble; Stablo had four of them, among which Croeff on the Mosel belonged. All are subordinate to one another, like the hierarchies, from whose midst spirits preside over them; but the highest is the main lodge, and with it the council days are held, in the assembly of all superiors, and the resolved is then communicated to the others.

Just as this locally limited number of nine seems again to be a subordinate member of a higher number of nine, since de Vaulr also speaks of a further assembly at Utrecht, where he often went; so downward from the bodies of each individual assembly is again divided according to another number, which seems to be the number three. Three tables are accordingly at every Sabbath: at the first sit those who are called by de Vaulr *les brarsz hommes*, with their wives. They are the actual sorcerers and sorceresses, twelve in number, under the presidency of the directing spirit with two associates. At the second table find the initiates of the second order their place, who occupy themselves with maleficia; while at the third the novices assemble, who are occupied with the household of the Sabbath; and because they thereby come into frequent contact with children and the uninitiated, in order not to be betrayed, they go masked. \[Page 172\]

All sit in the order of their initiation at the tables; only those meritorious for the purposes of the society are promoted to higher rank. In the same order they possess power to do evil, honor and are honored. In Spain it was more the number twelve that ruled there; Pampelona was the main lodge, Barrabon its superior. There the initiates came with their masters from twelve Sabbaths in the round together, and threw themselves down before the grand master; on the homeward journey the air was entirely filled with the flying ones.

In the same principle the times were also divided, according to the order of the abominations to be practiced in them. On Sundays, according to some accounts, the orgies of unnatural lusts were held; on Thursday and Saturday those of bestiality and sodomy; on Wednesday and Friday those of blasphemy and the works for the satisfaction of revenge; Monday and Tuesday the Sabbaths of ordinary lusts. In nature the dominion expresses itself in the movement that it effects in the subjugated through the forces at its disposal. Thus the power of the sun can be recognized, in which she moves the wandering stars around herself. Among men one can easily discern the field commander's order of power in the tactical movements of the army; and the ancient war dances have turned the seriousness of these evolutions into aesthetic play; and the commanding word, spread out into song and music, directs all movements therein, interpreting them and circumscribing them with the rhythm.

Just so has the natural drive, in the relation of the sexes, by multiplying and regulating the movements, brought forth the moriscos, the fandango, the sarabands, and similar dances. The evil drive in man, when it has found its master and surrendered itself to his service, is now also driven by him in certain lines of movements, which, when brought into the form of a dance, symbolically represent the alternating relation of dominance and submissiveness. In these dances the Lord of the Sabbath will be the ring leader; around him as the center all the whirlings will move, and because the circle appears as the line of the strictest subordination, therefore they will most gladly be turned into roundness; but the center will enclose the formula and the word of all these circlings within itself. But because evil has no harmony in itself, therefore there will also be only dissonance in the music of this word; the song and the shouting, and the instrumental clamor will, according to the accounts of eyewitnesses, sound so repugnant and confused. One blows on a stick, as on a transverse flute; another treats a dead horse's skull like a zither; yet another strikes with a club against the oak tree, so that it sounds like drums and army kettledrums. A blind man, sitting on a two-branched tree, lets a tambourine resound; castanets are again handled by others; violins cut through the noise with sharp tones, and the spirits mix in their hoarse, hollow voices like muffled trumpets: Everything calls, rustles, roars, and howls wildly together; and the desolate clamor sounds like the charivari of the Sybarites at Athenaeus, when each one, unconcerned about the other, sings his own song. And after all the displeasure that those present may perhaps feel, they must still thank the spirit for the splendid music; and whoever resists wins only blows from it. \[Page 173\]

The dance is in its kind just as much the reverse of the usual dance order, precisely because it is meant to express a fundamentally inverted relation. In the center sits the master, if he does not himself join in, seriously on his chair, from time to time humming inarticulate tones. The companions then in the round, naked or also in their shirts, turning their backsides to him; each with her demon at her side, all grasping each other with hands laid on their backs, and now under the most obscene movements always turning to the left.

According to the statements of the initiates, there are three kinds of these dances. One in the manner of the gypsies, who are frequently found in the Labourd, the borderland of France and Spain. The second is in the manner of the peasants with jumps; but just like the previous one going in a circle. In the third the dancers are lined up in a straight line, but man and woman turned with their backs to each other; and now, as they move toward each other and away from each other, colliding together in a brutal manner in certain cadences. Sometimes, however, they are also positioned in such a way that alternately one faces outward, the other toward the center, and they now thus begin the round dance.

One sees that, through the turning of the back, the usual order of the dimensions is reversed; because what was below has become above, the rear side is also declared to be the front; and thus the left must also count as the side of honor. The commissaries in the Basque country attributed the backward-bent posture of the girls there to their frequent attendance at the Sabbath. But Prieras lets himself be heard thus concerning those in northern Italy: "Often boys and girls of 8--10--14 years convert there, upon the exhortations and persuasions of the inquisitors; who then, on account of the strangeness of the matter, are sometimes even bidden to perform the dances as they are customary at the Sabbath.

They carry it out, and prove that they possess a superhuman art therein. These dances differ from human ones in that the girl holds herself behind the man's back, and jumps not forward, but backward while going backward. At the end, when a bow is made to the presiding demon, they incline---always turning their backs to him---the head not forward, but backward; and they bend the foot likewise not backward, but forward, lifting it high. But all this is executed with such grace and charm that it cannot possibly be learned in a short time and at a young age. Whoever doubts these statements can easily convince himself by ocular proof in the region of Como or Brescia; even here in Rome through the testimony of Brother J. B. de Biqueria, prior of Briren, and others. It would be desirable that one of the venerable cardinals might have 10--12 of these boys and girls brought to Rome; to give the city this spectacle, and to draw the veil of unbelief from the eyes of many."

This demonic St. Vitus dance is now called the pavana among those in Belgium; and the earth where it has been danced is struck with the curse that it shall no longer grow green henceforth. In its course, songs are sung in crude melodies and obscene content; from time to time interrupted with exclamations, such as, for example, those from Logny cried: Har! Har! Devil! Devil! Jump here, jump there! Play there, play here! while meanwhile the others in the chorus called Sabbath! Sabbath! So that everything may show itself in proper contrast to the usual course of the world, the lame, the limping, the old cripples and the infirm must likewise be present, who then display themselves in the dance with the greatest ease and nimbleness. \[Page 174\]

After such a dance, the company doubtless also amuses itself in the tumbling school. Maria de la Parque of Handaye, aged 19--20 years, and several others with her testified: when they had been at the Sabbath one night, Domingina Maletena, up on the mountain of La Rhune, which stands high and broad on the border of three kingdoms, Navarre, France, and Spain, had entered into a wager with another whose name they mentioned to us, as to who could perform the most beautiful jump, and she had thereupon jumped down from the summit of the mountain to the sandy stretch between Handaye and Fontarrabie. That was nearly two hours' journey, and the other could not match her; she came only as far as the gate of one of the inhabitants of Handaye. They all assured: they had seen it quite clearly; they had gone down to them when the Sabbath was ending, and Domingina had waited for them to receive the prize of the wager. These are jumps such as the Indian ape Hanuman was wont to perform; and they cannot surprise us in such ones, who transport themselves from afar to any distance in a short space of time. But the unembarrassed quality in the testimony speaks for the certainty that the vivid plasticity of the vision affords. \[Page 175\]

The question arises: whether such a round dance, formed in the spirit of a distant community and submitted to its modulation, might also be seen by one who possesses the second sight? The following case, which Remy recounts, appears to decide the question affirmatively. When Nicolaa Laghernhard from the Garminger Mill went to Assencauria in August 1590, and was walking along the edge of a forest at bright midday, she saw in the adjacent field a circle of dancing men and women who, however, turned their backs to her. When she looked more closely, she noticed among the dancers some interspersed whose feet appeared to her shaped like goat feet. Half-dead with fright, she called out the name of Jesus and prayed that she might return safely and unharmed to her home. In an instant, all the dancers vanished, with one exception: Peter Grospetter by name, who also quickly ascended into the air, but in the ascent let fall a baker's brush, with which bakers are accustomed to clean the oven before inserting the bread. She herself was likewise seized by a violent gust of wind, so that she could scarcely draw breath; and when she arrived home, she lay sick in bed for three days. The talk spread quickly among the people from her relatives; and Peter, so as not to give the appearance of confirming the truth of the story through his silence, lodged a vehement complaint about it with the judge---but then let it drop, in order not to expose himself through the trial to greater prolixities and dangers. This increased the suspicion against him, as it was attributed to a bad conscience. The judge therefore inquired all the more earnestly into the life he led and his morals; and since he found sufficient cause, he had him arrested and brought him to a confession that was not entirely unwilling, as well as to the naming of those who had been with him. Among these were Barbel, the wife of Johann the stonemason from Dusa, and Mazetta, the wife of Lorenz from the same place, who in February and March 1591 confirmed his statements about the Sabbath and the spirits rubbed into the dance. To their testimony was now added another confirmation. Michael, the herdsman from Dusa, testified: he had been present at the affair as a piper, in that he had placed a round shepherd's staff to his mouth and fingered it around as if on a pipe. But when that Nicolaa, trembling, had called out "Jesus!" and thereby signed herself with the cross, he had fallen down from the high branch of the oak on which he had been sitting, and then been seized by the whirlwind and carried to the meadow where he had just before been tending the herd. For further confirmation of these statements, the place where the round dance had been performed was found trampled, as in a riding school where the horses go; but interspersed were traces of goat and cattle feet. These remained visible even when, in the following autumn, the plot was plowed under. Testimony was given by Nickel Klein, Desiderius Verner, and Gaspar the tailor, who were questioned about it by the judge. \[Page 176\]

The visiting of the Sabbath becomes, for those who have once taken a liking to it, like opium-eating in the Orient, a passion of which they can scarcely gain mastery. Johanna Dibasson, aged 25 years, said: the Sabbath is a true paradise, and there are more joys there than can be expressed. All who visit it find the time so short amid sheer lust and pleasure that they part from it only with regret and always feel a longing within themselves to return to it. Maria de la Ralde, a very beautiful woman who otherwise had not visited it for five years, likewise spoke of the yearning that had driven her there; so that, when she had been called to it, it had felt to her as if she were to go to a wedding.

It was not due to the freedom and licentiousness enjoyed there, as she herself stated that she had never seen whoring or fornication there; but because the spirit binds her heart and will in such a way that it allows scarcely any other desire. Furthermore, the companions held the Sabbath to be a place where a hundred thousand wondrous and unheard-of things can be seen, and so many various, melody-rich instruments can be heard, that they believe themselves enchanted as if in an earthly paradise. 1)

At court they often questioned her: what attraction the Sabbath could possibly hold for her, since even merely hearing of its abominations and its filth makes the skin shudder? But she replied without concealment: they hear and see all these abominations with a wondrous lust and a raving desire to be present at them; the interval from day to night, when they could set out on the journey, seems to her all too long; the hours until then creep by for them with unbearable slowness, but there, in the enjoyment of so many delights, they pass with all too swift haste. All the abominations, all the terrors and shadows pass by so lightning-like quickly, and vanish so suddenly, that no displeasure or pain finds time to master their soul or body. Thus nothing remains behind but the feeling of astonishment at so much that is new pressing in upon them, satisfying their curiosity, and satiating all their desires, whether of amorous or vengeful kind. These are truly joys beyond human nature, and not of Jewish origin! 7

### Chapter 3. Personal States of the Spiritual Man in the Lord and in Sorcery

If Satan on the first stage has been host and steward, on the second king and unconditional ruler; then on the third he stands as God, whom they worship, opposite the companions, and these will form his church around him. Doubt has initiated the apostasy, sensuality has served as motive for the will; thus he has given his assent, and the perverted faith, which has taken root in the spirit in place of doubt, now holds him fast in the chosen decision. Once the demonic church of the night has thus first formed itself, through the free self-determination of its members; then it maintains and increases itself in the same way as the church of light, through the reception of the offspring of those who have joined. The children who are born in the bond, as well as others whom the companions seize, are offered to their God; so that he may receive them into his religion through a kind of baptism. \[Page 177\]

A certain rite is required for this, and definite formulas in which the reception takes place; and the judicial statements have by no means left us in the dark about this either. Those from Castile reported the following on the matter: When the assembly is together on the Prado del Cabron, the goat meadow; then the women offer these children to the Master while kneeling, with the words: Great mighty Lord! whom I worship, I bring you this new servant, who wishes to be your slave forever! The Master from his chair, as a sign of thanks and satisfaction, replies: Come closer to me! They now obeying, slide forward on their knees to him, and offer him the child, which he then takes on his arm and gives back to the one offering it, thanks her, and simultaneously admonishes her: Take care to nurture his youth, because his kingdom will thereby be increased. --- The mothers hasten more to offer their children on the Sabbath of reception than in the house of God; the time seems otherwise to depend on them, and mostly the second or third year is chosen. Until the ninth, they now guard the host of the Sabbath, and are only permitted to behold its wonders from afar.

Since the forcibly abducted can only be admitted with their free consent, there are arrangements there to extort this from them; deep abysses, for example, as in the trials of the Freemasons, into which they make as if to throw them if they resist denying God. Moreover, the women are beaten and scourged if they bring no children; that they, for the sake of peace, fetch them from other villages and regions; so that some in Mohra brought 15--16 children with them every night to the Sabbath. The children from Eüfdal knew much to say: of a white angel who forbade them to carry out what the devil had assigned them to do, and said thereby: the mischief shall not be overlooked much longer. On account of the base, dissolute life of the people, the matter had been tolerated hitherto; but now everything must be revealed. This angel had sometimes also placed himself in the doorway, between the malefactors and the children; and when they had come not far from Blokula, he had taken the children back, but the women had then gone in.

The Castilians now continue: "If the children, after they have reached the ninth year, unfortunately, without being compelled thereto by force from one of the companions, have surrendered themselves to the devil; then they throw themselves down before him on the earth. He, with fire flashing from his eyes, says to them: What do you desire, do you wish to become one of mine? He answers: Yes! Thereupon the other: Do you come with your full resolve of will? Answer again: Yes! Then will and do what I will and do! Thereupon the Queen of the Sabbath, who leads up the neophyte, says to him: Then speak after me with a loud voice: 'I deny God first, then Jesus Christ, his Son, the Holy Ghost, the Virgin, the Saints, the holy Cross, the Chrism, the Baptism and the faith that I have hitherto held, my godparents, and I deliver myself up in all things to your power, and into your hands; I acknowledge no other God, so that you are my God, and I your servant.'?" \[Page 178\]

Then a toad is handed over to him in its full state, and the master commands him to worship it; and now the usual homage is rendered on the knees with the kissing. Then the baptism is scratched off for him with the claws of the left hand on the forehead, and in its place the stigmatization is applied with a false gold needle in the white of the left eye, or also elsewhere; which thus stands here equivalent to the circumcision in the old covenant. The pains that this operation arouses are allayed in particularly favored ones by a herb that the master gives them. The oral promise is sometimes repeated in writing later on. The vow that Gaufredy had made read, according to the records of his trial, as follows: Je Louis Gaufredy renonce à tous les biens, tant spirituels que corporels, qui me pourroyent estre conferé de la part de Dieu, de la vierge Marie ei de tous les saincis de Paradis, pareillement de mon Patron S. Jean Baptiste, s. Pierre, s. Paul, s. Fran- cois, et de me donner de corps et d'ame à Lucifer iey present arec tous les biens, que je ferais à jamais: excepté la valeur du sacrament pour le regard de ceux qui le re- cevront. Ei ainsi le signe et atteste. The demon on his side now promised him: by the power of his oath he should inflame all girls and women whom he wished to possess with love, if the breath reached their nose. Ordinary heat of desire in this world, and still greater joy in that life.

This happens, however, only after they have renewed the vassal oath: to remain forever faithful to their new lord, never to return to Christianity, to attend the Sabbath regularly, to offer worship there, and to increase and extend the kingdom and the church by bringing in others. To the newly admitted ones there is then also given, probably as a mockery of the Christian baptism, a new one, in a special font filled with filth, under various ridiculous ceremonies. Instead of the old godfathers, new ones are assigned to them, who serve as sureties for the new faith. Instead of the old name, a new one is bestowed upon them, taken from the places where they were born, or from other accidental circumstances. Thus Cuno of Rohren on the Moselle was called Barbicapa in this rebaptism, others again differently. They vow at the same time: never to go to the Eucharist; or, if they do so, only with the intention of approaching the sacrament in order to misuse it. They promise: to dishonor and revile Mary and all the saints, by word and by deed; to trample and spit upon their relics; to abstain from the sign of the cross, and, where it may perchance be found molded in plastic form, to break and destroy it; likewise to avoid all sacramentals of the holy water, of the consecrated salt, the candles; never to confess their sins; to cover their relation to the demon and the secret of the Sabbath with silence; and to dedicate all their powers and possessions to their new lord, who is ever present to them, alone fulfills all their desires, and after death can make them blessed. \[Page 179\]

With the confirmation it is done later in the same way as before with the baptism, and new sponsors are also assigned to them for it. They then vow sacrifices, in order thereby to render divine honor to the lord. Some offer themselves to sacrifice a child every month. Others bind themselves to bring such a one every year, and to redeem the omitted performances with penances. As payment therefor, a piece of their clothing is given to the demon; for the spirit of darkness seeks to procure for himself a part of everything: from the spiritual goods the faith and the baptism, from the bodily blood, from the natural gifts the children, and from the goods of fortune this part of the clothing. Upon all this an oath is now also probably sworn; a circle is inscribed in the ground, the master seats himself in its center, and the oath-taker outside promises him that he will faithfully perform all this. The circle is the symbol of the deity and its dominion over all things, but the earth is the footstool of God: and through the symbolic oath-swearing it shall be expressed: that the recipient of the promise is the lord of heaven and earth, and is acknowledged as such by his faithful ones.

Now follows the request: to strike the petitioner out of the book of life, and in exchange to inscribe him in the book of death. This is done, and they now show themselves transformed in their whole nature; and the women become, to use the expressions of the Compendium Maleficarum: (allaces, proditiosae, loquaces, garrulosae, tenaces, glutinosae, ardentes et luxuriosae, leeres, rebelles et litigosae, nocivae et periculosae, comparantur Ursis, Vento, Scorpioni, Leoni, Draconi et laqueo. 1) Almost with the same words the above-cited matter is repeated in the judgment that the Inquisition of Avignon in 1592 pronounced over a number of the accused: Quod vos et vestrum quilibet Deum nostrum, omnium creatorem et opificem, unum et trinum abnegastis, et Imm.

You have worshipped the Devil, the ancient enemy of the human race, and devoted yourselves to him perpetually; and, renouncing the most sacred baptism, and those who were your sponsors therein, lifting up and repudiating them, and your portion of paradise, and the eternal inheritance which our Lord Jesus Christ acquired for you and the whole human race by His death, in the presence of the aforesaid Cacodaemon, appearing in human form, you renounced: pouring over you anew the water, which you received, with the Devil himself roaring as he did so, but with your name changed, and the sacred name imposed upon you in baptism now altered, so that another fictitious name might be imposed upon you in this fictitious baptism; and you did so, and received it: and as a pledge of faith given to the Demon, you gave him a fragment of your garments and a particle thereof; and that the father of lies might take care to erase and obliterate you from the book of life, you affixed your own signs with your own hand, at his command and bidding, to the blackest book prepared for this purpose, of the reprobate and damned, and of perpetual death: and that he might bind you to such great perfidy and impiety with a greater bond, he branded upon each of you a mark or stigma, as upon his own property: and by his command and orders, you bound yourselves with an oath, sworn by each of you over a circle, which is the symbol of Divinity, carved into the earth, trampling underfoot the sign of the Lord and the cross, etc. etc.

#### A. The Sabbath, the Church of the Initiated.

\[Page 180\]

After all the threads have thus been severed by which those who have departed from the Church of Light remained connected to it, they have now passed over into that of Night; they are initiated into its mysteries, and put into practice what its statutes command. The banquets were, on the first level, boisterous orgies for indulgence, in which the initiates debauched with their initiators. On the second level, they have taken shape as symposia, where the entire retinue, united in league around its duke, gathers at the common table. Now, on the third level, they become sacrificial meals, where their god breaks the bread for his worshippers, and offers the cup to the confederates after pronouncing the curse over it; so that, having partaken in this supper of his substance, and now appropriating it to themselves, they may be transubstantiated into the same, and no longer permitted to depart from him.

This is already announced in the outward form and posture of these banquets. According to Del Rio, the meal was always opened with the formula that served as the prayer before the table: *En nom de Belzebub nostre grand maistre, souverain Commandeur et seigneur, noz viandes, boire et manger soyent garnis et munis pour noz refections, plaisirs et voluptez!* whereupon all chorused: *Ainst soit il!* When the banquet was ended, it was said: *De nostre refection salutaire prinse et veceue nostre Commandeur seigneur ei maistre Belzebub soit loué, gracié et remercié a son exaltation et commun bien!* whereupon the chorus again responded: *Ainsi soit il!*

In the ancient love-feast, it was the wine, from the vine of mildly radiant sun, distilled into the blood of the earth asceticized through cultivation; thus purified in the process of vegetation, and cleansed once more of all its dregs in the process of fermentation, and now gentle, enspiriting, and uplifting, it was held as the symbolic bearer of the higher life-spirit, who bleeds out in death for the race. But in these unlovely gatherings, it is the drink that makes one drunken and raging; sprung from that vine planted in volcanic soil, and in the ash of earthly Solfatara; and, in Egyptian intimation, the heart-blood of the giants, which, when they fell in wild combat, flowed onto the earth, was absorbed; and now it is the fitting expression of the evil that sprouts forth in the sun's blaze, from the earth impregnated with wickedness. \[Page 181\]

This is therefore the potion that the woman on the beast offers to the peoples in the cup; from which the princes drink, and in which the peoples intoxicate themselves. As they now, instead of the mild food of earlier times---milk and honey---choose for their nourishment the milk of the euphorbias, and the honey that drove the Romans, who found it in the Caucasus, to madness: so is their bread not taken from pure, healthy wheat; but from such as has been struck by ergot, smut, and rust, and which therefore holds death and destruction enclosed within itself. Poison and death and putrefaction are thus the signature of the substances in which the Eucharist of Satan is consummated; and which, now taken up into the inner circle of life, unite and bind it with that in whose remembrance they are celebrated. But union on this side is separation on the other; and the Eucharist of Hell, first consummated in the Fall of Man, binds itself to the profanation of that other Eucharist, celebrated in the fruits of the Tree of Life. Hence the blasphemous abominations performed with it on the Sabbaths. A woman confessed in 1457, amid many tears and sighs, in a public avowal before a great multitude of people: how she, for thirty years in succession, had each time secretly removed from her mouth the host received in the Easter communion, and then trampled it underfoot. The same had a priest done with the host consecrated by him; and when he was now led to the stake, he demanded that a cross be erected at the place where he had done it, and along the path by which he was conducted.

Those who have partaken in the sacrificial meal of the Baalim, and thus unified their own life with theirs, have thereby also made themselves fit for spiritual adultery with them; and the whoredom practiced with the demons on the Sabbath is also a service of that gods' festival there. The offering of blood and of seed has the ancient Moloch demanded from his worshippers; both in the literal sense of a service at once bloody and dissolute; or in the offering of their own limbs and of the children who have proceeded from them or also in the natural order. The children of the flesh, following on a wild course the powers to which they have given themselves as prey; torn and rent asunder incurably within themselves by the ungovernable spirits that drag the life fallen to them in opposing directions, decomposed and disintegrated; become, like these spirits themselves, torn and divided in lust and pain, in madness and exhaustion, and again in lustful greed and thirsting blood-lust, in frenzy and deadly rigidity.

Whatever, therefore, the most dissolute madness in lust can devise; whatever a burning sensuality may drive up from its depths; whither unbridled passions, staggering, can lose themselves in delusion; the irremediable doom before which Nature herself recoils: all this is performed and practiced there as service to the new god. The wanton dances are therefore now sacrificial dances; in them death draws near to life, that he may court it; in ever narrower circles they swing around each other, and as the circles interweave themselves into a net, joy enkindles itself ragingly in pain. As tigers and leopards are wont to love, so do the frenzied ones tear each other to pieces in grim lust, and only in blood can the flames be quenched. \[Page 182\]

Therefore, when the witches, elves, druidesses, and night-women, holding the darkly burning pitch-torch in their hands, roam through the night, summoning up their spirits, and, when they have found them, weave them about with their round dances; when shrill tones hold together the torn, angular lines of their dances, and all movements in them take shape against the order of nature; when the swaying and tossing of their heads, as with the shamans, drags them ever deeper into the frenzy: then they resemble those ancient priestesses of Cybele, when these, dressed in women's garments, torch-bearing, head-shaking, with wild cries wandered through the mountains; and then, called by the dark, heavy horn-call, gathered themselves around the altars of the Phrygian mother of the gods; and now, to the rushing, driving sound of flutes, cymbals, and pipes that accompanied the wild galliambics, stamped the earth in sharp cadences; with the knives and daggers that they carried, cooled their frenzy in their own blood; and finally, when the dithyramb had risen to its height, castrated themselves.

Of such a kind is the pavana of the lords' feast, which the gypsies of the middle ages may well have brought from the Orient. That is the proper and common service of the magic church; but since this is built up in the midst of Christianity, another takes place in it as well, introduced for the mockery and scorn of the latter. On the Sabbath, the Devil has in fact built his sacristy onto the church's cathedral; and in this an apish cult is celebrated, of which the witches say that it is more solemn and beautiful than the churchly one. Such depictions in Weber's legends---and never an esteemed one---stood a church, comparable to their village church. Other testimonies of such witnesses who elsewhere had attended the Sabbath mass confirmed: that they had seen there a masonry church, and an altar in it, upon which a demon, the size of a twelve-year-old child, during the whole ceremony held himself motionless, and after the ending of the same disappeared with all the rest.

During the service one heard a music of instruments, intermixed with the ringing of bells, which sounded altogether lovely; without, however, either bells or instruments being visible. If crosses appeared, then their arms were broken; but if the sign of the cross was made, then it happened with mocking words in three languages: In nomine Patrico, aragueaco; Petrica, agora, agora Valentia; Jouanda goure gaitz goustia! accompanied. Holy water was present in a hollow of the wall, at the entrance of the church; it was the urine of the master, and the whole congregation was sprinkled with it. A hierarchy is also established, and just as a queen of the Sabbath makes her appearance, so too a bishop, distinguished by a tiara upon which he walks about; while at solemn masses deacons and subdeacons also come forth. \[Page 183\]

The service usually begins with a proper confession; but in it the penitents do not accuse themselves of their evil deeds, but rather of their good ones; and beg the master, who hears this their confession, for absolution on that account. He then, raising the left arm, absolves them, and imposes on them as penance something like eating meat on Fridays or Saturdays in the fast, or on the eves of feast days, or otherwise whatever pleases him. After the confession the demon clothes himself in priestly garments, and reads mass. Confiteor and Alleluia are omitted; the rest is murmured from a book that he holds in the left hand. At the Offertory he sits down, whereupon the attendees come with black candles to adore; and after they have tremblingly kissed his left hand, they offer to him bread, eggs, and the like, which offerings the queen, at his side, receives in a bowl with his image upon it. Those from Logroño knew only of an altar erected under a tree or rock.

Money is also sacrificed, preferably quartilles, because these have no cross; if they are quarters marked with one, then he steps aside for a time. After the adoration follows the sermon, either delivered by himself in the form of a goat, or by a sorcerer. In the first case, he usually speaks of how he is their true God; and that those who seek another cannot bring about their salvation. An exhortation to persecute the Christians concludes the address, which in the other case mostly urges them to do evil, to accuse the innocent, to help the guilty escape, and to offer many children to the demon. Thereupon the mass continues. The demon raises a black host, with his image, horns beneath the words: This is my body! and the congregation prostrates itself with the words: Aquerra goity, aquerra beity! Goat above, goat below! The same is repeated with the chalice, which he empties. Then the attendees surround the altar in the form of a half-moon; he delivers a second sermon to them, and then communicates them with a part of the host, and a sip of a foul-smelling and abominably tasting drink; which brings them outwardly into a sweat, while bitter cold makes all their nerves and the marrow in their bones stiffen and freeze.

It is not always the demon himself, however, who conducts this ceremony; sometimes ordained priests step in his place. For the ordination itself does not protect against the Sabbath, as shown in the investigations in Labourt and elsewhere. The first in the Basque country in whom the matter came to light was the pastor of Ascain, an old man who confessed himself: how twenty years before he had attended the assembly, had renounced his Creator, and instead of his ordination had accepted that of Satan; and how, although he had often wanted to rid himself of the abomination, the devil had so beset him on that account that he had nearly lost his senses, yet had brought it about: that in all that time he had neither confessed his sin in the confessional, nor admonished others about it from the confessional chair. He named persons whom he had seen at the Sabbath; while two witnesses declared how they too had seen him there; he repeated his confession three times in writing before the judges and his bishop, and stood by it in death. \[Page 184\]

Now accusations against the pastors poured in from all sides, and two of the most vehemently accused, Peter Bocal, 27 years old, and Migalena, 61 years old, were brought to trial. It was found that the first belonged to a family called by sorcery. Seventeen witnesses testified against him: how they had seen him at the Sabbath; indeed, according to these statements, in the night before he had celebrated his first mass, he had already held this one there with great pomp, and the sacrifice at the Sabbath had been more abundant than it later turned out in the church. Asked why he had read earlier at the Sabbath than in the church, he had replied: it had been done for practice, so that he might thereafter perform his office all the better. Twenty-four witnesses had also testified similarly against Migalena. Both were degraded and executed.

Similar statements also lay against others. One from St. Jean de Luz accused the priest Jean Sonhardibels: how at the place Cohandja, in such a mass, at the elevation he had positioned himself so that, with his head downward but his feet upward, he had floated in the air in such a way that the hands in which he held the black host had risen as high as is customary for priests in the church, and in this position he had remained for the duration of a Credo. According to others, the host on such occasions was not round, but triangular; and the congregation was accustomed at the elevation, instead of the prayer, to call out: Black raven, black raven!

According to others, the priest had directed his face not toward the altar, but toward the congregation; and after the elevation, he threw the host to the ground and trampled it underfoot. One must, in all these statements, on the one hand admire the consistency in their perversity; on the other hand, one sees that if, in the church for sanctification, a communal bond and rapport exists among all the members intermingled, in which they have grown together, which in the mystical states comes to consciousness, a similar relation returns in the church of corruption. However, no judgment can be passed on the degree of guilt of those accused, and from the numerous statements against them, this cannot by any means be measured with full certainty. For these statements rested on the vision, which, in order to be possible, certainly required rapports in which the witnesses were connected with the accused. But these must have been occasioned by some guilt, which could in any case be considered proven only for the spiritual realm, in which the testimony of the witnesses also held validity.

#### B. The Closed Sabbath of the Clergy

\[Page 185\]

All these notes are taken from judicial statements, mostly from people of the lower classes, where so much acts disturbingly and confusingly; it might therefore seem desirable if we had before us the memoir of some personality written down in a calmer situation, who had been in such circumstances and, recalling these things in her memory, would be in a position to sketch for us a faithful picture of the impressions she had experienced. This wish is fulfilled for us by that Magdalena Bavent, who played the leading role in the notorious history of the possessed nuns of Louviers. She had been seduced by her own temperament and the influence of bad priests who served as confessors at her convent; she had taken part in all the horrors of the debaucheries there, and when the consequences of them erupted in that affair; then all the possessed had testified against her as the instigator; the episcopal authority had conducted the investigation, but the Parliament of Rouen had taken the judgment in the matter to itself and pronounced a death sentence; Bavent, however, who faced the same fate, was still held once more in her prison. In this situation, she had come to repentance over her licentious life, and her confessor, the priest of the Oratory of the Marais, had induced her to compose a short history of it, in the form of final and testamentary confessions. She based it on the last confession she had made when she had to prepare herself for the impending death; her confessor assisted and guided the pen; and thus these memoirs of the forty-year-old woman arose. Calmly, as it seems, they are written with all the signs of serious repentance; concealing nothing of what might redound to her shame, rejecting only what seemed exaggerated to her in the accusations; and thus, with all the faithfulness and reliability that can be expected of a human being in such circumstances, sketching a picture of her aberrations. Regarding the closed Sabbath of her fellow members of the order, she now lets herself be heard there, p. 23 and following, as follows:

During my imprisonment in this city, I have, on the basis of my earlier statements, been approached by many people for more detailed information about the Sabbath. But my confessor had forbidden me to explain myself on this to anyone other than the judges; therefore I remained silent, a silence that brought me much humiliation from the side of the unsatisfied curiosity, which now refused to believe in my conversion. \[Page 186\]

Now, since I have permission to speak about it, I will give all necessary information on the matter; so that everyone may recognize the gravity of my terrible crimes, and learn to abhor the scene of them. It is for me in this to recount with sincerity what I believe I have seen; the readers will, according to their best judgment in my report, distinguish what they hold to be real from what seems to them illusion. --- I was never carried off otherwise than at nighttime, and after I had slept. Usually before Matins, which with us took place at midnight, it seemed to me once, twice, sometimes in longer indefinite intervals, as if I were called by a nun. I started up from sleep to answer; and when, rising, I came to the door of my cell, I felt myself led away from there, without being able to distinguish how or by whom; for I had lost all consciousness, until I arrived at the accursed place. My rising, as my confessor later observed, provided the occasion for the abduction; I myself, however, did not think of it at the time. Ointment or anything else I never used, but it happened through the power of Picard; of my own self, even if the greatest desire drove me to present myself there, I would not have been able to do it.

After an absence of one, or one and a half, two, or three hours, I found myself again in my cell, and lay down to bed. The place where the Sabbath was held, whether inside or outside the cloister, is unknown to me; I did not perceive the details with sufficient clarity to be able to make a description of it; I would therefore be deceiving the world if I were to sketch a drawing of it. I remember only that the place was rather narrow than spacious; there were no seats there on which to settle, but it was lighted, because of the lights that stood like torches on the altar. The company that appeared there was not numerous; only priests and nuns did I see there, laypeople seldom; perhaps it was not their Sabbath. The evil spirits were frequently present, in half-human, half-animal form, sometimes alone in the former; Picard, in whose presence I always found myself there, pointed them out to me expressly each time. I never saw them, as the nuns were accustomed to recount, in the form of a goat; their place was always near the altar; yet I never perceived any worship rendered to them.

When I speak of the altar, it is because there really was such a one, where the priests said Mass; and the evil spirits stood so near the altar because it was said in their praise; I, however, perhaps saw no worship, though it was, as my confessor said, the highest of all. The host was like ours, yet it always seemed reddish to me and without figure; of this I can judge, because there too one communed. One also performed the elevation, and I heard terrible blasphemies uttered during it. The Mass was said with the paper of blasphemies, which one read aloud in it as the canon, as well as at all consecrations and processions, and which contained the most frightful curses against the most holy Trinity, the holy altar sacrament, the other sacraments, and the ceremonies of the Church, and which was written in a language unknown to me. \[Page 187\]

When one holds banquets, which however, to my knowledge, happened only once or twice, human flesh is eaten thereat. I have also seen there a kind of register, but written in a script unknown to me, which seemed most to resemble that in the testament of the priest David, which was presented to me in court. Picard has indeed spoken to me of a list of the malefactors and the sorcerers, but he has never communicated it to me. The justice has asked me many times for the names of those present at the Sabbath; but I say in truth: these names are not spoken at the places of terror; one thus does not learn them there, unless one has acquaintance with them from elsewhere; to which my secluded life afforded me no opportunity. Everyone is also so occupied there with his own godless doings that he pays little heed to others; unless he is connected with them in some other way, as I was with Picard. Of the speeches made on the spot, I also know little; for aside from the public acts, speaking is done only softly, for the sake of secrecy.

I am in general not so knowledgeable in the mysteries of darkness as one believes; this writing of mine is a kind of open confession, in the face of the Church of God, for some atonement for the scandal that I have given; and it shall contain only truth, and come as close as possible to that which I shall one day lay before my higher Judge. Besides Picard, whom I have always seen there with me, and without whom I was never present there, I have also recognized his vicar Boullé; beside them several priests, whose names I do not know, engaged in the ceremonies there; then also four nuns of my convent: Catharina of the Cross, Catharina of St. Genevieve, Elisabeth of the Nativity, and Anna Barre; the latter, however, seldom. Of the others whom I glimpsed there by face, without knowing their names, two in particular have stuck in my mind: one 50--60 years old, clothed in violet, black hair mixed with gray, of middle stature, stout, but ill on his feet; and another, concerning whom I have always been questioned, and of whom the nuns have testified under exorcism: that it was Mother Franziska or Simonette of Paris, the former superior of the convent of St. Louis, who had then withdrawn to the capital. She was never named to me at the Sabbath, however, and I have also never known her personally; and I wish from my heart never to have seen her there.

All the acts that I have seen performed at the Sabbath are dishonorable; and it is impossible that I should recall them otherwise than with shuddering. Those who question me about the particulars do not know what pain they thereby inflict on me; my confessor himself has questioned me, on account of the shame and confusion in which he has always seen me thereby, only about the barest necessities. So much is certain: the saints of God do great things; but the unholy ones of the devil yield to them in nothing on the other side. The wickedness of the priests who attend the Sabbath drives them at times to read mass over large hosts, then to cut them out in the middle, to paste them onto a parchment prepared in like manner, and then to use them in shameful ways for their lusts. In such things I have indeed only once or twice participated, and it would be better to make such abominable vices forgotten than to bring them to mind; but since I here lay my general confession, I cannot pass over them in silence. \[Page 188\]

On a Maundy Thursday, Picard and Boullé had brought four hosts; they took two into their mouths, gave then two others to that aforementioned Simonette and to me, and finally they exchanged the ones taken; that served to strengthen the bond. One night, after the paper of blasphemy had been carried in procession for a while, a small cross was brought in, to which a large host was fastened with small nails at the hands and feet of the figure depicted upon it; at the same time, each of us had also to wound the side. Two or three drops of blood flowed out, which were collected and, combined with the host, used for magical purposes. This means, without doubt, crucifying the Lord a second time; as I then often saw the like practiced, even on hosts that had been consecrated on the Sabbath, though from these no blood flowed.

A priest once brought a host to the Sabbath to burn it; but this time the Savior himself appeared and struck the priest with his lightnings, so that nothing more of him could be found; the host, however, shot up into the air. The demons fled, all was in consternation; but this established example by no means put an end to the assemblies. I saw another priest carry a chalice with the blood of the Lord to the Sabbath. He thrust a knife into it, which became entirely bloody. A second did likewise, and the substance likewise turned to blood; and when a third repeated the act, it overflowed from the overfull chalice onto the earth. The Lord, in the company of the Holy Virgin and several saints, came thereunto and commanded the fleeing demons to remain. The priests were turned to ashes and seen no more; but the blood was collected with the earth and carried away. If these things thus occurred in reality---over which I leave the judgment to others---so are they great abominations, and alongside them great miracles; and my conviction of the real presence of the Savior in the holy sacrament has, through all these events wherein earth and hell have united in their rage against him, only been strengthened. \[Page 189\]

On a Good Friday a woman brought her newborn child; they resolved to nail it to a cross. The nails were driven through hosts, through which they nailed it fast; other nails were driven into its head as a crown, just as they also pierced its side; thereafter it was used for maleficia. Two persons who had perhaps strayed to the Sabbath out of curiosity were, because they refused to take part in its godlessnesses, crucified and killed there. On a Maundy Thursday I saw the Coena performed in a terrible manner. They brought a completely roasted child, and it was eaten by those present; I do not know with complete certainty whether I took part in it. I said to my confessor: it may well have been so; yet it seemed to me that I soon desisted, because the flesh seemed very tasteless to me. During the meal a demon went around the table and cried: Not one among you will betray me! I believe they repeat with these words the promise they gave one another not to betray each other, but to remain faithful to the devil. That is all that has remained in my memory with certainty from the Sabbath, after I have carefully searched my conscience and been questioned about it very often. One must not believe that more can be asked of me than I told my confessor, as he prepared me for death. The judgment over the reality of these things I leave to the discernment of others; but I beseech the justice, if it takes regard to my testimony, only to pay attention to what I can say with certainty. As long as Picard lived, I was moreover always led to the Sabbath.---Remarkable in this report is the threefold repetition: how she does not know whether all that was seen was thus in reality, or whether it only appeared so to her; a doubt whose good foundation we shall discuss elsewhere.

Also what is of importance, that in their prescriptions, where they demand back a part of their body, which the spirit, as with the Ferry, has taken from her under great pains--- what Picard called a flesh knot for the maleficia--- first she herself speaks, and then lets the demon reply; and likewise the acceptation of their bill of exchange drawn on body and life, which Astaroth adds. When the confessor asked her about this circumstance, she replied: she had not known what she had written, since she had been entirely beside herself, and had scarcely known herself.

#### C. The Liturgy of the Sabbath

\[Page 190\]

After these revelations about the service, as it is celebrated on the Sabbath, that which Maria von Sains has stated about the rituals there is only the consequence of the once-adopted principle; and it matters little whether, in these statements--- which may very well be so--- the lucubrations and brooding thoughts of the waking state have imagined themselves into the demonic hell-sleep; or whether, conversely, the visions of this sleep have mirrored themselves in the remembrance of wakefulness. After she has spoken, namely, of the images of the gods, which in animal form as dragon, serpent; or in human form, after the manner of the ancient pagans, are formed, baptized, and worshiped on the Sabbath; she also speaks of the sacraments of the synagogue, of which she knows only four: baptism, confirmation, Eucharist, and marriage, since confession is practiced only in mockery of the Christians. Not all priests are admitted to the sacrifice; only twelve out of all are chosen, to perform it in the order prescribed by the master. Every Sunday the attendees are sprinkled with the blood of the Lord, under the general outcry: Sanguis ejus super nos et super filios nostros! In the mass a thousand unworthinesses are committed: Some stick out their tongues, others blaspheme, others uncover their nakedness; all of which becomes even more boisterous at the elevation, since then the demons and the notables of the society, turning their backs to the sacrament, approach the altar. No singing is done at the mass, the lights smell foul; instead of Ite Missa est! the synagogue says: Allez à tous les Diables! All the Psalms of David are sung, as in the church, but all directed to Lucifer, Beelzebub, Leviathan. The Pater noster is likewise turned toward Lucifer: Ego te accipio in patrem, qui in coelis es, sanctificetur nomen tuum per universum mundum --- --- et libera nos ab omni malo! The English greeting is directed in the same manner to the mother of the Antichrist: Salve virgo plarimum veneranda, plena gratiarum, Dominus tecum est etc. The Symbolum begins: Credo in Deum patrem Luciferum, qui creavit coelum et terram. Et in filium ejus Belzebub, qui conceptus est de spiritu sancto, qui reducit mundum, qui venturus est judicare vivos et mortuos. Credo in spiritum sanctum Leviathan, et Ecclesiam sanctam Catholicam, reformatam Synagogam, Communionem sanctorum, Remissionem peccatorum, et vitam aeternam, Amen. The Sabbath also keeps the ten commandments: Luciferum ut Deum verum adorabis, et alium extra ipsum non amabis. Nomen Jesu assidue blasphemabis. Sabbata Synagogae sanctificabis. Patrem ac matrem odio habebis. Viros pariter ac mulieres, puerosque trucidabis. Adulteria, et omnem fornicationem et crimina nefanda committere non dubitabis. Usuras, furta atque rapinas exercebis. Falsa testimonia ac mendacia dicundo praeelectabis. Uxorem proximi tui et possessionem proximi tui concupiscis. \[Page 191\]

As works of mercy are considered: to refuse food, drink, and clothing to the poor, not to take in the stranger, to abandon the weak and the imprisoned, to dig up the buried children for the Sabbath, to sow errors and heresies, to multiply doubts and scruples, to burden the afflicted with even greater affliction, to make those who have fallen into sin fall even deeper, not to pray for the deceased, to bear adversities with impatience. Mortal sins are held there to be: to live in humility, chastity, patience, moderation, compassion, and piety. For all virtues count as vices: extravagance stands in for chastity, gluttony for moderation, envy for neighborly love, avarice for generosity, pride for humility, impatience for long-suffering, and so too blasphemy for fortitude. Litanies are likewise held there, and in them, for example: *Ut Ecclesiam Catholicam apostolicam Romanam, per haereses turbare et destruere digneris, te rogamus audi nos*; *ut Ordines ac Religiones difformare et extirpare digneris*. --- *Ut congregationes nostras conservare in sanitate ab omni malo digneris*. --- *Ut rabiem nostram contra Deum et homines et Sanctos, qui sunt et futuri sunt, semper fovere digneris*. --- *Ut nos in cordis nostri duritie perpetuo retinere digneris*. --- *Ut nobis auxilium dones, ad resistendum semper spiritui sancto et divinis eius inspirationibus et admonitionibus, et quicquid saluti nostrae deseruire posset*. --- *Te rogamus audi nos*.

One sees that much from this ritual is still today useful for the secret service of many a doctrine that has purified the Sabbath, after cleansing it of all superstition and the ridiculous abstractions of the Middle Ages, and setting it upon tangibility, now holds it in broad daylight on the open market. Also a sermon that Beelzebub held on Trinity Sunday would be very useful; if one were to seat at the throne, instead of the obsolete three demons of the speaker, Leviathan's, and Asmodeus's, who sat there at that time --- their faces like a man's face, body, feet, and hands of a devil's feet, each with horns on the head, a golden tiara like the high priest --- three God-men: the God-philosopher, in whom pantheism has incarnated itself; the God-pleasure-seeker, husband of the exalted Lady Sophia of the Saint-Simonists; and the God-emperor of this world, in whom absolute liberal tyranny has become flesh.

The three could then speak from one mouth with the orator: My friends, today the great day of the most holy Trinity shines forth in humanity. We three are one in essence, but in substance completely equal to one another; almighty, because the three kings of the world; all-knowing, precisely because we ourselves are the All. In a word, we are able to bring forth everything, and again to transform it into nothing. *Filioli mei, vestrum est omni conamine sanctissimam trinitatem coeli contemnere: vestrum est, contemnentes dicere: Draco crudelissime, serpens venenose, Cerbere triceps!* Rejoice, my sons, that you have brought forth from your midst a God, threefold in person but one in full union; who in the first has freed you from all your superstition in the being of a supernatural God and his entire court; who in the second has overwhelmed you with all delights and blessed you with the liberation of the flesh; who in the third has freed you from all the needs of free will, and directed you to your true Lord, fate. At the close, the choir then sings the hymn: *Cerbere triceps, Draco crudelissime!*

Section III. Atmospheres and Modes of Action in the State of Enchantment
------------------------------------------------------------------------

\[Page 192\]

Those who have turned themselves toward the nocturnal side of nature have there found the star of the night; and by setting themselves in rapport with it through their abdominal cerebrum, which is itself a moon in the organic body, they have become moonstruck from the side of nature, and the moon, moving them in ebbs and flows, has drawn them up to itself, but in truth down beneath itself. In this direction of nature, which has made them moon-women if they belong to the other sex; or such as conduct themselves in the manner of women if they were men who have turned aside to this side; the realm of death is unveiled to them in clear sleep, that realm which hides itself in the midst of the realm of life and encompasses within itself all the lower roots of being; and they now behold the rising and descending of the elements in the alternating intercourse of both realms. In this natural relation of such moon-wives, the mythical has been added in antiquity; in those nocturnal domains they have found Hecate, the terrible night-goddess, who, as the moon has three forms, so has a threefold countenance. She has been to them the guardian of all night-births, the ruler in the angle named after her, that great cave on the moon's disk where the departed obtain punishment for their wickednesses. She was to them the wrathful one who drives the night-wanderer along his paths; she has unlocked for them the underworld of the departed, which adjoins that realm of death; and thus the moon-women of antiquity have become necromantic sorceresses when they have turned to the evil side. In Christendom, where all relations of nature are spiritualized, and in this spiritualization the opposition of the religious-ethical good and evil is purely and sharply driven forth, those sorceresses, passing through the domain of nature and the psychic, have turned even more decisively to the final side. By taking the demonic as their center, and nourishing themselves physically with the shadows of substances, but spiritually satisfying themselves with the empty semblances of ideas, and working all this into somnambulistic illusory movements; they have likewise had to transpose themselves, formally transubstantiating themselves into the object of their choice, out of truth into the lie of a semblance-existence; which, however, in the concrete reality of evil, has nonetheless attained its negative reality as a contradiction against the positive of the good. But he who in spirit and will and in life has chosen a new center, gains, by appropriating it to himself in all these powers, new modalities of the thus remodeled faculties; in life, spirit, and will, new circles form for him, altered rapports, other ranges of his activities; and with changing intentions and purposes, altered modes of effect in differently positioned spheres of effect. We have therefore previously considered the subjective transformations that he experiences who enters into the domain of the new center of gravity, and the new polarities and tensions around it; then it remains for us now to assume also these differently modified repercussions of our mode of consideration. How has one who has become at home in those circles found his way in them? What new atmospheres have his powers drawn around themselves? What domain, what range and scope of force have they gained? What elective affinities have thrust themselves forth around them? How have their directions been modified? In short, how has the subjectively overturned human now also transformed himself in all his objective modes of effect, and what power has he attained in them? This investigation too we shall conduct, following the facts at hand, in such a way that we descend gradually from the height we reached in the previous one down to the depths.

### Chapter 1. Spiritual Reports

\[Page 193\]

There are two invisible churches on earth: that of the Lord, to which all good belongs that this earth holds within itself; and that of his adversary, in which all evil is enclosed that has spread itself within it. All those in whom the good dwells in an eminent degree; all who, in his possession, enjoy a highly elevated inner life; all mystical saints, are beholding, active members of the first of these two churches; they stand in immediate intercourse with their invisible center, which reveals itself to them nearer or more distant. But others are connected to it only by the bond of faith; they do not behold, in the measure in which they have remained strangers to the inner life, into the inner of the mysteries---only their outer side becomes manifest to them; there they traffic only actively insofar as they are called by grace. Both, however---the esoteric as well as the exoteric---are embraced by one and the same visible outer church, in which that invisible inner one dwells, which now reveals itself to different ones in different ways; but all are regulated and led to the goal by the common, universally valid norm revealed for this purpose.

In analogous manner is it also arranged with the other invisible church, in which is found the center that unites and cherishes all evil. It is the night-covered abyss in which it is built; the subterranean hearth where the evil flames drive the evil waters above themselves to the surface; where the poison dragon lies at the roots of the world tree and gnaws them. Also in human nature open wells that reach into this abyss; but the other church, hostile to it, has closed and sealed them. Whoever now tears open these seals; whoever presses into an inner life, not to elevate himself in it and drink from the source of the good water, but to question the abyss for its secrets and to make its powers allies to himself: he will indeed become an active and beholding member of this other church; he sees the guiding center of this realm and feels its influences. He knows henceforth what to do in all his doing; the evil does not proceed from him as if by chance, but it is sought with consciousness; for it has substantially incorporated itself into him. He therefore acts also in the whole inner power and might of this evil; while those who stand outside enjoy only the help that its outer bond offers them.

Because, however, things down here are calculated on the outer life, on the sober state of waking, this invisible church of evil also has the inner drive to embody itself in an outer, visible one and, in it, to transplant itself into the midst of the waking world. The invisible inner center therefore seeks outer and visible centers for itself, on which it lays from its spirit, and in which it can therefore now regulate itself in the outer world. Such are now the representatives and the mandataries of the center; they act in its full power and its might, and immediately begins the process of appropriation and organization around them. But all organic organization on earth is carried out through instincts. Thus it has been natural instincts, life instincts, in which the household---the common ground of all other association---has shaped itself; political instincts for protection and defense and for shielding personal freedom, and spiritual instincts to bring forth the best well-order, have then founded the state thereon. From just such instincts, only directed to a higher world order, inasmuch as they, ascending, meet the downward-directed effect of the spirit from above, was the Christian church, in the midst of heathendom, to the astonishment of the world-wise, built up. \[Page 194\]
