In like manner, there will now arise demonic darknesses, self-destructive and deformative impulses in evil, growing toward the enchantment of the negating spirit from below, building around him and his vicars the false structures of an external church of evil. These visible viceroys of the invisible principle in the midst are the depositories of the enchantment; they preserve in the scrinium pectoris the curse that has become living and sprouting within them; they rule the instincts in which it has taken root; and thereby they are lords and regents among the children of the dragon's seed, the queen bees around whom their swarms gather; the preservers and increasers of their realm. In the demonic rapportages, as whose tangible and visible central points they appear, they are masters of the throng that presses around them; and they form around themselves the dioceses of that rebellious church which descends into the realms of downfall.

#### A. The Mystagogues of the Enchantment-Being

If someone has attained the consecration of the spirit of midnight, and the seven-parted ray of the darkness dwelling within him has come over him, then he becomes its vicar; the nights stream together in him, so that in the midst of their gloom he becomes a blacker, night-enveloped point that engulfs the light, and binds to himself all spirits that enter into the current, and henceforth appears as their central point and their leader and their master. Of such a kind was that succession of degenerate priests in Norman Louviers, of whom we have already made mention earlier: David, Picard, Boulle, who, by handing down their mandate---the canon of blasphemies---from one to the other on the deathbed as a hereditary bequest, transmitted their consecration to one another, and thus formed a whole lineage of such mystagogues.

They were Ophites, after the manner of that ancient Gnostic school, who, abusing the inexperience of the girls shut up in that convent in the most wicked way, endeavored to gradually divert their zeal for advancing on the path of the inner life into their own ways. They spoke to them of contemplation, inner light, ecstasies, transformations, self-annihilations, and of the hidden life in the spirit; they ceaselessly urged them on to rise to that spirituality which would lead them to the choirs of angels, and finally even into God himself. Then they would be exalted above the law, living only in love, comforted by the anointing of the Holy Spirit, and free in the freedom of the Lord, and established in this freedom, they need no longer heed the stirrings of the passions in the deeper regions; but mortifying all shame and timidity, they would find themselves empowered to give free rein to sensuality; because a spirit most intimately united with God could never sin.

Thus combining the highest spiritual tension with the deepest profligacy, they must gradually gain the greatest power over the spirit of those who had been incautiously surrendered to them; all the more so, since the seclusion and solitude of the conventual life at once furthered and concealed the designs of the seducers. This spiritual dominion soon manifested itself physically as well. One of the nuns testified later against Picard: that when he once unexpectedly touched her on the side with the tip of his finger, she immediately felt a violent pain at that spot, which thereafter persisted constantly, and intensified every time relics were brought near the place; moreover, since that moment a violent agitation had seized her whenever she went to communion or beheld the magician. \[Page 195\]

Magdalena Bavent testified against him: how she had seen in his hands a register, consisting of three closely written sheets, into which he had inscribed the names of those whom he boasted of ruling, or who had assisted him helpfully in his misdeeds. All these had their intention directed toward him; he formed the center in which all these directions met, and mediated their connection with the root-like Evil. Just as in the Savior the highest ground, the supernatural moment, is present, while in the spiritually heightened nature of the Saints the natural element of all visions of the heights prevails; so likewise in the root-like Evil does the higher---or rather deeper---ground of all demonic visions lie, the Sabbath included; and in the central nature of such magical mystagogues, more closely bound up with it, the natural vinculum prevails, in which everything connects itself into a whole.

If now the outer waking life, in all earthly relations, has its logical categories, in which it comprehends all natural effects; then the inner life, whether in light-sleep or in dark-sleep, likewise has its own, in which it comprehends the inner impressions. The color and application of these categories, belonging to the subjective human being, will change with his nature and mood; while that other overarching moment, essentially always the same, takes the fleeting change in the visions---arising from subjectivity---and always directs it enduringly toward the same point, thereby fixing it. Thus will it also be arranged around the Sabbath. In its innermost essence built up around the core of Evil, it is among the peasants predominantly grasped in the character of the Venusberg and a raw debauchery; in the midst of a warlike knighthood it would have assumed the form of a wild hunt and a hellish Valhalla. Here around Picard, and with his retinue, under the enclosure of cloistered nuns, it has---as we have seen---taken the form of an abyssal monastery, in which every sort of blasphemy and desecration of the Holy is practiced. What in the novitiate partly occurred in reality has, in the vision, only been heightened. Especially with Bavent was the degenerate priest closely bound, and one sees clearly that both had concluded a demonic marriage with each other, and that the Sabbath was the foundation on which they built their house. Therefore it is he who, in his patriarchal power, always abducts her to the Sabbath according to his intention; she finds herself there, always inseparably at his side, just as others hold to others---the same persons always meet there together. But she beholds everything always in and through her leader. \[Page 196\]

The Logos in the human being, when in the saints it binds itself more closely to the Logos in God, and in greater proximity to the light also greens forth in its own heightened vegetation and ramifies; has there---as we have noticed---formed its own mystical language. The same Logos, when in the underground shafts, in the proximity of the shadowing principle, torn asunder and cleft in sickly drive-force, will likewise acquire its own idiom. That we see returning here also in the relation of this marriage, concluded under a curse; an own language has formed among the companions, and this has formed its own secret script, which only the initiates understood how to read. The nuns said of her: she had given birth four times on the Sabbath; a testimony that she does not accept, probably because she did not grasp that it happened in the spirit. This marriage was concluded, moreover, for life and death; indeed, beyond death, she would have roused the audacity for it within herself. "In the night of the day on which Picard died," she herself recounts to us, "I was abducted to the barn of Mesnil-Jourdain, five quarter-hours from the monastery, to his corpse. He was at the edge of a grave, and the vicar Boulle raised him somewhat by the shoulders; many demons were gathered around the body."

He urged me thus: it was now time to fulfill my promise to share the same fate with him. I was ordered to seize him by the feet, which I found very cold. I was told to descend three steps into the pit toward him; but when I saw frightful flames therein, I quickly climbed back out, declaring that I had never promised to be damned with him, and that now, having come to my senses, I must take thought for my own salvation; whereupon I was led back to my cell. Twice more I was later brought to him, saw his corpse, and beside it a frightful beast.\" She had already earlier shared in the sufferings of the dying man, which appeared to her quite naturally in the form of demonic temptations; after the hour of death had passed, there came the admonitions to restore the rapport, beyond life, through the conclusion of a marriage. But now, frightened by the flames, she breaks loose from the bond, rends the tie asunder, and the Sabbath is henceforth sunk from her sight. What we have here shown by the example of Picard and of Bavent can likewise be traced into others; although, to our knowledge, in no second case do recorded reminiscences of one of the parties involved permit us deeper insights into the nature of the contracted relation. The Provençal Louis Goffredy of Beauvezer had, by his own confession, among other things received from his uncle a book on magic, which at first he had not esteemed, but whose spells he one day attempted. \[Page 197\]

Then the invoked spirit appeared to him, talked him out of his scruples against a pact, and concluded such a one on the condition that, in return for the threefold surrender of his soul, his body, and all his actions, he would render him threefold service: to make him the most honored of all priests in Provence; to grant him 34 years of life without illness or other affliction; and to inflame in his name all women whom he breathed upon with love for him. He now goes to Marseille and obtains there, at the church of the Accoules, a benefice. The fame of his holiness soon fills the region; all women crowd to his confessional, and he now finds opportunity to apply the magic of his breath, more than a thousand times, as he says, and rejoices as all around bursts into love for him. The wife of the innkeeper Perrin was brought so far that a palpitating heart announced to her his approach from afar each time; another, named Bouchette, and a third, named Pintade, likewise became, one after another, victims of his lusts. But preeminently the three daughters of a nobleman, Mandals de la Pallus, and among them especially the then ten-year-old Magdalena, had aroused this lust of his, because his reputation had granted him free access to the house. Since the girl had taken him as her confessor, he had already in this relation allowed himself many liberties with her, and a deep melancholy had developed in her from such intercourse. She often lived on an estate near the city, and he too went there back and forth. First he breathed upon the mother, so that she too was won over and led the daughter to the seducer; whom he himself likewise so often made to feel the power of his breath, and whom moreover he assailed multifariously with other magic, until she, meanwhile advanced in age, yielded herself to him. When he once found her alone on the country estate, he induced her to accompany him to a cave near the estate, where he promised to show her great wonders. There they found many men and women engaged in dancing around the goat. Magdalena at first felt a great terror, but Goffredy gave her courage: they were only her friends whom she saw gathered here, and whose company she henceforth should belong to. \[Page 198\]

He had previously told her: for her sake he had called upon all the demonic powers to his aid; and since he had now won everything in her, he wished to unite her in the bonds of marriage with the prince of the demons, so that she might find herself united with him and one another in him, with all the greater security, indissolubly. She, who had already previously acknowledged the principle that the spiritual fathers had the right to dispose over their spiritual daughters, also took a liking to this proposal. This was now concluded and carried out in this assembly. She was baptized with sulfur, salt, and urine; she now renounced, from her whole heart, from all her powers, and from her entire soul, her God and her faith, and signed the renunciation with the blood from the little finger of her right hand, which he had incised. Six or seven written vows followed this first one, to draw the already tied knot even tighter. She was then marked on her head, on her heart, and on various other places; and now all those present danced around her jubilantly, and in general acclamation they proclaimed the newly received one as the princess of the Sabbath; which she from then on regularly attended in this capacity. Goffredy himself had already belonged to it since his pact; they had appointed him there as prince of the synagogues of France, Spain, England, Teutschland, Turkey, thus of Europe and a part of Asia; and as such he had visited the Sabbaths of all these countries and presided over them.

Her master thereupon gave her the demon Asmodeus as her attendant, so that he might serve her, guard her for him, and preserve and increase in her the love for him. Things had thus proceeded for a time when the bizarre thought came to her: to enter the convent of the holy Ursula, which flourished under the care of the priests of the Christian Doctrine. Goffredy opposed this plan with the utmost vigor; but since he could not become master over it, he threatened to unleash the powers of hell against the convent. She remained three years with the Ursulines in considerable calm, only that on Wednesdays and Fridays, the critical days when the Sabbath was held, a black melancholy would take possession of her, which made her unbearable to herself and to all the world. She is now, after her reception, possessed by five demons, and beside her Louise Cappel by three; and the otherwise so peaceful convent becomes full of the noise and contortions of the possessed, so that terror and horror seize the superiors.

Here too it is visibly apparent: that a somnambulistic predisposition lay at the foundation, which a bad priest had turned toward the demonic, and finally heightened to possession. The means he first employed was the breath, that aura in which so many natural connections are forged; in the ecclesiastical so often the conductor of the spirit from above and of his gifts, therefore also in the anti-ecclesiastical of the spirit from below and of his curse. The melancholy in early youth marks the first stage of the evil. This is heightened with persistently maintained sensuality, until the demonic witches' sleep with the entire scenery of the Sabbath has developed itself, and the second stage is now fully formed. Now the incipient partial possession emerges, and with it the third stage, where Asmodeus has taken possession of those organs to which the actions of sensuality are also directed. Finally the fourth stage has begun, when, in an impulse of return, those earlier melancholic attacks, still chained to the Sabbath time, have likewise returned, and now at last the full fivefold possession with all its manifestations sets in. \[Page 199\]

It is worthy of note that here it is expressly stated that the marriage with the seducer is not concluded immediately with him, but with the demon. The Church is the bride of the Redeemer, and all spiritual marriages within her compass are concluded in him. In the same way, the Church of the Demon is bound to him by a like bond of marriage; all her members draw one another together because they are drawn by him, all their connections are thus concluded in him. This too is remarkable enough: that the instincts in this case have already driven forth a kind of universal monarchy over two parts of the world, which should have been allotted to him who on the mountain height had paid homage to the denying spirit.

#### B. The Spiritual Magic Means in the Misuse of the Sacraments and Sacramentals

If now such a hierophant has been found for the formation of a branch of the underworld Church, and has begun the work of appropriation around him; then this work will be powerfully advanced if such binding means stand at his disposal: those which on the one hand permanently bind to him all who already stand in community with him; on the other hand, working outward, help to draw others across into the same through sensuality, terror, fear, despair. Such binding means are now the maleficia of a twofold kind: such as aim merely at temptation, and others that bind more closely in possession. We have already found the like in the earliest times among the demonic sects; and tradition has known how to report to us concerning the irresistibility of their effects, once the assent of the will has joined in. Through the more recent times the evil has propagated itself, and the magic books are full of praise for their efficacy.

Like the sacraments of the Church, a material enters into their composition, mostly of obscene kind and bordering on putrefaction and decay. As form, the holy then unites itself with that which thus in abhorrence outrages nature; and thus one of the sacramentals in the lower degrees, higher up a sacrament, in the deepest sense the Eucharist; and the gray or black powder that has now arisen is sprinkled about, or taken in food, and now does its never-failing work. As alkahest and actual spiritual death-tincture, there prevails in this realm that olla podrida which, according to the account of Ma ria of Sains, Goffredy first brewed. It consisted of consecrated hosts, specially desecrated beforehand, of the blood consecrated by him on the Sabbath, mixed with bones from the goat, the powder of skulls of murdered children, the seed of the men and women present, blood, hairs, nails, and all uncleanness.

Three times had the demons held council over the new invention, the inventor and his confidants had pronounced the words of consecration over it, and they had then sent it to the prince of the demons, and he had imparted to it the effective power, infallibly to bring forth possession. The Sabbath brought him in thanks there for many boy-sacrifices; but the inventor of the new poison-means was on that account elevated to the highest principality over the magic realms. We let the truth or falsehood of these specific statements rest here for themselves, and investigate here only what truth there is in the whole matter. The sacraments and sacramentals are in their inmost essence withdrawn from the natural region of things, and belong to a higher order of the same. Their effect is therefore also, in the ordinary course of things, directed toward this order of salvation, and spreads itself only exceptionally down to the lower natural orders, since these by no means entirely close themselves to them. \[Page 200\]

For there is also a natural side to them, in which their higher being dwells; and they are now received into the double order of man, affecting the higher order preferentially through their essential nature, but in the deeper order finding the paths of transition mediated through their matter; only that in the current circumstances of life this their influence hides itself behind the plasticity of the envelope. But if this envelope has become more easily penetrable in the saints, and more opened in transparency and permeability; then also this their action will become perceptible in the more mobile medium, and we have seen in the second volume of this book many examples of that hagioscopic susceptibility for such influences.

Sister Margaretha of the Holy Sacrament was thus, in her twelfth year, overtaken by violent convulsions, followed by a twelve-day state of half-sleep. Then a frightful condition came over her, from which only the laying on of a scapular freed her. Soon there followed such a heaviness in all her limbs that she could no longer hold herself on her feet, and, lying on the bed, could not move any of her leaden-heavy limbs; so that for seven to eight days she could scarcely take any food to herself. Then again, since all the doctors' remedies proved ineffective, violent convulsions followed. In this state one heard her call out with the accent of an enraptured soul: Let me regain my strength before the most holy Sacrament! The sisters resolved, upon her repeated cry, to carry the sick one into the choir; but when they tried to take the suppliant into their arms, none was able to lift her alone; only the strongest among them could at last, with unspeakable effort, bring her to the place. As soon as she had arrived at the door of the choir, there came, like a shining cloud from the tabernacle, which enveloped her and drove out the spirits. The cloud not only restored strength to her body, but made it so agile that she was sometimes carried from the choir door, at other times even from the cloister gate, as far as the altar railing. A wonderful peace descended upon her, and she, who through her illness had also lost the use of her sight, yet saw the object of her longing when it was exposed.

Once the efficacy of the remedy was known, they brought her from time to time into the choir and let her remain there for 3--4 hours; when she then returned to the sickroom, all her sufferings immediately returned. The doctors attributed her ills to a congestion of evil humors in the brain, and applied cupping to her head against it; she endured everything with the greatest resignation, although she well recognized the uselessness of the procedure. They then wanted to provide an outlet for the fluids between the skull and the brain membrane through trepanation. It was done, but no fluid nor vapor could be seen: everything was perfectly sound and healthy. This determined the superior, a wise and virtuous woman, to make a trial with obedience. In the convent was preserved the little cloak of the saintly Cardinal de Bérulle; this she laid upon her with the words: My sister, be healthy out of obedience to our most revered father! Immediately her convulsions ceased, which upon its return happened several times with the same success. At last the superior spoke the words: Be completely healthy in obedience, without convulsions, ravings, and blindness, and eat unhindered like the others. Immediately she was freed from all her ills, and henceforth ate without discomfort, as the doctors attested with official certificates. \[Page 201\]

Thus, the sacraments, on the good side, in properly attuned dispositions, produce such physical changes; then, toward the left side as well, this influence will not fail, provided that in the organs there exists that easily movable mobility. Such a mobility-attuned excitability is never lacking here, where the true virtuosity is at hand; only is it arranged, according to its kind, for infernal stimuli. Such a nature will now, as we have already seen in many examples, spasmodically close itself entirely to the higher, sacramental stimulus, and reject it as hostile. If it is therefore to enter into her, something homogeneous to the repelling element must mediate the transition, and that can be nothing other than the profaning, blaspheming element, which, by veiling the inner indestructible form, now becomes a means of appropriation between opposing natures. The same personal guilt that enwraps the dominated will in the malicious one has now also embraced the sacrament with its abomination; and as it reaches over with this congenial atmosphere into the circle of life, its direct direction is turned into the perverted one prevailing there; and with the same energy with which it otherwise acts elevatingly, we now see it exert a depressing effect, one physically perceptible as well.

Thus the efficacy of this kind of magical means is understood, which, deflecting from healthy life, by no means lead it over into the morbid state; but upon that already inwardly diseased, they exert their full influence, and in the case of a certain attunement, draw it deeper and deeper down into confusion. In all reports on sorcery, frequent mention is made of these means; the belief in their power is rooted most deeply in this entire domain, just as much as the belief in the power of medicines in the natural domain; and there must have lain in this conviction a truth, but one of a magical nature, to be sure. The entire practice rested on the principle of the Manicheans: below in the depths is the dwelling of the Prince of Night, who, surrounded there by his people at the borders of darkness, ceaselessly labors to capture away the rays of the uncreated light, and to lay the words of God in fetters. The simple consequence was now that for these emanations of the divinity, which had fallen into the captivity of the powers of darkness, a food and a drink for preservation and strengthening had to be prepared; and that was that magical repast, prepared from the sacraments and sacramentals; just as those rays of light are captured into the material night, so into the horror and the abhorrence and the putrefaction, the frothing of sin.

Very instructive and significant is what occurred in the convent of Louviers regarding such things. As a result of the errors and confusions there, many nuns had become possessed; they were exorcised, and from the statements of their spirits it emerged that Picard had applied six different kinds of magic within the convent. One was composed to keep the nuns in constant discord; another, to awaken in their hearts a disordered inclination toward Picard and la Bavent; the third, to shake their chastity; the fourth, to awaken in them an inner aversion to faith, hope, and love, and to provoke blasphemies against God in them; the fifth, to arouse in them a desire for the Sabbath and all magic; the sixth, to produce in them a contempt and abhorrence toward all sacraments. They now continued the exorcisms to compel them to indicate the places where they were hidden, and to bring them to light. \[Page 202\]

The sorely pressed ones at last found themselves compelled to obey; and a great multitude of persons drawn together were eyewitnesses as they were truly found in their hiding places, and authentic verbal protocols were drawn up concerning it. On 14 June 1643, in accordance with the declaration of the spirit in Sister Maria of the Holy Sacrament, who called himself Putiphar, in the evening between 7 and 8 in her chamber, from a wooden paneling of the walls that had never seemed to be opened, the first was drawn forth. The second, the last among those enumerated above, was found on the 30th of July under the high altar six feet deep under the earth. On the 19th in the evening at half eleven a third in the sacristy, from the same depth; and on the 24th of August at half twelve in the cloister between the four doors a fourth. On the 8th of September at eight o'clock in the evening another followed, nine feet deep under the pillar of the new building, brought to light in the presence of the Archbishop of Toulouse. Again two others on the epistle and gospel sides of the altar, from a depth of 6 to 8 feet; and yet a tenth on the 1st of December between 1 and 2 after midnight, in the interior of the choir, near the door; from a place that had more than twelve feet of depth. An eleventh and a twelfth then came still on the 22nd of January, and were drawn to the light from a depth of more than 7 feet, directly under the image of the Holy Virgin in her chapel,

The possessed now spoke with wonder, concerning all these magic instruments, those who had indicated their place even before they were found, circumstantially of their composition, of the inscriptions under which they had been fabricated on the Sabbath; they gave all their components, the ligatures and knots applied to them, the letters with which they were marked, and all other circumstances, without ever erring in the smallest detail. Before one began to dig, they designated some spot on the floor, and indicated: directly perpendicular beneath it, in a depth of 6 to 7, 8 to 9 up to 12 feet, the magic lay. One proceeded accordingly in digging, and always found it at the spot indicated by the exorcism. They stated: some were marked with the letters M. P. and M. B., the names of Picard and of Bavent; they testified that at a certain place lay the testament of David and Picard written in the Arabic language of the Sabbath; and everything was found exactly at the place they had indicated. No one could read and understand the writing; but the two nuns who had attested their presence read it one after the other, word for word, and explained it in agreement with each other. \[Page 203\]

In all these things deception lay very near, and it is obvious that all these results are utterly worthless, if one did not employ all prudence to exclude the possibility of fraud. Let us see how it was handled in this regard. The next suspicion that had to arise was naturally: that the possessed, who descended into the pit to bring the hidden thing to light, had themselves carried it down with them. The appeal to their simplicity, education, and conscientiousness could here give no sure guarantee; because all that became invalid in the paroxysm. Therefore, before they descended into the pit, for greater security, they were most strictly searched by other sensible, prudent nuns of good judgment, and moreover unmolested by the spirits. With them other thoughtful persons, clerics and doctors, descended into the trench, who kept them sharply under watch, and never permitted them to come near the place where the amulets were hidden. One was accustomed to give the searchers a pole with a hook into their hand; and all had to remain at a distance from the spot as far as the pole reached, and to bring the magic to light from there with the point of the hook.

More than that, the edge of the trench was lined with other people who paid very close attention to the hands and all the movements of the possessed woman, and who would not easily have missed any practiced deception. It was advantageous that the time of discovery always fell at night; for now many torches were lit, which, properly distributed, mutually dispelled all shadows on the walls of the pit; so that everything stood in full light, which would not have been achievable by day. The Bishop of Embrun, who was present everywhere, moreover had the Most Blessed Sacrament held over the heads of the exorcised possessed woman in the pit at the decisive moment; in order to strike down any deceit also through the terrors of sacrilege. Despite all this caution, the result was always the same: the possessed woman dug up the earth at the indicated spot with her lance; the paper in which the charm was wrapped then became visible in its whiteness through a kind of glow; but it immediately clouded when touched by the air, and became dirty, moldy, and unsightly. But the possessed woman, in the instant when she perceived the hidden thing, was cast backward as if struck by a thunderbolt, uttered a terrible scream, and the spirits howled and roared out of her like wolves and tigers. \[Page 204\]

Since all these precautionary measures that had been taken still did not fully dispel every doubt, as long as the nuns descended into the pit; the method of procedure was also changed in this respect when searching for the last three talismans. The one buried under the choir door was exhumed on 15 December 1645, and two others in the Loreto chapel on 3 January; so that the possessed woman, kept far from the edge of the trench, indicated the spot from outside with a 15-foot-long pole, where the buried item was then found, without the finder ever approaching it. The last one was likewise indicated by the possessed woman from outside the trench, with her face turned away; as she thrust the pole into the earth at one spot, and then ordered them to dig further. From time to time she then called out: One moment more! At last she made a violent thrust, always with her face turned away; and immediately the little package came to light, two finger-breadths from the tip of her pole. Skepticism now had to yield to the evidence of the facts, and the commissioners, sent on behalf of the queen and the council of state, with the Archbishop of Toulouse at their head, issued an authentic testimony as to with what caution and deliberation the proceedings had been conducted in their presence; how they had placed the searching nun between them, and how the paper, white and intact at the first finding, had become moldy, dissolved, and dirty under their eyes.

And yet, despite all this praiseworthy caution, deceptions may have slipped in among them; not exactly such as were consciously devised and carried out by the girls, but begun in the paroxysm under the impulsion of the power possessing them, and completed with the skill that then entered in. The voices called out from the possessed women several times during the whole search: I will play a trick on you! I assure you, you are being fooled! In the case of one who had thus called out, the outcome seemed indeed to confirm the warning. She had indicated a spot with her 12-foot rod; they searched and could find nothing. They therefore emptied a portion of the earth at the bishop's feet to examine it; the bishop held the hands of the possessed woman in his own. She claimed that the sought-after item was in this earth, and threw herself upon it; now, after she had searched for some time, some of those present saw the charm under the little fingers of her hands, and thought that she had rather trickily carried it into the pile.

One sees truth and lies border in these realms so closely upon one another that they falsify and mingle with each other mutually, and a hair-sharp separation of the two becomes nearly impossible. What, however, emerges in all these attempts is a result that, given all that has gone before, can by no means surprise us. As natural stimulants pass unnoticed over life tuned to the middle average temperature, but touch the more tender resonating part most strongly; so too will it be arranged in like manner with the stimulants of a higher kind, and their relation to the higher spirituality. As the rhabdomancer thus feels out the metals and salts in the bosom of the earth; so too does the possessed one harbor the same excitability for the magic stimulants to which precisely his condition appears tied; and this will make all the narrated events fully explainable to us.

#### C. The Spiritual Possession

\[Page 205\]

The curse that rests upon the head of the favored ones in the nocturnal regions acts like the rigid, staring gaze of the serpent upon the mobile nature of the birds; fettering, bewitching, banishing, and then drawing into itself. It thus forms a whirl around itself, and whoever falls into this whirlpool is driven about and swallowed down like the ship in the maw of the sea; whereby those artificial magic stimulants act subsidiarily, like magnets, to strengthen and heighten the pull. The consequence of being bound in this magic circle is now the state of obsession, in which the tightly held grasp of the relations binds all the entangled ones into a real community of fellowship. This state usually leads in gradually through a whole series of visions, apparitions, and ghostly occurrences, in many intermediate stages; which, increasing gradually, finally bring about the height of the enchantment. This gradual increase was quite strikingly noticeable in the convent of Louviers. It began with the Sister Barbe de St. Michael beholding, several times at night, in her cell a great number of lights kindled, and soon she herself could not take three steps without her knee being violently struck against the ground, until at last she fell to the earth.

When she and some others, who afterward came into the same state with her, went to Communion; then they saw the grating toward the church illuminated with torches, but pursued by all sorts of phantoms, which, after frightening them greatly, flew off through the chimney. At the same time one saw bowls and pots falling in the kitchen without anyone touching them. To Sister Maria de St. Nicolas came a phantom in the form of Picard, at about the time of sunrise, sat upon her bed, and spoke to her; while at another time, amid great noise, all sorts of utensils were overturned around her. Upon the Sister of St. Laurent it came from the heel, and made her fall often; but soon it climbed up to the head, so that henceforth severe headache alternated with the ailment in the foot. Still more strongly was Sister Anna de la Nativité disturbed. She saw a phantom in terrible forms that stood motionless before her the whole night in her cell; if she went anywhere, it hurried ahead of her; in the choir it performed all sorts of juggling tricks before her to amuse her; and threatened her fiercely when she discovered the matter to the superior, who advised her to treat all the spook with contempt. At the time when she performed any act of humility and renunciation, the form fled; but upon returning, made what had happened ridiculous. During Mass it gaped its maw against the assembled, and threatened to devour them; set naked people before her, and sometimes struck them hard as well. Once during the Preface there appeared to her a crucifix, from which a voice declared itself to be her husband, promised her his protection, freed an arm to embrace her, and recommended to her only to keep their relationship secret. \[Page 206\]

Since she did not answer at all, the apparition finally vanished amid great noise. Against these temptations she held a nine-day prayer before the Holy Virgin. Then an exceedingly bright-shining sun appeared before her, and the voice brought forth the same language from her, gave her sweet words of love, and urged her to union with the eternal light. Since she did not consent, the voice first fell silent; then later the glow also went out, when she made the sign of the cross against the illusion. The apparition soon returned in the form of other sisters and the superior; during the fast she saw meat dishes in abundance, smelled the odor of flesh everywhere, and men were there who urged her to seize them. Then followed violent convulsions and rigidities that pressed her hard; and the superior found her several times lying on the ground, stiff as wood.

During a service in the choir, her breviary was thrown from her four or five times without her moving her arm, and during the prayer she herself was thrust forward. When she once came out of herself, her sandals were tied without her moving; her rule was torn from her sleeve and thrown away, sometimes all the way over the altar; and the same happened with her rosary. Another time, in the presence of the superior, this rule was hurled into the middle of the fire; the superior quickly pulled it out again, and found it not damaged, although it had lain in the flames long enough. Another time, her relics were torn from her neck; the superior fastened them with three knots in the name of the Trinity, and the confessor forbade them to be torn away any further. It did not happen anymore; but from then on she was more often strangled at the girdle. When she sang with the others in the choir, she was often lifted a cubit high; and when others, to prevent this, placed their feet on hers, they felt these themselves lifted. Finally the spirit came in the form of the Holy Virgin, confirming all earlier apparitions as if they had come from her Son, and repeatedly demanding silence from her. \[Page 207\]

She had to overcome some reluctance, also to disclose this to her superiors; and on account of her fear, two sisters were assigned to her at night with a burning lamp. But the lights were repeatedly blown out, the utensils thrown into disorder, and the beds shaken for so long until the light was relit. With Sister Maria of the Holy Spirit it was done in the same way, the same noise and throwing and falling surrounded her; three nights in a row circles were made before her, and she heard the words: When we are finished, then we have you at the right point! When she knelt at Christmas before the exposed Sacrament, reflected on her life, and offered herself to the Lord, suddenly a horror in the spirit came over her; blasphemous ideas rose up in her, and she no longer dared to look up at the Sacrament; for she saw there things that the human mind cannot bear. In the following night she felt a heaviness that laid itself three times upon her head; then she lost her senses, and could neither speak nor move herself. Thereupon two phantoms appeared to her, one large, which seated itself in a chair; the other dwarfish, only a cubit high, which settled on her stomach; both spoke with each other as if the whole convent, and she herself also, belonged to them. Meanwhile she lay under her alp unconscious, and could not bring forth her usual saying: Et verbum caro factum est! although the two constantly mocked her to do so. But what was most remarkable of all on this occasion was what happened with Sister Maria of the Holy Sacrament, and what she herself recorded. The event began with that touch at the pit of the heart, which her Picard, as we have mentioned earlier, had made.

When I had gone to bed in the evening after nine o'clock, she recounts, three strong fire sparks fell from the ceiling onto the bedcover, such that I had great fear on account of it. When I once imposed the discipline upon myself, the scourge was snatched from my hand and thrown into my face; a light was blown out for me in the attic, and I was seized by the girdle and thrown down the stairs. Another time a heavy mass was laid upon my shoulders, such that I thought I would suffocate; when I dragged myself with difficulty to the worthy Mother, I felt how the mass tumbled down onto a step of the stairs with a great crash; but I was thrown down at the same time, such that blood gushed forth from my mouth and nose. I was to ask fearlessly, if it returned: Who are you, what do you want here, and why do you turn to me?

When therefore I again one night around 11 o'clock heard a confused noise, I spoke the words. A terrible voice said: My sister, I have a secret to entrust to you! I cried out in horror; people came running, and still heard the sound of a blow that I received. The following night the spirit came in the form of a deceased convent sister, begging for certain prayers for the comfort of her soul, which however the confessor forbade in the prescribed form, allowing me some other devotional exercises. After some days a voice came, as if from a flash of lightning, thanking me for what I had done; I took it for the voice of the soul that I had freed, and formed a good opinion of myself. \[Page 208\]

Several apparitions in various forms followed, some very frightful; and I was plagued in every way. Once my signature was tricked from me for a paper that was supposed to be a creed; in truth however, as it was later read to me, it contained all imaginable blasphemies. Again it came to me in the form of a convent sister who was my friend, who now brought me roses and carnations; then again struck, bit, and scratched me. One night I saw a young, naked man standing before me; I made the sign of the cross against it, and sprinkled holy water; but the form only mocked me. I, holding it for a ghost, then went toward it; but when I noticed that it did not vanish, I cried out with all my strength. The worthy Mother came running, asked what was the matter with me; but I only kept crying, holding fast to the form, which dragged me to the chimney, and in doing so lifted me two feet high. I feared being dragged out of the convent thereby, let go on that account, and now fell to the ground; where they found me, my hands full of black, reddish-glinting, stinking ointment.

They cleansed me of the filth, and then threw the cloth into the fire. The confessor now ordered that one of the older sisters go to me from time to time, to see how I was each time. But if this one omitted it once, then the demon came in her form, flattered itself into my trust; and as I gradually placed some faith in the deceiving words, and confided my perplexity amid the many apparitions to the seeming figure, this one advised me: no longer to entrust myself to people, nor to appear before my superiors, confessor, and directors; God would lead me by his own ways, to him alone must I turn my whole trust. In later meetings the form then let itself be drawn into various teachings, which amounted to this: all flesh is like hay; the Lord had therefore taken it upon himself, not to honor it, but to make it contemptible to us through the assumption of so many mistreatments. For that reason he had also reproved his apostles that through too great attachment to his humanity they had become unreceptive to the spirit.

For his true worshippers worship God in spirit and in truth; only the carnal ones have made the body into a sacrament for themselves, which they now adore; whereas the divine Majesty abhors flesh and blood. She then declared herself with equal definiteness against another life; hell is an invention of men, who knew no other way to maintain order here below. The true hell is rather on earth in the midst of men, and there also paradise is to be found; it is therefore a great folly to give up a present good for a fantastical hope that will never be fulfilled; for the soul must die with the body, otherwise God would have spoken untruth when he said: Thou shalt surely die. \[Page 209\]

I became wholly confused, and at last told it to my confessor; and now the apparition sought, in my opinion, to ruin this one too, by appearing one morning in his form in my cell, and making me a formal declaration of love. Amidst my horror at this, doubts yet arose in me again, and I drove him away with the sign of the cross. The apparition came likewise another time in his form to the speaking grille, until the arrival of the real one drove it away. The spirit then made me believe that the confessor handed me a magic potion in the host of the sacrament every time; as a sign of this I should pay attention, and I would find it marked red every time. I now looked more closely indeed, and beheld on it as he had told me. Another time the hosts appeared to me half-blackened, and only the firm conviction of the confessor's spotless virtue could destroy this illusion for me.

Now the matter took another turn. One day in the early morning, a glow like that of a summer dawn illuminated my cell; and a beautiful youth of fifteen or sixteen years appeared to me in it, who greeted me graciously, saying: he was sent to me for my protection, because I had found grace before God, who had been pleased with what I had done hitherto. But he wanted now to lead me further on his ways, and had sent him to me for that purpose. For this, it was first of all necessary that I trust in him alone; for men, since their fall, have taken ignorance, mortality, and bestiality into themselves, and now one blind man would lead another. Silence and secrecy is therefore the first thing he demands of thee; for thou canst not serve two masters, and where God's Majesty is active, the reason of man must stand aside. Say therefore, like the mother of the Savior: Behold the handmaid of the Lord; be it unto me according to thy word! and henceforth ask no more at the high priest of the law.

The conversation lasted three hours; I had weighed everything carefully, and found nothing suspicious; he truly seemed to me to be my guardian angel, and I thanked God in full joy, for that day I felt no temptation. On the following day his discourse turned to the predestination of God; how he chooses his brides, and leads them on unusual paths, and allows them not the smallest thought of infidelity, which I therefore must combat even as it arises. Then for three days in succession it was spoken of the essence of God, and of the nature of men, who were created in the image of the angels---who themselves are images of God---but have defiled this image, and now wrongly call themselves fathers, masters, and doctors, and true Christians; whereas God, as Christ has said, should alone be called Father. In the sixth conference it was set forth how God created the angels from his essence, who, being of like nature with him, are also bound in perfect union with his substance. The two conferences next following spread themselves over the diversity of opinions and the disunity among men; for which God therefore sent his own Son, to bring them back to obedience. \[Page 210\]

Gabriel was there the bringer of the commandments of the Most High, and since he found her willing, he entered into her, and incarnated himself in her body; therefore he is the one whom men call the Redeemer of the world. I too should arm myself with prayer to receive the approaching Bridegroom. At the now following return, he asked me: whether I was now resolved to serve God in utmost perfection and renunciation. I replied: how I had therefore left the world to serve God; body and soul stood without reservation at his service. He praised me for it, and I felt such comfort and longing to be pleasing to God that I could scarcely bear it. He said now: Permit me to touch your heart, to strengthen it, and to fix it in this love.

At these words a kind of fear came over me, and I laid my hands on my breast: Know that before my confessor I have made a resolution to permit no one, whoever it may be, any touching! He said: he had done it only for my testing; but I replied: If it is God's will, then do it, otherwise I can never will it! I saw his countenance change, he seemed angry, yet without his splendor being diminished. He touched me, and said: that I was wrong to doubt him. For the tenth time he came shining brighter than ever before, to cleanse me, as he said, from my imperfections. He touched my heart, but in all chastity, and no evil thought arose in me, only a longing to love God; and I truly held him to be my good angel.

At his eleventh visit he asked me what I had, because I showed some unrest; I confessed to him at last that I had been in temptation the whole day to disclose the matter to my confessor. He reproved me for it, and said: Give me your tongue, that I may touch it and strengthen it. I could not help telling him: that all these touchings of his highly displeased me; because they seemed to me unsuitable for a spirit. He replied: You must mortify your own judgment even more strongly, for you will only your own will, and not that of the Lord! So do then, I replied, what pleases God's Majesty; he touched, however, only after a long speech on submission to God's will, my tongue. In the morning he came earlier than usual, in the full splendor of his beauty, and spoke so movingly of the glory of the blessed that my heart was ravished; and he, after touching my heart and eyes, had to keep his hand on the former to give me strength. They found me as if out of my senses, the whole day I could scarcely hold myself; and since I reproached myself for it: as if I sought only my own comfort in the All, and therefore grasped the nettles, and gave myself a hard discipline; he fully approved at evening what I had done. \[Page 211\]

He returned in the morning, an exceedingly beautiful rose in his hand, which he offered me. But I covered my face, beseeching him: that he might moderate his all too great splendor, because I could not bear it. He touched my eyes and heart, I took the rose and kissed it; but he spoke to me of the immortality of the soul, and how only one man had been immortal, because without sin; since sin makes the spirit mortal, as the body is. I rejoiced over all these speeches, and my better knowledge before other men, and attributed it to my unceasing zeal to serve God. In the evening I had withdrawn to my cell, and prayed to God: that he, if the form was my good angel, might let it appear to me now for my comfort; but not permit that I be deceitfully led astray. He was immediately present, and after some exchanges of words I said to him: O you who are so good, and will the peace of souls, disclose yet to my confessor or to one of my superiors the relation that exists between us, so that I may find full peace!

He replied: the most beautiful gift that he could bestow upon me was my complete seclusion from all fellowship with men. In doing so, he touched my heart: "See," he said, "this is the seat of the passions; but you feel none at the touch, for I purify and sanctify all that approaches me in simplicity and faithfulness of heart." In the fourteenth meeting, he spoke to me of God and the fall of the angels, which had occurred only because, through lack of steadfastness and trust in their will, they had moved unstably; and thereby stepped out of their union with God, the highest bliss, to which they, as intelligences whom God had not called forth from nothing but from his own essence, had been predestined. All this was said so beautifully and compellingly that I cannot reproduce it, yet some apprehension always lingered in the background for me; so that when he demanded a pledge of fidelity from me, I always replied: "If God so wills!" or: "I have placed God in full possession of my heart!"

The next day, after Communion, a great dryness had come over me, and I complained of it to him. He said: he had imposed it upon me for my testing, and to draw me away from all earthly things; and then he asked me three times in succession, with a sweet voice: "My daughter! my beloved! do you love me?" Each time I lost the use of my senses; he had to bring me back to myself by touching me, and then he vanished with the words: "Three more days, and you shall be forever established in my grace." After the next Communion, the same sadness and aridity returned, and I withdrew quickly into my cell. My spirit soon visited me again and reproached me for my weakness in bearing my trial; nothing on this earth is won without effort. Finally, on the last day, when he came and inquired about the state of my inner self, I said to him: nothing troubles me at present, for I have come to full resignation in God's will; although, whatever I may undertake, I cannot master a certain fear of possible deception. Yet I promise, if nothing contrary to God arises in me, deep silence. He approved of all this, and spoke to me ravishingly of the joys that awaited me. \[Page 212\]

In the evening, the confessor had me summoned to the speaking grille; I went with reluctance. When I appeared, he asked me: how things stood with me, and what was passing within me? I answered: things stood well, and only good passed within me! He, in turn: "So something is indeed passing in you, and I want to know what it is!" "Jesus! my father," I said, "if something were passing between God and me, I would be bound to disclose it! For the left hand should know nothing of the good that the right hand does." He now commanded me, upon holy obedience, to tell him what I wished to conceal; and I said: nothing except that I had come to a full indifference toward all creatures. He found this well done, but warned me to be on my guard; lest under the pretext of the good I be led into evil. "But," I said, "my father! is there something in my behavior that perhaps arouses suspicion?" "I have no suspicion," was the reply, "but rather fear of deception; your fainting spells after holy Communion, the sadness on your face, your silence about the state of your conscience for fifteen days or three weeks, make me believe that something is the matter with you." "Truly!" I replied, "for some time now I have been withdrawing from men, because true consolation is only with God; from men, however, only hindrance comes." "Well!" he said, "I believe you, my daughter, and I pray to God that he may let you recognize the truth, so that you may not be deceived, and that all may end to his glory!"

I looked at him without saying a word, for I did not know what I should do; but I thought to myself: this is a temptation, for I have today pledged fidelity and silence. He, noticing my uncertainty, said: I see well that you do have something to share with me after all! No, I replied, I am only pondering the words I have heard, and at the same time I rose to leave. When I was in the middle of the parlor, I stopped to consider what I should do. He called me back: My daughter! I beg you, tell me the truth---that was his address; do you perhaps have some fear? I fear no one but God, was my answer. Then go on your way, I believe you! When I was near the door, I turned toward him and said: Farewell, my father! He in turn: Farewell, my daughter! I kept looking at him, and said once more: Farewell, my father! I am going now. He called me back yet again: My daughter! one more little word; come closer, I will tell it to you softly. I approached the speaking grille, and he gently took hold of the cord with which I was girded, and said to me: I see clearly that you have something to share with me; I will not let you go now until you have spoken the word to me, even if I should not depart from here until tomorrow! \[Page 213\]

I was greatly astonished, and said: It is true, my father! something extraordinary is taking place between me and my good angel. God imparts many graces to me through him; but I cannot speak of all this, because I have pledged fidelity and silence, and I fear otherwise to lose the consolation of his visits. The confessor replied to these words: In truth, my daughter! this angel is the devil himself! An immense trembling seized my whole body, my teeth chattered against each other so that I could not speak. The confessor spoke prayers and exorcisms over me, and in the end had to summon the worthy mother to my assistance. The trembling lasted perhaps half an hour; when it had passed, the father wanted me to abjure all the words of agreement and affection that I might have spoken. I replied: as I renounce everything that I might have said contrary to God's will. But he would not be satisfied with that; I was to renounce the angel entirely and regard him as a devil; I, however, refused to proceed further that day, saying that one must first see what the matter truly was. I promised him in this that I would faithfully report the further outcome. He handed me over to the sister with the charge: not to leave me until she had brought me to bed.

I, when I was alone, spoke words of courage to myself, and when all in the convent had become quiet, he came in his clarity; but with an expression of such raging anger as if he wished to destroy me. He reproached me as unfaithful, ungrateful, wretched; I knew not what misfortune awaited me; only repentance and a solemn vow of greater fidelity for the future could save me. He looked at me with a piercing, loving gaze: Promise me, he cried, only better fidelity for the future, and I will forgive your weakness! I felt a great tenderness toward him, but at the same time a fear of giving my consent, and without answering, I turned to the other side. But he immediately turned me back, and said: What is this, my daughter? How changed you are! Do you not wish me to take possession of your heart? I replied: This heart belongs to God alone; I do not regret what I did earlier in the confessional. If you are from God, then it will also be pleasing to you; but if you wish to remove all suspicion from me, appear before the confessor at the speaking grille in your full clarity, and reveal to him what you have undertaken for my guidance. If he approves everything and declares you to be an angel of God, then I promise you unwavering fidelity; if not, then leave off from me, unworthy as I am. \[Page 214\]

With every word that I spoke, the expression on his face changed; at last he became furious, and losing all composure, he said: Wretch! Is this the fulfillment of your promise from yesterday? What have you noticed in me since then that is hateful to God? I see, I have shown you too much love, you have turned the medicine into poison; once more, do not force me, after so much mildness, to turn to severity against you! I was so moved that it was a close thing---I would have agreed. But I said: Even if I promise you fidelity, I cannot keep it; the confessor will question me, and for all the world I will not deceive him. Give me only your heart, he said, and I will manage it somehow. My heart belongs to God, I cried out; I renounce you, wretched deceiver! Now I see, you are not from God, and I despise your flattering words and threats. Ha, unhappy one! With this word I deliver you to your enemy, as punishment for you! With that he vanished. That was on April 4, 1642; splendor and glory were gone, and from then on he returned to her armed only with all terrors.

Nächtliche cross and zigzag wanderings, one will say, of a nun dancing about in the garden of love, who by day, through cloister and rule, saw herself excluded from entering the enchanted gardens, and now in the silence of the night recovered from her harm. The confessor was the lord and master of the waking world that surrounded her; and in her prose, her asceticism, her penances and her constraints he kept her enclosed. But when she had sunk into the arms of sleep in her solitary cell, then the poetess awoke within her; the alleged angel was the lord of the new dream world; he touched her creative imagination with a glowing finger, and this then gave birth to the extravagant images in which she reveled, entirely forgetting the troubles of waking states. But soon a strife arose between the two realms, for the master of prose and the master of poetry could not in the long run get along under one roof. The mother of the nun had cried out, at that time when the goddess-mother Isis had tried to burn out the daughter, purifying her in her flames.

The master of prose was crude; by her girdle he drew the reluctant one down into his phlegm. In the sinking down, her inner being was transformed; the genius of gentle beauty turned for her, in frightful fashion, into a terrible demon; the idyllic drama, since the tragic element had veered into the comic, was translated into a baroque parody of itself---that is, she became possessed as punishment for her fall; with a different outcome, the monk would have become a Philistine, just as the peasants who had blasphemed Latona were transformed into frogs. --- \[Page 215\]

All this sounds round and witty; but it fits only poorly with the dubious barter between the two regions. This alleged dream world finds itself, below and to the side, built around and framed by the waking world; and of the arabesques that traverse it, a part does indeed take root, in its plant-like half, in sobriety, and only the winged spirits in the flower calyces grow over into the enclosed realm. For just as the strong, encroaching color in the eye awakens its complementary color; so one may assume that the imagination complements the prose of life with poetry awakened from within, in contrast. But these poetic dreams and foams have at other times entered very tangibly into life; and one cannot deny that the plant-like then took root in the dream world, but the marvelous, which had blossomed above, was carried out into the waking world. When the possessions broke out in the cloister, and the Bishop of Evreux Picard, proceeding thither in a six-horse carriage; the possessed nuns came, who knew how to run swiftly like the wind over the roofs and the walls, and who walked over the waters without sinking, nimbly towards him, threw themselves between the horses, and it succeeded for them more than once to halt the carriage.

Was that perhaps also a dream which the horses had dreamed? When in the choir the breviaries and order rules of the tormented flew about, desks and utensils were overturned at their approach; when their sandals hung on their veils; when at dead of night a murmur of many voices arose around them; when the dreaming Marie herself was thrown down the stairs: were all these wondrous things perhaps dreams that had escaped from the dream-world into the waking world? When the same Marie once, in the presence of witnesses, ran with impetuosity up a mulberry tree to its outermost tender summit branches, and now from branch to branch circled and flew around the tree like a bird; did the tree that had borne this wondrous fruit stand in the open cloister garden, or in the nun's cell behind the dream portal? Thus the truth that has fallen from waking into the alleged world of illusion stands opposed by another, which has stepped forth from this world of illusion into the real; each of the two thus has a root of truth within itself, and they are therefore placed on equal footing with one another. \[Page 216\]

This equal validity of both spheres, and the complete parallelism in their effects, utterly inexplicable under the presupposition that the one is merely the negation of the other; explains itself readily if one lays beneath them a double ground of truth, an inner and an outer. Then arises a state which takes its first origin from certain mediating personalities, here that of Picard. Its genesis, and the gradual development of the symptoms in both directions, we have seen pass before us in what has gone before. If on this path it has reached its height, then it ends at last in that possession which calls forth voices from the inner realm, named the spiritual obsession. Sixteen or eighteen nuns of the convent were in this state. They were, shaken by the most violent convulsions, rolled into balls, twisted in the strangest contortions; but the doctors were astonished to find them, amid all this, in perfect health, and after three to four hours of paroxysms of the most violent kind their pulse was mostly unmoved and calm. They declared unanimously: it is impossible to explain such violent, prolonged, frequently recurring attacks, which leave no trace after their passing, by mere natural forces. For four to five years the thus affected ones were tormented day and night; for two years during the exorcisms they were for many hours at a stretch in raging, howling, screaming, and convulsions; moreover they felt the movement of their spirits often, so that they were for 6--8 hours of the day in the most terrifying excitement: but when the attack or the exorcism ceased, and the stole had scarcely been removed; then they went away dancing and laughing, without a sign of fatigue, and without after-effects.

### Chapter 2. Psychic Reports

The spiritual reports connect the personalities with one another in their midpoints, and with the center of the radical evil; the psychic ones continue the begun work then in the middle man. The psyche, which with a spiritual one gives itself to the spirit, with a vital one to vitality, has, although both moments properly belong to it, yet in them tinged itself with the color and manner of the two regions into which it has thus inserted itself, and which have given themselves to it through it.

But she herself entirely, in her specific particularity, is she only in her middle moment, in that wherein she reveals herself outwardly, in every kind of voluntary movement. Where, therefore, a short and compact intuition is in question, this movement can be taken as her most proper expression, and as the medium in which her essence and her manner inscribes itself in the purest and most compact form, and from which her properties and inner relations can again be derived. In the movement expresses itself the higher will, within a certain, precisely psychical limitation; and its inhibitions and morbidities make themselves felt in it, just as one feels in the pulse the disturbances of physical life. This thus regulating will stands now, first, in a determinate relation to itself, and then in another to the surrounding nature and its forces, divides itself therefore into a subjective and an objective. \[Page 217\]

Since now the movement is the expression of the in- dwelling inner, so will it also divide itself into a purely voluntary one, and one of mixed kind, a so-called in- voluntary; and from the natural relations of both kinds will the power and freedom of the total will in this domain be dependent. The relation adequate to the ordinary conditions of life can now be disturbed: either by the one subjective moment, in that this once claims too much for itself, and seeks to emancipate itself entirely from all involuntary movement; or in that it surrenders itself too much to the other, so that the involuntary, overflowing its banks, threatens to master the whole. There then arises a possession of this will immediately through nature, or mediately through itself; which will appear as a work of guilt, and thus as an obsession. Or the natural relation is disturbed by the other involuntary moment: which either, overwhelmed by positive natural forces, breaks over into the domain of voluntary movements; or, yielding itself too much to the negative, calls forth the irruption of these movements. In both cases it is a natural possession, which, as a work of contagion, is a misfortune and a disease. To this belong therefore the rigid spasms, the St. Vitus' dances, and the over- tensions of the movement-systems in all kinds of manias, which are mostly at the same time connected with deeper natural intuitions, in the activities pointing toward the purpose.

With such intuitions, however, the view into the otherwise closed spirit-realm is also opened, and there a second relation of the psychical will-forces to the powers native there makes itself known. This relation, however, forms itself now either in the involuntary will-forces: those powers master these forces, and pave their way through them to the other order of subjectively voluntary forces, which they, binding to unfree ones, to evil purposes immediately or in the back-effect of the loosed, press toward. Then the demonic ob- session will emerge as disease; whereas conversely, if the outset comes from the voluntary will-forces, and these smooth the paths for the evil, and prepare the ways for it, that demonic obsession enters, which as guilt intervenes more deeply.

The first kind of obsession, if it finds many individuals in similar situations, in determinate rapports toward one another, and toward the contagious demonic miasma placed, can therefore spread itself epidemically over all; and the same power will seize it in those rapports and bind it to its center. They all will therefore, infected by the same possession, form around it a group of their own; and a demonic epidemic, spread more narrowly or more widely, will then emerge. The other kind of obsession likewise, when it arises either in an individual of superior powers, who knows how to draw strongly to himself, through his relations, as the center of an entire sphere, those belonging to it whom he has won over by means of these relations; or when it otherwise arises simultaneously in several individual personalities who are capable of forming such a nucleus; will likewise become epidemic, and thus can bring forth an entire circle, not without the complicity of the possessed. This epidemic of obsession, intermingled in the personal contagion of the afflicted, will thus form the second object of our consideration. To the third will then be subordinated the cases of mixed kind and doubtful nature.

#### A. The Psychic Symptoms of Possession

\[Page 218\]

Such evils will, as is easily recognized, occur for the most part there where many persons, under similar influences, in similar circumstances of life, live in close contact with one another; most of all, when they are individuals of the female sex, who already in themselves stand in a closer natural union with the men. Female convents will thus first be the scenes of such occurrences, and indeed there is no lack of examples where such things have taken place in such conventual associations. Among these cases there is especially one that was exactly and sharply observed by four bishops and four doctors of the Sorbonne; which they then likewise sharply weighed and discussed in its various circumstances; and concerning which, after they had confirmed the individual facts through repeated experiments, excluded the doubtful, and retained only what was evidently certain, they then drew up the following clear and luminous report, which dispels all suspicion of fraud and deception, and presents the matter roundly and plainly.

It reads, however, as follows: We, the undersigned, after having heard the report made to us by His Episcopal Grace of Châlons-sur-Saône concerning the occurrences that took place in his presence among many persons, some ecclesiastical, some secular, who seemed to be plagued and seized by the evil spirit, in Auxonne; at that time when, by order of the King and on the commission of His Highness the Archbishop of Besançon, he conducted the exorcisms on the spot for fourteen days; after he had called in several priests chosen by him, all persons of great piety and great merit, and moreover assigned to them Mr. Morel, formerly the city physician of Châlons, known for his science and experience; who all agreed in the same judgment concerning the matter, which the aforesaid Lord Bishop presented to us under the following points of view:

First, that all those virgins in their entirety, 18 in number, some secular, some ecclesiastical, and without excepting even one, appeared to him to have the gift of tongues; inasmuch as they always answered correctly to the Latin with which the exorcists addressed them, not from the ritual, and still less by prior agreement. Often they also expressed themselves in Latin, sometimes in whole periods, once or twice through formal speeches. One among them, Anne des Ecolos, called of the Purification, when one of the exorcists spoke Irish to her, testified that she understood him very well, and explained what was said to him several times in the French language. Secondly, that all or nearly all showed that they possessed a knowledge of the interior, and of the secret of thoughts when these were directed toward them; which showed itself especially in the inner commands that the exorcists gave them on many occasions, to which they in general obeyed very exactly, without these commands being translated into words or any external sign; concerning which the Lord Bishop himself made various experiments. \[Page 219\]

Thus among others in the person of Denise Parisot, maid of the General-Lieutenant von Auronne, to whose demon he, in the depths of his thoughts, had directed the command: to come to him, in order to allow himself to be exorcized. She came at once, although she lived in a distant quarter of the city, and said: that she had been commanded to present herself before him; an experiment which repeated itself with her several times. Further in the person of Sister Margaretha Janini, called of the Child Jesus, novice; who, when the exorcism was at an end, recited to him the command which he had imposed on the demon in the course of it. Even more in the person of Humberte Borthon, called of the holy Francis, to whom he, in the midst of her highest agitation, had given the order to prostrate herself at full length before the holy Sacrament with outstretched hands; a command which she fulfilled in the moment of its utterance with extraordinary zeal and great speed. The other clergymen who had been present there, according to his report, since the same thing occurred with them every day, had adopted it as the manner of making them obey, into their practice.

Thirdly, that they on various occasions had foretold future things, especially in regard to the maleficia and sorceries which one must find; not only at various places in the convent, where they were indeed really found; but also in the bodies of other sisters, with whom they had not previously spoken, and who then vomited them forth and expelled them from themselves exactly at the hour which those had determined for them. At times they had told the Holy Bishop, and some of his clergymen, very secret particulars in regard to their household affairs, and the time of his journey to Paris, which he himself had not even known; which things then turned out in truth just as stated, but could neither be guessed nor combined from the circumstances. Fourthly, that nearly all of them, especially at the height of their agitation, had shown a great aversion to all holy things, especially the sacraments of the Eucharist and Penance; so that sometimes on account of the violent resistance and outcries, which could only be subdued by commands directed to the demon, several hours were spent over such a confession.

Before Communion they were seized with convulsions and visibly involuntary movements; as soon as they received the holy Host, they cried out and howled terribly, and rolled on the ground; while the received Host always remained on the tip of the tongue, which they, at the command of the exorcist, stuck out or drew back; without, however, committing any irreverence against the holy Sacrament. This lasted sometimes half an hour, more or less; but when at last the received particle was swallowed, then she who had taken it remained immediately calm, and without remembrance of what had occurred. That further they had felt the most extraordinary aversions and fits of rage, at the approach of the relics of the saints, which they often recognized and named by name, before they had seen them, and without knowing anything of them. That furthermore nearly all, when the holy Bishop several times secretly laid hands on them, and without their being able to know it, had given to understand how they felt it; as they cried out: this hand is unbearable to them, it presses heavily, they would be burned by it! That finally at the height of the exorcism, especially during holy Mass, they had uttered blasphemies, and such frequent and terrible imprecations against God and his holy Mother, that one could not possibly hear them without horror; which, as may be supposed, could only proceed from the mouth of the demon. \[Page 220\]

Fifthly, that, when they were pressed to prove the presence of the demon through supernatural signs, they seemed to comply; among others, the maid Denise Parisot, who, when the Lord Bishop commanded her, caused the pulse of her right arm to stand completely still, while it continued undisturbed on the left; then the beating was transferred from the left to the right, while it now stood still on the left; all of which she executed with the utmost precision in the presence of several clerics and the physician, who examined and confirmed it. That the Sister of the Purification performed the same feat two or three times; both the one and the other in full health, and thus holding or releasing the pulse according to the command of the exorcist. That the Sister Margaretha Janini of the Child Jesus achieved the same, and at the exorcist's bidding inflated her breast to a monstrous height; but when he commanded a halt under the sign of the cross, she immediately caused it to subside: and this three times in succession with an astonishing efficacy, taking effect as rapidly as the word. That the Sister Lazara Arivey, called of the Resurrection, came to one of the clerics; carrying in her hand a coal of considerable length in full glow, without giving any sign of feeling the burn; and so several other effects of a similar nature, which cannot easily be set forth here in detail.
