Sixthly, that at the mere command of the exorcist they sometimes fell into a wonderful insensibility; among others, Denise, who, when the Lord Bishop commanded the demon to withhold her senses, and the physician, to whom she expressly declared that she was entirely painless, thrust a needle under the nail of her finger, where, according to her own account, it shows itself most sensitive, immediately stated: that she felt not the slightest thing. When she was commanded: to hold back the blood, the needle was withdrawn without any blood following. But at the command to let it flow, it flowed forth at once in abundance; then holding it back again, when the command to halt was repeated. The same thing recurred a few days later on the person of the Sister of the Purification, whose skin on the arm one had wounded with a needle that was driven into her finger up to its head; without any pain or blood making itself felt, and without the sister appearing ill or faint; she rather always spoke, and urged those present to apply fire and iron, because she felt nothing of any of it. That some among them, especially the Sister of the Purification, when on a night in which, according to the assurance that the others had given the exorcist the day before, she was to be fetched away for the Sabbath, was prevented from leaving the cloister; at the hour of this alleged assembly suddenly fell into a kind of stupor and wonderful insensibility, which lasted five quarters of an hour and longer. All her senses were closed; she lay without movement, without speech, and without self-consciousness; her arms crossed on her breast, and so rigid that it was impossible to pull them apart; her eyes at first closed, and then opened, but held immovably fixed, and without power of sight; as was evident when one passed hands before her, and she did not twitch her eyelids like a dead or entirely insensible person. When she returned from this trance, she recounted: how she had been at the Sabbath in spirit, and all that she had seen there. \[Page 221\]

Seventhly, that they often, after several hours had been spent in conjurations and exorcisms, appeared to vomit up from the bottom of their stomachs certain foreign bodies, which they were accustomed to call maleficia and magic remedies of various kinds: pieces of wax, bones, hairs; besides pebbles of such size---according to our judgment broader and thicker than a silver thaler---so that it seemed difficult to us that they could be driven upward through the throat in a natural way. Finally, that the possessed one, among other things, after three hours of exorcisms and extraordinary exertions, expelled through her mouth a living frog or toad the breadth of a fist, and that the creature was immediately burned.

Eighthly, that the demons, by whom the girls claimed to be possessed, when pressed by the exorcisms to depart, appeared to give supernatural and convincing signs in the vicinity of the Most Holy Sacrament. When the bishop commanded them to depart from the possessed one, and as a sign thereof to break a pane which he indicated with his finger, the pane was broken. That Sister Humberthe Borthon was found completely and entirely healed on the day of the Presentation of the Virgin in 1661; and as a sign of her deliverance she vomited through her mouth a folded piece of taffeta, upon which in red script the name of Mary was written, and four other initial letters signifying St. Hubert and the blessed Francis de Sales. That the sister named of the Purification had been freed from several demons on the day of St. Gregory the Wonderworker; and as a sign thereof she gave forth through her mouth a piece of cloth in a circle of copper, upon which the name Gregory was written; and that the same one, on that same day of the Presentation, as a sign of another deliverance from several demons, caused the words Jesus, Mary, Joseph to appear in large letters, as if written with blood, on her bandage in an instant; while the exorcists had seen the bandage entirely white just a moment before.

Ninthly, that among the violent movements and postures which they made during the exorcism, some appeared so extraordinary that one had to judge they exceeded the strength of a girl; indeed, the powers of nature. That Sister Borthon, when commanded to adore the Most Holy Sacrament, threw herself to the ground, touching it only with the tip of her belly over the stomach; but with her head, feet, and hands, as well as the rest of her body, directed into the air. That the sister of the Resurrection practiced the same, and sometimes lay thus with her body bent into a circle; so that her soles touched her forehead. That Constantia and the possessed one were sometimes seen thrown to the ground, touching it only with the crown of the head and the feet, the entire rest of the body in the air, and that they walked about in this state. That all or nearly all, when they lay on their knees with their arms crossed over the stomach, turned themselves backward; so that the crown of the head connected with the soles of the feet, but the mouth kissed the earth, and with the tongue traced the sign of the cross on the ground. That some, among others Sister Catherine, during the exorcism appeared with the head thrown back, the eyes open; yet in such a way that, as the pupil was entirely hidden under the upper eyelid, one saw only the white in the eye, whereby she probably had lost the power of sight; an appearance that had been frightful to behold. That the possessed one, who was young and weak in appearance, when she was in agitation, with two fingers threw to the ground a vessel of a kind of marble, filled with holy water, and so heavy that two exceedingly strong persons would have had difficulty lifting it and removing it from its pedestal, with an ease that she might have used for a small stone. \[Page 222\]

That it has often happened to some and to others, in the heat of their attacks, to dash their heads against the wall or the ground; sometimes with such violent and hard blows that, in the natural order of things, they must have severely injured themselves with bloodshed; but that neither contusion, nor wound, nor any sign thereof appeared. Tenthly, that all these girls are of diverse stations: secular, novices, postulants, professed; further, young and more advanced in years; some from the city, others not; some of good and some of lowly origin; poor and rich; that this misfortune has already begun in the convent for ten years and more; that it is scarcely conceivable how, in so long a time, a scheme of deceit and subterfuge, among so many girls of such diverse dispositions and opposing interests, could have remained undiscovered; that in a sharp investigation and precise inquiry, the Lord Bishop found no one, whether in the convent or in the city, who did not speak to him most favorably of the innocence and blamelessness, both of the virgins and of the clerics who had worked before him in the exorcisms; and he testifies on his part that he recognized them in their conduct as exemplary, deserving, and pious persons: a testimony which he believes himself obliged to give in duty to truth and justice. To all this added the testimony of Mr. Morel, the physician, who was present at everything, and who assures that all these things surpass the bounds of nature, and can only proceed from the demon; so we believe, having weighed everything well, that all these extraordinary facts in those virgins go beyond the powers of human nature, and can only be wrought by the demon, who possesses and besets their bodies. That is our opinion. Given in Paris on the 20th of January 1662.

One sees with what circumspection these men proceeded, examining and weighing everything carefully; and we shall see who will have the forehead to contradict their testimony, and to declare respectable men as deceivers, or as deceived by the juggling tricks of the companions of a convent and its conniving spiritual directors, continued for more than ten years, whose good reputation is secured by the testimony of an entire city. But assuming the event to be true, since no one was found upon whom any suspicion of bewitchment rested, the evil must therefore have arisen within the convent itself through immediate communication, either simultaneously in all, or also in one or more, and then passed from one to the other through epidemic contagion; until finally the entire community was seized. Since they drew it upon themselves on the Sabbath, it has been a true obsession that overtook them; but since none among them was found from whom one could truly have suspected that she had first given occasion to the evil through her own fault; it has therefore come upon them as a judgment, and it has been an obsession that yet again emerged in all the forms of a possession; which therefore here proceeded from a source of contagion lying entirely outside the circle of the human realm. \[Page 223\]

Such obsessions differ, except for the Sabbath, in none of the other phenomena from those which the possessions exhibit; but they are at the same time, except for goal and intention, otherwise in all things equal to the symptoms of higher ecstasies. The gift of languages, the beholding of another's thoughts, the hearing of the commands of the exorcist from afar, the knowledge of holy things, of the sacraments, of relics and consecrations, here expressing itself as loathing and horror, the power of the will over the unfree ganglionic life, invulnerability to fire, painlessness and closure of the senses, the stopping and flowing of the blood at will, the drawing in of the whole body into the form of a circle, or successively into the forms of two half-circles divided from one another and turned toward each other: all of this we have already seen mutatis mutandis in the saints just as well. That circle which the one formed would, had the exorcist so willed, have rolled itself just as much in the circular streaming of the forces, toward any arbitrary point on the radial line; as the holy Peter of Alcántara did it voluntarily in his ecstasies toward the Most Holy Sacrament.

These events are proven in the saints by the most unimpeachable testimonies; they are proven here now in the possessed by equally unimpeachable witnesses; the facts confirm one another just as much, and here as always the devil, so far as it lies in his power, must against his will bear witness for the higher truth. All of this is in nature, for it is executed with natural forces; but it is also above nature, for the ground to which these forces attach themselves lies beyond the region of ordinary life. Next to this, the casting forth of objects designated by certain names seems still to point to jugglery and deception. So much is certainly true: these things did not write themselves, the devil did not write them either; therefore it was the nuns who did it. But they did not do it in waking senses, with the intention of deception, but rather as they were beside themselves, in the properly negative demonic ecstasy; in it they also swallowed the written things, which alone would have been possible in such a state. \[Page 224\]

As the exorcism now called forth a kind of positive, anti-demonic ecstasy, all the movements of the negative ones reversed themselves, thus also the peristaltic movements; and they had to cast forth again what they had previously swallowed down. In all these proceedings, the saint stands to the one under whose obedience he has placed himself, and the possessed to the exorcist, in the same relation as the magnetized stands to the magnetizer; only that this natural relation there passes over into a higher or deeper region of things through intensification, here through depression, according to the positivity or negativity of the exponents. It is otherwise remarkable that the witnesses of this proceeding, who believed in the bodily departure, in the Sabbath, had the departing ones watched at the appointed hour, and now found them as if caught in a vision. The possibility of such a departure in very rare cases is, as we have seen, by no means to be denied; but had the investigators been able to occupy themselves with the matter longer than fourteen days, they would, as can scarcely be doubted, always have found only the vision. What was thus found in Auronne had also earlier been discerned in Louviers. There the Sister du Saint Esprit was possessed by Dagon; this one once wound himself around the girl's body in a threefold coil, like a writhing snake, by twisting the region of the stomach on the body to one side like a loop, the feet to the opposite side, but elongating the head toward the shoulders, so that she had the appearance of a knotted coil of snakes. \[Page 225\]

The same one, when she was once confronted with Bavent, stood with one foot stretched out three shoe-lengths high against the speaking grating; her face pale, emaciated, parched, her eyes sunk deep in her head like those of a death's-head, for fully a quarter of an hour in an unchanged position, staring fixedly at Bavent with rage. Once she lay senseless for half an hour in the refectory, and when the bishop commanded her spirit to depart from her, it threw her into strange contortions. Suddenly she shot away like a flash of lightning into a fairly strong fire; her face and one hand were thrust into the glowing coals, and when people ran to pull her out, no burn damage was found on her; only some blackness and a little ash lay on the part of the face that the heat had touched, which could easily be blown away. She was thrown violently backward onto her head in the cloister courtyard, without it harming her; she climbed up a ten-foot-high wall on an old piece of wood, and ran along it to a spot where no ladder could be placed. The nuns begged her to go back to where she could be brought down. One of the exorcists adjured her spirit and began to pray on his knees. Dagon cried out: If you do not stop, I will hurl the carcass down! And indeed, he threw her the ten feet down onto stones and bricks, without her being injured in the slightest. Sister Anna of St. Augustine was to go to confession, but her spirit Gonzag would not allow it for two hours. Her confessor Bosroger, weary of his obstinacy, finally commanded him in the Latin tongue to enclose himself in the left foot of the possessed one and to set her spirit free for the task. He resisted most violently for an hour, but finally had to obey; and he gave the sign of obedience imposed upon him by striking the floor in rhythm with that foot. The nun now confessed without disturbance and then also went to the Lord's table; but as she did not know what had actually occurred, she limped on the left foot and finally fell to that side, so that she had to be led. Later Gonzag would not come out of his hiding place and had to be forced once more to free the foot.

The same Marie of the Holy Spirit was likewise to go to communion at the time of examination; for four hours her Dagon resisted, driving her through the crowd into all corners of the church; and finally he jumped with her onto the high altar, where he blasphemed God and demanded adoration from those present. The exorcists now called out to him: *Illa superbia quae te de coelo praecipitavit, deturbet te de altari.* Immediately, as if struck by a thunderbolt, he fell to the ground against the railing, four or five steps from the altar. They also banished him into a foot, which stiffness immediately seized, so that she might complete the communion in peace.

All the obsessed ones in general were, after their attacks---in which the head was bent backward against the heels---brought into the bow form. Sister of St. Lawrence, allegedly possessed by Behemoth, was during one hour bent two or three times into this form; similarly the one of the Redeemer, so perfectly that the head lay down to the mouth at the feet, while the belly formed a complete arch. Once she was as if broken in two, the head and face hanging backward to below the middle of the feet near the heels; like a handkerchief laid over the finger, so that the ends hung down on both sides. Sister Louise of the Ascension, terribly plagued for a whole year with every sort of nervous ailment, was several times placed in such a position that she touched the earth only with a flank of the left side or of the belly, in a breadth of about four inches. \[Page 226\]

The entire rest of the body was in the air, the two arms extended with all force, and bent backwards and from below upwards; the head thrown entirely back over the shoulders, almost to the region of the loins, as one is accustomed to depict the Sirens; the legs and feet likewise thrown backwards, drawn close to the head to the breadth of four fingers, without any part of the thus intertwined body touching the earth in the slightest. She remained so for a quarter of an hour with narrowed, exceedingly small eyes, until the bishop commanded the demon to cease. In this way the spirit sought to prevent Maria of St. Nicholas from making her confession at the grille. He therefore bent her head backwards into the choir, as she sat before the grille, down almost to the floor, two feet lower than the bench; so that, since Father Esprit, for the sake of propriety, grasped her only by the hem of her garment, she held herself on the bench only with half of her feet; in which position a sister who had hurried up straightened her by the head.

The confessor commanded the spirit to make her kneel before him. He then cried out that no one should hold her; and with a single swing, without her aiding herself with any limb in the process, she threw herself backwards to the feet of the confessor, to whom she now made her confession in all tranquility. Often her demons, after the exorcism, sought to drown her in the wells; and they came down now, leaning with the shoulders or the head against one wall, with the tip of one foot against the opposite one, and thus sliding down lengthwise, as Sister Marie of the Holy Spirit had likewise done. Or her entire body hung in the air, and she held herself to the masonry with her fingers or toes. Or finally, as it happened with the Sister of the Holy Sacrament, she slid down in a horizontal position, without being held anywhere, and was thus pulled out. Another time the Sister of the Redeemer knelt before the Archbishop of Toulouse, and told him in all composure of mind what was passing within her. Then her spirit Asmodeus suddenly flew into a rage, and bent her backwards; so that the head stood two fingers' breadth from the floor, without touching it in any way. She supported herself thereby solely on the heel of the right foot; the left foot was raised high into the air, the hands stiffly outstretched. In this way the body remained for a time standing outside its center of gravity, while the mouth meanwhile vomited forth blasphemies against God. \[Page 227\]

The mobility of the spirits in the obsession, or if one prefers, the interchange among the obsessed, is easily recognized in the following occurrences, which testify to a migration of the evil. Putiphar, who directed the Sister of the Holy Sacrament, said in the inner choir to Eneitif, who had his dwelling in Sister Barbel of St. Michael: Shall I not come into the lair that you possess? The one asked replied: Yes, I will. In an instant, Putiphar had entered the other; the Sister of the Holy Sacrament was meanwhile entirely free of her demon, threw herself immediately before the altar, and quietly prayed her breviary up to the Lauds. Sister Barbel, who meanwhile had both demons, was near the door as if nailed to the earth; the arms stretched out like two iron bars, likewise the right foot, on which no heel was any longer visible; the head of unspeakable weight, so that it could not be raised from the earth with any exertion, not even so high that the tips of the fingers could have been placed between them; and thus she remained lying for half an hour. Meanwhile the other had made her confession to the bishop, but when she too went to communion, and the holy Host had just been placed on her tongue, Putiphar came back like a flash of lightning, and cried: To the devil, I will not endure that! While I am absent, they deceive me, and let the bitch receive communion. \[Page 228\]

In the moment when he thus cried out, the other one began to twitch; and she started to howl and scream, as her demon was accustomed to do. Since the doctor, for whom they had sent, arrived too late, the bishop believed he must compel Puttiphar, through the power of the Church, to make restitution. He refused; but after they had shouted at him: "Si sit voluntas Dei, fiat!" he finally obeyed on the fourth call, and the one became free again, while the other was doubly possessed. This lasted a quarter of an hour, until they brought the holy Sacrament to the stomach of the latter, who lay stiff and heavy upon the ground. When they had progressed from the words "O salutaris hostia!" to the others "Da robur, fer auxilium!", she began to stir and move. In the same instant, the sister of the holy Sacrament collapsed in convulsions at the other end of the choir; as swiftly as a shot wild animal in the flash of the gun. The same transfer repeated itself several times in the presence of many people, among whom were also doctors, who wrote down their report on it, and noted therein how the actions and sufferings had been separated by sufficient intervals from the general tetanus. Often the demon, in such a transfusion---after the stiffness and heaviness---produced a great pliancy and incomparable lightness; as we indeed found several times the head of one such person, who had two demons, as light as a ball of wool, but the neck as flexible as a piece of old linen cloth, and as if it had no sinews. The demon himself attributed the heaviness of the head to the strife between the two for the upper position in the head.

After these events, which occurred among crowds of nuns, it will not be surprising if we see similar symptoms break out in whole masses of the people. When, in July 1214, the Church of the Apostles in Liège was consecrated, whole crowds of a wondrous sect came from Upper Germany, from the Rhine and the Meuse, first to Aachen, then to Utrecht, and finally to Liège, whose manner was as follows. Men and women, possessed by the demon, half-naked, with wreaths on their heads, went along; and, holding each other by the hands, they performed dances before the spectators on the streets, in the churches, and in the houses, without the least shame. They jumped high in the air during this, and in the songs that they sang, they named demons such as Friskus and the like, which had never been heard before. When the dances were finished, they were plagued by the most violent chest cramps; so that, if their friends did not gird them around the navel region with linen cloths and draw the girdle tight, they would rage that they must die. \[Page 229\]

These hordes swelled from September to October to many thousands; for more and more dancers kept coming from Germany, and in Liège and the neighboring provinces many healthy people, and such as were completely in their right minds, were suddenly seized by the demon; and, extending their hands to the dancers, they immediately joined their choruses. Sensible people saw the cause of this phenomenon in the ignorance that prevailed in those times concerning the faith and the commandments of God. The people, however, sought the cause in the priests who kept concubines, who had not baptized the people properly; and they prepared themselves, especially in Liège, to rise up against the clergy, to strangle the culprits, and to plunder their goods. But God wished to demonstrate to men that baptism, whether administered by good or bad hands, was all the same to Him; therefore He gave to the secular priests of Liège the gift of healing such possessed persons through the laying on of hands and exorcism, which He refused to other priests.

In the Kreuzkirche there, a man who had been assigned to carry the censer around the choir during the divine service suddenly began to swing it about in a playful manner, to dance around with it, and to sing numerous songs in unknown words; and since he did not cease from all this despite reminders, people came to believe that he belonged to that sect. A priest called upon him to recite the Lord's Prayer and then the Creed; he refused to do both, and said: he believed in the devil. The priest therefore placed the stole around his neck, spoke the usual exorcisms over him, and immediately freed him; so that he recited the Creed and Pater Noster with great devotion. Around All Saints' Day, the dancers in Heristall, scarcely half a mile from Liège, had gathered in large numbers, and had resolved among themselves to go to Liège and murder the entire clergy there. But their resolution came to nothing; for when they arrived in the city, they were led by pious people to the priests, who did not harm them, but from whom they received healing. Some were brought to the Marian chapel in the St. Lambert's Church, where the priest L. Lones freed the first one, and then nine others, with the stole and the Gospel: "In the beginning was the Word." The rumor soon spread, and now they came in droves, and were freed in the same manner. Others were led to other churches, where the same was accomplished with them by good and bad priests alike, without distinction.

They made use of that same Gospel for this, and subsidiarily of others as well; especially where Christ healed the demonic, such as "to the eleven as they reclined" and "Jesus sent" and the like. In cases where the freeing was more difficult, the priests either placed the Sacrament of the Eucharist on the head, or gave the blessing with it before them. To some, consecrated or exorcised water was given to drink, or, if they refused, poured into them; also the consecrated fingers were placed in the mouth under the words: "Depart, unclean spirit!" and so forth. Words were spoken into their ears, and breath blown into their faces, to break the power of the enemy. \[Page 230\]

In the St. Bartholomew's Church, a demon said to the priest: he should just stop, he would depart of his own accord. One had already gone out because of the torment, and they would never again enter a Christian person. If the exorcisms had not been performed, they would have gone from the poor into the rich and powerful, in order to drive out the clerics. A girl, treated fruitlessly by several priests, had gone to Aachen; and the cleric named Symon had dressed her there in alb and stole, and immersed her in a vessel of exorcised water up to her mouth. On the question of how long he had been in the girl? The answer was: Two years! Where he had been when she went to Easter Communion? In the toe joints. When conjured, he wanted to enter the nearby castle of Schremborg and guard it against thieves. Asked if he could blow the horn? He began to blow it with great noise before all those present. Since they also would not let him enter the Bath of Charlemagne, he finally departed, after the girl had expelled a coal from herself. When it did not succeed for a priest to free a possessed person, he added prayers and fasting to the exorcisms, and he immediately became master of it. Thus the rush to Liège was great over the course of a year; but it gradually diminished, and around three thousand were healed, lightly or severely, and they said: during the entire course of the affliction, it had seemed to them that they were immersed in a stream of blood, and that was why they had jumped so high. Even after three or four years, individuals came sporadically, and were easily freed by the clerics.

So the matter was settled to the satisfaction of the people and to the glory of the Liège clergy; since the evil, which particular dispensations had imposed, was also removed again through the intervention of higher powers. As a byproduct, the teaching of the Church was thereby strikingly confirmed, that grace is not defiled by the impure vessel, and thus that all tangible reformation is foolishness. The occasion from the natural side was probably a kind of St. Vitus' dance, which had taken its seat in the abdominal ganglia, and now discharging itself against the pulmonary ganglia, excited those dances; but in the reaction, the spasmodic affliction toward the diaphragm, which could only be alleviated by the constriction of the epigastric region. The depolarization had proceeded downward, from where a sloping inclination toward the demonic sets in; the people had therefore directed their solicited intention thither, and it had taken on the character of obsession for the evil; and the dances, to the foreign-sounding Sabbath songs with the demon names, became a pavane. But this turn had now also made it possible to attack the evil from the ecclesiastical side, and it had succeeded happily thereby. In our times, less fuss would have been made; the police would have dispersed the dancers as lunatics, and in any case beaten those who resisted; the compliant ones would have been shunted back to their homes, and there might have made their peace with their friskiness or withered away. Enlightenment would have triumphed over darkness, and the applause of all friends of the victor would have fallen to the expedition.

#### B. The Psychic Contagion in the Obsession

\[Page 231\]

The ease of transmission in this and the preceding case brings us close to the fact that there must be a contagion, which, as it were, atmospherically envelops the inner core, carrying the effect from one to another. Whoever enters into the demonic circles experiences there a transmutation of his entire being, through all organic regions; thus in the fluid as in the solid, in the nervous as in that which envelops the nerves; hence also in the aura, which surrounds the human being and every single organ in him from afar. But the demonization now communicates itself, just as electrification, magnetization, heating, and the like do on physical bodies; and the demonized corporeality becomes a ferment, a yeast and mother of vinegar, which is capable of producing again in others, even in still healthy personalities, and thus all the more easily in those already inclined toward the pathological, the same process from which it itself has emerged in this manner. The most suitable medium in which this communication occurs at a distance will therefore be precisely that aura which surrounds the entire fermenting corporeality; which participates in its conditions in its own way, and carrying it over into the foreign, thereby awakens the like in the encompassed personalities. This aura, like that around the sun which mediates the reciprocal intercourse to its world bodies, will have different regions, propagating itself to farther or nearer distances through the higher or deeper; but the processes on this side and that, above and below the mediating, will always relate to each other as archetype and copy. \[Page 232\]

If, therefore, in the midst of a fellowship anyone has been found who has attained virtuosity in these domains; if the demonic has not merely, as in ordinary life, operated through distribution and in a mere aggregate state; but if it has struck and ignited within him, so that he has now become an independent source of the wild fire: then such a one, acting as deputy for evil, kindling it himself, can bring the conflagration into the surrounding bonds; and all those who, even if spatially distant from him, yet stand inwardly connected to him in sympathy, will be seized by him; unintentionally, where the transmission still belongs to the previous category, but also intentionally and with premeditation, where the practice then falls to its own \[category\]. If these are indeed spiritually, morally, and physically healthy natures, at the height of their vital force, then he will indeed accomplish little. But if it is an age less guarded against external impressions, a youthful stage that comes in his path; or a disposition disarmed by illness, or otherwise already inclined by temperament that draws near to him; if above all a spiritual, especially a moral, means of appropriation is already present: then he strikes swiftly, draws such personalities, appropriating them to himself, into his circle; and armed with them, he lords and rules in this sphere of action at his pleasure.

As for the children, in the Basque country some two thousand of them had been found, who, according to their statements, had been to the Sabbath. They had all confessed: if a sorceress wanted to lead them there, she would merely pass her hand over their face or head; immediately thereafter they would find themselves wholly confused, and as if out of themselves; but they did not say that the hands had been anointed. Sometimes, they protested, the women would give them an apple to eat, or a piece of black millet bread; after they had eaten it, they would become entirely defenseless, and then it would not fail---they would come the following night to fetch them. Even if they were then held fast in the arms of their elders and siblings, no one could awaken them. Such was the unanimous testimony of 2--300 children who were examined on the matter.

Johanna du Hard, 56 years old, had testified: when she had gone out of the church with a professed sorceress named Chorrozique, the latter had touched her arm, and she had immediately become as if dead. Corneille Brolu, 12 years old, deposed: that once, in 1608 during the fast at St. Jean de Luz, the sorceress Marie Martin had passed her hand over his head; and thereafter, in the following night, in the form of a cat, had taken him from his bed, out from the midst of two other boys; and had led him to Lecohanda, that is, to the great lake, where the Sabbath was held. Since that woman had died, he had not gone there for a month; until another took charge of him and led him there again. Since then he had been disenchanted, in that the woman whom they had summoned to justify herself---because she had not white but, like all her kind, red blood---had had some drops of it drawn, and with it a belt had been smeared. In the Swedish Elfdale as well, the children were awakened from sleep and taken there, with or against their will. If they betrayed it to anyone, they were harshly beaten at the following Sabbath; signs of this, however, were seldom to be discovered. Upon their return, the children usually looked quite weak, pale, and battered, and could scarcely recover the next day. They therefore often sought to save themselves before being led away, and when it began to come upon them, they would lie in the arms of their elders. These would sit by them and watch over them whole nights through; and as soon as they noticed an unusual pallor in them, they would shake them violently, but it helped nothing.

They also noticed that their breast became entirely cold; they also stuck a burning light into their hair, but it did not ignite. Their state of being away from themselves lasted sometimes half an hour, a full hour, or even two hours; and when the children came back to themselves, they lamented and wept most piteously, and begged forgiveness to the utmost of their ability, as much as they could. This was solemnly declared on oath before the court by two old men, who wished to call all the residents of the village as witnesses; for their children had mostly all experienced the same thing. Those grips of the witches were magnetic grips, which transferred the state of the one grasping into the one grasped. The state was, from the natural side, a magnetism; an inner awakening of the ganglia of the lower body, connected with the closure of the senses, the concentration of life in that region, and thus a cooling of the lung system; as it all showed itself in those Nordic children. But since the magnetism was at the same time of a demonic nature, the Sabbath had necessarily to be evoked in the circle of visions. \[Page 233\]

Such a communication of the evil also manifests itself in manifold other ways. The father of a Swiss woman in Bayonne wanted to buy apples in 1605 from two notorious women, Galanta and Mandiburo. While haggling, his daughter bit into one of the apples that was offered to her; and she was immediately seized by a nervous disorder that returned at once every time she caught sight of the two women. It consisted in such a violent movement of one arm that the whole body was shaken by it and thrown to the ground; whereby her fingers moved with such rapidity that no virtuoso on any instrument could have matched her in agility. This repeated itself every time she sighted the woman, and with such violence that when de Lancre, who at first took it for simulation, together with two others tried to hold the arm fast and prevent its movement, they found it impossible; and instead, all three were most violently shaken by it. No other means remained to calm the half-dead one again than to remove the women; whereupon she, as was shown by the threefold repetition of the experiment, immediately came back to herself. \[Page 234\]

Since then, when the same de Lancre was instructing at the Parliament of Bordeaux the trial of a sorcerer and of four witches from Amou near Eaux, these confessed how they transmitted two kinds of such diseases: once the falling sickness in full fury, more violent than the natural kind; and then the evil called Layra. This evil showed itself from time to time in the church of that place; where, as often as a witch entered who had given it to one or more in the assembly, sometimes forty or more persons began to bark like dogs in the full-moon nights. But sometimes the barking also occurred at a distance from the witch-women, because these could evoke it at their pleasure even from afar; then the afflicted did not cease calling them by name. One had already become so accustomed to it that if someone in their house felt an attack of the evil, their household immediately ran out into the street; and if they then found the called one there, this served them as testimony that often confirmed the confession. The court in Bordeaux, which had found these circumstances in the instruction of the judge from Amou, wanted to assure itself of the matter; and therefore dispatched two commissioners, Moneins and de Lancre, to take the thus bewitched into closer examination. The wife of a captain, who had suffered from the Layra for two years, was brought into the hall of the Tour de la Lanterne to the commission. She walked calmly about in it, viewing some pictures hanging there.

As soon as the gentlemen, against whom she had testified, without her being able to know it, were brought near her, she began at the very moment when they entered the staircase to bark most violently; so that it resounded through the entire house. The women were made to go back down the stairs, and the sick woman was spoken to reassuringly; she replied that she had no fear; and indeed, large as she was, she had a brave, manly appearance; but she could not overcome the abhorrence of coming into the nearness of these women. The malady had been done to her, as she believed, during a childbirth, since which she had remained barren; and while telling this, she stood there, arms akimbo, and stroking toward the womb for about a quarter of an hour, after which she became calm again. The commission repeated the experiment two more times with the same result; as the women, named Four and Fezendin, came near, the malady manifested itself both times so violently that the gentlemen came running together from all the rooms, and all became witnesses themselves of the trial. The screaming was so piercing that she had to be completely removed from the building. 1) It was also sometimes found that the sorceresses had passed the malady on to one another, in order to remain beyond suspicion. Thus the Violone of St. Jehan was accused by the Françoise Broqueiro of having been at the Sabbath in a conspiracy, where the same evil was inflicted upon her. \[Page 235\]

But she replied: she was innocent, and had suffered the evil like herself. And in fact, she had such a severe attack on the witness stand that she had to be carried away. The same woman always named nine different people who had collaborated in it, among them Jean de la Lanne; and every time she was brought to the torture after him, she had a new attack. The same Broqueiron also confessed: how she had given a powder to the liver of a woman, which however only stayed with her for two days. That the transfer could also be done to animals, even to plants themselves, she affirmed; on the one hand, she stated how she had made birds fall down like epileptics; on the other hand, she recounted: all the witches of the diocese of Amiens, who were known, were obliged every year on the same day, at the same hour, to wither an elder tree (Ulmus); by circling it three times, and laying some salt on its most vigorously growing branch.

The latter can be left to rest until closer examination; but what was told before is remarkable, because it strikingly shows: that one who, in a tense mood, has drawn a far-reaching aura around herself, can evoke an analogous mood in a circle of such predisposed persons. A case in which all circumstances, well considered, and the confessions of those involved taken into aid, hardly offers any other explanation than through conscious transfer, is the story of Renata Sänger, who at the end of the first half of the previous century ascended the stake. She was, according to the intelligently written report that the Premonstratensian Oswald Loschert, abbot of the monastery of Oberzell, as an eyewitness wrote down immediately after her death, and sent to Empress Maria Theresa, born around 1680 in Munich, and without the knowledge of her parents already in early youth in contact with suspicious people, and thus initiated into various traditional magical arts circulating among them.

Taught by an old woman, she had already begun these studies in her seventh year; a rider had then continued the begun work in her ninth; and in the eleventh and thirteenth, two officers, a maid, and a noble lady had successively joined. From them she had received various magical herbs, especially a root of great power, and a little black man, which however soon disappeared again, probably a mandrake; various talismans with numbers and letters and incantations of all kinds, and learned many arts: to make people sick at will by her blowing upon them, by fixed gazing, accompanied by reciting certain formulas, by needle pricks into specifically shaped figures, by placing the herbs under the door threshold, or by communicating falsified foods, to drive them out of their senses, or to plunge them into demonic relations. Here one sees the aftereffect of the Thirty Years' War, whose terrible dissolution, barbarization, and despair had recently brought forth all these traditions of malice from earlier centuries, further developed them, and spread them among all classes, especially the lower ones and the wild soldiery. In the practice of these arts she soon became visionary; she heard, gazing into the distance, what was secretly spoken of her here and there; she saw herself at the Sabbath, with the change of her name to Emma Renata, entered into the black book, and received seventy years of life promised in exchange for her renunciation. All this was now a poor preparatory school for the monastic life that she, compelled by her parents who were unable to do otherwise, around 1699 entered in the monastery of Unterzell, which was highly esteemed for its discipline and strictness. \[Page 236\]

Had she been endowed with a less resolute character, and possessed less mastery over herself than was truly the case; then this disproportion would have had to lead to a swifter outbreak. But resolute as she was, once she had taken her side, she went her ways in silence, without letting anything outwardly be noticed. She submitted herself to all the rigor of discipline; was careful in the fulfillment of her order's duties, and even knew how to spread around herself an appearance of piety; so that many held her in high esteem, and her convent sisters appointed her subprioress; indeed, they would have elected her prioress, if not a frequent dissatisfaction with her state, often rushing into it, a persistent aversion against her superiors, and a continuing restlessness on account of inner concerns, which she only hinted at with half words and would confide to no one, had held her back from it. This uncanny quality in her being, combined with the dark seclusion in which she set herself apart from all, also brought it about that for many years she came into no closer intercourse or more intimate association with any of her fellow sisters; which in turn preserved these from contagion by her arts, which she ceaselessly practiced for herself, drawing the herbs in the convent garden, and procuring from outside whatever else she lacked. Meanwhile it could not fail to happen that her heart must have embittered itself in this isolation; the compulsion to outward hypocrisy, alongside the secret practice of wicked arts, must have, ever increasing the tornness of her nature, filled her with resentment and hatred. This was greatly augmented still further by outward circumstances that arose; such as when in the year 1738 the provost of the convent removed the many cats with which she surrounded herself---already characteristic of her disposition, even if they did not, as she later confessed, hang together with her sorcery---on account of the great unrest they caused. Her mind, it seems, was thereby embittered to the depths, and from then on she began to direct her arts against those who had drawn her hatred upon themselves. From this moment onward peace and quiet had fled from the community of sisters; and the convent became the scene of the strangest events. Nightly there arose tumult and unrest within and without the cells; now it seemed to the sisters as if coaches and wagons were driving through the dormitory; now they heard in the garden, beneath the windows of the same, an unusual clamor. When they lay in their beds, then they were pressed, struck, pinched, and strangled; so that in the morning they could scarcely stir, and more than once bore blue marks from it; the locking of the cell, the sprinkling with holy water, and the blessing helped for a time, but never in the long run. Once when one of the convent women, on such an occasion, struck about her with her scourge, and the tormenting spirit fled from her after she seemed to have hit it hard, there was seen early in the morning on Renata's eye a bloody mark; which indeed awakened some suspicion against her, but naturally led to no certainty. But soon others fell gravely ill, and it was noticed that it was always the best, and those most useful to the convent, who in this manner were suddenly, and as if struck by evil sorcery, afflicted with burdensome and painful illnesses. This fate befell four in succession within the convent walls; and it was soon observed that the evil also spread outside of them, in a striking manner, to the male and female relatives of the provost. In five other sisters there soon appeared symptoms of another kind. \[Page 237\]

They retired to rest, then they came---without really sleeping---out of themselves; and in this state, having become clairvoyant, they now saw various persons standing before them, among these also Renata; who tormented them in every conceivable manner and way, without their being able to stir themselves, to defend, or even to cry out. On the whole following day they were then tormented by inner anxieties, which especially multiplied in the church; from which they were often driven out against their will, as by an irresistible force. When they went to choir, their voice was alternately taken away and restored, and their singing in between transformed into a hideous howling; whereby the throat sometimes swelled high, and then fell together again. All this was connected with trembling, head-shaking, striking of hands and breast, and various convulsive movements; accompanied by the feeling as if an animal moved in their body; great despondency and despairing thoughts joined themselves likewise to these evils.

All who had been seized by this state were, according to the testimony of the doctors, previously of good bodily constitution; their mental powers were unimpaired, their conduct showed itself blameless. Thus neither in a natural cause nor in a sinful play of lies could the ground of those hitherto unheard-of effects be sought; but no one thought of possession and sorcery. Among the sick was also Cäcilia Pistorini from Amberg, and from this one the spirit had begun to speak in 1745, named his name, and predicted much of the future; but since she did not speak in foreign languages and nothing very remarkable, one still took offense at advising possession. Moreover, one was not sure of her as one who had only recently been in the convent; and that had brought her many humiliations and hard trials from the side of the superior. Renata had been very active in this; she persecuted the afflicted one, on whom she had cast a hatred, to the utmost; and since on account of her age and understanding she stood in some esteem with many, she took all pains to teach those in the convent: there are neither witches nor possessed, and what showed itself in Cäcilia was a pretended thing, mixed with many punishable disorders. In the meantime, however, no one could see what the unfortunate one drove to such a play; one had previously, when her states began to show themselves, given her leave to leave the convent; with tears in her eyes she had begged for her admission, to all trials she had willingly submitted with humility and obedience.

She herself, when her mouth in her attacks spoke terrible blasphemies, or to her shame blurted out the secrets of her heart, and the most terrible convulsions shook her; then she nevertheless never wanted to be persuaded that she was really possessed; she held herself only for one who on account of her sins had been abandoned and rejected by God. In the meantime, however, one had at last decided on the application of exorcism on her, this had not missed its effect; but the states had always returned again, and one had then each time noticed: that Renata had come close to her shortly before, breathed on her, murmured some words to her, or made some gestures; and it had then each time been to her as if a fireball passed through her body, whereupon the convulsions immediately set in again. That must of course awaken suspicion; all the more, since also one of the sick convent women, who on account of her spirit and her exceptional piety stood in great veneration in the convent, on her deathbed had repeatedly testified against Renata. \[Page 238\]

But they still took scruple at allowing themselves to be prompted by this to any measure against her; and instead ordered a general church prayer in the convent: to implore from above help in the heavy distress, and light in the dark matter. The devotion had been continued for about three days; when the mouths of two more among the five opened, whose spirits had hitherto been mute; and amid the most violent convulsions it cried forth from them: Alas, our time has come, we may no longer conceal ourselves; whereby they, as ones compelled thereto by higher power, testified against Renata as the originator of all the evils. When one immediately applied the exorcism against them, they confirmed what had earlier been said voluntarily.

A few weeks later the remaining three also began to speak, and all six now unanimously attested the same; so that, as at the same time the torments and plagues of the afflicted were raised to the highest pitch, and no one could any longer doubt a real possession, general mourning arose in the convent, from which even Renata did not outwardly withdraw herself. The spirits, however, did not cease to testify against her; they gave the year, day and hour, place and occasion with the utmost exactness, where she there four or six, there ten and eleven years before had wrought evil; so that finally the long-spun net over the unfortunate one had to draw itself together. Her superiors had, in praiseworthy calm and moderation, still taken scruple at doing her any harm; until finally the provost of the convent found it advisable to carry out that upon which Renata herself, out of hatred against Cäcilia, had pressed for a year and a day; by requesting the abbot of Oberzell to institute a formal investigation of the matter. This one came over, examined the convent sisters under oath, and found Renata so multiply implicated through their statements, that he could not refrain from separating her for the time being from the rest of the convent.

She herself, when questioned about the accusations, had steadfastly maintained her innocence; and when the abbot pronounced the separation against her, she had begged to be allowed to go once more to her cell beforehand, in order to take with her some writings containing matters of conscience and confession; which was naturally not permitted to her, and now in the investigation the ointment box, various magic herbs, a yellow robe and the like were found. When, at her imprisonment, the possessed were quickly brought near, it began to howl and lament miserably from them, and it cried forth from some: O ye accursed hounds! why will ye destroy our nest? O little love---thus they called Renata---do not forsake us! The confessor of the convent now gave himself all effort to bring the unfortunate one to a sincere confession and to a conversion of life; and it seemed to him in so far to succeed, that she not only to him outside of confession, but also to the superiors of the convent quite voluntarily laid the confession: that she was a sorceress, had learned sorcery outside the convent, and had brought the six possessed into the state in which they found themselves; and that indeed with all the circumstances as the voices from them had earlier spoken. \[Page 239\]

There was now no exercise of repentance, no renunciation and abjuration, which Renata did not repeat after the priests with all outward signs of contrition; thereby showing such composure of mind as if she had never committed any evil. When she was alone in solitude, then one saw her lying on her knees before the crucifix, or reciting the rosary; so that, to judge thereby, a complete change seemed to have taken place in her. But the nightly torments of the possessed continued as before and after, and Renata was always visible to them therein as a helper; although meanwhile a lay sister did not let her out of her sight in her room.

The voices only mocked with their pretended conversion, and in doing so revealed blasphemies that they had committed during their confinement without the presence of a single human being; so that one again began to doubt the sincerity of their improvement; doubts which were later justified by her own confession.

Up to this point, the whole matter had been kept secret and confined within the cloister walls, and in accordance with the manner of ecclesiastical procedure in such cases, in the hope that a way might be found to settle the affair quietly, every public step and summoning of witnesses had been avoided. But the cries and howls of the demons from the possessed became so noisy that they resounded throughout the entire region around the cloister; from one of them they had betrayed to the visiting elders the condition of their daughter, and accused Renata as the originator; so that soon the rumor of what was happening spread all around. They now first resorted to a new confessor; Father Maurus from the Scottish monastery in Würzburg was summoned, in the hope that he might perhaps succeed in moving her heart. Her confessions, tears, and contrition at first made him believe that he had succeeded; but new events in the cloister, and the continuing accusations of the possessed, soon led him to doubt his opinion again.

The confrontation with her accusers brought her to new confessions of ongoing misdeeds, and to repeated vows of improvement; on which occasion she, among other things, declared: how she would no longer be able to do harm if she were taken to another place. One doubted the truth of this statement; for in the meantime the nightly unrest would not subside, and indeed several voices were heard speaking with Renata at night on more than one occasion, and then, at a horn call, she rose up from them like a light cloud; moreover, since the voices of the possessed threatened her with death, and once even suddenly hacked in the outermost door of the place of her confinement with an axe that happened to be seized, it was believed necessary to agree to her removal from the cloister. The matter was therefore reported to the Prince-Bishop, and a request was made for the dispatch of a commission, so that this commission might examine Renata, and, according to the findings, order her safekeeping in Marienberg Castle. \[Page 240\]

It happened as the petitioners wished; the bishop at that time, with some companions of both ecclesiastical and secular estates, among whom there were also some physicians, appeared in the cloister, and above all had the possessed nuns brought forward. One addressed him with these words: Cur venis in brevibus, ei non in longis vestibus? Another jumped out the window before the eyes of the assembly, laughed and made noise, holding onto the window frame, and was soon back in the room just as quickly. Yet another seized the bishop by the arm, pulled him out of the room with her to the cell in which Renata was locked up; hastily she took off her slipper from her foot, struck the padlock, and it opened. The commission then withdrew again, and the scenes in the cloister continued their course once more. All the sisters prayed for Renata, the possessed offered up their torments for her; and one after the other, after a terrible attack had preceded in each, delivered, driven by her spirit, an address to her, praising God's long-suffering, but also threatening her with His wrath; so that tears came to the eyes of all those present. She alone stood obstinate; she did indeed confess the misdeeds that the spirits charged her with, but at the same time asserted: her time was not yet up; and when once all the possessed unanimously pressed in upon her to compel her to renounce the pact and hand over the magic root, she did deliver some herbs and men's hairs that she had managed to keep even in her dungeon; but at the same time, suspicious events were reported again.

Finally, the spirits had granted her, as the last period of grace, three more days; when these had passed, Renata suddenly collapsed in the presence of the possessed, as if struck by lightning, at the feet of the confessor---so that he thought her dead, and the spirits howled triumphantly. She came to herself again, however, and was now, while the possessed were handed over to medical care in Würzburg, brought in secular clothes to Castle Marienberg, and her trial immediately instituted. During the same, she continuously gave all signs of true repentance; but the torments in the monastery and among the possessed would not cease on that account. \[Page 241\]

They disregarded it and did not stop. She was still seen at night, as she with others inflicted these torments; the hands and faces of the maltreated showed traces in the morning, and various objects were found in the beds, which had been dragged from other places in the monastery for this purpose. The possessed were alternately freed through the exorcisms and newly afflicted again; and the spirits continuously testified from them against Renata. She was therefore interrogated repeatedly, and since she persisted in her previous confessions and continuously admitted herself guilty of sorcery, she was finally declared forfeit of all spiritual privileges and immediately handed over to the secular courts: which, after a newly conducted investigation, condemned her according to the laws on sorcery to the fire; which the highest authority mitigated to the effect that she should first be executed with the sword. The judgment was executed on the sixth of February 1629; both at the announcement and at the execution, Renata remained calm and composed, and the external signs of repentance continued as before; but the spirits of the possessed interpreted this calm differently, and predicted certain circumstances of the execution.

That is the course of this wondrous story, as the most credible witnesses have communicated it. Many writings of the time have sharply criticized the severity of the judgment; but one could not help granting full justice to the calm, impartiality, and humanity with which the investigation was conducted from all sides. Every attempt at an interpretation that would exclude all demonic influences involves completely insoluble difficulties. The most immediate thing that offers itself to such an interpretation---the assumption of an unintentional self-deception among all involved---will least lead to the goal. Were all the possessed, the sick, Renata, the superiors, and the judges---the former insane, the latter accomplices---then scarcely any mark would remain by which one could then securely recognize the state of unaltered health. Renata and the possessed were obviously in opposite states; they are in self-contradicting tensions; and yet the one, when pressed into a corner, always confirms the statement of the others; they mutually respond to each other and complement each other in a certain alternating manner. Thus there is a kind of established harmony between their spheres, and it by no means suffices to assume a simple madness or a general delusion; but a world of madness must be assumed, which in the midst of denying its being yet affirms itself in its members; and in the most thorough dissonance yet, as it were against its will, remains subject to the law of harmony. The assumption of a fraud that crept in must drive into even greater confusions. Judges and superiors are beyond such an assumption, and among the other participants, suspicion and doubt do not know where to settle.

The only possibility might point to that Cäcilia who had stood as a special object of Renata's hatred; but precisely in this case the spirit does not testify against Renata as the immediate author of the evil that she had to endure; and the testimony that her superiors give regarding her disposition and conduct is incompatible with such a presupposition. But, even if allowed, it further demands, in order to become serviceable for explanation, the assumption of a continued understanding over many years with the other possessed, the sick and even the remaining convent sisters. All that raging, all those convulsions were either fabricated, and the physicians and other witnesses blind; or they were truly grounded in reality. \[Page 242\]

Should they now all have been directed against the one unfortunate with intent; this demands the presupposition of an understanding between the ringleader and her tools, and of a deliberate plan, kept secret for so long a time among so many people, logically carried out again and again toward the ruin of a human being; an infamy that one can attribute only to very rare cases in human nature, and which moreover must have stood in alliance with her own victim; since without such a thing her cooperation would be entirely incomprehensible. It could thus at most be an unconscious rapport, such as exists between the one from whom the contagion has proceeded, and those infected by it; in which case that Cäcilia would stand as the unconscious intermediary person; as it were the living miasma whose the others made use, in order to spread the infection generally around them. One sees how complicated this case had been, and how, despite all moderation and caution that prevailed among the judges, it would nevertheless have been more advisable to pronounce, instead of the death penalty, imprisonment until the cessation of the evil and the conversion. The continuance of the evil in the convent, during her imprisonment at Marienberg, could not prove the necessity of removing the author from the way; for it continued also for a considerable time after her death, and was dispelled only by continued exorcism.

#### C. Transitions of the Obsession into the Possession through Demonic

Epidemics

The obsession requires the intervention of a personality that knots the rapports, and in the negating unity rounds the banishing magic circle of the obsessed. The possession requires no such mediation; the negating unity strikes immediately into a personality, makes it its shell, and the one thus sporadically seized does not, as a rule, spread further infection around herself. But this striking can also happen simultaneously into many individuals, and these, placed near to one another by their calling and other circumstances of life, then enter into rapports with one another, and with the invisible center, which altogether has an epidemic character. One easily comprehends that such states have great affinity with those of epidemic obsessions, and form the transitions between the being afflicted and the being attacked. First, such cases will present themselves where, although the suspicion may well have pointed to a personal center, nothing certain has been ascertained about it. Thus Massäus says: In the year 1491, around the feast of Peter's Chair, the demons began to inhabit and possess the convent of the nuns of Quercy (Quercetensium), and to torment its inhabitants most cruelly for four years and four months. One saw them frequently running through the fields like dogs, flying in the air like birds, climbing trees in the manner of cats, hanging from the branches, imitating the voices of various animals, penetrating secrets, and prophesying future things. \[Page 243\]

So often Heinrich, Bishop of Cambrai, or Aegidius Nettetet, Dean of his church, both pious men, set out for exorcism, they knew it beforehand, and cried: The one with the horns is again on the way to threaten us. After all manner of means had been applied, which were sought out from everywhere, their names were brought to Rome and read out by Alexander VI on Maundy Thursday under the Mass; but without any effect. Johanna Potier, who was held to be the beginning of the evil, had been in confidential relations with the demon from her ninth year onward, and this one accused her in the convent: that she had gone to Communion 434 times unworthily; which statement, however, since he is a liar from the beginning, cannot be trusted. She was led to Cambrai and died in the dungeon on St. Martin's Day; the others were freed in June after four years of possession. Joh. Molinet in his Belgian chronicle for the year 1490 confirms these accounts, adding: that the evil had passed from one to the other innocents. The demons had given themselves out as angels of light who belonged to the hierarchy of the Seraphim, and had at last been driven out by the Dean of Cambrai. He had carried the Eucharist to the sick, and set the demons the condition: if it were nothing but bread, then it might by no means disturb them in their possession; but if the body of the Lord, then they must withdraw from the possessed.

Wier, whose testimony as a physician and Protestant one may here allow to stand,¹ even if he had the weakness of believing in the devil, has recorded several other cases of this kind from his own experience. In the convent of Kentorp, in the county of Mark not far from Hamm, the enclosed nuns, noblewomen as well as others, were seized by a possession; and the individuals in various ways, some more violently, others more mildly, tormented. In this variety, however, there was one thing common to all: that as soon as one was seized by an attack, all the others, even if they were in completely separate rooms, as soon as they heard the noise, were likewise drawn into it and miserably plagued. Anna Lemgon was one of the older and stout-hearted sisters who clearly explained to the physician Wier the circumstances of the whole evil. It began with her, who was one of the first seized, with pains in the left hypochondrium; she was held to be seized by epilepsy, and was sent to the convent of Nonnery so that she might drink from the skull of the holy Cornelius; she did so, and the nuns now falsely said that she was better. \[Page 244\]

But when she was soon more violently visited by the evil, and other nuns were likewise found drawn into it; a soothsayer was consulted, who gave testimony against the convent's cook as the originator of the evil. Now the malignancy of the plague increased; the convulsions became more manifold and more deeply cutting, and the seized were driven to bite one another, and so also other strangers, to strike and throw down; yet without further harm, since they seemed to themselves as light as feathers, and now noticed that they were not masters of themselves. If they were held back from striking or the other acts of violence, they were pressed in the heart; but if they were let loose again, they felt, even if they injured or bit themselves, no evil at all; so that it seemed as if it had become a necessity for them to rage against their own bodies. If Anna gave herself to prayer, she could by no means follow it with attention or move her tongue for it; but if she merely chattered off her hours thoughtlessly, then she was in no way hindered from it; it rather seemed to her as if she were thereby relieved and refreshed.

She could not think seriously about any good or evil matter; it seemed to her then as if she were stupid in spirit, without sense, without distinction, and without judgment. If a religious, God-consecrated man addressed her, she was as it were scolded by the devil on that account; but if she spoke with this one, or with another female person, about vain and trivial things, then she was wonderfully uplifted and exalted thereby. Although all were plagued in manifold ways, they were nevertheless all of good appetite, and the nourishment proceeded well. From here the malady now soon spread also to the nearby city of Hamm, afflicting not a few citizens of this city with various torments. When they were instructed by the pastor of the place in his room, and he had them recite the Ten Commandments, the Creed, and the Lord's Prayer; they began to question one another, and the demons now named themselves with jesting names, as one said: he was called Flederwisch, another Flatfoot, the third Rosenbaum; but he who now wrought mischief in the monastery at Kentorp named himself Hornuar.

At last one asked: The pastor wants to drive us out; what shall we do now? The other replied: I will ride on a black buck to that woman whom he named; I shall be a dear guest to her. The other said: he would go with the same conveyance to a second one. Both, sitting backward on chairs like fools, now seemed, as gesture and voice indicated, to ride to the aforementioned places; without, however, having moved from the spot. A third, rolled and drawn together like a ball, rushed toward the closed door; and as this was suddenly opened, he fell down the stairs, but entirely unharmed. In the place Houel near Hamm, likewise many possessed persons came to light. Also in another neighboring city the inhabitants were seized by similar attacks and plagues, on account of which many investigations arose there against individuals. As in this case the manifestation of possession often hovers midway between malice and jest; so the contagion that produced it hovers between a moral and a physical one. \[Page 245\]

The cook Elsa of Camen was named to the nuns by the soothsayer as the originator of their ills; and she, or her mother and her brother, or the image of a black cat, appeared to them henceforth always during the attacks. She herself suffered from an epileptic malady, like the others; but now it was said that she had inflicted it upon herself, to divert suspicion from herself. When imprisoned, she at first confessed to poison; but dying, she denied having used anything other than curses. Wondrous was the plague of a number of nuns in the monastery of Werte in the county of Horn. The beginning of it was traced there to a poor woman who, during Lent, had borrowed a quart, about three pounds of salt, from the monastery, and had returned the loan nearly double by Easter. Now white pellets were found in the dormitory, resembling sugar-coated seeds in appearance, but of salty taste; these, however, were not eaten, and no one knew how they had come there. Then something was heard sighing about there, like a sick person; voices were also sometimes heard inviting several of the virgins to rise and go with it to the fire, for it was sick. If they really got up to look after the sick sister, they found no one. If one of them wanted to relieve herself into the chamber pot, it was violently snatched from her, and the bed besmirched with what had been passed. Sometimes they were dragged out of bed a few steps, and tickled under the soles of their feet in such a way that they feared they must die from excessive laughter.

Several pieces of flesh were torn out from some; but from many others, their legs, arms, and faces were twisted backward. Some of those thus tormented, although they had taken nothing for 59 days but turnip broth with bread, nevertheless vomited up a black substance like ink in great quantities; it was so sharp and bitter that it ate away the hands in their mouths. Some were lifted up above the heads of the people and thrown down again. Once, when the sick were calmed and therefore very cheerful, about thirteen friends visited the convent at the same time; the nuns were thrown senseless and speechless from the table, so that several lay there with twisted arms and legs as if dead. One was lifted up, and although those present laid hands to resist, she was nevertheless torn out above their heads and then dashed down again in such a way that she lay there as if dead. Afterward she came to herself as if from a deep sleep and walked about unharmed. Some walked supported on the ends of their leg bones, without making use of their feet, which they dragged after them as if entirely loosened from their ligaments. \[Page 246\]

They climbed the trees like cats and crept down them again without making any movement of the body. The worthy mother of the convent, while she was engaged in conversation with the noble and pious Margaretha, Countess of Bur, had a piece of flesh torn from her loins. She cried out in pain and was carried to bed; but the wound suppurated in part, and in part it was black; however, she was healed. Once, when two of the afflicted nuns were sitting together laughing and cheerful, and speaking with one another of a black cat that a matron of the town, whom they named, had sent locked in a basket into the dormitory; a third healthy one had secretly listened to their talk, and the prioress had examined the basket with her and two or three others, whereupon the cat then jumped away. For this reason the woman was accused of maleficium, and thrown into the dungeon with seven others. Although neighbors and the poor gave her testimony of such mercy toward the needy that she herself went hungry; she was put to the torture but could not be brought to confession by any torment. When the bailiff thereupon offered her food according to custom, she declared: she was too weak to eat, but begged for something to drink. When the drink was immediately handed to her by the bailiff, she seized his garment and, leaning on him, immediately breathed out her life. Still much other wondrous things were to be seen there, and the evil lasted three full years, and was afterward driven out.

It was probably one of those kobolds at play here, who brought this woman, who was most likely innocent, to misfortune. The Brigittines at Fanten were likewise visited with manifold demonic plagues. Jumping about, they sometimes uttered a roaring and frightful noise; they were at times driven out of their appointed seats in the church, and their veils torn off; also their throats were sometimes closed so that they could take no food. The manifold changing and harsh affliction lasted among most of them for ten years. The cause was sought in a maiden who had formerly been inflamed with love for a youth whom her parents would not admit into their kinship. As she was now in great sorrow on this account, the demon persuaded her, in the form of the youth, to take the vow in the convent, and she allowed herself to be clothed. Once received into the order, she was seized as if by a frenzy and gave all a horrible, manifold changing spectacle. Her affliction now communicated itself, like a contagion, to many other sisters; who then, based on her own confession, held her to be the cause of all their misery.

With her, who was subsequently captured and taken away, the jailer begot two children; she was then released, and lived on, burdened with the suspicion of maleficium. The matter had occurred a considerable time before in Marienbaum; he therefore wrote for information to a nun there, and she replied: there were still two nearly eighty-year-olds from that time remaining, and from them she had often heard talk of it. They said: for much would they not have wished to forgo this heavy misfortune, ordained by God; because they had felt what gifts of grace and enlightenment had been granted to them from it; which their lives also bore witness to. At that time many learned people had been sent for, who had closely examined the terrible appearances, and attempted to penetrate into their interior and to provide help. But the more trust one placed in their advice, the more violent the evil became. \[Page 247\]

Then the afflicted finally recognized the matter as God's work; submitting themselves from the whole heart to his mighty arm, and completely denying themselves, they had ordered their lives according to God's Word, and now the evil gradually vanished. Wier adds: how he himself had visited the convent, and made inquiry with one of the old women who had borne the evil for ten years. She likewise praised God for it, and said: that she, if age permitted, would gladly let the same floods of misfortune pass over her once more. She counseled me: that if I should ever be consulted by such sufferers, I should certainly never permit exorcism. One who was such a suffering sister was, on the advice of some, beaten with rods by her brother; as madmen still advise today, as if the demon could be driven out with rods. She, however, from shame and displeasure, gradually wasted away: but in dying she sang; and when asked about the cause of her singing, she answered: because she did not doubt her eternal salvation. Another, long since plagued by the demon and near to death, offered herself entirely to God in her prayer, that he might do with her according to his will in time and eternity, provided only that his name be praised; and she asked her remaining sisters, after her death, not to sing the Miserere in the usual manner, but the Gloria Patri.
