The Hollander Hoofft, in his Netherlandish histories, describes under the year 1566 the following occurrence in the orphanage of Amsterdam, which we supplement in some circumstances from other reports. "At this time the evil spirit plagued the poor children in that city in such a manner with all manner of temptations that the fancies from it, although he sometimes withdrew from them, did not leave their brains for as long as they lived. The greater part of them---there were about seventy in the house---were possessed by evil spirits, and were plagued and tormented in manifold ways. They climbed like cats up walls and roofs. Their faces, when they began to grow angry, they distorted so hideously and gruesomely that, if one looked upon them, even the most stouthearted man's hair stood on end. Often they ran toward the water as if they intended to drown themselves; but as soon as they reached the edge of it, they stood stock-still and said: The great man (as they were wont to call God) will not permit it. In general, whenever they wished to do something evil but could not bring it to pass, they always said: that the great man forbade it. They spoke, in the expression of Laurenz Regals, with playing tongues, all sorts of foreign languages which they had yet never learned; and they knew---what astonished people the most---to recount what was being handled at that very moment in the town hall. \[Page 248\]

Reaal reports on it: one of the children, in a fit, told the orphanage mother Catharina Gereits that the council was still assembled and had just resolved to send her son Johann Claeß to The Hague. It was found that this was indeed the resolution. The council had indeed deliberated on it and withdrawn the sending; but the child had nonetheless seen correctly. In their possession, the children were accustomed to raging and raving terribly, especially before the doors of certain women. In particular, one named Bametie was hateful to them; they unanimously accused her of having bewitched them, and against her they now poured out all their malice; so that these women were always held suspect on that account and cried out as sorceresses. But this suspicion fell most heavily on Bametie, because she was already blamed for having been out many times at night to practice her juggling or sorcery. Moreover, she had also been found many times in the Holy Ghost Chapel (Amsterdam was still Catholic in its government at that time) as if dead and entranced, with hands and feet spread wide apart, stretched out on the floor before the altar; and she would then come back to herself after several hours out of this ecstasy, with deep-drawn sighs.

The aforementioned orphans, when they had climbed up the tower of the old church like cats and played on the carillon bells with their fingers, were accustomed to sing in loud voices from her: We will not go away from here until we see Bametie sitting in the fire. At times they also pointed with their fingers at a spot, as if they wanted to show the bystanders the witch; who, however, was then of course not to be seen despite all efforts, although the children cried: she had just come there to do them some harm. They were also, no one knew why, exceedingly enraged against the schultheiß, reviling and scolding him harshly, and calling him a Deventer cake; either on account of his long, lean figure, or because he let them open their mouths with this children's fare to stop their scolding. ---

The children slept together in one hall, and thus the contagion can easily be understood. But one also sees clearly in this case: that the infected, when no visible center is present from which their evil has proceeded, seek out such a one for themselves; around which they then unite. It is understandable that a center of this sort must have an analogous state dwelling in it to their own, and that seems to have been the case with this woman. She had, as it is written, convulsions; whether these were of a higher mystical kind, or demonic, has not been ascertained. Probably, if we give weight to her evil reputation, brought about by her nocturnal outings, they alternated intermittently with one another; whereupon the possessed held to those corresponding to them. As, moreover, in the higher order of things, connections form themselves in love and attractive instincts; so in this lower one through hatred and repulsion; the choruses are thus scolding, armed against their choir leader, and striving against him.

Something over a hundred years later, in the orphanage of Hoorn in 1670, something quite similar occurred. At that time in this house there was a very large number of children, --- both boys and girls, older and younger, but none under twelve years, and mostly all of the most unruly sort ---, afflicted for several months with a severe plague; on account of which many doctors were consulted, who did not know what to make of the matter. \[Page 249\]

But the plague consisted in this: that the aforementioned children suddenly and unexpectedly fell to the ground, and as soon as they came to themselves, they were pulled and torn with such force that it was unbearable to witness: how they trampled with their legs, knocked their heads against the earth, struck about with their arms, gnashed their teeth, and howled and barked like dogs. In some, the belly rose and fell so violently that it seemed as if a living creature sat within it, which was moving; or as if little barrels were being rolled about in their bodies. They then had to be held by three, four, five, or sometimes even by six people; of whom one held the head, two others the hands, one sat on the legs, and sometimes a fourth had to press down the belly. When they lay still, they were stiff and rigid like wood; so that if one grasped them only by the head and the feet, one could carry them wherever one wished, without their making the slightest movement. This often lasted for several hours in succession, even into the night until twelve, one, or two o'clock.

One of them, the daughter of Tryn Lucas, one of the oldest orphans in the house, was seized by the plague early in the morning around eight, when the morning bell rang for breakfast. The attack lasted without any interruption until four in the afternoon, when the bell rang again for vespers. The sick girl thought, when she came to herself again, that she had only lain in the attack for a short time, because she believed she heard the morning bell ringing once more. These attacks most often came upon the children when they saw others seized by it; or also when they merely heard someone in the plague gnashing their teeth, or howling and barking. Some therefore were accustomed to run away at once, but mostly in vain; unless they happened to be near the gate and could leave the house. Thus, through hearing and seeing, so many often contracted it that there was scarcely enough household staff to be found to help them. Secondly, it also fell upon them very frequently, and almost always, during spiritual exercises, for example under the sermon, from which they therefore had to be kept away; then during the catechetical instruction, which the preachers gave in the house from time to time; but most of all during the prayers, which were recited aloud by the assistant masters. \[Page 250\]

The more earnest and fervent these prayers were, the more God was implored therein to curb the power of Satan; the worse the children had it, and they fell into the plague all the more. During the days of carnival, almost an entire week long, the afflicted were the most unbound and reckless children; indeed so unrestrained, as if they were full of fire and inner burning. Throughout the whole time they could not be tamed, and the plague was in this period, as it were, hidden and suspended. No remedy helped the children, except first of all prayer, which, at the request of the superintendents and the house mother, was constantly observed in all churches and assemblies by all except the Catholics. Furthermore, that the afflicted were allowed to live outside the house with other citizens. When they were away, they soon felt improvement, and the plague began gradually to diminish; so that they were all, sooner or later, delivered from it; except for two female persons, with whom the attacks later returned from time to time. The last case, which we shall here mention only in passing, is the one with the children in the institution that Bourignon established in Ryssel. There were about fifty of these children who received instruction and upbringing in the institute, and the matter seemed to be proceeding well; when the directress first noticed traces of the demonic in some children, and soon convinced herself that the evil was spread through the whole group. The children made their confessions to the pastor of St. Sauveur, and there the Sabbath reappears with its revelries, dances, and all its debaucheries.

These assemblies united, according to their own account, all estates: young and old, rich and poor, noble and ignoble, priests and laymen; and each took his place in due order, as his rank in the world brought with it. One confessed that from her youth she had had a spirit which had grown up with her, and remained with her day and night. Her malice was here chiefly directed against the mistress herself, over whom once an assembly of 25 persons had been held to find means of removing her from the way. Here too, without doubt, a pestilence had come among the children; the essential moments were present, as in other cases; but the matter was taken from the viewpoint of the school. They were those Arcadian shepherds of the old, earnest Sabbath who had gathered together; and now, in childish fashion, boasting of things inaccessible to them, they imitated them among themselves as best they could; much like how they in play practiced handiwork, or behind the drum rehearsed the work of war. \[Page 251\]

If one surveys the whole of the cases cited here, then it cannot hide itself from us: that the Sabbath is a Fata Morgana of the surrounding world of things; only with the difference that the reflection does not occur from the solid into the airy, and is therefore an optical illusion; but that it proceeds from the tangible physical into the spiritual psychic, thus having a real reality within itself; so that in such cases one could with equal right also call the physical the Fata Morgana of the Sabbath. We have already seen it in the nuns of Louviers, how they were exercised in all the horrors of that assembly; which then in the hellish sleep were merely delivered from the burden of the cooperating, but by no means absolutely necessary, matter, in order to stand forth at once in naked spiritual deliverance as it were demons. Just so does the cyclic nature of the Sabbath show itself, in all the cases cited, in the rounded connections of communal contagion. In the midst of the choruses of these fellowships stands guilt, in its personality, as chorus leader; and the complicity binds all around it in their round dance, and a discordant rhythm holds them in their formal formlessness. Hence the solidary obligation of those thus afflicted; if one of the nuns of Kentorp was seized by the attack, then it immediately entered all the others; and if the orphans of Amsterdam saw one from their midst seized, then the like-tuned string immediately resonated in them as well.

For all the members were one in that one whom they had taken as their master, or who had chosen them as his organs; and thus they were also at one with each other, and one felt himself in the other. Their bond was thus a Sabbath in the flesh; it required only a reversal of the vital relations to represent it at once in the spirit; and that ease with which the seized climbed up towers, trees, walls, was what stood at the transition from one state to the other in the excursion. In the representation of the ecstatic states, toward the light side, we have seen examples of how in the more earnest times, in the midst of the fellowships of the Beguines, such states likewise passed over to all members of the same, as through spiritual transfusion; and how now all forms and degrees of these states emerged in the individuals, according to the stage they had reached. Here was a different center, around which the Lord a different bond was closed; and this one invited his own into his wine press, where the jars of his must stood sealed, but not with lust, rather with pains. \[Page 252\]

These were the counter-alliances, set against the demon's followers; and if these, as in Kentorp, showed themselves hostile to all earnest, religious endeavor, and devoted to vain pursuits and mockery; or as in Hoorn, averse to prayer, but given over to mummery and masquerade to the utmost excess; then among the others the opposite sympathies and antipathies would prevail. The role that the hammer-wielders perform on the Sabbath is here fulfilled by the kobolds, who mingle in the throng, perpetrate their mischief, torment the afflicted even more severely, and increase the confusion in every way. Just as the forces of nature sometimes break into society, and in secular, epidemic, and endemic diseases form whirlwinds in their midst, in which they rule and command; so do the psychic powers in these formations, which veer toward the good or evil side, divide themselves again according to the day or night aspect. But that such hauntings by no means necessarily have a fault as their ground is best shown by the example of the Brigittines in Tanten, who, as long as they kicked against the pricks, saw their affliction multiplied; and only after they had submitted in resignation did they see it turn into an asceticism, which, once it had fulfilled its purpose, was taken from them.

### Chapter 3. Vital Relations

Life, which stands open to the most palpable things in creation, also most frequently allows possession to take hold; and thus serves most often the seizing entity as the ground and bearer into which it enters, and from which it then, as much as is permitted to it, overlays the rest of the person. But the outer ground of life is split and divided into multiplicity, and many levels of life are arranged one above the other, and grouped around certain vital central points. The occupation, whether the involuntary one or the one deliberately brought about, will therefore articulate itself in the same way, and can then appear multiply divided. We have already spoken of this multiplicity in connection with possession; here we encounter it again, and we must discuss it once more from another viewpoint.

Father J. J. Surin, a man of deep inner life, has recorded some observations on this from his own experience. His provincial had sent him to Loudun to become the confessor of the possessed nuns there; at a time when the main scenes of the drama there had already passed. In his life¹ it is said of the chief person among them, Mother Johanna: there were four demons that held her in possession. \"Balaam had entrenched himself in her humor, her temperament was the playground in which he operated; and since she was by nature very merry, he did nothing but play pranks; he spoke of eating, drinking, and other pleasures, which then drew her mind away from all contrition and made her averse to all divine things.

Isaacaron spoke of nothing but carnal delights and impurities. Behemoth had seated himself in the wrathful part, hurled a multitude of blasphemies about, and spoke of nothing but planned misdeeds, murder, and manslaughter. The fourth, Leviathan, had seated himself in pride, and haughtiness, boasting, and ostentatious display were his constant occupation. He sometimes gave her a proud bearing, so that she appeared resplendent like an abbess; she then spoke with head held high in pride of wondrous things; she knew the holy fathers, and cited them with great understanding and penetrating eloquence. She kept herself neat in her attire, and had a majestic appearance; while a thousand jests and vanities swirled in her head.\" \[Page 253\]

Their spirits sometimes bestowed upon her a greater beauty than she possessed by nature; especially a loveliness in her gestures, in her bearing and her speech, and an unusual radiance and shining in her eyes.\"

The names mentioned here and everywhere in such cases are conventional, designating the vices, which also alone fall into the circle of deeply inwardly signifying appellations. Three of these demons are now the three principal powers and dominions of the evil signature, toward which human life inclines itself: Balaam, the frivolous mocker and jester; Isacaron, the foul-mouthed teller of obscenities; Behemoth, the wrathful rager and the tearing beast in man. The fourth, however, Leviathan, the arrogant braggart, does indeed rise above these lower regions; but only borne upon the forces that dwell within them, and in which it ever strives to elevate itself above itself, carried to their highest pinnacles. The seat of this life is, however, as we know, the ganglionic system, in its entire extension gathered around certain central points, and the lower principal center laid in the abdominal cerebrum. This nerve-cluster is heaped from twelve ganglia, which pairwise, according to the division into the right and left halves of the body, are thus divided into six pairs forming all the functions of this life.

The uppermost of these six pairs, passing upward into the lung ganglia, appears destined for the life of the breast and lungs; the middle one, as it spreads into the spleen and liver, devoted to these organs and their specific mode of life; a lower one to the genital organs and their functions. The three other pairs appear assigned to the stomach, the organ of this kind of ingestion, as well as to the egestion in the intestinal-anal region and the kidneys. Above all these lower central points, ordered around a middle, there then hover the heart ganglia, as the once-more centering, upward-mediating unification. If any life is now demonically seized, then the incursion must occur into that center whose system appears most affected by the specific mode of the seizure.

There, therefore, to speak in the language of the exorcists, the demon has his seat; the systems that depend from this center fall, from the side of nature, into a profound dormancy; but from the pairs of ganglia outward, this one is demonized by the principle dwelling there. Balaam, therefore, the frivolous, teasing jester, has his seat in that pair of ganglia directed upward, and in the ganglionic plexuses subordinate to it; which serves those systems in which the bright, clear, warm arterial blood is prepared, and the corresponding vital spirit is drawn off; which is therefore the seat of all that is sanguine, light, fleeting, bird-like in man. Behemoth, the wrath-grim one, who thinks only bloody thoughts of murder, and with fury blasphemes every power that restrictingly opposes him; will dwell in that middle pair, and indeed first and foremost in the ganglion that governs the liver.

But as the spleen connects itself with the liver, although complementarily in opposition, so will this spirit of wrath also have two sides. To the flaming one there will be opposed an inward-devouring; to the atrabilious one a stagnating in black spleen-sickness, a self-consuming in melancholy, which vents itself in the spleen ganglion. Both will dominate the system of the black blood and the nocturnal vital spirits in man. Finally, Isacaron or Asmodeus will set up the throne of his dominion in the ganglia that form the center in the genital organs, and from there rule over the flesh; while Leviathan, the spirit of pride, from the heart-center works over into the higher organs of the brain, and inflames them in pride. \[Page 254\]

If we add to these four pure spirits the spirit of gluttony and voracity, of gormandizing and greediness, which dwell in the three remaining pairs of ganglia of the life-system; then the hierarchy of these spirits is closed and rounded off, the vicissitudes are exhausted, and the path for our contemplation is marked out. The sphere of action of these life-spirits properly belongs still to the second region of man; but because they root in the third, and as regards their lower principle belong to it, therefore they are most fittingly dealt with in it, and as its regents can also most fittingly serve us as guides in these domains.

But if we now consider the order and relation of these fundamental drives to one another; then we find the drive to generation, the destructive drive, and the balancing life-drive as the truly root-like forces of all life. Life, once posited, maintains itself through a regulated process of preservation; which appears under the form of an augmenting act of self-generation. Since for this the duality of the sexes belongs, it is inwardly divided in this dualism; and according as the one or the other prevails, the engendering sex alone steps forth outwardly. This dualism, which is ever complementing itself, would now from within ceaselessly continue to generate, and multiply itself through ongoing accretion without end; were it not that another dualism is added to this one, which stands in contrarian opposition to that first one. This second dualism can be none other than the dualism of death: as death forming the counterforce to life, and because this life divides itself in sex, dividing itself antagonistically. Thus to the positively generating life there stands opposed a positively life-limiting death, which manifests itself through actively incisive, wrathful blood-lust; to the femininely receptive life, that negative side of the self-destruction drive, the mother of death, who does not beget him but receives and bears him. \[Page 255\]

This self-destructive drive and that self-preservative drive, if left free to themselves, would now simply annul one another; were it not for a third force above them, which rules both, preserves both in their existence, moderates them and balances them against each other; so that from their counteraction a product, the overall structure of life, can emerge. This preservative force dwells in the innermost unity and the center of life, and intervenes in those double dualisms; it maintains the members of each in equilibrium against one another, so that they mutually complement each other; and it ordains the one against the other, so that they reciprocally limit each other, and thus a limited product comes about. This threefold compounded process now repeats itself three times in organic life. For the first time in the lowest region, in the organic domain of the white, chylous blood. Life, here thrusting its palisade-root across into nature, receives the material from it; not merely admitting it mechanically, but opening itself to it with selection. But it also gives of its own to the received; thus enlivening it with this, yet it also kills what has served its purpose; in that the eating-greed toward the to-be-taken-up and to-be-assimilated is met by a blood-lust against what is already taken up; and in that both split themselves according to expulsion and reception, the life-unity steps in moderating and boundary-setting; and so between ingestion and egestion, in the organic system of the roots and root-leaves on the lowest level, the assimilation into white blood is completed. Upon the second level this process ascends, in the organic focus of the black blood, in the portal-vein system. A new assimilation is here undertaken, and the central points of the assimilating activities are expressed in the liver and the spleen.

The result of the previous process is here grasped with choice, and spread out in the spleen, as the organ of the negative preservation drive; while the positive one presses itself together into the liver. In these same organs, however, the destructive principle of death is also housed; in the one, setting its self-sunken melancholy against the richness of the material; in the other, by its bursting forth in rage's fury, inhibiting the productivity of positive life. But in that the heart, which is everywhere in life, through its power holds asunder and joins together with measure; after the egestion has carried out the killed as bile, the ingested chylous white blood, in the cooperation of the preservation drives, is transformed into black blood.

This immediately enters the third life region into the third process, and must undergo a third transformation in the lungs, which reshapes it into light, arterial blood. To these functions, as they fall apart into a venous and an arterial pair, the double dualism of the generative and the forces of annihilation is indeed imparted; and as the heart, lying entirely in their proximity, again holds the two dualities in itself and to itself in measure and in right order; life works in them heightening, elevating, and introducing and reproducing into an upper region; while death, on the other side, in something opposed to the generative act, disembodies the consumed, depresses it, and, killing it as to matter as well as force, casts it out in exhalation into the surrounding circles. \[Page 256\]

Thus in this process the light, warm, brightly reddened blood is prepared, in which the whole freshness of life, and the germ of higher formations, dwell, and which spreads itself through all life organs. In it the colored blossom of the tree of life will have unfolded itself, which has displayed its leafy richness in the second region, as in the lowest it has only first unfolded itself into the cotyledons. And what is now in such a way secretly hidden in itself building up the organism, that now, going asunder outward, gives itself openly and without covering to be recognized. The lowest process enters into rapport with external nature in the glandular system, the breasts of the organism sitting downward upon nature, in which milk has been prepared for life, from which it prepares its own subsistence; and as in the Indian Trimurti, Brahma, Shiva, Vishnu are life-creators.

#### A. The Demonization of the Nourishment Drive

In the nourishment drive the lowest rapports of the higher organic life with the deeper animated natures take place, thus from life to life intertwined across. Love is in it as appetite, hate as disgust; it has its lust and dis- lust laid out in the whole ladder of stages of tastes and distaste; its irascible drives lie in the zealous anger, which first kills life, before then transforming the killed: its antipathies reveal themselves in the excretions, and its sympathies give notice of themselves in the attachments of the assimilated mat- ter. All these elements can be driven to the extreme, and are then prepared for reversal; when this then happens in the interest of the evil sought with premeditation, and under its cooperation and its incubation; then obsession can occur, as we have seen that possession often occurs accidentally. If here it has been a poisonous plant that the grazing animal in man, among other nourishing herbs, has found on the meadow, and against which no instinct has warned him; then there it is the Eucharist of the demon, which he has sought, for which he has prepared himself, and to which he has gone with premeditation; imagining that he wins life, but in truth taking death into himself. The lust heightened beyond all measure will, under the various drives of that order, first initiate this process; and to the fruits, which are beautiful in appearance and good to eat, gluttony will first lead over.

She will then awaken the zeal of anger, so that it turns destructively, instead of against the harmful, against the nourishing and strengthening; and since the likewise perverted antipathy likewise casts it out, only the unhealthy will be assimilated and permanently incorporated. An example will suffice to make the entire process clear to us. Bekker¹ tells it from his own experience, to be sure in his superficial, arbitrarily rational manner; but nevertheless circumstantially enough to serve our purpose. A young man, about 16 years old, of dull comprehension, mentally and physically not of particular drive or vigor, had become conspicuous to his fellow pupils: through the strange gestures, eye-rollings and contortions of his body, which manifested themselves in him. He had let them eat ripe cherries in the middle of winter; and after first offering them to them, he had then eaten them himself. In the church he had shown them his empty hands, and then taken money from the pews, and asserted: that he did all this with the help of an evil spirit, which he called Serug. \[Page 257\]

They had once caught him at it, how he had drawn a circle with chalk in the school, and described it with some figures and numbers, which Bekker had seen. On being asked: what does that mean? he had stood long silent and still, and blinked with his eyes; but finally confessed: that he had drawn it to speak with him through it. Likewise, when asked: how he had come by the cherries and the money? he had replied, that he had given it to him. Asked: who this he might be? he had, blinking again and looking in front of him, named Beelzebub. Into a hole in the wall, which according to the rector's deputy was much too small to admit his hand, he had nevertheless thrust it in, and upon pulling it out had torn a stone along with it. More sharply questioned, he explained: that the spirit sometimes appeared to him, now agreeably as a maiden, now repulsively as a goat; that it had happened to him for the first time in Leeuwarden, where money for playing had been lacking to him, and that he had given him a handwriting.

The school authorities resolved to exclude him from it, and to inform the parents of the matter; who now agreed upon it, to keep him at home. A maid watched over him during the day, wherever he went and stood; at night he slept with his brother, who was a clever man, and entirely capable for this guardianship. They prayed for him in the church; the maid was accustomed to seat him in front of the pulpit, where he was exposed to the eyes of many people as well as the preacher. There he would then sit stiffly looking in front of him, often blinking, more frequently shaking with his feet, like one who is freezing, and suffering from a twitching of the sinews, as epileptics are wont to have; without, however, ever having fallen in the church.

The maid knew much to tell about him, but this rested only on her belief; because the father, who loved solitude, mostly remained in his chamber; but the mother, although very sensible and attentive, was very burdened with bodily weakness. He presented himself to Bekker as if he felt remorse and sorrow, but took no heart toward the one who scolded him more often; for which reason this one henceforth spoke more kindly with him, and once took him, with the prior knowledge of the parents, on a walk; after having previously bought him some sweets for him, with which, as he very well knew, his trust was most easily to be gained. He now told him on this walk: how his spirit Serug still kept him company, and spoke invisibly with him in various shapes; and that he, in order not to be tormented, still sometimes yielded to him in evil.

He wanted to lure him out continually, and although he had little desire for it, he had nevertheless been very well entertained by him twice at special places: first in the little house by the gallows at Leeuwarden, which then transformed into a beautiful hall; and then in Franeker, on the first piece of pastureland that lies northward from the road by the city moat. There was a pit there, which, except on the hottest summer days, is otherwise mostly full of water; that pit had suddenly dried up at that time, and been full of fiery flames. In it many devils had been flying about, who declared that hell indeed had such a fire as well; but they knew how to render it harmless. To a company of men and women who had been there, splendid fare had been served; there had also been music, dancing, and games. \[Page 258\]

People had spoken Hebrew there; a language which he understood as well as his mother tongue, but outside the assembly not at all. He named those present, among others a woman from Leeuwarden who already had a reputation for this. At night, after he had slept a little, his spirit would make him rise; and lead him along a height which he never saw by day, to that place. Once he had brought him to the sea dike at Harlingen, and made him thrust through two men with the sword that he had placed in his hand. Bekker asked: whether he remembered any Hebrew word at all? He said: Yes, one, "alley," which I use when I want to call him. Bekker replied: that is no Hebrew word, and wrote for him on a small coin the words: *Soer nimmenin Satan! Depart from me, Satan!* with the instruction: to ask the devil about the meaning of the words; and instead of the few shillings that he always used to give him, to demand from him a Hungarian double ducat.

He later reported back: that he had shown the words to the devil, and he had told him that they meant: he should go away from him; but the double ducat he had promised him if he would only first go out; but that he had neither been able nor willing to do. His parents had told Bekker that he sometimes fell into a faint, and then told much about the places where he had been. He asked to be called if it happened again, and now found him once lying flat on the ground, rolling about on it; holding his eyes now closed, now stiffly open; his body mostly drawn together, and in violent motion. After that he came to himself again, and began to speak weakly, but gave little account, except that he was better; though later on he knew how to tell much again.

Once around the summer solstice, when his brother awoke early in the morning, he saw him lying next to him in bed; with closed eyes in sleep, making all the movements of the mouth, the hands, and the body like one who greedily eats and drinks there. He named now the name of Serug, now of another spirit; and demanded this and that from one or the other tree. He then acted like one who receives something and bites into it; he praised the same and laughed, as if it tasted good to him. Finally, when he received something that did not taste good to him, he scolded his spirit vehemently, something like with the words: Now you deceive me again, and give me what you well know that I do not want at all! With that he drew back, and struck with the flat of his hand so forcefully that a mark of it could be seen on the wall, and from the rebound of it he half awoke. Only when he parted from the meal in the pleasure garden did he clearly make the gesture of taking off the garments that he had received there; and that he had to leave behind, in order to go home in his own clothes. He now got up, really dressed himself, and performed his prayer. The brother then said: You were absent the night, where have you been after all? \[Page 259\]

He denied it at first, and now related, under the seal of confidentiality: that he had been in a most beautiful garden, full of delicious fruits, in good company, and so forth. The brother now sought to make it clear to him from what he had seen that it had only been fantasies; but he could not be persuaded, and instead asserted that the brother had only seen his semblance. Moreover, he must have had great bodily flexibility to wriggle through everywhere. Once Bekter was called into his house, where he found the entire household in consternation. He had gone out onto the street in a moment when the maid had turned her back; and when they searched for him, he met the maid on her return from the baker's, where he had bought and paid for something.

No one could comprehend how he had gotten out; the doors were locked from the inside, and the courtyard door was barred; he had not been in front, and had not gone through the courtyard, that much they knew. He would say nothing, but finally pointed out two missing bricks in the roof, toward a roof beam; through that the spirit had led him. In the rear building there was a cellar opening under a bedstead, which without bed and straw was covered only with bare planks, on which 2--3 wash tubs lay. The mother found him in the cellar, the doors locked, and the wash tubs in their place. One sees from this account: the nature that was at play here was of limited intellect; but of a nervous, spasmodic, easily agitated, almost epileptic constitution, which made him capable of every extreme. At the same time, he was physically extremely supple, and as his hand had reached into the narrow opening in the wall; so his body through the one in the roof.

His predominant drive was that gluttony which had already manifested in his early youth with the cherries that Better exploited; and which reappeared when he escaped from supervision in a mysterious manner. That constitution brought on frequent crises that threw him to the ground; but in the midst of the convulsive movements awakened the somnambulism in him. The modality of this state was determined by the ruling drive; banquets, gardens with costly fruits that could satisfy him, were the forms in which the vision made itself known. During his earlier stay in Leeuwarden he had probably 393 come into contact with people who gave the matter a demonic direction; at least Bekker relates that at first a man had been sent to him from there as a guard, who also had the reputation of having been sorely plagued by the devil; but who left again because he seemed even more confused than the young man. \[Page 260\]

Through this it came about that the visions took on entirely the form of the Sabbath vision; predominantly expressed in the shape of the banquet. The degenerate instinct for nourishment had here acted as the pimp; it had led him into those circles to seek satisfaction in them, and to find them in the substitution of inner enjoyments for the outer ones. As grossly sensual as the relationship had been in its root, it may also in its development have risen little above this sphere; tricks and lies had probably, as usual, been added. But it is not necessary to reject the whole as a deliberate deception by the man, as Bekker did in his narrow-minded way; basing himself on the explanation he gave when he later wished to be admitted into the society of the Labadists, and now testified: that it had all been mere fiction, and that he had never seen or heard devils. We have already encountered such explanations with new protestations to the contrary more than once; they rest on the split between body and soul that stands out clearly in such states, and never allows a full and secure conviction as to the reality or ideality of the appearances.

##### i. The Demonic Aberration of the Instinct for Nourishment Downward.

The drive for nutrition, directed toward organic nature for its satisfaction, has in the previous case strayed into the inner spiritual realms; and thus remained unsated in its bodily element. But there is yet another aberration of this drive, where the same, instead of deviating---as there---beyond the natural midpoint, sinks below it, and seeks its satisfaction in the deeper, inorganic realms. The reports of sorcery are full of incidents where those deemed bewitched, or who were in a state of possession, have vomited up utterly inedible objects: hairs, stones, pieces of wood, metals in various forms. Fraud has played its part in this, and such phenomena have been artificially produced; but enough facts remain where, through the application of all caution, fraud has been rendered impossible; and thus a natural process must underlie them, which demands explanation.

All those objects contradict the natural instinct, which is stationed at all the gates of life and stands guard there, to keep the harmful from entering. These instincts must therefore have either been lulled to sleep, or deceived by an illusion that presented the objects to them as edible. The objects often appear not merely threatening to life through their composition; but also through form and mass, scarcely capable---in the ordinary relations of life---of admission and passage through the narrow pathways. There must thus be a condition that allows their intake, in which these pathways open wider, and forces manifest themselves within them that are capable of enforcing this opening; and which may then also drive them out again in the sequel. That is what emerges from the superficial consideration of the fact presupposed as true. Let us now consider some facts of this kind, partly to confirm this truth, partly to derive from them the nearer consequences. \[Page 261\]

One of the oldest facts of this class, of which reports exist, is that which occurred in Lyon. Gaufried, Abbot of Altatuba, reports in the life of the holy Peter Tarantaise---which he, at the command of Pope Lucius, was commissioned by the abbots of Cîteaux and Clairvaux to write: At the castle of Lugdunum there was a pious man who had a daughter bewitched by a woman, suffering from a desperate illness, who could endure neither her husband's presence nor even his sight. Her mother had therefore summoned a known sorcerer to her. He had examined the matter, declared her bewitched, rubbed tree bark, and herbs incantated with words, and administered them to her in a cup; finally, he also gave her a bite in the arm. The woman now partook of her ailment, but from that time on it was as if needles were pressing out from her heart from time to time. She then suffered violent pains, until through the bite in the arm---which did not scar over---needles were driven forth by a secret force. More than thirty of them had thus emerged one after another; when a famous abbot, whom Gaufried, because he was still alive, hesitates to name, passed by on his way, and under the hospitable roof of the father was received, saw the sick woman, and heard her misery recounted by the distressed father.

The account was immediately confirmed by the evidence of the eyes, as the woman anew felt a needle painfully; in a short time it had advanced to the opening, and soon some blood, then the needle itself, appeared. It was soon pushed further forward, and now a lay brother in the abbot's retinue approached, grasped the protruding one, and drew it out bloody, to preserve it for all time to come as a witness to what had occurred. The abbot betook himself to prayer, and touching the wound, said in the power of faith: henceforth neither iron nor steel shall come forth here. It happened thus, but the matter had only changed, because the power of the sorcery was not yet entirely broken. \[Page 262\]

Now there came forth, namely, small wooden splinters or pegs of oak or ash wood, thicker than thorns and a little longer, in place of the needles; however, they were no more of equal length than those had been. Sixteen such had, in the course of a year and fewer months, come from the woman; when finally the holy Peter Tarantusius, to whom this miracle had been reserved, arrived on the scene. The woman was presented to him, as he had ordered the evening before, while he offered the Mass. At that hour the seventeenth peg went from her, which the sacristan drew forth before the eyes of all. The woman went to confession with the saint, received absolution, and after he had administered the Eucharist to her, he bade her be calm; henceforth no matter of any kind would go from her in such a manner. Freed from all enchantment, she lived thereafter with her husband, bore him children; and, as it is said, still alive at the time of this writing, she praises the wondrous power by which she had been deemed worthy to be tried. Peter de Frarineto is called her father, known and honored by all the inhabitants of his place---this is said here; thus ends Gaufried the account, so that if anyone harbors doubt about the event, he may seek conviction from what he is unwilling to believe.

Since then, one has had all too frequent occasion to observe similar events; in some cases fraud has been discovered therein, but others exclude such an interpretation entirely by the circumstances. So the case that Dr. H. ab Heer cites in Observ. VIII. A nine-year-old child had, in May 1625 at Utrecht, taken a sorrel leaf into its mouth, which a woman had offered it, and thereupon felt such pains that it fell down as if dead. Since no medicine helped, it had been exorcised; and now needles, glass, feathers, hairs, nails had burst forth; and it was noticed: as often as that woman approached it within 200 paces, it was each time more severely tormented. She was later arrested and condemned, and with the noose around her neck, confessed herself guilty of the child's harm. This was now brought to Dr. Heer in mid-September, and remained with him for some weeks; and he now relates simply and plainly what he observed in it during that time. \[Page 263\]

He had summoned the Father Modestus of Liège. When this one was still 50 paces distant from the room, the child fell down as if dead; no breath could be felt in it, the fingers and toes were so twisted together that I could not separate them with anything. When the Capuchins began to read the exorcism, the child moved with such violence that six persons present could not hold it still; I myself had grasped its head, and felt how it was drawn, through an inner convulsion, with the nape ever against the shoulders. Meanwhile the body swelled up beyond all measure, and at ten paces distant a sound could be heard from it, as when the unruly waves strike against the forepart of a ship; and the child again burst forth from time to time with those objects. I begged the exorcists, out of pity, to pause. They had scarcely spoken the last word when the sufferer lay still; and when they had departed, the hands and feet unclasped; it soon stood up, ate and drank, and played, as if nothing had happened. This repeated itself always; but when I saw that the ejected things were completely dry, I expressed my doubts to those present. The child now cried: Do not doubt that these things come from me! With that it seized my hand and led it into its throat. Feel, it said, a headless pin, which will come forth at once! I really felt it; but when I thought to grasp it firmly between the fingers of my left hand in its throat, it was torn away from me with force; the child, however, now bent over to vomit, and I received it into my hand.

I have at other times often felt the points at the mouth of the stomach; and when they now came up, then many who wanted to perform experiments meant that they could hold the end of the point fast in the middle of their throat; but all their efforts were each time thwarted. --- Heer healed, more than a year later, the child with an ointment from the hazel bush, which he had found in Carrichter; and the healed one was completely well three years later, only that every year during the Lenten season a melancholy would come over her. In Wiers's time, the ailment seems to have spread epidemically along the Lower Rhine; for whole wagonloads of such afflicted people were brought to him in Cleves. He examined them medically, but could never feel any of the hard objects in the lower abdomen before the vomiting. In more recent times something similar happened with Maria von Mörk in Caltern; at that time, when the conflict within her had not yet been resolved, she too had to endure this temptation.

She began on July 25, 1832, with an unnatural cheerfulness, which, except for the communion days, otherwise continued uninterrupted until the middle of September. In this state she committed various foolish acts, no longer called even her best acquaintances by their names, gnawed with great haste at her own hands as well as at those of others; and wept when one tried to deny it to her. From time to time she would then cry out in the midst of this frenzy: O my God! O, what misery is this! When she came to herself again in lucid intervals, she knew nothing of what she had said and done; and when her siblings made her aware of it, at most a dim recollection of it would dawn on her, and she showed herself extremely dismayed by it. \[Page 264\]

This agitation, whose focal point, as the gnawing reveals, had been in the plexuses of the stomach region, had entered only in the company of a new affliction, which had begun on the same day. For on the aforementioned day, one first noticed in her mouth lumps or pins and other similar things; on which she bit vigorously, and which she gave up again only after long efforts. This phenomenon repeated itself daily in frightful manner two to three times, and continued for eight long weeks until the middle of September. Pins, needles, spirally twisted wires, pieces of glass, horsehairs, nails of all kinds came forth one after another. Most came out of the mouth, following a stabbing pain that she felt in her entrails; whereupon these objects were immediately vomited up amid violent convulsions. The confessor, dismayed by these events, could scarcely bring himself to credit the evidence of his eyes; he therefore reported what had occurred to the parish priest of the place at that time, Mr. Eberl. This man had visited her more often earlier; her appearance had never led him to suspect any unusual state that had come over her.

When, therefore, the occurrence was reported to him, he must have felt struck by the communication; and, as was natural, he expressed his doubts about the truth of the strange things, and how perhaps some deception might have crept in. When it was replied in the meantime that similar doubts had also arisen earlier with the confessor, but that he had been compelled to yield before the evidence of the facts; he went there to take insight into the event himself. He found the afflicted one in violent convulsions; she threw herself, when the crisis approached, backward over the pillows; and since her mouth stood open thereby, one could easily see deep down into the gullet. The priest now had more than one opportunity to observe how the objects were driven up in it, sometimes placing themselves crosswise, resisting the expulsion; and gradually forced higher and higher up, finally entering the mouth, and then, as if blown out by a wind, being expelled.

Initially fearful, he soon gathered courage at the confessor's urging; and whenever he again caught sight of such objects---needles, nails, or pieces of wood---he reached into the gullet and drew them out deeply, so that any possibility of deception was entirely ruled out. To this day he still preserves many of the things that he thus helped bring to light.¹ Not only through the mouth did these objects leave her, but also through the lower passages; under great pain, the sharp things---as she called them in the local dialect---were expelled from her; and one could hear them, if metallic, clinking as they fell below. In the same way, similar objects emerged externally from her after she had felt the pain in her side or elsewhere, when she straightened up, as if they had forced their way through her skin. \[Page 265\]

In May of that year, a paralysis had set in at her left foot, so that she could not move it. In the following September, finally, a board nail more than three inches long worked its way through the skin of her leg, and the limb immediately regained its former flexibility. The same happened sometimes at the back between the shoulder blades; at other times, however, also at the head, where they opened a way out for themselves. It was remarkable in this that the straight pins did not advance, as would have been the case if they had been introduced from outside, with their heads turned outward; rather, the points were turned outward, so that, since they sat fast and could only be grasped with force, the confessor and others often wounded themselves bloody before they managed to pull them out. All these sharp and injurious objects caused her no bleeding, and left no suppurating wound behind; except when one had injured her through incautious removal of them. But once they were finally removed, the sufferer regained control of herself and felt greatly relieved.

Along with this phenomenon, there was also another closely related one, that of the strange infestation of the bed. On the bedsheet, under it on the mattress, on the straw tick, needles, straw stems, nails, hairs, pieces of glass, and so forth were found; and scarcely had the bed been cleaned when, sometimes in the presence of the very same persons who had removed the earlier objects, quite similar ones appeared in the same place, and the cleaning had to be repeated. As long as these bed infestations were around her, the sufferer found herself in such agitation and mental confusion that she not infrequently cried out with a distorted face, flashing eyes, and protruding tongue: she wanted to kill herself; she was damned anyway, she wanted to go with the men who were turning her bed topsy-turvy. Immediately afterward she would complain again of painful stinging in the eyes, in the lower body, on the chest; she howled and cried miserably, often tore out whole handfuls of hair, and wanted to jump violently from the bed out the window. It is noteworthy that the maids who made the bed never found the mentioned infestations; except when the confessor was present in the room. He had, as was natural, taken all precautions, as far as it was at all feasible, to keep such objects---as are usually found in the sweepings---away from her. All the women who approached her had been instructed to pay close attention to needles and whatever similar things they carried on them. But all caution proved useless; the things gathered around her, as if drawn to her. One day, as they were just cleaning the bed again, Marie suddenly began to tremble and called out quivering: Oh! Oh! The confessor asked: what was the matter?

Oh, she replied, now something ugly and large is coming and wants to get into my bed. In fact, one heard how something from the next room, continually striking against the floor, clattered through the open door toward the bed standing close by it. The confessor commanded: Seize it in the name of Jesus, and hand it here! Oh, she cried, it is already running away again, and now it is going into the next room! One of the girls present had the courage to follow it there and pick it up; and there it was found to be a piece of hard wood that had been wrapped with human hair, alternately striking the floor with one end and the other, thus coming along. \[Page 266\]

The confessor, dismayed by all these occurrences, inquired in many ways: how it could be that these strange objects came to her in this manner, and even pressed into her body; but she could give no definite information about it. She said: sometimes it seemed to her as if they entered through the eyes, sometimes again through the mouth; it also seemed to her at times as if they were thrown up against her breast and throat by a little man. Only this one thing was certain, and she maintained the same for a long time afterward: that each time abominable men of dark form surrounded her, and offered and presented to her shapes of various enjoyable objects and delicacies, chestnuts, pastries, and confections. Then she lusted after what was offered, and it was immediately forced upon her by the men; whereupon always violent stabbing and cutting pains would set in, until all that stuff was removed from the body again.

The whole matter had been sought to be concealed as much as possible on account of the sensation; but it came out nevertheless, at least in part, and the strangeness that lay in the entire occurrence made people suspicious; they suspected witchcraft and evil arts, and many who had previously wished well to the afflicted one withdrew from her. Therefore the confessor said to her one day: You see, Marie! how all these hideous things lead people astray; therefore turn yourself in fervent prayer to God, that he may take the plague from you. She promised to do as he had said; and then after some time, when she had gone to holy communion around the middle of September, she said: The Lord has said: I am to have the general prayer held for me in a church, then the torments will cease. But to you I am to vow strict obedience in all things; then you can forbid, in the future, accepting anything from the abominable men, and I shall remain freed. Both happened with the foretold success.

The plague was meanwhile not entirely at an end all at once. For a long time Marie still lamented that the dark men still stood at her bed, and wanted to give her abominable things to put her to death. Once also, when through convulsions her mouth was forced open, three needles were thrown at once into the open throat in the presence of the confessor. The one present heard the clinking of them, and at his command Marie immediately spat them out. Here too, fortunately, everything necessary for judging the phenomenon comes together again. One can follow the things with that walking piece of wood, as it were on their path, from all corners up to her; for there are busy forces around her that, in the manner of goblins, carry it to her from all sides. But the access to her is nevertheless barred to all that filth, until she herself has led her desire into it. \[Page 267\]

To this now approach the dark figures, tempting her with it, by clothing the rigid with the appearance of the enjoyable, indeed of the enticing deliciousness; so that it is not the stone, the metal, that---as in the temptation of the Lord---is to be transformed into bread within her; but rather, that it already appears in the deceptive form of bread, in order to open access to her; where it then, after the disappearance of the appearance, reveals itself again in its true form. She now, seduced by sensual lust, cannot resist the desire; and immediately bound by it, she gives those dark forces power over herself, to force upon her now the desired thing.

For the desire has arisen in the palate, and from there organically reflected upon the solar plexus as its focal point, and has organically assumed the form of a magnetic pull that has become irresistible through consent; and the direction of this pull goes toward the mouth and stomach and those plexuses. The objects therefore, seized by the magnetic attraction, are carried onward in this direction---like the Eucharist in the saints; and since they find the gate opened by the cramp, they are inhaled down to the stomach with unusual force. Through the access of the mouth, they have thus penetrated into the interior, but only into the relative interior; for even the spirits are not able to withdraw spatial objects from space, and to bring them again from the absolute interior---out of the spatial, say the organic---into it. But arrived there, they step forth in their peculiar, life-destroying form; the stinging and the pains in the entrails begin; but with that also simultaneously the counteraction of the life forces, which manifests itself in cramps and convulsions.

In the activity of these forces heightened in themselves, and strengthened through higher influence, now begins the opposite process of expelling the harmfulness once more. The needles are---as shown on the three that were thrown into her throat in the presence of the one witness---expelled, as if blown inward through the pull that arose in her; now they are, in the reversal, blown out again through a living repulsion. In the entrance they probably turned the points downward and inward; in the exit they will be directed reversed upward and outward. Since the desire found its beginning in the eye, it has often seemed to the afflicted as if they had taken their entrance beside the mouth also through this organ. The exit will likewise not be bound only to the mouth and intestinal canal; for it is an indwelling life force, in which the foreign objects are driven; and as this whole body is permeable, so it also drives that seized by it, in its current, without finding resistance, through all parts of the body toward the surface.

Dark figures have mediated the entrance as seducers; the expelling power will likewise sometimes appear personally, in the little helpful manikin that, working inside, throws them outward. Because they are not---through a mechanical force---mechanically expelled; but rather through a vital one, in a kind of secretion, discharged, the objects also leave no injury or suppuration behind. As the haunted one, through the power of obedience, has strengthened her will power, and thus made her consent more difficult; so the whole phenomenon also ceases, although from time to time some relapses return.

##### ii. Greed as Mediator of the Relations to the Metals.

As here gluttony has become the mediator between the warm life and the rigid death; so in another form an affect more akin to the metal, namely greed and avarice. Very significant from this side is what took place with Gertrud Fischer in Frankfurt on the Oder during the time of the Reformation. \[Page 268\]

The daughter of a man named Martini Fischer from Lebus; she had become weak in the head while with him, as the preacher Andreas Ebert of Frankfurt first made known in an open letter, whereupon a citizen of that city, Georg von Kulisch, took her in and had her cared for according to her needs for a long time, during which she became partly healthy again. But this recovery of hers soon changed again afterward, and her ailment grew worse and worse the longer it lasted; so that she became possessed by the enemy of truth, and began to do all manner of things.

Among other things, the preacher says, it happened thus: whenever the aforementioned maid grabbed hold of someone by the coat, sleeve, beard, or otherwise, she always seized money current and valid in this land; and she would quickly carry it to her mouth, chew it, and finally swallow it down, unless the people took it away from her beforehand; and likewise much of this still remains among the citizens here. But after such things had happened from her many times, it was reported to the honorable council, which had her taken into safe custody and care. But what wonders she performed would well deserve a special book to be written about them. She also seized 405 needles, which she chewed and also swallowed. In addition, she spoke good Upper German, which had previously been unknown to her; for she could speak nothing but her mother tongue, namely Markish, and even now can speak no differently. Therefore I was moved, as a preacher in that place at the time, to write to the reverend and highly learned Herr Doctor Martin Luther, according to this enclosed copy, and to ask him to share with me his counsel and good judgment in this matter. To which he replied to me: that it was a strange, unheard-of thing to him, if it were so; and therefore he requested that I write to him in my own hand the truth of it, whether it was indeed real money.

This I wrote back to him, that it was in no way otherwise. Thereupon he gave his recognition and shared with us his advice: that one should lead the maid into the sermon, and pray to God for her; so would it in time become better with her. In the meantime, she had been exorcised by a papist priest, in the hope of driving the devil out of her; over which she made much mockery, and scorned all such things. But when she was led into the sermon, the devil through her often accused me of lies during the preaching; and when I commanded him to be silent, she was silent, and thus she was helped through the common prayer; and I now know not what has happened to her, and what she has done, for to this day she is here a fresh and healthy serving maid. Which all is known and manifest not only in Frankfurt, but also in the whole Mark and many other places.

Somewhat later the following document appeared concerning her and her doings: Before all men in general and each one in particular, of whatever rank, estate, or condition they may be, who shall see, hear, or read this our public attestation, we, the judges and aldermen of the city of Frankfurt on the Oder, do hereby make known, by means of our friendly service in advance, that the worshipful Herr Erasmus Alberus, preacher at Küstrin, has earnestly requested of us, and sought from us a true testimony concerning the wondrous event which occurred here in Frankfurt about a year and a half ago with a maid, who by chance seized money with her hand and swallowed it, etc., as it pertains thereto. \[Page 269\]

We, the undersigned inhabitants, to attest to the truth and without hesitation in declaring it, provide this testimony: that the aforementioned wondrous event and miracle is here in Frankfurt well known, and publicly evident and widely rumored; that the said maiden, by mere chance, wherever she has touched with her hand---be it upon a coat, beret, doublet, hand, sleeve, head, beard, or upon a table, bench, wood, stone, earth, wall, or the like---has grasped therewith money in her hand, brought it to her mouth, and bitten into it so that it has cracked between her teeth; and she has let the coin protrude from her mouth, so that it could be clearly seen, and thereafter swallowed it, whereby she has often changed color in her face from a single swallow. Likewise, she has done this at night in bed while lying beside her nurse: from the featherbed, pillow, bedboard, and whatever else she has grasped, she has caught money, rustled with it, and stuffed her mouth full, so that she has horribly choked and gurgled from it, nearly suffocating, such that a light had to be kindled and aid brought to her, leaving her neck immediately bruised and blackened.

People have also at first, whenever she has grasped at some object, swiftly seized her hand before she could bring it to her mouth, and by force pried open her hand to take the money from it, whereupon she has screamed horribly. She has also handed over the money from her own self to certain honorable folk, both men and women, after making such a grasp; and at times she has stuffed her entire mouth full of money with her hand, rustled it about in her mouth, and gnashed it with her teeth. And it has been all manner of valid coinage, such as Markish groschen, pfennigs, Stettin, Meissen, Polish, and Bohemian money, as well as Prussian groschen; and among them some bad, reddish coin as well. Otherwise, when questioned, she has spoken strange and wondrous words. All this, as reported above---and much else besides---through grasping at money, she has done to herself.

In truth, it happened just as described, as many people, including council members, are still present who have the money that they received from her. To confirm the truth of this, I, Theobald Dürrekragen, the honorable and wise council's appointed and established judge at the court in Frankfurt an der Oder, have knowingly had the court's seal affixed to this letter by the assessors. Given on Saturday after the Nativity of St. Anne, 1585.

One sees that much is still missing for this remarkable appearance to be fully investigated and recorded in all its circumstances. Only one thing must be regarded as firmly established---since one cannot assume that the people were foolish enough to let themselves be deceived by sleight of hand---that is, the money-grabbing and the swallowing of what was grabbed. Georg Sabinus, who in the fourth book of his Latin elegies dedicated a special one to it, has added some decisive circumstances therein. A voice called out to her in her sleep: "Arise, great riches will be given to you!" She awakens and sees, not far from her bed, a distinguished man who says to her: "If you will be my beloved, then you shall enjoy all my treasures that lie hidden in the earth." She is said to have replied: "Whoever you may be, you shall be mine." Now the apparition suddenly takes on a different, terrible form; the girl is frightened by it and by the glow of its eyes, and becomes enraged. Chained up, the raving one says: she will bring the treasures from the earth's bosom to the light of day; and now holds out money and silver to the guards, which, if they do not wrest it from her, she buries in her entrails. \[Page 270\]

This lust, however, reveals itself as greed, which in its deepest vital root is already a kind of wolf's hunger for gold; which, here demonized through consent, gives itself to be known physiologically through the attraction of the hot-hungrily delighted one. But this attraction is, in pull and counter-pull, mutual, and already in the commonly occurring greed, when it cuts deeply, a certain mutual tenderness can be noticed between the lover and the beloved metal; so that the latter seems to gather around him as if instinctively. Here, in the heightened state, the dark inclination becomes a clear striving, the money gathers around her like iron filings around the poles of the magnet; but she, intoxicated by it to frenzy, and hungering and thirsting for it with haste, does not hide it like the others in chests and boxes; but swallows it down in hot hunger, in order to preserve it in her entrails in the closest proximity. In all these appearances, a Sabbath of the inanimate nature has gathered around the life; a mirror image of that other one, in which life itself unites around its self-chosen, false center. To bind such a mirror Sabbath enduringly to the person requires a powerful natural instinct in her: greed and the desire to eat, which may become tools of a deeply incising temptation; and when these now approach, demand consent; just as it was also the case with the other drive that lies at the base of this its spectrum. If this assent does not follow, as was the case with Marie von Mörl, who moreover built a wall around herself through obedience; then the gathering disperses soon.

But if the will yields itself to the tempter, and is even accepted as a paramour, as was the case with the fisherwoman; then the metals come, drawn by a magnetic attraction, and set out on the bridal journey, in order to serve as bride pennies at the wedding. The meal of needles, nails, shards, which the master offers to his own, is however only a meal of trial for the neophytes; for the initiates, as we have seen, a higher and more spiritual food is prepared, which rises gradually from carrion and refuse and human flesh, or that from unclean and uneatable animals, up to the highest and best, but only in the remoteness of a shadow, and quenches no thirst and stills no hunger. For the food of the demon has not sprung forth from life and ripened in the light; it has grown forth from death, and the night has nurtured it, and steeped it in poison.

But what has taken its origin from death cannot, in entering into life, be life-promoting; rather it sows in it the seed of the same perdition in which it itself is prepared. Therefore it can also satisfy no hunger, and quench no burning of thirst, and thereby bring forth any enjoyment of life; for there is no gentle, refreshing coolness or nourishing power in it. Rather a scorching fire is hidden in it, which never gives, but always only taking, increases the hunger and thirst in proportion as it is offered to them for satisfaction. But the root of death is a bitter root, and what has sprung up from this is steeped through and through with bitterness by it; whereas only from life can sweetness flow forth. Therefore this food, unlike the pure, loving nourishment of the transfigured ones, is coarse and refractory, and fills the mouth with bitterness; in opposition to that sweetness, of which the saints have so much to tell. \[Page 271\]

The wine also is made equal to this nourishment; it is not unlocked from the sun-ripened sweetness, through the incubation of mild warmth, into a heart-gladdening drink; rather the subterranean, unbound fire has torn apart the bitterness congealed in the shadow; and thus everything is fermented into that drink which kindles a heavy, turbid, wildly raging intoxication in the veins of the drinker. And just because all fare here is from death, and returns again to death; therefore the guests must also prove themselves therein as the army of death, in that at these Thyestean banquets, like the all-devourer, they must mutually devour one another: because, while life, from generation to generation, spreads itself ever richer; death forms a backward-going, ever more constricting current. And thus the idea underlying all these visions is this: the demon, as the apparent feeder, is in truth the insatiably hungering eater; and he cheats his guests of the life which he assumes the appearance of promoting.

##### iii. The Connections to the Animal Kingdom

The directions of the appetite become monstrous, and go, on the paths just pursued, into inorganic nature; and the substances belonging to it follow the attraction which the connections have tied, up to the hearth in the corresponding organ from which they take their origin. But these appetites are also directed into the living creation, and when they are inflamed to monstrosity, they also enter into an exchange with it; which, through its measureless, grotesque exaggeration, has a hellish character. The transition into this realm is made by that kind of visions in which the evil clothes itself in the form of an animal; and sets itself in a definite relation to the life-circle of the obsessed one. There especially in the English witchcraft the peculiarity comes to the fore: that in the interrogations there it is frequently spoken of the so-called imps, in the retinue of the witches; which appear in the form of birds, moles, and the like. \[Page 272\]

Always in their vicinity they are, and evidently, like the toads in the south, they have come to them from the herd of the Sabbath. It is now remarkable in this regard that the interrogated persons nearly unanimously know how to recount the sucking to which they must submit for these their companions. Elizabeth Style of Stoketrister, in the county of Somerset, confessed voluntarily without torture, in the year 1664 before Judge Hunt: her spirit, to whom she had devoted herself, had frequently appeared to her in the form of a butterfly; and, according to the contract she had concluded with him, had sucked her every morning at four o'clock in the early hours on the whirl of her head; and it had almost hurt her when she thus had to let herself be sucked.

Alice Dicke of Wincanton confesses: how she too had had a familiar spirit that sucked her breast, commonly in the evenings, on the side; while Christina Green of Brewham reports: how she no less had consented to let herself be sucked once every 24 hours; and how the spirit now every morning, in the form of a stingless hedgehog, fulfilled the contract. She adds: how this sucking caused her no small pain, and how she commonly found herself in a state of ecstasy when she was being sucked.

The connection of this appearance with the previous one is not easy to overlook. As the nerve-exhausted, sick life sucks on the healthy one to fill its own emptiness from it; so it seems also to be the case with the life-spirits from the left side: which, although immortal, yet in life impoverished, needy as they are, seek to supplement their lack from elsewhere. The means for this the human being will now provide, who has what they must lack. But it cannot be stolen, that over which he disposes as his endowment in being; if, however, it succeeds in deceiving the possessor out of his consent, then the overlusters dispose as they please over what has been ceded to them. The death-frost now warms itself at the warm life; and what happens in the root from force to force, that mirrors itself in the bodily, onto which it transfers itself from within outward. Because now the life is in the blood, the yearning for life will make itself known as a blood-sucking; and the spirit becomes a vampire, who in manifold forms, at determined critical times regulated by the movements of life, comes to take blood; but not, like the Redeemer, to revive the perishing life anew. But in a demonic ecstasy this act is accomplished: it is thus no outer, but an inner one, directed against the life, and not immediately against its sheath, which is only drawn into the action through participation.

The reverse side of this sequence of appearances emerges there where the reports, from the ecstatically become bodily nature, go directly into the actual animal kingdom, and now the relation that in ordinary life exists between the organism and the intestinal worms is extended in a magical manner also to other animal classes. The most instructive thing that has occurred in this way is what at the end of the sixteenth century took place in the Upper Palatinate. On 20 November 1694, the twelve-year-old son Theodor of the pastor Z. Döderlin there, at the church of Berolzheim near Weissenburg am Sand, had begun to complain of headache and stomach ache, with complete loss of appetite; but the mother, who believed he had perhaps eaten something harmful while playing in the garden, had given him a home remedy, which however on the following day had only produced vomiting and stool, with the expulsion of some worms.

It took another six days of all sorts of remedies to still the vomiting; but since fainting fits, heart palpitations, and epileptic convulsions followed, they called in the physician from Weissenburg, Dr. Wider, for counsel; who advised on worms, and prescribed helminthogogic remedies, mixed with stomach-strengthening and anti-epileptic ones. These too were applied fruitlessly for a whole month, and the symptoms of the illness multiplied; they therefore discontinued the medicines, and resorted only to a bloodletting, after which the patient's strength increased somewhat, and only the vomiting persisted. Wider therefore prescribed, on the 5th of January 1695, pills against it once more, as well as against the worms; whereupon the boy for the first time began to feel a large worm in his intestines, and on the 2nd became so deranged that it seemed his end was at hand. But when he came to himself again, he filled the house with weeping and lamenting, threw himself from the bed onto a bench, and rolled about on it, continually crying out that the worm would kill him with its bites. They gave him all manner of things, especially garlic juice, after which the worm ceased biting, and the boy stopped his wailing. The doctor prescribed what was fitting, but the worm proceeded once more to bite, now on the right side, now on the left; and the boy rolled about screaming again, and the pain nearly drove him to madness. \[Page 273\]

This continued for so long, until someone advised soothing the creature with milk; it then indeed desisted from biting, but was by no means thereby expelled. They immediately administered suitable medicines, of which, however, only the Marrubium album drove a millipede out through the stool. Since the tartar emetic weakened the boy immensely, he was conveyed under medical care to Weissenburg, where quicksilver and the decoction of Hypericum procured him three days of rest; but upon that the worm, ascending as far as the pit of the stomach, began once more to stir most violently. Only by means of milk could it be pacified; with bitter drinks it bit furiously about. Abstinence from food and drink brought on labored breathing, swelling of the face, and choking fits. They administered such violent purgatives that it seemed either the boy or the worm must succumb to them; all to no avail.
