They were therefore obliged to resolve on sending him back again to his parents. In the meantime, someone had made the proposal to the despairing ones, to assist the patient against the worm with warm cloths, and this proved effective: they could drive it or lure it backwards or forwards with them; it came sometimes as far as the gullet, and had to be repelled with vinegar.

From that time onward the boy could retain the foods that pleased the creature; the others, however, it cast back from the gullet. They obtained the judgment of the medical faculty at Altdorf; who, since medicines would not avail, proposed a dissection to be performed by a skilled hand; and since this did not seem agreeable, the most renowned physicians in Nuremberg, Augsburg, Frankfurt, Oettingen, and Switzerland were consulted, but their counsel remained wholly without effect. Full three hundred times a day the worm ascended into the throat; the belly meanwhile swelled enormously from sundry creatures, which from time to time could be felt externally; but these always remained below, while that one alone mounted upward. They placed the boy on his head, and had him inhale the vapor of milk. The worm, following after the milk, came up so far that it became visible to those standing by, but could nevertheless never be drawn forth; only another millipede was expelled. Only before the Marrubium album did the creature show aversion; its decoction always drove it from the stomach into the intestines, under great pains to the boy; which pains endured until it had reached the lowest bowels. But when it was just on the point of being expelled from there, it suddenly mounted back up to the stomach, and celebrated its happy return with some merry leaps. \[Page 274\]

It was equally sensitive to heat; a burning wax candle, the flame from the stove, the rubbing with warm cloths drove it to flight; and it immediately rolled itself into a lump, in which one could feel a movement like that of vipers. If one brought an even hotter cloth near, it fled to another corner. When the abdomen swelled, which happened several times daily, then the strongest man could not press it down; but as soon as someone pressed the head of the worm with a finger, the others, all of them smaller, fled to another place. Rue was so hateful to them that, if the boy smelled it, ate it, or laid it on the abdomen, they were all thrown into great rage and agitation. They likewise abhorred radish, vinegar, and everything bitter; but the sweet was exceedingly pleasant to them, and the scent of a musk ball made the larger worm leap up perhaps a hundred times in a quarter of an hour. From then on, however, he abated somewhat in his wildness; for although he climbed up into the throat more than a thousand times every day, and each time had to be removed by swallowing, whereby the noise he made could be heard a hundred paces away; yet he bit only when provoked to anger, and then only lightly.

Now one of those folk healers appeared, of the kind that the faculty is wont to call medicaster, who advised removing the bitter, but recommended sweet and fatty things. His advice was followed, and whether it was due to the application of these remedies or to chance, from March 4 to 26 the following creatures emerged from the boy's mouth and anus, to the astonishment of all witnesses. Namely: 162 larger and smaller centipedes, ten or twenty at a time; two moths; a white worm with a black head, while a similar one bored into the navel; four fast-running worms, each with twenty stinger-bearing feet; four hopping butterflies; four other swiftly moving red maggots resembling large ants; a white centipede; 42 dark-colored caterpillars of various sizes; finally, a full-grown beetle. Not all emerged through the mouth, but some crawled along the palate to the ethmoid bone, and were then driven out through the nose with a warm cloth. They were all very lively and so nimble that, if one did not catch them immediately, they soon ran away. They did not come mixed together, but the like kinds appeared together; the smaller insects were surrounded by the four larger ones, and by some smaller earthworms, as if by a dam; and some of them lived 3, 8, up to 12 days, until they finally starved to death.

The parents joyfully considered the boy already freed; but on March 26 an interlude occurred that led them to conclude it was sorcery. As the other children were playing in the garden on March 26, they found in a new bird's nest a white bird's egg painted with red figures; but when they opened it to eat, the yolk was black and sprinkled as if with gunpowder. For this reason they threw it against the fence and washed their hands; but as the parents and neighbors now came running up because of the novelty of the thing, suddenly a rooster fell down dead; two hens, however, were seized with convulsions, and on the following day the crossroads in the garden was found sprinkled with a black powder. That incompetent doctor now had the boy's abdomen covered with plasters, gave him all sorts of things unceasingly, and had the belly bound and pressed upward. Now, from that day until the end of May, four frogs of medium size were driven out from the boy's mouth, by applying stinking things from below but sweet ones from above; one of which had a beetle, a mealworm, and a frog in its stomach, the second slime, but the other two nothing in their stomachs. When the first one had been expelled, some friends advised: to bring the boy at night to the fish pond, where there were many frogs; in the hope that, if he still had more inside him, these might perhaps be lured out by sympathy with those in the pond. \[Page 275\]

Scarcely had he, however, come near the pond, when his belly swelled beyond measure. The worm, which for several weeks had not bitten, now began again its old cruel game, and rose up in the following days perhaps a thousand times; but the frogs in the boy's body answered those outside with the same croaking and the same motion; so that, on account of the uproar in his body, the boy from then on never again dared to go out at the time when the frogs croaked. After the expulsion of the frogs followed some toads, then 21 lizards of various sizes; the frogs as well as the toads were lively in color, and of different kinds. The larger span-long toad killed the smaller one at once with her breath, and filled perhaps a glass with her slime, which she then swallowed up again. Before the separation of all these animals went a feverish chill, followed by a tickling in the throat. Then the animals were vomited up lengthwise, without particular pain.

The last lizard was covered with a piece of skin from another dead one. It was now believed that the great worm too had in some way departed. But when the boy, after his daily prayer, went to bed again, which he had shunned for two days out of fear, and now fell asleep easily; he suddenly raised himself up, and cried: something bitter had flowed into his throat, from which his lower belly was swelling; at the same time the worm began to rage again. Since the insect nest was now destroyed, it ran up and down freely and as if in a fury, and bit most violently at the slightest movement of the boy. Whether it had been vomited up and returned, or had remained, had to remain undecided.

But when on the 9th of June friends who visited the boy brought him confections, the creature was thereby lured several times into his throat; and caused him such distress that he lay down on a cushion of the bench by the window in the sun; and there, holding a piece of confection in his hand, he became a little beside himself. The creature, lured by the sweetness, now sprang forth; to those present it seemed a viper, and the boy's body fell together at once. The housemates searched most eagerly for the viper in all corners for a whole hour, but could not find it. So that it might not slip into the boy's mouth again, it was resolved to convey him over to the house of a trusted neighbor; where he remained for eight days sound and cheerful. Meanwhile, some remedies were provided to the boy by a respectable person, which were supposed to be particularly salutary against sorcery: a water, a powder for fumigating, another with an oil to rinse the mouth, and an amulet. At the same time the remedies of the unqualified doctor were continued, and now the boy vomited up, from the 17th to the 21st of June, some shoe nails, half of a chain ring, seven pieces of bowls, stones among which two quite large ones, a ball of hair, pieces of white and red eggshells, two forks one of which was wound around with hair, a piece of a medicine glass, finally two large nails.

At all these things, as at the departure of the animals, were present the collector Knebel, the pastor of Trommetsheim, and many other most credible people. All the objects came singly, under sometimes hours-long exertions; which at the forks were so great that they produced an exceedingly strong hoarseness. The boy now felt nothing more, and the parents resolved to take him home again; but they placed him in another room, and he slept with a relative who watched over him the whole night until six o'clock in the morning. \[Page 276\]

Shortly after she had fallen asleep, the viper returned, however, to the horror of all. Since they applied triple doses of the medicine and manifold prayers, she soon departed again in that light ecstasy which overtakes the severely exhausted; after she had previously bitten his foot, so that he came to from it, and ran screaming into the father's study, showing the swollen foot and calling for help. Some theriac and the anointing with scorpion oil soon restored him, so that his parents took him to church on Sunday. But as he was on the stairs, from the lower story to the upper, the viper pursued him again; so that he hurriedly slammed the door of the upper hallway behind him and cried for help. Trembling as he was, he therefore could not be let out of sight the entire day; during which he then, in the evening, expelled one of the forks from himself. He spent the night in the house of C. Bambrucker, under the watch of his grandmother and constant prayer, peacefully. But early in the morning at 6 o'clock, he felt the viper in his body again, and one could plainly hear it hissing.

He was therefore brought home once more; the grandmother, who constantly remained at his bedside, did not take her eyes off him, in case she might see the creature at its exit. In vain, however---as soon as sleep and that kind of ecstasy came over the boy, it had gone out for the fourth time, and bit him so fiercely in the hand that the blood began to flow from it. The parents now sent the boy, under the care of his grandmother, to Weissenburg, and there he continued the use of the medicines under good care. He still vomited some smaller frogs, and three pieces of a smaller viper, such as the son of the apothecary Höchstetter had found him lying on the ground and picked up; but now, after some tufts of hair had passed from him in Rotenburg in July 1695, he became completely healthy in body and soul, and at the time of the report's composition lived at the Gymnasium in Heilbronn, devoted to his studies.

In this story, palpable bestiality and mystical superstition border so closely upon one another in an animal fable that a rational age could neither withhold nor grant belief, and thus strove most eagerly to dispose of the whole matter as quickly as possible through forgetting, in which it succeeded quite well. Since we cannot do the many sensible people who had dealings with the story the indignity of believing that they let themselves be fooled for longer than six months by a cunning boy; we must therefore look elsewhere to connect the event with other things heard, and thereby make it somewhat comprehensible to ourselves. \[Page 277\]

On the occasion of the viper, we learn that the boy, in all the acts where it actively intervenes and seems to come and go, was in a kind of ecstatic sleep. We must assume that this was already an innate disposition in him, and that the entry of all the animals that made their home in him had already occurred in a seizure of this ecstasy. In the garden or nearby there was a fish pond, in and around which all these animals were to be found; the boy had played near it the day before the outbreak of the affliction, and had likely fallen into that sleep-waking state at its edge. All those rapports that sleep even in life itself had now awakened in him, and begun their play. Just as the underground metals enter the circle of the rhodomancer, the movements of the stars into the sphere of the star-sick, the dead into that of the vampirically afflicted; so it was here with the animals, within the sphere of action of these instincts: they were not merely perceived, but felt their pull on their own side as well, and yielded to it. This showed itself still, after the counter-act of the intake, in the act of their expulsion.

All the animals, namely, as soon as they had come to light through vomiting, ran about with great agility; fleeing every other human being except the boy, toward whom they felt a secret sympathy; and he could lure them wherever he wished, touch them if he pleased, and, to preserve them, lock them up in a vessel, in which they lived for a time nourished with milk, but then, when sprinkled with horse urine, died. Drawn by this secret sympathy, the animals at that time---whether in pairs, or merely fertilized female individuals---had entered through the boy's open mouth, just as all sexes had then entered the saving ark; they had settled in his interior, and in the same instincts gained a right of home in the domain of their lord and king: a right that was first canceled for them only when the sympathy, through the medicines and the reactions of nature, had turned into antipathy. They were now expelled, especially in the reversal of the peristaltic movement; and the sequence in which they had gone out in masses, grouped according to species, shows the sequence in which they had built their nests inside from above downward. \[Page 278\]

The first to have come were the lizards, those nimble, agile creatures that easily slip into any opening; they had therefore settled deepest in the lower entrails, and there multiplied fruitfully. The toads and the frogs had joined them, and taken up residence in the next higher regions of the entrails. These had been followed by the earthworms; a beetle that had remained infertile, and the host of caterpillars had spread through the thin intestines, and two of them had already completed their metamorphosis. Finally, nearest the lower gate of the stomach, the last to arrive---and therefore also the first to be expelled---centipedes had found their lodging. In proportion as the settlers had multiplied, the boy's abdomen had swollen; but the animals themselves in their lightless abode had become equally distended, like the plants that by chance had grown up in the night of the mines. It was observed of all of them that they were of unusual size, and had fat bellies; but if they were dead, they quickly collapsed, and shriveled away into insignificant remnants. The animal heat had slowly promoted them, but their cold-blooded nature had given them that irritability toward higher degrees of heat. Also remarkable are the other observations made on this occasion concerning their household: their aversion to horehound, rue, beet, St. John's wort, all things bitter and sour; their love for milk and all things sweet, and for the pleasant scent of musk; remarkable too that, hearing through all the belly coverings, they had been collectively excited by the frogs in the pond, and even the enclosed ones had begun to cry out.

The innate head of the animal sabbath, which the boy had abidingly assembled in his entrails, was that viper who had pitched her court in the stomach, from there ruled the upper parts, and, when she wished, stretched her snakelike body through the realms and nests of the lower animals. Her dominion showed itself when her head was roughly touched; at which all the animals took flight before her wrath and the convulsive movements of her body. One might doubt her existence, and believe that she owed her being only to the ecstatic vision of the intestine filled with that parasitic life, which would now have to project itself snakelike into the inner sense; had she not been felt all too clearly at that time, upon the application of heat, in that tangle, and otherwise; and had not actual parts belonging to a snakelike body been later discharged.

However, there was always a connection between her and the ecstatic state of the boy, which confused in her the realms of the tangible and the visionary, and particularly made uncertain the reports concerning her exit and entrance. For she was never seen and found by anyone with clarity, although she was sought everywhere with the utmost care; for which reason a doubt was also entertained regarding her actual existence, since she never appeared without a slight state of being beside himself on the part of the boy, who thereafter could never quite remember what had happened to him. Only once did one believe to have seen her, as she slipped out with her larger half from the mouth of the boy, and, startled only by the outcry of those standing around, went back. Entrance and exit were always accompanied by a bitter-gall taste in the boy's mouth; which proved her close connection with her domain, the liver system. As it appears, she met her death shortly before the end of the illness, and the expelled fragments belonged to her. The departed inorganic objects seem to attach themselves to a later form of the illness; but little weight can be given to the point of incidence with the found egg, since it stands only episodically without further connection to the object.

#### B. The Reproductive Drive and the Blood-Lust as Points of Attachment for Demonic Rapports

\[Page 279\]

All external reproduction is, from the organic side, a self-reproduction that steps outward, continuing itself in another individual. The two causes of life, the active and the passive, which in the latter of these work united in the same personality, divide themselves in the other between the two sexes; and thus these, alongside the self-reproduction that each practices inwardly for itself, also encounter one another externally for a third reproduction; in the continuation and connection of the fundamental acts into a third act, and in the union of the two self-reproduced, a third-reproduced comes forth, in which each claims its share. For the orderly, natural, and fruitful reproduction, therefore, it is required that not only the two self-reproductions, in their powers and organs, proceed in living sufficiency; but that beyond this, enough of life remain over, so as likewise, in its separate powers and organs, to step forth organically, to accomplish the third act, with corresponding energy of power, in the fullness of the material; so that thus, for the reception of the spiritual, the third life may ignite itself in the appropriate corporeality.

For this, the sexes are now placed in a special rapport to one another, in which they meet and unite themselves for the work. But as the process of self-reproduction on both sides, toward the outside, is connected with an assimilation process, through which the corporeality, from natural substances and in natural powers, produces and births itself again and again anew and yet the same, and thus maintains itself in enduring existence; so will it also be arranged around the third reproduction in the midst of the two. The life-germ that has arisen in the interaction of both sexes appropriates to itself from the maternal organism what is agreeable to it; and when it has thereby attained a certain degree of development, it steps forth into the daylight, in order as an independent organism to practice the same appropriation against the external nature.

So, in that every succeeding generation has always proceeded through procreation from the preceding one, and through appropriation has taken up into itself the beginnings of corporeality; the first-created life-germ of the entire race, ever creating out of nature and giving back to it, has spread itself more and more within it; and in that the drop, which was hewn down from on high, has in this way gradually grown into a broad and full stream; the continuance of the entire race, bound together through all times, finds itself secured, through this never-stagnating process of appropriation, in the midst of physical nature; while its spiritual \[aspect\] is preserved in the continuing activation of the souls created potentially in the original beginning.

What, therefore, on the path of nature, has founded this bodily-earthly existence of humanity, that had to happen once more in the realm of grace, in order to secure and restore that spiritual-super-earthly \[existence\] as well. The work of redemption has founded this securing and restoration; and since then we see, in the midst of the race, upon the natural organism and the natural process active within it---which Christianity presupposes both as given---a churchly organism planted, and within this an unremittingly active, much-divided act of grace, through which it too, remaining in the midst of change and unchangeably the same, maintains itself. For through the Incarnation a new life-germ has namely been founded in the midst of spiritually sickened humanity; and proceeding from it, that great process of grace, encompassing all times, has now immediately begun. This higher process is also, like the natural one, divided into two parts; it begins with a spiritual begetting, just as the other with a natural one, and continues in the same way into an unceasing appropriation. \[Page 280\]

But for both acts, the Redeemer now stands, in his God-united humanity, in relation to the entire race as the active cause to the passive \[recipient\]; because before his higher supernatural unity the sexual opposition entirely disappears. For as both sexes, equally needy of the higher impregnation through grace, enter into the same relation to him; the Church, to which they are united, appears as his bride; and as she is united with him in orderly spiritual marriage, he stands as her head and husband, she as the domina opposite the Dominus. He, now, from the beginning and from then on through the course of time, has begotten in himself the life reborn in him, and himself in him, in the circle of churchly vitality; but she, and in her all who belong to her, have received, and cooperating in his effect have brought forth the received \[life\] outwardly. But the bringing forth has also occurred through a process of assimilation; in that he, the one begetting himself, as appropriating life-germ active within her, first from her, and then everything that is outside, viewing as appropriable nature, has truly appropriated it to himself and continues to appropriate; and so it has come to pass that, as here too from one many have become, a new reborn human race has proceeded forth in the midst of the old.

Beside this Church and her head, however, there now arises her counterpart, the counter-church, likewise united under her head. For as all good in human nature stands in a rapport of consonance, sympathy, and love to its first giver and later restorer, through which precisely that higher life-germ gains entry for implantation, and then, nourishing and thriving in that which is turned toward it, comes to development; so the evil in it is inclined to its first originator and disseminator, and connected with him in an equal rapport, strives to take him into itself and itself into him, so that he may embody himself in its material.

The demon thus stands in the same relation to this dark nature in man as the Savior stands to the light and better one; and just as the latter, begetting life in it, assimilates it to life, so the former, since he has no true life in himself, can only beget what he possesses, namely death, and can only appropriate to the given seed of death what is sickly and dead. He can therefore also form nothing organic for himself with it, determine himself in harmony, shape himself, precisely because dissonance and contradiction form his peculiar essence; he thus requires for his semblance-formations a true formation, so that he may implant death into his life, and the formless, cadaverous deformity into his maintained form. His counter-church thus requires the church, so that it may come to appearance in it, if not through it, through the dark, as sickness does in healthy life. \[Page 281\]

Bound to this darkness in rapport, he now begets the seed of death in it; and the implanted one now becomes the striking point, around which in the in and out all appropriation of the like occurs. Here too, therefore, in the realm of life there exists a sexual relation between the demon and those who mark themselves with his sign. But because before him, the creaturely spirit, the sexual opposition of the creature does not vanish; therefore he also does not stand to it, as does the head of the church, in the unconditional relation of the active to the passive cause; but the active becomes passive to him, the passive active in opposition. Upon this relation, therefore, a marriage will also ground itself in the realm of life; but this marriage is a wild marriage, the counter-church is connected to its lord as a concubine, not as a mistress, but as a maid to her tyrant; and it is not the blessing of that chaste begetting, as it rests upon the union of heaven and earth; but the curse of whoredom, as it lay upon the service of the Baals, which shrank from no abomination and had no scruple about proceeding even against nature. Therefore, however, this union can never be fruitful; pregnant with ruin, it gives birth to destruction, because all negation only takes, but can never give anything.

What in this way, in the two churches, valid for all, inwardly veiled in hiddenness, and yet felt by all, outwardly entered into life, that shows itself in the twofold mysticism, now more withdrawn from externality, but inwardly for that reason unveiled. For with all other drives and powers, the sexual drive has also turned inward, and intensified itself in its exponent. Toward the good side, this intensification is connected with a withdrawal from the animal, and an inner purification; so that, just as there in the inner self-begetting the life and the corporeality allotted to it are transfigured, so too the same life, in its inbirth into the mystical body of the church, gives birth only to what is good and transfigured from its head. But in the dark nature, this apparent intensification is directed toward the abyss, in truth a deepening through the animal beneath nature, from which only the distorted and prodigious emerges. The life that dwells in the sexual organs, unbound from its bearer, and now centering and gathering itself in itself, can now, having become receptive to spiritual touches, there form rapports from which relations of the most brutal kind develop; to which the outer reality has indeed faded, but which for that are compensated by a very definite inner one. We have spoken of them in their generality earlier already on the occasion of the Sabbath; it remains for us here only to consider them in their particularity, insofar as they, proceeding from an individuality, strive to raise themselves to that generality.

They now seek, in the guise of the act of generation, to unite disparate realms; and now there arises, as either the demonic life actively causes in the passionate human, or this takes the active role while that assumes the passive one, the Incubus and the Succubus as a modality of the drive thus demonizing itself, which can again spread in an epidemic and contagious manner. Or the relations thus attached by it seek hostilely to force themselves into the natural act of generation, and to paralyze and thwart the natural act; and thus the relations manifest themselves in a destructive way in the tying of the navel-cord and in everything connected with it.

##### i. The Incubus and the Succubus.

\[Page 282\]

The natural phenomenon that forms the basis here, and the predisposition, is the Alp, which we have already considered earlier. It is twofold: a pressing, anxiety-inducing, binding, paralyzing kind, and another elastic, expansive, loosening, stimulating kind: the former, proceeding from the solar plexus, inhibiting and restricting the nervous activity; the latter, from there into the sexual organs, as the other focal point, driving, exciting, and determining this activity to increased vigor. These are the beginnings of the evil, as all natural adiaphoric nature, and as all disease, arising from a power foreign to life, confusing and clouding it. The evil can intensify, the inner disharmony can become so confused that, in the counteraction, a deep sleep arises that has these organs as its center. Then a hysterical somnambulism emerges, proceeding from this center, in which what appears confused, darkened, and disordered in the ordinary Alp takes on definite forms, and already betrays traces of the proximity of spiritual powers. It will not yet appear altogether necessary that such a state must be of a demonic nature; but the danger lies close that it may pass over into one.

For life is now polarized over to this side, it points over into the spiritual realms; relations valid there have become unbound in it, and it now seeks in them that with which it may satiate itself. If it now, when the drive has turned to the demonic side, finds a place where the feelers that have emerged from it can attach themselves; then it strikes them in there, sucks itself fast, and now becomes at home in this realm, and forms a continuum with its center. The demonization of the drive thus intensified has then proceeded from its own assent, and the partial obsession is its own deed. Or the nature prepared through inner division is merely taken possession of by the foreign power; whether this throws itself upon it, or whether it is determined to do so through the influence of another; then it is possession, which is a demonic illness, and cannot be imputed in the absence of the will's assent.

Among the numerous facts that present themselves, we shall select only those that either lie at the transition into the demonic character, or appear fully expressed in it. The first was around the middle of the seventeenth century the case with a poor widow in Bergamo, of whom the exorcist Brognoli tells: when she was alone in her bedroom, she was always afflicted by the speaking of many voices. Some said: Let us sleep with her! Others replied to that: She will not consent, for she fears God! whereupon others again interjected: She will indeed consent, and if she will not, then we need only use force! It then seemed to her as if one ascended her bed, and so she lay seized by the greatest fear, and no sleep came into her eyes. :) That was the indecision, and the struggle; the approach of the evil and its repulsion through the resolve of the will. If this resolve remains firm and well-grounded, then the approaching demonium can do nothing against it, and help will then come easily. \[Page 283\]

Thus it was with those of whom Coleti¹ tells. A woman of his parish came to him with her husband. She was pious and of good morals, but for ten years she had been plagued by such a spirit who suggested shameful things to her, and day and night, even when she was not asleep, behaved as an Incubus toward her, so that what she suffered was by no means a dream. But with regard to her consent, she could not be won over, and she remained unshaken. The Exorcist did nothing but pronounce the mild precept against the demon, and from then on she had peace from him. Another woman of his acquaintance had likewise been tempted for eight years by such a one; the woman had actual, real dealings with him; but she too had not consented, but rather abhorred the mischief, and so she too was freed by a simple command to him.

But if there is pleasure in the act, then the evil takes deeper root. In the year 1643, Brognoli recounts, I traveled, on the command of my superiors, to a place to free a twenty-year-old girl who was plagued by an Incubus, and went with her confessor to her dwelling. Scarcely had we entered the house when the demon, who was just in the midst of it, immediately ceased. I now spoke to her, and she laid out for me clearly and distinctly everything that the demon was accustomed to do with her. From this report I soon understood: that she, although she denied it, had nevertheless given the demon an indirect consent. For when she felt his nearness, through the swelling of the affected parts and the violent titillation, then she did not take refuge in prayer; she did not call upon God and the Virgin for help, nor upon the angel of her chastity; but instead she hurried to her chamber and lay down in bed, so that thus the Evil One could more conveniently and pleasantly perform his business. When I therefore sought to awaken in her the act of firm trust in God for her deliverance, she remained dry and without any emotion; indeed, she felt in her heart continually a contradiction, that she should not be freed. I therefore left her, after first leaving some instructions to her confessor and her elders, on penance and on subduing her body through fasting and mortifications.

But this consent is most easily obtained when the approaching evil takes the form of a beloved object. In Bergamo, in the year 1650, a young merchant, about twenty years old, was plagued by a Succubus, as the same Brognoli³ told him: several months before, as he lay in bed in his chamber, the demon had appeared to him in the form of an exceedingly beautiful girl whom he loved. When he, seeing this form, had cried out, she had immediately commanded him to be silent, assuring him: she was that girl, and had fled from the house because her mother had mistreated her with blows; and now she came to see her beloved. He himself knew very well that it was not his Theresa, but some house-demon; nevertheless, after some words and embraces, he took it into his bed. After that the form said to him: she was not the girl, but a demon who loved him, and therefore joined herself to him day and night. So it lasted for several months, until God freed him through my intervention, and he did penance for his sins. \[Page 284\]

But if consent has occurred, it reveals itself easily through the ensuing familiarity. The same Exorcist was told by a woman in 1694: every night the Incubus lay with her, practiced all sorts of unchastities with her, led her to blaspheme God, and to talk and chat with him as with her husband. Moreover, she was often led out of the house to practice the same with other sorcerers.

One sees how here already the evil has risen from the lower regions into the higher ones, there calling forth blasphemies, and then turning into the vision of the Sabbath. Just as clearly does this agreement reveal itself through external signs and the boldness of the behavior. In the year 1649, Brognoli recounts, I was to exorcise a possessed woman on the order of the Apostolic Nuncio; she visited me the following day at the door of the monastery of St. Bonaventure, dressed in the habit of a Tertiary of St. Francis, but very vainly adorned, quite beautiful and about 35 years old. When I asked her: What sort of torment the demon was inflicting upon her? she replied: It has been about 18 years since he, in the form of a handsome youth, has abused my body; which happened, as now, so also during the lifetime of my husband, when he would then send a sleep over him and do as he pleased. In the conversations that I have with him, he always drives me to blasphemy; he also often brings me out of the house at night to consort with other sorcerers.

I now began to exorcise her in her house; but soon noticed that she was in complete agreement with the demon. For she brought me a message from his side: if I wished to free the woman from him, I must proceed according to the ancient *Rituale Romanum* and according to the *Flagellum Daemonum* of Menghi. I must first inquire of him the signs of the maleficium, which were laid in a human skull; and moreover procure for myself the fish gall with which the young Tobias drove the demon out of his wife. The intention to trick him with this was all too obvious; he therefore replied: he had no need at all to let himself be instructed by the devil on how to drive him out of believing and God-fearing men and women. She should therefore tell him: he, being a spirit and easily traversing all seas, should search out that fish in them and bring it to the fish market in Venice for sale. I would then, if it seemed right and fitting to me, take the liver and do with it what seemed appropriate according to Catholic custom.

The cunning woman fell silent with a smile and only begged me to visit her again when she summoned me; and I left her with good admonitions to repentance and to the use of spiritual means to free herself from the power to which she belonged body and soul. Since she in the meantime had me summoned a second time to the house of a painter where she lived, the painter's maid, a pious and God-fearing woman, warned me against her: she was a sorceress who went out of the house half-naked and nude. When I therefore entered her room, I asked her: whether she had followed my admonitions? She answered: the demon had resisted and not wanted her to follow them. From which it was clear to recognize: that she had sought me out not to be freed from the demon, but to draw me into perdition. But she had deceived herself in her wicked intent. \[Page 285\]

In the lower degrees there is no vision connected with the state, where the evil then appears like a monomaniac of the corresponding organs. Sprenger recounts: in Koblenz there was one struck with this evil who, in the presence of his wife, performed the act several times and could in no way be hindered from it by her wailing and cries; but always only replied: Let us begin anew! and that until complete exhaustion. No one was seen with him, and he, when questioned about it, answered: that he likewise saw no one, but felt himself driven by an irresistible force!

A woman was under suspicion in this regard because she had harshly threatened him with abusive words, on account of an insult, that she would do him in!²) If the vision joins in the progress of the development, then goblin-like appearances first make themselves known. Two sisters, honest and chaste, had the sensation as if something fell upon them at nighttime and pressed them like a heavy burden. In the moonlight it sometimes came like a dusky shadow-image, immediately throwing itself onto the bedcover. In addition, almost daily a terrible rumbling could be heard by day as well as by night; in addition a throwing about and a clamor, during which from time to time the black shadow became visible, even in the bright midday. It continued thus for half a year, until they left the dwelling, and it had even, right before the departure, once more increased in intensity.

In such cases the haunting also becomes visible to others. Thus Heurn reports of himself: how as a small boy he had slept at the side of a very respectable, unimpeachable matron; and when he once awoke from sleep, he had seen a black figure that seemed to lay itself over her onto the bedcover. In the morning she had complained how the Alp had pressed her; but he had not been permitted to tell her anything, because the figure had threatened him if he betrayed anything.¹) From this the observation is understood, which, as Sprenger reports, was made in various places. For suspected witches were seen, lying backwards in woods and fields, and performing the act. Finally a black vapor, the length of a man, had risen from them and dissolved in the air. However, the latter had seldom occurred; a circumstance which, given the obvious possibility of manifold deceptions, recommends caution in judgment.

Nider also knew in the Basel diocese a virgin, pious and of beautiful bodily form, who was his penitent; whose cell and bed was often disturbed by such a spirit through the frightful form that he assumed and through the noise that he made. She conducted herself in all this like a pure virgin, did not even allow her foot to be seen naked once, slept always clothed, and thus the Incubus did not dare to approach her.³) This vision sometimes rises to such tangibility that, in the absence of consent, it comes to a struggle between the demon and the afflicted person. The author of the *Specimens of British Prose Writers*, Barnett, relates an example of this from his own experience. Fifty years ago there lived in a village of Somersetshire an old woman who was generally regarded as a hag. Her body was dry, bent by age she went about on crutches. Her voice was hollow, of a mysterious but hypocritical solemnity; from her eyes went forth a piercing, stinging light that struck the one who looked at her with silent terror. \[Page 286\]

Suddenly a young, healthy man of 21--22 years from the same place was haunted by the Alp; so persistently and frequently that his health was attacked by it, and within 3--4 months he was weak, pale, emaciated, bearing all the signs of a life drawing to its end. Neither he nor any of his family had any doubt about the cause; and as he was resolved, he decided to wait for the hag while awake. For a long time he did not succeed in this; finally his resolution prevailed, and he now heard at midnight a soft, cautious step on the stairs. She came to the foot of the bed, climbed onto it, and then pressed herself slowly up along his feet. He let it happen until she had come to his knees and wanted to throw herself upon him with her full weight.

Now he seized her with both hands by the hair and held her fast with convulsive strength, while at the same time calling out to his mother, who was sleeping in the nearby room, that she should bring a light. While she ran for the light, the two of them struggled with each other in fury on the floor, for so long until, with the first glimmer from the stairs, the woman tore herself from his fists with supernatural force and vanished from his eyes like a flash of lightning. His mother found him standing there, still breathless from the exertion, holding both hands full of hair. When he, says Barnelt, recounted the incident to me, I asked him curiously where he had put the hair. He replied: It was clumsy of me that I did not keep it; that would have proven the identity of the person best. But in the storm of my emotions, I let it fall to the ground; and she to whom it belonged took care that it never came before my eyes again. But on that occasion I covered it over in such a way that she has not returned since to plague me. It is strange, he added, that while I seized her and wrestled with her, although I was certain that it must be she, yet her breath and her entire being seemed like that of a blooming young girl. The man to whom this happened still lives; he told me the story more than once; I can therefore vouch for the truth of the effect, whatever one may think of the cause.

This cause one can seek first in a vision of the agent himself, without great danger of erring, which went forth as a critical one into that struggle, which yielded with the first glimmer of light and let the one who had returned to consciousness glimpse the hair in the intermediate moments, which then vanished later on. But whether this vision was a merely one-sided one, proceeding from him, or whether the woman took part in it, cannot be determined from the circumstances cited, since the womanly appearance of the woman decides nothing in that regard. \[Page 287\]

If there is consent and thus the cooperation of the will in the matter, then the evil is very hard to heal. Thomas of Brabant had a nun in the confessional who said that she had never consented; which now put him in great astonishment as to why she had let it happen nonetheless. He therefore pressed her most earnestly, and finally received the confession that she had earlier, in spirit more than in body, taken the corruption into herself. She now became earnestly repentant and confessed continually amid many tears; but there was now nothing to be devised that could free her from her incubus: neither the sign of the cross, consecrations and blessings, nor even the altar sacrament itself, which terrifies the angels, would bring her help. The evil now seemed to persist in her as a punishment and only vanished after many years and much prayer. In its course, she once complained, on the eve of Pentecost, in 's-Hertogenbosch to a pious sister, Christine, of her misfortune, which took away her courage to go to communion.

Christine now said to her: Lie down calmly and go tomorrow to the Lord's table! For I will take your evil upon myself. She now went away joyfully, slept in peace, and rose in the morning and hastened to the sacrament. But Christine did not take seriously what she had undertaken; when she had gone to bed, however, she perceived, as she was falling asleep, that it was restless in her straw bedding, as if a piglet were stirring and moving about. She therefore got up unconcerned, sought to drive the animal away with the distaff, and then lay down again. She was roused again; and since this repeated itself several times, she finally recognized the trick, devoting herself to prayer; but in doing so she was so tormented by the Evil One that she had never endured anything like it. In the morning she said to the other: I am casting your evil back from me again, for I have escaped the violence of the tempter only at the risk of my life.

The misfortune is, however, also present where it appears as illness and possession, sometimes so malignant that it brings the reluctant one to death without any consent. In the year 1645, in the Bergomese territory, there was a youth of about 25 years, so attacked by a maleficium that he could neither eat, drink, nor perform other natural functions, indeed could scarcely breathe or speak. He came to Brognoli, who blessed him; and since the demonic revealed itself through various movements and exertions, he subdued it by means of ecclesiastical regulations. He now advised the youth to go to confession and communion, and then to seek out in Brescia a famous exorcist, because he himself at that time did not yet engage in exorcism. But this youth, once he recognized himself as possessed, cast the suspicion that he had caused the same upon an old woman, whose malice toward him he well knew. \[Page 288\]

Upon returning home, he therefore said to his friends and household companions: that he had been so ill-treated by the woman; he knew that she had done the same to others as well, and he therefore wanted to report her to the Inquisition. In the meantime, he had asked the superior of the monastery in his place to take him in for that night with a friend who was devoted to him. This was granted to him, but after the fourth hour of the night, while he was fully awake in the room, with the window and door standing open, he saw that woman come into the room, climb onto the bed, and seize him by the throat with her hands, so that he was nearly strangled. He sought to hold her off from himself with all his might, reviling her with many abusive words; and so great was the force that he exerted in the process that his bedstead was broken by it; all of which his companion heard, without, however, seeing anyone.

And it did not stop at one time; after half an hour, the apparition attacked him in the other bed, where he lay with his friend, and sought to drag him out of it. But the companion held him back, embracing him, sensing a great force and much exertion against his struggling, but otherwise still seeing no one. The result was that the head and neck of the unfortunate one swelled up so much that he was entirely disfigured by it, and behaved like a madman; foaming at the mouth, gnashing his teeth, striking himself against the floor, and intent upon hurling himself down from it. In the morning, he told me everything, in the presence of many witnesses; with a rough and broken voice, he complained about the old woman, and added: "The woman torments me, and will not stop until she has killed me." And that came to pass around the ninth hour of the same day, when he died.

It was said to have been observed that that old woman had not been in the church that morning in her usual manner; she was not seen until the evening after the death of the wretch. The suspicion also seemed confirmed by the death of her niece, who died within less than a month of an unusual illness; a death that was attributed to a maleficium, because she had loved that youth passionately, and now, grieving over his death, had recounted that it had happened through a bite that the old woman had offered him. She herself betrayed herself: by afterward threatening the youth's companion, who had been an eyewitness to everything, with the same death if he did not keep silent. In any case, one sees from this incident that the evil, at the height of its development, can become life-threatening. \[Page 289\]

egarding the healing of the affliction, Brognoli without doubt introduced the best practice in his circle. As he reports, when I had returned to Bergamo in 1650, a girl had me asked through her confessor for my help, who told me: she had been visited daily for some time by an incubus, in the form of a clergyman whom she loved, and could by no means free herself from his power; although she resisted bravely 1) Alexicacon Disp. II. No. 505. p. 163. 437 and had performed great penances for this liberation. I now instructed her in all acts of faith and trust, advised her to attack the incubus with all kinds of curses, mockery, and derision, and then blessed the room and the bed. I then commanded that in this room, with a lamp burning, in another bed, two other nuns of the same congregation, venerable and mature through their age, should lie down there undaunted and with fresh courage, in such a way that, while one slept, the other knelt watching at the bed and continually observed the one plagued by the demon, whether she showed any movement in her face, around her mouth, or on the rest of her body. If she noticed anything like that, she was to immediately wake the other and command the demon in the name of the Lord to depart from there, and to pull the one plagued by him out of the bed. All together were then to kneel, pray the psalm Miserere, give themselves the discipline, and after that recite the Litany of the Holy Virgin.

Before midnight of the first watch, the incubus came and began, invisible to the one watching, to press upon the sleeping one; she in turn made some movement with her mouth and face and gave a thin, lamenting sound. The one watching woke her companion; both together now fearlessly seized the sleeping one to pull her out of the bed. But the demon held her back strongly; they pulled harder but could by no means overcome the power of the demon. Finally, the command that I had advised came to one of them; and she commanded the demon in the name of Jesus to depart from there! He now fled, and the three immediately carried out what I had assigned to them. On the following day, when I visited the convent and heard what had happened, I encouraged them to continue fighting bravely against the demon, blessed the room again, and commanded the demon never to dare approach her again. Now, although he showed himself in the following night and even ventured to enter through the door, he did not go as far as the bed.

The afflicted one saw him indeed in the form of the clergyman whom she loved; but she drove him easily to flight by invoking the name of Jesus. On my part, I repeated my advice on the following day, as before. In the third night, the apparition indeed returned, but invisibly, and only causing some slight noise in the chamber; then he completely left the afflicted one, and she was completely freed with God's help. That was without doubt the most rational manner of treatment. The nun had directed her entire intention toward the object of her love, and he appeared to her as a spiritual vampire. \[Page 290\]

In the moment of the attack, she was pressed upon; the heaviness that she felt, she also exerted outward, and the other nuns perceived this heaviness when they tried to pull the sick one out of the bed. The instructions that the exorcist had given, effective in two directions, uprooted the evil at its root; and it vanished, now gradually making a stepwise lysis. Otherwise, it is St. Cajetan whose help is frequently invoked in such cases. In life he was distinguished by the greatest purity, and he tolerated nothing that could cast even the slightest shadow upon it. Therefore he had the property, both during his lifetime and after his death---as proven by many witnesses in the process---of freeing those who had long suffered from the temptation to lust.

All who had come near him for this purpose attested: he then exhaled the most delightful scent of oranges, which, spreading far and wide, lingered for a long time. But the agrumi are held, on account of their evergreen nature, to be a symbol of virginity. Therefore he also drove out the demons that incited to such things, and his life recounts many instances thereof. Thus there was in Vicenza a respectable woman who suffered from this affliction. After a strong attack she had come near to falling; when the Saint, to whom she had commended herself from the bottom of her heart, appeared to her clothed in light, and drove out the evil spirits in the form of serpents. He then reproved the woman, who from then on suffered no such temptation again; only that later once she felt herself strongly impelled to spit upon his image, which she had hung up for her protection.

From the course of the investigation thus far, it has emerged: that the affection often takes its origin from a topical disease which has found its seat in the corresponding organs; and that it then, with or without the cooperation of the will, can rise from stage to stage up to a local possession. Once it has arrived at this point, it will by no means be necessary that it now stand still, and, confining itself within the bounds of its system, not dare to venture beyond them. But if it breaks forth over these bounds, then this can happen in a twofold manner, one of which goes more inward, the other more outward. Beside that sphere of life which most closely belongs to the drive dedicated from its course, other regions of the same life-circle border; and beyond these, up to the spirit, yet others and others still, which rise above life, and now all can be drawn into sympathy. \[Page 291\]

The evil may therefore, breaking forth from its seat, and in regressus burrowing deeper and deeper, overspread system after system; until it finally arrives at the innermost center with the spiritual powers. It will then, after it has taken possession of the whole man, imprint upon him its stamp and its color; it will fetter all the higher regions of the same to its own center; thus imprinting upon the whole its hysterical character, and thereby shaping itself in him into a practice and doctrine, into a system, indeed into a kind of philosophy and sexual mysticism. Or, since the region in which it nests is surrounded outward by similar life-spheres, which in any case already stand in a certain connection with one another through the sexual natural rapport; so the morbidly excited drive, overflowing, may also leap over from life to life in that magnetic bond, spreading itself outwardly progressive, and infecting all that is attuned to it in a certain consonance, preparing for itself a sphere of action outward. Thus there will arise a sexual disease which on the lower stages has the character of a natural evil; but on the higher appears as a social sexual possession. Let us go through both forms of the evil in sequence.

The first was found in a certain Mabertha, who in the year 1615 was taken into his house by a noble and worthy man, Suerz, at the request of his wife, a matron equally pious; since she boasted of a higher grace overflowing, and at her frequent confessions and communions of higher absolution and exhortation. This first made her host suspicious whether she might not be subject to the deception of Satan; and he insisted that she consult a pious and learned man. She replied: she had already done so many times, and received various answers; later, however, agreeing, she had, in order to withdraw herself again from this promise, spent 15 days outside the house with a friend.

Lately urged once more to approach a bishop who was present at that place on this account; she had finally yielded, had gone to the bishop, and he had directed her to a Dominican, a pious, experienced man proven in the examination of spirits. But she would not follow this instruction; the father would demand a general confession from her, and also, to test her, would withhold communion from her for a long time; moreover, an inner voice had forbidden her to go to him. In the meantime she spoke various suspicious things again. She was without all sin, even without venial; God hearkens to her in all that she desires. She sees the inner man; God unites himself bodily with her, and she often falls into ecstasy outside herself. \[Page 292\]

She said to her hosts: they could attain the same if they would only renounce the imprint of evil with which they were born, and all high-mindedness and all vanity and discord. When it was replied to her: we do all that, she rejoined: You still have a veil before your eyes, I will pray to God that he remove it from you! Suerz now pressed all the more eagerly that she go to the father, with whom he had previously spoken, and she finally consented. He received her kindly; but she was at first somewhat abashed, and said nothing. The father then said: I have heard much of your rare virtues; I hope through you to gain closer knowledge of them for my own good. But she answered: I am a sinner; and to that he: That comes surely only from your humility; I hope you will not hide your graces from me. They are rare, these graces, on account of my sinfulness, said she; and he again: Your ecstasies and illuminations, the seeing through of spirits, the foresight, all that is well known to me; God does not grant such things to wicked people.

She now came two or three times out of herself before the father; he fell upon his knees and besought God for his help, and then he said to her: O blessed one, you who are so closely united with God, and enjoy his sacred embraces! She rejoined: In that you speak truly! So he spoke back and forth, and plainly recognized that she was exceedingly vain, thought greatly of herself, and had a mighty desire for praise and honor. He said to her now: It seems to me in all this that your humility yet deserves a higher reward; and it appears fitting to me that the body also should share in the enjoyment, as is the case with bride and bridegroom. By these words she was, as it were, transported out of herself, and said: You speak the truth, my father! and no one has yet spoken so aptly therein as you. The father then asked whether God was visible to her, how often and under what form he united himself with her.

She took pleasure in these questions, and said: she did not see her God, but felt him very well; she rejoiced for full two to three hours in his embraces, and gave things to understand that cannot well be repeated. The father said in response: It sometimes dreams to me that I come into company with many people; do you also have such dreams? She answered: Indeed! and when asked: what then the people did together? she replied: They worship God, eat and drink, and are in good spirits for two to four hours. She now went away very pleased, and promised to come again soon. At home she immediately recounted: such as this she had found none before; she would never have another confessor, he had approved everything about her. Believe me, she added, he will yet learn much from me that is not in his books! for the father is actually a simple man, of no great intellectual gifts, who would easily be deceived. Thereafter she went to him more often, and soon let herself out openly against him: that she believed in another God than the God of the Christians, and in another Virgin. \[Page 293\]

She lived with him as man and wife, she had already told the landlady, and confided to the landlord: that she had already been in this state of grace for ten years. When he expressed that he too wished to enter among these elect, she made revelations to him that would have determined him to expel her from the house, had not the father begged him to have patience with her for a while longer. She now advanced further, and said to the landlord, who complained of inner unrest and uncertainty on the new path: since he had begun so happily, she would not conceal from him that above all he must renounce baptism and the Christian Trinity, pride, vanity, and discord. For among them there existed an entirely different Trinity, which the father did not yet know; and when she had declared herself for this one in her night of birth, the angels of the Lord had appeared to her.

She also confessed that she was marked; she recounted how she spent the nights sleepless, lingering five, six, seven hours in the work of love with her God. Other joys, in comparison with these, were utterly void, because the powers of God were inexhaustible, and his might penetrated to the heart. On the eve of All Saints' Day she said impatiently to her landlords: Had you done in time as I have taught you; then we would be merry together tonight, on one of the principal feasts of the year. She went to bed early in the evening, and when the niece of the house, who slept with her, said in the morning: You said that you had to go to the feast tonight, and yet you did not leave your bed; she replied: You are still too young to comprehend how that can happen.

She often recounted how things went at the banquets, and spoke of three orders: the first sought only enjoyment and union with God, of whom there were 36, mostly poor and powerless women; the second desired knowledge, insight, and understanding; the third riches, dignities, honors, goods, and these were mostly esteemed people who dreamed only of ambition. There was also a virgin there, with the Christ-child on her lap; but this would first reveal itself in its glory after the destruction of Paradise. All were now filled with horror against these abominations and blasphemies; the father too had obtained what he wanted; and when she therefore appeared before him again in the confessional, he uncovered for her the abyss of perdition in which she wandered in her delusion.

She was at first frightened, and became as if stunned; then she began to weep and to accuse herself of sorcery. But the emotion lasted only a short time, then the old hardness returned, and she departed with the words: The hour of my conversion has not yet come; but you will have no cause to complain of me. At home she said that she must have three or four days to consider. But since they no longer wished to tolerate her in the house, she left it; yet she continued to hold conversations that pointed toward conversion. However, since she feared an accusation, she resolved, on the advice of her friends, to preempt it, and now accused the father: that he had sought to seduce her into sorcery, had made her deny Christ, had allowed himself attacks on her chastity, and had given her consecrated hosts in order to commit abuses with them. Confronted with him before the convent, she at first repeated her accusation; but then she suddenly fell at his feet, confessing that she had spoken untruth, and that she was the most wretched of all creatures. \[Page 294\]

As in this case a grossly demonic nymphomania, in the one who deliberately deceived herself, was elevated to the highest union; so has this evil sometimes spread in the opposite direction, from above downward. As I, Brognoli recounts, was staying in Venice in 1664, the vicar general of a bishop from the mainland came to me to seek counsel regarding the following incident.

In a convent of nuns there was a nun who was greatly devoted to fasting and abstinence, though according to her own will. Her desire and love were moreover directed toward reading profane books that dealt with the transformations wrought by Circe and other enchantresses, or those performed by the ancient gods, by which they changed men into animals, birds, serpents, and spirits. One night, the form of an exceedingly beautiful youth came to this nun, and as she gazed at him in astonishment, he said to her:

"Do not fear, my dearest sister! Are you not that nun who loves fasting beyond all measure, and have you not devoted yourself to it with your whole heart? Know then that I am the angel called Fasting, and I come to you to thank you and to meet your love with equal love. Once I was a king's son; but in my youthful years, in which you too now still stand, I greatly loved fasting and devoted myself entirely to it; so my father, seeing this with displeasure, rebuked me harshly for it. But I, disregarding his admonitions, persisted in my will; for which reason he, full of anger, cast me out of the house. But the gods whom I revered, and who disapproved of such banishment, took me in and transformed me into an angel. As they now gave me the name Fasting, they added the privilege that I may assume the form of a youth as you see me, so that I never age. Moreover, I am endowed with such swiftness that in an inconceivably short time I move from one part of the world to another, coming and going invisibly; but to those who love me, I become visible. Since the gods have now indicated to me that you have directed your whole love toward me, I come to you now to offer my thanks, to stay with you, and to serve you in all things according to your pleasure. For this reason I have today completed the great journey; so let me sleep tonight in your little bed, if it pleases you; fear nothing in my company, for I am a friend of chastity and modesty."

The nun, now most delighted by this speech and lured by it, took him into her bed. The first night passed well, and he did not touch her. But on the second, he began, as a sign of gratitude and love, to embrace and kiss her; then he did not cease from her by day or by night, and he admonished her never to reveal the secret to her confessor or to anyone else. He served her most zealously and followed her everywhere through the convent and the garden, like a faithful servant and companion. Finally, in the year 1664, when the time of the Jubilee came, the nun was seized by remorse in her heart and disclosed everything to her confessor, who persuaded her to reveal the matter outside of confession to the vicar general of the diocese, so that he might take the appropriate measures to free her from the evil. \[Page 295\]

This vicar general now came to me to seek counsel in the matter, which I duly provided. In this remarkable psychological case, the disordered inclination toward fasting, combined with an equally extravagant one toward the fables of the ancients, merged into one; and as the nun persistently directed her attention there, the combination personified itself in that apparition which she experienced and which belonged to the demonic side of human nature. Since she found herself equipped with beauty and youth, the third sensual element soon entered in, and by an established path an incubus was now made from the abstinent king's son. The evil gains its spread in another way when it breaks through the barrier of personality and then spreads over an entire community.

By the nature of the matter, such diffusion will occur most frequently in nunneries, where the evil itself takes root most easily; and now in close living together, under entirely similar influences, the spread of what has taken hold is promoted by the most similar disposition. I could, Alvaro Pelagio recounts, in such a cloister hardly eradicate this demonic plague through many penances, good counsel, and sermons. The demons had established such great familiarity with many of the nuns that these no longer shuddered at their sight; but instead conversed with them without any fear, and allowed themselves to be assailed by them, as I learned from their judicial confession. Likewise, other theologians speak from their practical experience.

If the mischief takes on more the character of possession, then it also manifests here in a more goblin-like manner. In Hessimont near Neumagen, the nuns, as Wyer, the body physician of Cleve, recounts, were plagued for many years by a spirit that at nightfall, like in a whirlwind, burst into the dormitory; and then played so sweetly on the zither that the nuns might have been lured to dance. Then it leaped in the form of a dog into the bed of one of them, upon whom a harsh suspicion thereby fell. Even more vexatious things had occurred in the same cloister, during the lifetime of Father Paulus; which the reporter, since those affected had suppressed it, did not wish to make public. In another, not insignificant cloister of the Cologne diocese, a similar mischief held its haunt, which for eight years went about in the form of a dog, and slipped into the undergarments of the nuns, in order through the movements it caused in them to betray signs of unclean doings. It is easy to interpret such things as erotic, very palpable haunting; but harder then to comprehend the long-standing blindness of all the uninterested parties; without, which of course costs little, declaring an entire cloister a brothel.

That, moreover, where the matter appears more in the form of obsession, it took its first origin in the same way, is proved by the example of the nuns of Nazareth in Cologne, which the same witness recounts. They had been, says the physician, disturbed for many years by various devilish afflictions; when suddenly in the year 1564 a gruesome spectacle arose among them. They were thrown to the ground, entirely in the manner of the act; during the course of which they always kept their eyes closed, and only opened them afterward with great shame. A young girl of fourteen years, who had been enclosed in the cloister, had given the first occasion for it. She had often experienced these strange apparitions in her bed, and had been discovered by her giggling over them; and although she strove to ward off the haunting with a consecrated stole, it nevertheless returned every night. One had placed a sister in bed with her to help fend off the apparition; but the poor thing was miserably frightened when she heard the noise of the struggle. She was finally completely possessed and wretchedly plagued by convulsions. \[Page 296\]

When she had her seizure, it seemed as if her vision were impeded; and even when she gave the appearance of being in her right mind, she yet uttered strange and uncertain words that bordered on despair. Several soon followed her lead, and thus the pestilence gained more and more ground; especially when, in their great distress, they resorted to forbidden means. I examined these occurrences as a physician in the cloister on the 2nd of May 1565, in the presence of the noble and sensible gentlemen Constantin von Lyskerken, worthy councilor, and Master Johann Altenan, formerly dean of Cleve. Also present were: Master Johann Echst, excellent doctor of medicine; finally my son Heinrich, likewise doctor of medicine and of philosophy.

I read, on this occasion, terrible letters that the young girl had written to her lover; but none of us all doubted for even a moment that they had been written by the possessed one in her attack. It turned out that the cause of the evil had come from some dissolute young people who, after they had, during ball-playing nearby, arranged a love affair with some nuns, soon thereafter climbed over the walls to enjoy themselves with their beloved ones. The matter had been discovered, and their paths barred; but now the devil, that thousand-cunning artist, poisoned the fancy of the poor things, and conjured up before them the forms of their friends, and made them perform the whole play before the eyes of all the world. I sent letters to the convent, in which I laid the whole matter out for them, and prescribed the appropriate and Christian means by which they could bring this sad tragedy to an end.

This instructive case offers everything necessary to form a clear conception of the origin and spread of the evil. The break-in into the cloister had made the nuns involved fully acquainted with the practice of the thing. The break-in was stopped, and the encircling wall restored; the evil was now hedged about and enclosed, and, repelled from without, it gnawed inward in the lonely seclusion, and at last took firm root in the inner sphere of life. It had now escaped the cloister for the second time; for walls cannot hinder the far-reaching effect into the distance, here mediated through the unchained drive; and the binding of the outer eyes cannot prevent the opening of the inner ones.

Thus the earlier communion was reestablished only in a higher realm; what it lost in tangible reality was compensated in a correspondingly greater intensive concentration; and since the act occurred in a state of unconsciousness to itself, the guardian of shame slept, and he, otherwise driven back into the hidden, now had to step forth openly. But understanding spins itself onward in the intervals, in a kind of demonic correspondence, which likewise is carried on in the attacks of that unconsciousness, spinning the magnetic rapport across the wall, where the realm of the duties of one's station parts from that of the forbidden, thus of the evil. But if the fire has once kindled on this side of that hedge, then it kindles onward in all equally prepared and attuned ones, and the evil now spreads miasmatically.

##### ii. The Love Spell and the Tying of Love Knots

\[Page 297\]

The events in the convent of Nazareth, where the incubus assumed the form of a definite person from whom the evil had originally proceeded, lead over into a realm where the drive makes use of artificial means to bind the lust to definite persons, or to make it impossible for others to practice the same. In ordinary life, where every personality stands round and closed and bounded, and repels everything that might thrust itself upon it by force, there are no other means of the kind than those in which the instincts to mutual sympathy are aroused; where then, in the play of spiritual and bodily elective affinities, the mutual process of appropriation is accomplished. But this drive, like the life that pours itself into it, is not of simple nature; it has indeed a simple element within it, but also a manifold one, and from the relation of the two depends its tension or its slackening in degree. It also dwells, like life itself, in an organic bearer, and this too is grasped in a much-divided unity and graded stepwise; this indwelling vital force manifests itself outward, and translates its intensity into the extensive.

The entire life complex thus has an outer bodily side, in which the entire vitality collects itself toward this side; and \[it has\] toward the outside a limited, extensive sphere of action, and an inner \[side\], through which the living element in it is connected with the soul-related, derives its power from it, and exerts a determinate, inwardly psychic effect. If all this, according to the measure of ordinary life, works together in an ordered sequence; then the inner act also reflects itself, in each of the sexes, in the outer \[relations\] between them, and the process runs its course in the usual, orderly track. But this order can be disturbed in a twofold manner: either through disordered influences that disturb the equilibrium in the organically bodily, so that it becomes protrusive in more or less degree; or through such \[influences\] that throw themselves more upon the inner spiritual side, and assign to it the preponderance. Both kinds will find their consideration in turn.

The way of building, through physical \[means\], thus also through those acting directly upon the bodily, a bridge to a foreign personality, has naturally been the first one upon which men hit. There it was soon found that there are substances which in such a way act specifically stimulating upon those organs, the aphrodisiacs; and others again which possess a depressing effect, thus appearing opposed to those. In the first case the life flame burns more strongly in the organ, its inner gradated strength increases, and its sphere of action expands. But the direction of the thus strengthened drive goes in general; there is no means to give it a determinate direction toward a particular person, if this one does not throw itself in its way.

In the other case the life breaking forth toward this side is held down, and its manifestations are dammed up, again against all and every one; so that thus the intended personality also finds itself only incidentally hit. Since now on the one hand it is aimed at the gaining, on the other hand at the denial of the coarser pleasure; since through the immoderate heightening of the drive that which is irresistible, which lies in the matter itself, is heightened almost to irresistibility, and the satisfaction in the positive case can only take place at the cost of life, but the paralysis in the other does not redound to its benefit; so the inevitable consequences of the use of these means are exhaustion, madness, and the drying up of all life sources. \[Page 298\]

The physicians have made manifold experiences concerning these consequences, and Heer has one such, which we will here only mention in passing. To a fourteen-year-old youth, exhausted and thirsting through walking, a girl known to him had put such a philtrum into the beer; as, she said, above all suitable to lift the fatigue. The youth had drunk with greed, thereupon slept deeply the whole night; but found himself in the morning assailed by great weariness, so that he could scarcely drag himself home. A hemorrhage, through mouth and anus and urine, in superabundant quantity, occurred; ligatures were not able to staunch it. Only sympathetic means could staunch the blood flow, which however returned upon their abandonment; so that the tears which he wept were blood, and blood secreted itself in the ears. The former means indeed stilled the blood, but the young man became more and more enfeebled; so that at last he was held for dead, and as a corpse, sewn into a cloth, laid aside.

He came to himself, however, fell into excessive sweat, and finally a thumb-thick crust formed over his entire body, which compelled him to stand for six days and nights on a pole until the rash had dried up, and life, at such a price, had expelled the intruded harmfulness once more.

Kircher tells: A youth noticed that, whenever he visited a spot in his garden, distinguished equally by its greenery as by the freshness of its shade, he was each time moved by a violent impulse to lust; so that it seemed as if he had been seized by satyriasis.
