She said: she did not consider herself guilty of what they demanded of her; Maria replied, so it had been with her too, only when she had affirmed the questions had her memory returned. Simona answered: she would not say "yes" until she had true knowledge of what she was to affirm; all their speeches now appeared to her like dreams. Thereupon Maria: so it had often happened to her too; but the father had then asked her: whether her marks were likewise illusions? Maria tried many more means on her, confessing herself as the worst sinner; they brought Simona into a church and exorcised her at midnight, the hour of the Sabbath; the spirits joined in speaking, and swore vehemently; Simona remained unmoved.

On the following day Maria reported: the hour of the Sabbath had been shifted to three o'clock in the morning; both of them had been there, and Simona had brought three marks. They were found, exactly as she described, on the left arm. One of the possessed women now swore a solemn oath: that she was a sorceress, and now the same three questions were put to her as to Gaufridy. She affirmed all of them, yet maintained: the possessed one did not speak the truth regarding her, and finally said: she would no longer answer the spirits henceforth; when they had talked themselves out, they would fall silent of their own accord.

The demons now press upon the silent one, presenting to her: what God has done for her, how all the saints of heaven have interceded for her; how her hardness of heart, in thrusting away all this grace from herself, has infinitely heaped up the measure of her sins, and will finally, at the approaching downfall of the world, make her a child of perdition. This at last seemed to break her stubborn spirit, and she began to weep. All those present urged her on, she wept more violently; the Dominican placed the Sacrament upon her head, and still weeping she cried out: I will say no more, I say no more no!

The demon drew nearer to her and said: The eternal Father receives you, the Son pleads for you that he may receive you, all the saints unite their supplications. She, entirely dissolved in lamentations, said: I am a sorceress, truly I am such a one. The demon spoke through the mouth of the Perona: By this God who created the angels and cast us out, do you deny that I am Beelzebub, the prince of the demons, who has so often marked you? She replied: I know you, I say it with displeasure, God's power compels me to it. Now follow in sequence the confessions, during which the demons of the possessed assist her helpfully and refresh her memory; yet on the second day already, when asked if she persisted, she said: I dare not contradict, but if I agree, then everything seems to me like a dream; and it comes to me as if I were speaking lies. \[Page 396\]

In between, she herself gave signs on her body, confirmed the statements of the others regarding the manner of the Sabbath, regarding the birth of the Antichrist; she shared sermons that Beelzebub had delivered there; she censured the doctrines of Binsfeld with the saintly condemnations, and corrected the statements of this saint, whereby again the demons helped, and Simona and Maria sang Latin hymns of praise to the honor of God. Soon, however, Simona recanted everything that she had stated and confessed, point by point.

If one follows the course of all these strange events, one believes oneself transported into that Sibyl's cave: the Dominican carries the torch ahead, strangely the paths intertwine, everything seems fashioned below as it is fashioned above on the earth, the darkness lacks only the sun; column positions, bridges, towers, castles, human figures and animal shapes and palm canopies, all have formed themselves from the stalactite; all truth looks like lie, all lie like truth, for the inner confirming soul is not present. The women who move on this stage, if one does not, in the previously favored manner, declare them the dregs of worthlessness, and those who had dealings with them all together as selected fools, were truly possessed.

As regards Magdalena Palud first of all, the course of the story from January 11 onward, when the Parliament of Aix took up the matter, proved this her possession. The President du Bair, the councilors Thoron and Segniran, Calas and Thomassin the procurator, the most skilled jurists of their time, the physicians Fontaine, Merindol, Grassi, the anatomists and surgeons Bon-Temps and Pronet, likewise university professors, clerics in great number, belonging to various orders, inclined to differing opinions in this matter, had examined her condition, and had all at last agreed: that the phenomena observed in her went beyond the powers of nature.

Her own peculiarity was especially the remarkable contrast in her brain, that in her paroxysms, in the anterior half of the same, under the influence of Beelzebub---probably owing to an incomplete closure of the skull sutures---one felt the great brain moving convulsively; a movement that immediately stilled itself as the exorcists commanded her demon to depart for the duration of a Miserere; while a similar movement, attaching itself to Leviathan, in like manner, at her command, excited the little brain and stilled it again.

Now Luise, as has been said, a quiet, pious, simple and ignorant girl, who had formerly been Huguenot; thus at least in her youth she had not imbibed the prejudices that are usually attributed to Catholics, had fallen into the magical circle of these possessed ones, and thereby become possessed in a lesser degree than she. Her spirit, which itself, in the manner of demons by arbitrarily assuming names, called itself Verrin, was thus weaker than the demon of Magdalena, Beelzebub; he, the one bound by him, thus subordinate in rank to the binder. But this difference could balance itself out through the difference that the stronger one, by the fault of the possessed, had entered into her; whereas the weaker one had been sent to the innocent other. \[Page 397\]

This one could thus turn to God, that He might arm him with strength for the battle against the overpowering one. In her lucid intervals, the thought may well have come to her more frequently: by this path to win the friend back to God, so that then, as demon armed itself against demon, her own chains might also be broken. But as what occurs in ecstasy returns to memory in the waking state; so too does that which is earnestly and deeply pondered in the waking world reach into the ecstatic state, and what is conceived there fulfills itself within it. Her demon, bound by exorcism, thus rose up against the demon of Magdalena, just as her will stood in opposition to that of the other. That the conduct of this struggle was guided not by her will in its freedom, but rather by the demonic necessity dwelling within her, of this she was well aware; and the state of her conscience, amid all these events, had just given voice through her mouth to the power that compelled her in the demonic ecstasy, as she said: How could you priests administer the Communion to this sevenfold perjurer, were she not possessed? She would truly be worthy to suffer a sevenfold death by fire.

Thus it developed, since her exorcist had entered into it, that the matter proceeded in the manner demonstrated to its end. In the events in Flanders, it was the same case, only reversed in form. That Maria de Sains was in boldness and sinful audacity of thought, of Titanic kind and root; quite worthy to represent the great woman of the Simonians of her time. Through strange dispensation she had fallen into that newly founded convent, and soon drew it into the whirlpools of her immeasurably turbulent nature. At first she had tried holiness; but since this role suited her being poorly, turning to the demonic she devoted herself to it, and soon her fellow sisters had to feel her power. All had fallen into the fetters of her superior demonic spirit; all had succumbed to obsession, only varying gradually according to the personalities; whereby that Simona Dourlet, as it seems, had stood particularly close to her.

The events at St. Baume, the reports of the Prince of the Sabbath and the birth of the Antichrist, occupied all minds at that time; and since she had mastered all fantasies, they also became vocal in the convent where the Sabbath raged. The terrors that threatened in the wake of these imaginings may well not have failed to have their effect even on the otherwise fearless one; the involuntary, suddenly rising impulses that are frequent in this state did their part; and she had confessed herself as the originator of the evils that oppressed the convent; without, in one-and-a-half years of imprisonment, allowing any further confession to be extorted or dissuaded from her otherwise.

Only after the passage of this time had the same spark that had been kindled in the Louise also excited the energumens, especially the Imberta Perona; and when the demon betrayed signs from her that the demonic state had produced in her; then her defiance was broken, the exorcism over her had taken effect, and she had made all confessions, and now helped herself again to induce others to the same. The Simona Dourlet offered herself to her at the right moment, and a struggle began between the two women as to which was the stronger, and which could master and bind the other. One was well practiced in defense, but the other in attack yet more energetic and quick in strength. \[Page 398\]

Thus the alternating struggle lasted long; finally the attacker drew the other into her magical circle; she awakened her sleeping conscience, stirred her slumbering memory, and effected through the superiority of the rapports emanating from her: that what she had hitherto persuaded herself to regard as dreams and illusions possessed reality; so that she, who had earlier denied everything, now bound to the train of ideas of the victor, confirmed everything that the latter had previously communicated about it; however, as always in such cases, with relapses into the old belief.

The first ground of this entire chain of strange occurrences lay in the opinion of the exorcist Dompt: that it was feasible to set the devil in the possessed upon the lampstand, and to make him a witness of the truth in court and everywhere. He knew very well that the Lord had said of him: he was a murderer from the beginning, and has not stood in the truth, because there is no truth in him; when he speaks a lie, then he speaks from his own, because he is a liar and the father of lies. But he judged: if therefore there is no truth in him, then it must be placed into him. But that can only happen through the almighty God, and through the mediation of the Church, which has the power to command the demons. Thus the Church adjures the demon in his name, through the mouth of the possessed, to speak the truth; and he himself confirms the stated truth with an oath valid in all forms, and the intended purpose is achieved.

He forgot, however, first of all: that the Lord Himself, who was at that time still at once the Church, did not accept the testimony of the possessed ones of Gerasa, who greeted Him as the Son of the most high God; that He by no means sent them forth, as His prophets from the denying side, into all the world to spread abroad this their testimony; but that He banned this whole cloud in the demonic legion into the herd, where then the waves of the sea swallowed up their testimony. When the Godhead, fully well informed about their circumstances, placed all created spirits in the position to prove their freedom, it granted them free choice between their Creator and themselves. Of them, one part chose Him, and these thereby won for their will the full freedom of the Good.

Another part chose itself, and as their sin set itself separating between them and God, and they, losing their freedom, fell into the bondage of Evil, of which they had been the originators, and Satan was rejected. Satan is therefore a murderer from the beginning, and indeed he began with suicide, in that he cast himself out of the life of freedom into that eternal death which is precisely rejection. For since he was not able to annihilate the being created for him, all the power implanted in this being remained to him also, and he turned it denyingly against his Originator; but since the denial of the God-willed is the ground of the lie, the lie must also recognize him as its father; and he lies by virtue of his essence, driven to it by an inner necessity. \[Page 399\]

God respects this necessity, which attaches itself to his will corrupted in the root, and guides his arbitrariness; as the Godhead did not compel him to the first choice, so it does not compel him either in the consequences that have arisen from the choice made; only in his power does he find himself limited, and he must, against his will, cooperate in the execution of the will of Providence. It does not compel him, therefore, to speak the truth against his nature; and if upon that limitation the power of exorcism rests, then no such one will be able to compel the lie to speak the truth. No oath will be able to prove the spoken word as such either; for as the speaker has only expressed herself in the words, so she also swears only by herself, and by her personality, which has no faith. One might say: that, since the oath happens through the mouth of the possessed creature, God could not allow that this one be compelled to a false oath. But she has not in truth sworn falsely; for as the spirit spoke out of her, so has he also given the oath out of her; she herself, however, has the complete conviction of the necessity that has seized her, and bound her as an instrument. The exorcist who thus builds further upon the ground of such an exorcism and oath has himself mounted the hobby-horse of dominion, and will be carried away by it over heights and abysses. The ecstatic one finds herself demonized in her paroxysm, in all her drives and inclinations; and to the speeches that she takes from the store of the possessing spirit, she may well add others from her own, without being fully mistress of herself therein. One already knows how close, in the somnambulistic states, especially those of the dark kind, the lie stands to the truth. We have earlier explained how manifoldly errors even arise among the higher ecclesiastical ecstatics, who were held in the strict discipline of their confessors, and how wild waters from near-lying, false sources stream even to the clarified will, and how, especially in the lower degrees, the incautious guide can become a plaything of wild fantasies, especially among women. This possibility of deception increases, among the demonically ecstatic ones, to the infinite.

They stand to their exorcists in the same relation as those to their leaders; the one side is placed under the power of obedience, the other side is in servitude obedient to their commanders. Both are clairvoyant, and read the commander's thoughts already in their workshop; but whereas there error and mistake condition the evasion, here it is the lie that formally rebels in a slavish manner. Thus in the present case the exorcists, with the fable-work about the Antichrist, have been formally deceived. As, as the founder of the church, a concrete divine-human personality, in the Incarnation, stands at the beginning of history: so at the end of it a similarly concrete, demonically human one, with a kind of false Incarnation, the aping of the Antichrist, who there seeks to destroy the work of the First.

As now Christ, in the church, as in his body spreading himself out, passes through all history, and at the end appears again victoriously in concrete personality; so too the Antichrist has already been at the beginning, is in everything that happens throughout the whole history as Antichristian, in doctrine and statute and outward expression of life, born anew again and again; tempts and seduces, fights and resists, flourishes and succumbs, until he at the end of the days gathers himself together into concreteness for the last decisive battle. \[Page 400\]

This historical Antichrist of their time the women have seen in their ecstasy; that was the truth in their visions. But whereas they have performed the opposite of the work of our pantheists---who seek to dissipate the concrete Christ into the generally historical---, and on their side have brought the general Antichrist into a personal concreteness; and have now attached this one to themselves, to their Sabbaths, and their mystical births from the Incubus, just as those philosophers to their schools and coteries, they have spun out lies for that fable-work which sets us in wonder at their statements. Let us look at it more closely, then we find how it has proceeded from the study of the Apocalypse, supplemented by the Gospels.

The former had given the fundamental type of the figure of the Antichrist, and since he was now to be in everything the counterpart of Christ; so the others had to enclose the form within themselves, in order to grasp him and his surroundings in definite features. That was now, in its plastic execution, the work of the ecstatics; but what lies at the basis of this, the plan and outline, came to them from elsewhere. It was probably the Dominican who, already initiated into the whole circle of ideas of St. Baume, had made those apocalyptic and evangelical studies. He now stood in the midst of all these possessed ones; the exorcism had placed him in the closest spiritual intercourse with them; so that they around him mirrored his whole circle of ideas; not merely themselves unmoved, and only reflecting how they had taken it in, but livingly fructified by him, and in the rest incorporated, bearing it forth again.

What thus in him existed merely subjectively as a power of thought, that objectified itself in them; it was as it were clothed with flesh and bone, and now tangibly born out to him by the women. All this happened without conscious intervention on his side and on their side, in a night-shrouded region, unconscious to the waking world. Of coarse deception there could be no question, a truth lay also in the whole; but the deception was hard to detect and separate, because in the pre-established harmony of both circles every thought found its confirmation in every fact, and in the unconsciousness of the whole state every external means of examination failed in its service.

It was just as it was with the scientific systems of our days; the method of progress, mathematical or logical, is impeccable, the thoughts are linked together in the best possible way; every step forward is most perfectly justified by the preceding ones, and yet all the results are false, because the assumptions had been false; and one had now, in a perfectly school-like manner, calculated out a false final result. Just as the Jews, deceiving themselves in many ways and often accustomed to believe that their Messiah-idea had become concrete in this or that individual; so had one built up the whole labyrinth on the false assumption that the Anti-Messiah-idea must now reach concretion. The error was thus also the whole fruit that one had gained; the proclaimed Antichrist failed to appear, although he raged through the history of the entire era; and it showed itself once more that one had completely misunderstood the whole symbolism of these conditions, interpreting them in a grossly human manner. Fortunately, as far as one can see, none of those involved had to atone for the hermeneutic error with their lives. \[Page 401\]

More closely or more distantly connected with these events was everything that occurred around that time relating to such matters; even 25 years later, in the history of Louviers, the spirits knew to speak of it. When Mathurin Picard there, in the year 1642, had died a shameful death, he had, after appointing a successor of the same stamp, had himself buried in the church at the grating of the nuns' choir. Now nearly all the nuns of the community became possessed; so that they, from that point onward and into the fourth year, fell into a state of rage and demonic madness that completely robbed them of their freedom and the use of reason. Scarcely had the body been laid in its place when all of them, without exception, fell into rage, burst into terrible screams, and under frightful contortions railed against the deceased in the most shameful and filthy words, and against religion and the sacraments in every sort of blasphemy.

The supplemental confessor of the convent had already earlier, 613 still during Picard's lifetime, made a report to François Bertier, Bishop of Evreux, a well-meaning and pious man; and this one had personally betaken himself to the convent, heard the nuns' general confession two to four times, and therein learned a part of the truth. Reasonable provisions that he had taken for their protection had been the consequence of this visit; but Picard had known how to turn the repentant ones away again, and they had made a new donation to him. Now, after the death, a report was made once more, and he came a second time to gain insight into the matter. He found everything in the greatest uproar, the whole convent filled with screams, horror, and despair. He had exorcism applied, and all screamed that they saw Picard's cadaver in the chapel, borne by four demons, and now bore witness to his sorcery, to his appearance at the Sabbath; his body was the true bewitchment of the convent, and no healing was to be thought of until it had been removed. Other inquiries and the testimony of la Bavent seemed to confirm the same. One therefore resolved on the removal of the corpse from the church; it was, after prior excommunication, dug up at night, and, to conceal the matter for the sake of the order's honor, carried to the cave of Crosnier and there thrown into a tower-deep abyss. Meanwhile the spirits of the possessed screamed: how clever one thinks oneself, yet the matter would still come to the light of day; for God's decree lets itself not be determined by the blindness of men.

Two months the matter remained hidden; now a dark rumor circulated that something was amiss in the cave of Crosniersen, children had noticed something unusual in the abyss; finally they had descended, and had found and recognized Picard. The relatives of the man had now taken the matter in hand, and the courts had involved themselves in it. The spirits had declared themselves just as unanimously against Bavent as they had against Picard: she had first brought the devil into the house; if the malefactress were driven out, then first could healing come to the house. All said the most horrible things about her; 56 points, many of which she, however, staunchly denies in her memoirs, and also revokes several of her own earlier statements. The end was that the bishop, after she had previously been examined for stigmatization, ordered her to be unveiled; she was to spend her lifetime in prison, and to fast three times in every week on water and bread. The judgment was carried out, and she was locked in an underground prison. \[Page 402\]

She does not complain against the injustice of the judgment, although it was passed without really hearing her; but she does complain against the harshness, that in prison every other confessor than the bishop's penitentiary was denied her; against whom she had an invincible aversion. A dark despair therefore soon took hold of her, in her five years' long solitude. With a rusty knife that she had found there, she gave herself stabs in the arm, to hit the veins; then sought to cut her throat, and finally thrust it into her belly up to the handle, keeping it in the wound for four hours, and turning it from time to time. All else aside, she suffered from the wounds like from a cancerous ulcer that had attached itself to her breast. Three days later she ground glass, and took it spoonful by spoonful, abstaining from every other nourishment; she vomited much blood, fell often into fainting fits, but likewise survived the desperate attempt.

Five times in succession she persisted in this her desperation, each time seven days long, without taking any nourishment into herself; she was thereby examined four times with great pains by doctors and surgeons; she had fits of the most violent rage against the Lord, on account of her sufferings; called upon the demons for revenge, but had thereby, in her very greatest anger, the comforting appearance of an angel; then fell back again into her despair, ate spiders, and held back her menstruation; was already about to take arsenic, which she had managed to procure for herself, when another appearance hindered her; and in between had to struggle with the importunities of the crude folk who guarded her. Thus did her earlier godlessness avenge itself upon her.

The relatives of the exhumed Picard had meanwhile become complainants before the government; the council of state had referred the investigation of the whole matter to the Parliament of Rouen. This had inquired into the life and conduct of the nuns, heard the witnesses, and recognized the guilt of some and the innocence of the others. At the end of August 1646 the judgment was passed, whereby Picard, Boulé and Bavent, convicted of sorcery, sacrilege, and other abominable crimes, were declared guilty of death. Picard was to be dragged on a hurdle and burned, Boulé hanged and burned; Bavent was to be kept in custody until the decision of the investigation pending against Louise, a co-defendant. The first judgments were carried out, and the records now thrown into the flames along with them; but no further judgment on Bavent is to be found. The exorcisms had likewise been continued until the beginning of 1646, and had finally achieved the liberation. The bishop died from the exertion and vexation.

Almost simultaneously with this story in Normandy, another highly remarkable event occurred in Loudun, a small town that separates the provinces of Touraine, Poitou, and Anjou from one another without ever having belonged to any of them. There, Urbain Grandier was the first pastor of the town at St. Peter's, and moreover capitular at the foundation of the Holy Cross. He was one of those characters who, wherever they may be found, appear destined by nature to rule; for he combined great talent with an equal energy of will, and a rich vein of life dwelt in him within a tall stature. He was an outstanding preacher, knew how to express himself with grace and ease in social intercourse; a firm and penetrating spirit made itself known in all his utterances; thus he soon became a phenomenon in the little town. But he lacked the religious and ethical foundation upon which these gifts could develop. \[Page 403\]

A great inclination toward lust had been given to him as an additional trait, and he soon allowed himself to be mastered by it. Sixty unimpeachable witnesses testified in his later trial to all the adulteries, incests, sacrileges, and other godless acts that he committed in his church, in the vicinity of the Sacrament, without distinction of time of day, at every hour and in every moment. In order to gloss over this licentiousness before his conscience, he wrote a treatise against celibacy, which was found among his papers along with various obscene poems under investigation. The old men whose daughters, and the men whose wives he dishonored, became furious against him; and he now turned the entire cutting sharpness of his character against them, instead of doing anything conciliatory.

The complaint of the injured parties was lodged with his bishop in Poitiers; he was arrested in connection with it, and by the judgment of the officialate on the third of January 1630 was interdicted for five years in the diocese, and forever in Loudun. He appealed to the archbishop of Bordeaux, who acquitted him; however, with the advice to exchange his benefices. But he instead made his entry into Loudun with a laurel branch in his hands; he pressed his hard-won right to the utmost point, held the cold point of mockery toward his enemies everywhere, and involved them one after another in quarrels and lawsuits of every kind. Thus he became the tyrant of the place, an object of fear and terror to the weak and of irreconcilable hatred to the strong.

While the Catholics were thus averse to him in this way, and many did not attend his church, the Huguenots had taken his side. Loudun had been their stronghold in the earlier wars, and many of the Calvinists who lived there at the time judged not without reason that Grandier belonged in his innermost conviction to their sect, and that only the inevitable threatening loss of his benefices had held him back from openly joining them.

They therefore took his side without hesitation; it is true that in times when their confession lay wholly prostrate and Richelieu ruled with absolute power, these were dangerous allies. Thus stood things around him in the ordinary course of the world; but they had yet another side. Every person has a spiritual sphere of influence about himself, which, however, only extends in the inner circles, but in ordinary life, incorporated into the outer sphere of existence and enveloped by it, makes itself felt only through it and within it.

But if that interpenetration is partially suspended; if, without their being wholly separated from one another, a division nonetheless arises, and an overstepping of the inner over the outer occurs, whether in giving or receiving; then the intensive effects also disentangle themselves from the extensive ones, and spiritual rapports develop from the earlier physical sympathies and antipathies. Grandier, relying on his personal superiority, secured against the aversion of his fellow believers by the affections of their opponents, outwardly, as it seemed, unassailable, should yet not escape the fate of all pride, and Nemesis lay in wait for him on these night-shrouded paths. A convent of the then still new order of Ursulines had been established in Loudun since 1626. \[Page 404\]

Fourteen girls, all from good families, noble and non-noble, altogether of blameless life, had come together in one house; and, under the direction of a director, eked out, in their poverty, the continuance of their community through a pension school which they had founded. Things had proceeded in the usual tracks in this nascent convent, when the director died; Grandier, proposed as his successor, was rejected by the superior, and in his place Mignon, one of his adversaries, was chosen by the convent. The convent had been somewhat earlier disturbed by nocturnal apparitions, as the opponents said, or by the caprice of some nuns. Now disquieting signs began to appear, which were at first taken for symptoms of female illness and quietly sought to be dispelled.

The signs multiplied and became ever more unequivocal; the physicians had to be dismissed, and exorcists called in for aid. Dark rumors first flew through the town; soon the whole truth became known: fourteen nuns showed themselves possessed in the convent; the people took their children back, and while want and distress now entered among the nuns, they were regarded by some as those who had forsaken God, by others as fools and hysterical visionaries. The seal with which the nocturnal world is closed had been broken open for them; the first thing they perceived there was the magnet toward which the little town had long been accustomed to turn in hatred and love.

Their negatively demonic state sought about for an object on which it could complete itself; and found it in Grandier, brought into close rapport with them by his scoundrelly nature, pride, and hypocrisy. The relations of the sexes, which by day had friendly or hostile brought the female town into connection with him, had also here, conducting through the night, exerted their influence. For months the nuns saw him every night at their bedside, ceaselessly inciting them to evil; their statements gained credence when it was seen how, despite their bitter poverty, they remained blameless and fulfilled all the duties of their station with zeal and exactitude. In the exorcism the spirits named him unanimously as the one who had bound them in obsession. Into the mass of passions that had accumulated in the town, the igniting spark had now been cast. From the hearts the conflagration spread swiftly to the heads; everyone took sides for or against; Grandier and his closer adherents naturally did not remain idle, and great ferment began to stir in the little town.

When the royal councilor Laubardemont arrived in Loudun to carry out the decree that ordered the demolition of all fortresses in the interior at the castle there, he found the entire city in the most violent agitation, which his mission only further increased. 619\
Upon his return, he made his report on this to King Louis XIII, and the latter instructed him, in late November 1633, to select thirteen of the most honest and skilled judges from the jurisdictions in the surrounding area, and with them to decide the matter without appeal. It happened as the king had commanded, and Grandier was provisionally arrested. In such exceptional courts, politics is to sit in judgment alongside the law. But that is an evil alliance, where one of the allies indeed represents the accused, while the other, speaking in the name of the whole, places the reason of state into the scales. \[Page 405\]

In times when this politics has not yet fully emancipated itself from conscience and morality, it will not demand of the judges that they declare the innocent guilty against their conviction; but it will nonetheless always, in doubtful cases where the verdict wavers, not hesitate to intervene subsidiarly and tip the scales. Grandier's case had become a party matter, and this had precisely provided the occasion to allow that alliance to enter the court as a counterforce. The more his party reacted, the more it had to increase the power of the political element. The conscience of the judges found its reassurance in the fact that, as soon became evident, Grandier's case had from the outset been ethically utterly lost; and the trial, conducted in the ordinary civil forms, had to lead to his ruin.

Thus the investigation into sorcery soon took a ominous turn for him, and it could be foreseen that it must lead to an evil outcome. However much the defeated party reviled the verdict, it did not dare to cast suspicion on the integrity of the thirteen judges; it reproached them only with all too great credulity: a reproach that, in a certain sense, but different from how it was meant here, was not entirely unfounded.

The commissioner Laubardemont began by taking the depositions of the witnesses; among them also those who had previously been frightened away from their testimony. The possessed were separated in houses, and then interrogated in their calm periods; the speeches that they delivered during their paroxysms, which the exorcism, performed each time by the Bishop of Poitiers, brought about, were to count only as indications for the further investigation. Their entire lives were subjected to the sharpest scrutiny; never did the statements of 20 individuals conflict on a point.

Three and a half months of continued exorcism had demonstrated with evidence that they were truly in a state of obsession, for they had shown all the signs that the Church requires to determine the judgment on it. With regard to the understanding of languages, M. de Launoy de Razilly, who had long resided in America, gave testimony that he had spoken with the possessed in the language of some native tribes of that country; that they had answered him quite appropriately, and had also revealed to him several things that had occurred there. Some noblemen from Normandy testified that they had put questions to Sister Claire of Sazilly in Turkish, Spanish, and Italian, and that she had answered them satisfactorily. M. de Nismes, Doctor of the Sorbonne, one of the almoners of the Cardinal of Lyon, had posed his questions in German and Greek; Father Vignier, Superior of the Oratorians, likewise, for an entire afternoon, in the latter language: both had been completely satisfied. \[Page 406\]

The Bishop of Nîmes had commanded Sister Clara in Greek: to lift her veil and kiss the grating; she had obeyed, and done much else besides, so that he said: one must be a fool or an atheist to not believe in her possession. The doctors likewise questioned her about Greek expressions of their science known only to the initiated, and received clear answers. In the same way, the possessed obeyed commands that were given to them only inwardly. The Prior of Maillezais conducted such a test; he whispered in the ear of Canon Fernaison how he wished the possessed one, in the missal that lay at the grating, to place her finger on the beginning of the Mass of the Blessed Virgin, and the words: Salva, sancta parens lege. The exorcist, Mr. von Morans, who had heard nothing of these words, now commanded her to follow the intention of the Prior. She fell into strong convulsions, spoke blasphemies, named the Prior, whom she did not know, by name, and after repeated commands, took hold of the missal, saying: I will pray, and now averting her eyes, placed her finger on the large S at the entrance of this Mass.

A verbal record was taken of this event. As Mr. von Millières knelt praying during the exorcism of Sister Clara, she asked him: whether he was praying a De Profundis for his wife? which was indeed the case. Sister Louise of Nogaret testified to the Marquis de la Mothe: that she had revealed to him the state of his conscience. Father Surin, whose truthfulness even the most vehement opponents never dared to question, testifies: how Johanna, the superior, revealed to him many hundreds of times the most secret things, and how a priest of his order directed an inner command to the demon, then revoked it inwardly with a second, and so on up to the seventh, and then he called out: Obediat ad mentem. The possessed repeated the first command and then said: but the Lord does not wish it, and so she continued with all six one after another; whereupon at the seventh she finally said: so let us then carry this out, wherein he had remained standing! In the same way, they came to the commands of the exorcists from distant places.

They astonished these by the quick answers they gave to the most difficult theological questions on grace, the vision of God, the angels, and the Incarnation, and indeed in the expressions of the School. They looked into the distance as they looked into the inner depths of souls: and while the superior Johanna, according to his testimony, revealed to Father Surin the secrets also of those whose guidance he had undertaken at his earlier residence in Marennes in Saintonge; the parliamentary councillor of Brittany, Kerioles, likewise made an experience of this gift that was decisive for his life. This man was sunk in all vices, without any religion or any faith; a raging atheist and of such rabid defiance that, when a thunderstorm rose in the sky, he directed the muzzle of his pistols against it, and once when the lightning struck his room, he, surrounded by fire and flames, while all his people cried for mercy, alone poured himself out in mockery and scorn. \[Page 407\]

All his thinking was forever directed only toward doing evil, and even more evil than all others; and he had once resolved to become a Mohammedan among the Turks, only so that he might have the opportunity to inflict all conceivable harm on the Christians. As all his thinking and striving were directed only toward atrocities and vices, so he also came to Loudun for such a goal and end; in short, one might well, in Surin's words, scarcely have seen a more despairing and vice-ridden man than this one. Immediately upon his arrival, he poured out his mockery over the nuns, and declared them all and sundry to be foolish. But God knows how to lead things to His end, and saved this bondsman of Satan through him himself.

Right at the first exorcism, where he was present, the possessed revealed to him his most secret affairs, which no one could know except himself; so that he was most profoundly shaken. He returned a second time, and was now so moved and turned within himself that he performed terrible penance, and from then on led a holy life. The spirits confessed that it was the holy Virgin who had snatched him from their hands. He sold his position, later became a priest, and converted his house into a hospital. More than fifty doctors, one after another, declared in authentic verbal processes that what the possessed performed physically surpassed all the powers of nature.

At the command of the exorcists they went immediately, without their pulse changing in the slightest, into the most violent convulsions; the face became frightful to behold; the tongue protruded black, thick, hard, and covered with pustules from the mouth, without this hindering them in the least from speaking clearly. They supported themselves solely on their stomachs, placed the palms of their hands on the soles of their feet with their arms twisted or threw their heads back to their heels, and in this way ran quickly and much about. They remained awake continuously, and fasted sometimes uninterruptedly for 5--6 days; without this being detrimental to their health, but rather seeming only to strengthen that of the weaker ones.

They often fell suddenly asleep; in the case of Francisca Filastreau one then heard, with her mouth tightly closed, many voices quarreling about which of them should speak. One saw several times the Elisabeth Blanchard, in her convulsions, holding herself with her feet upward and her head downward on a chair or window without support. The superior Johanna, according to a verbal process, once hovered two feet above the ground. Lying full length, they were lifted up like statues without the slightest movement on their part. Many became flexible like a lead strip, so that one could bend them into any form, which they then retained. Others stretched their legs so far apart to left and right that their perineum touched the ground: the body held straight upright, the hands folded. In the case of the superior, the distance of one foot from the other in this position was seven feet, although she was only four feet tall.

On May 9, 1635, Monsieur, the brother of the king, came to Loudun to witness the events that were causing such a sensation throughout all of France. On the following day he went to the church of St. Ursula, where Elisabeth Blanchard was to receive communion. She was possessed by six spirits, one of which, called Ashtaroth, soon stirred, and now, conjured by the exorcist, soon made her fall into convulsions: so that she, twitching and rolling about, crawled to the feet of the priest, who placed the holy Sacrament on her lips, at the same time commanding the demon: to undertake nothing irreverent against it, or even to moisten the host in any way. \[Page 408\]

The possessed woman was immediately thrown to the ground, bent backward three times so that she touched the ground with her feet and the tip of her nose; whereby it appeared as if she wanted to rub the host on the earth, as she came so close to it that only the thickness of the paper separated them.

When the exorcist hindered the execution through his repeated prohibition, the demon raised the girl again and blew upon the host that was visible on his lips; it moved like a tree leaf in the breeze, oscillating between the lips. When the exorcist now adjured Beelzebub to ascend into her face, the throat swelled extraordinarily, became hard, and one felt a throbbing in it. Thus one of her spirits after the other was adjured to make itself visible, and each obeyed, distorting the face in a manner peculiar to it into something gruesome; whereby Astaroth, under the left armpit, produced a large swelling with violent throbbing, to the astonishment of the prince's body physician.

He then ascended, driven from there by the exorcist, into her face, and caused the host to fall onto the paten; where it was found, upon close examination by the exorcist's finger, entirely dry. The lips of the possessed were also in truth so parched that they peeled off, and the skin appeared entirely white. The exorcist now wiped her teeth with a cloth and brought the host to one of the upper row, where it, touching the jaw with only a part of its circumference, again hung there for a long time; despite the most violent shakings of the entire body, the strangest contortions of the mouth, and a violent blowing that the spirit produced. She was now commanded to swallow the forms, which happened immediately.

The exorcist now asked the body physician himself to examine the girl's mouth, to see whether the host was still present. He did so, by running his fingers along the gum to the throat, and thus convinced himself that nothing was present in the mouth. The girl was now allowed to drink water, and her mouth was examined again afterward. Upon the command that the exorcist now directed at Astaroth---to bring back the host---one saw it immediately thereafter on the tip of the tongue. The same test was repeated twice more. The prince was likewise an eyewitness to most of the above-mentioned phenomena, and had a detailed, authentic testimony drawn up about them, beginning with the words: Nous Gaston fils de France Duc d'Orléans, certifions etc., under the 11th of May 1635.

The judges, under these circumstances, could not deny their belief in the truth of the obsession; they also prepared themselves churchly for their judicial office with earnestness, and examined the process for 40 days; Grandier was confronted with the witnesses, and these stood by their statements. He, for his part, denied everything, all the accusations made were lies or imaginings, and he had never engaged in magic. In doing so, he displayed the firmness of his character, and conducted himself throughout the course of the affair with cool blood and great composure and presence of mind. Since he denied the truth of the nuns' possession, he was called upon to conduct the exorcism himself. \[Page 409\]

The Bishop of Poitiers gave him permission and authority; he put on the stole, the possessed were brought into the choir of the church, and now a terrible scene began. He started the exorcism with Sister Catherine, the most ignorant of all, whom he adjured in Latin. But all the others were now seized at once, and began to howl and scream. Sister Clara was the loudest of all, and went at him; he therefore desisted from the former, and turned to her, who, however, without paying attention to him, spoke confused nonsense. The superior stepped in between, he now addressed her again, but had previously said: since she understood Latin, he would speak Greek to her. The response he received then was: Thou art cunning, for thou knowest full well that it is the first condition of the pact not to speak Greek; he had rightly replied: O pulchra illusio, egregia evasio!

Now he was told: he should exorcise in Greek, but first write down what he intended to say. But the possessed ones fell anew into rage, raged and howled, suffered convulsions, accused him of sorcery, and offered to break his neck if it were permitted; but this, as was natural, the exorcists prevented. He himself remained calm and composed amid all the clamor, looked the possessed ones firmly in the eye, spoke of his innocence, and boldly requested only this: that they allow the demons to break his neck, or merely to make a mark on his forehead if he were truly guilty; yet none of the possessed might touch him in the process.

The exorcists brought the raging ones back to calm, and now a chafing dish was brought in to burn four documents of Grandier's that the possessed had submitted. This was done, but now the previous scene repeated itself with double the intensity; the confusion became indescribable, the screaming so piercing, the bearing so frightful, that the assembly---honoring the sanctity of the place---could pass for a true Sabbath. Grandier alone remained unshaken and expressed no astonishment, even though the raving ones threw all his sins in his face, which he in turn denied, renouncing Satan and declaring: that he was, in defiance of him, still a Christian, and more than that, a priest; at times he even joined with the assembled people in singing hymns. This continued, the fury against him increasing from time to time, and he would have been torn apart had the bystanders not prevented it and led him out of the church. On that day they had all the trouble in the world to calm the nuns again.

One must not be astonished at this rabid uproar and this tumult of the powers of hell in human nature. Grandier, a man vigorous in outward life but morally decayed toward death within, unworthy as he might always have been as a priest: now confronted the demonic forces, armed with all the power and authority of the Church, in order to exorcise them. The nuns, as such belonging likewise more closely to the Church, of blameless conduct in their free moments, quiet and good-natured by nature, who carried within themselves the full subjective sense of the man's entanglement---sober though it was---in the demonic, now heard the words of exorcism from his mouth. \[Page 410\]

It had to turn out as when a drop of water falls into red-hot molten copper; their own demonic element had to rise up in wrath and explode terribly. But the entire event could lead to the trace of the whole error and make it comprehensible: that here opposing spheres, which could never understand one another, had come into conflict; and that therefore none could give testimony against the other. Grandier was well aware of his crimes and the untenability of his inner foundation; since every sin entwines itself with the demon, he---as a priest though he was---must know himself to be entangled and confused with him as well. But his sins were of a prosaic nature, committed in clear deliberation, and thus the bond was of like kind; but of actual sorcery he knew himself to be free, and he did not consider it possible that such a thing could be proven against him. Hence his cool-headedness and composure, which now had to explain the nuns' accusations as a work of lies and the malice of his enemies.

The possessed, for their part, were free from all deliberate deceit; they beheld what they uttered with full, subjective conviction of its truth; for the inner side of the man was turned toward their own inner being, and they merely bore witness to what they found inscribed there. But the language in which it was inscribed was a symbolic one, which they, in reading it, had only to translate into the ordinary tongue. The entanglements into which he had fallen with the demon on his path, however, led directly, on their paths, back into their own inner selves; for the same demon had also seized and ensnared them, albeit in a mystical manner; and the same phallic symbols, which appeared frequently in that process and expressed the connection in their intuitions, returned also for the other relations, and they interpreted them in their mystical language. And just as he, on his side, found their accusations---taking them according to the letter---unfounded, and therefore declared them to spring from infamous malice; so the others, in turn, misunderstood this denial of his, and they marveled and were outraged at the shamelessness that dared to deny what lay so clearly and openly before their eyes, even to the point of tangibility.

Thus the matter became ever more deeply confused with every step forward, until it reached utter inextricability; and it could not be expected of the judges that they, alone, should peer beyond the spiritual horizon of the time into the inner recesses of these entanglements. They had the choice: either to declare an entire convent, along with all who had taken part in the affair, as accomplices in a grievous, devilish deception; or to find guilty the one whose evil character they knew full well. If the nuns had recognized him---whom, according to their assurances, they had never seen---at the very first confrontation; then they could not know that this might, at most, be explained by natural clairvoyance.

They had no experiences yet to show that the convulsions which seized the obsessed upon the mere mention of his name gave no conclusive testimony to his objective guilt. If one of the spirits of the superior Johanna had indicated the spots on his body marked by five signs; and now eight physicians, sent to search for them on him, believed they had truly found only two---one on the shoulder, the other on the scrotum---because the needle, driven in there thumb-thick, had produced only a dull pain, and no blood had followed---; then they could not know that even these signs, if they were indubitably present, led into error. \[Page 411\]

The coincidence of a scar on his thumb with a few drops of blood on an attached prescription gave free play to every interpretation. The judges, assembled for the last time, pronounced all unanimously: "We convict, and declare the said Urbain Grandier guilty and convicted of the crime of magic, witchcraft, and possession caused by his actions, in the persons of certain Ursuline nuns of this town of Loudun and other secular individuals; together with the other cases and crimes resulting from this."

Although no court of today, even a thoroughly Catholic one, would render such a judgment in this case; yet one may fully credit the reporter when, in the *Relation veritable* p. 43, he says: they had felt a complete satisfaction in their consciences at their verdict. Before his execution, he was to be put to the torture in the usual manner, in order to discover his accomplices. But he utterly denied having any such; even in the midst of harsh torment he said only that he was no sorcerer, but otherwise he had in truth committed greater crimes than this. When asked: what crimes? he replied: such as arise from human frailty; adding: it would have cost him more to confess these than that of which he was accused.

When they prepared to lead him to his death, he refused every consolation, and pushed away the crucifix that was offered to him. Thus he mounted the pyre; it had been granted to him that he should first be strangled before the flames consumed him; but these seized the rope before the executioner could carry out the deed. So he fell into the flames, which mercilessly devoured the unfortunate man; he who had not the comfort of a clear conscience, and who spurned the consolations of religion because he believed himself abandoned by it.

As he had fallen into the conflict between unbridled sensuality and the duties of his station; so in its train had he fallen into the other, between the inner and outer world, which then entangled him in the third, the external one between Catholics and Huguenots; and now he was torn asunder, as the opposing whirlpools that had seized him pulled him apart. His contemporaries found the judgment of the judges not unjust; only fifty years later, after judges and witnesses had long since died, did Aubin, an exiled Huguenot, write his book. Grandier had here fallen as a victim of the powerful Richelieu, against whom he was said to have written a satire; Laubardemont was the instrument of the minister, Mignon and Barré were the infamous mountebanks who had trained the nuns in their arts; the Bishop of Poitiers and all others who had otherwise taken part in the affair were in agreement; all the rest, Monsieur and the court at their head, weak, credulous fools; all this set forth with bold courage, without further warrant of the facts, and argued through with great intellectual sharpness in a rationalizing manner.

It was the protestation of the ruling exclusive understanding, directed against the equally exclusive inner vision; the rational times that now followed allowed no other word to arise in this matter, and for them it rested in the manner in which this their spokesman had presented it¹⁾. With the death of Grandier, moreover, the matter of the possessions in the convent was by no means settled; they continued for a long time after this catastrophe in all their violence. The act had been of too tragic a nature for the surroundings who had taken part in it to entirely escape participation in this character. \[Page 412\]

Therefore an uncanny spirit went among them, striking to the right and to the left at whatever it encountered. The civil lieutenant Louis Chauvet had taken Grandier's side in the trial, especially in the beginning of the exorcisms, and one of the possessed had later accused him too of sorcery. Terror had now become his demon, and he fell into a state in which he was never again seen fully in his senses thereafter. The surgeon Mannoury, who had examined the accused for stigmatization with the probe, was once going home at night after his death, and suddenly recoiled: Ah, Grandier! what do you want from me? The apparition did not leave him until his own death, which occurred a few days later. Father Lactance, one of the exorcists, felt, while he was occupied with the exorcism, brought upon himself manifold reactions; he soon lost his sight, his memory, then again his senses; he suffered now from heartache, then again from temptations in the spirit; he likewise fell ill a few days after Grandier's death, and died after having endured great demonic assaults.

Five years later, P. Tranquillus, a man of saintly demeanor, died of the same affliction. Everything that had previously transpired over two years in Loudun around him repeated itself in him; without it being able to shake him inwardly, and it did not cease from him even later. When he was supposed to preach at vespers, the tumult became so severe that he did not dare to step forward; his confessor now adjured the demon to release him; immediately he ascended the pulpit and preached for the last time in a way that carried all his listeners away; only with the last unction did the demon depart from him, and seized a brother who was present. All the terrors of hell that had been unleashed in that conflict, while all human passions raged around them, must of themselves have exercised a destructive effect upon sensitive souls; but party spirit, forgetting that friends and enemies alike experienced this influence equally, and that it had itself declared the whole affair a play of human depravity, now unhesitatingly believed in the full truth, in order to recognize therein the work of retributive Nemesis.

In any case, the idea of such retribution has no application to Father Surin, who did not come to Loudun until four months after Grandier's death. Soon he too found himself there in that interchange with the spirits of Jeanne previously described; so that once, in the presence of the Bishop of Nîmes, one of them, during the exorcism, threatened him vehemently from the face of the possessed; then suddenly vanished from there, but instead manifested itself in him through pressure on the breast and loss of speech. Driven out from there by ecclesiastical means, it appeared anew on the face of the superior in all its hideousness, while the father on his side again found himself entirely free. \[Page 413\]

This repeated itself on one morning perhaps up to the eighth time; he was struck as if by an arrow, suddenly thrown to the ground, so that he cried out, and they had to touch him with the sacrament at the places where he felt the demon, in order to free him again. Concerning his inner state during this, the sufferer expressed himself in a very remarkable manner in a letter to his fellow order brother P. Dumesnil in Rennes, dated May 3, 1635. There he says among other things: I cannot explain to you what takes place in me during this time, and how this spirit unites itself with mine, without taking from my soul either its consciousness or its freedom; while it yet behaves like my other self, as if I had two souls, one of which is deprived of the use of its organs, and now, holding itself at a distance, looks on at the doings of the other.

The two spirits contend with each other on the same battlefield, the body, and the soul is as if divided, open in the one to hellish impressions, in the other surrendered to its own movements, or to such as come from God. In the same moment I feel a great peace under God's good pleasure, and at the same time I cannot comprehend the raging aversion against him, which calls forth a fury to separate me from him; to the astonishment of all who see it. At the same time great joy and gentleness come over me, and then again a sadness that manifests itself in complaints and in a screaming, as the demons induce it.

I feel and fear the state of damnation, and sense that foreign soul which seems to me to be my own, pierced by despair as if with thorns; while the other, full of good trust, mocks such sensations, and in all freedom curses the one who calls them forth. In truth, I recognize that that cry which issues from my mouth arises equally from these two souls, and I am at a loss to decide whether it is joyfulness that forces it out, or the extraordinary rage that fills me. The trembling that seizes me when the holy Sacrament is brought near to me seems, as I sense, to have its origin just as much in the abhorrence of its proximity, which is unbearable to me, as in a heartfelt and gentle reverence, without my being able to decide or command that it is more the one or the other.

If I wish, at the urging of the one, to mark my mouth with the cross, the other pulls my arm back with great hatred, and makes me seize the finger with my teeth and bite it in rage. In such storms I always find prayer the easiest; while the body writhes on the ground, and the servants of the church speak to me as to a devil, and pronounce curses against me. I cannot describe to you the joy I feel in being a devil in such a manner; not through rebellion against God, but through the calamity which sincerely shows me the state into which sin has placed me: and as I apply the pronounced imprecations to myself, my soul can immerse itself in its own nothingness. \[Page 414\]

When the other possessed see me in this state, it is a joy to observe how they rejoice, and how the demons make merry over me, saying: Physician, heal thyself now! Mount the pulpit, it would be fine to hear you preach after you have thus wallowed on the ground. --- My state is such that few entirely free actions remain to me. If I wish to speak, my tongue fails me; in the Mass I must suddenly stop; at the table I cannot bring the bite to my mouth; in confession all sins suddenly escape me, and I feel that the devil goes in and out of me as in his own house. When I wake, he is there; when I pray, he stirs my thoughts at will; when the heart begins to open itself to God, he fills it with rage; he lulls me to sleep when I would stay awake, and through the mouths of my possessed he publicly boasts: he is my master, against which I can raise no objection.

Thus two demons deal with me, one is Leviathan, the adversary of the Holy Spirit, and the operations of this false Paraclete are entirely the opposite of those of the true one; they produce a desolation that cannot be described; he is the chief of the band of all demons who here perform this strangest of all things, and we have here at once paradise and hell together, and the nuns 634 here are in one sense true Ursulas, in another sense worse than the most lost ones in filth, blasphemies, and fits of rage.

This remarkable self-confession of a man who surely never let an untrue word pass his lips appears instructive and worthy of great attention in many respects. First, it teaches us to know this state of inner decomposition of the indivisible I in man, which in its higher conscious half walks before and after in the light of grace: while the lower, more deeply entangled with the body, other side lies in the shadowing of the nocturnal principle, and everywhere desiring the opposite and driving to accomplish it, yet is recognized by the observing higher self as its other I. Secondly, the testimony imprints on the other, concerning the reality of the nuns' affliction, who were in states only still more highly intensified, the final seal of certainty.

What finally happened to him in such a manner; what later for twelve more years did not leave him; what once in a paroxysm led him to jump out the window of his order's house, so that he broke a leg, and only later finally left him, so that he for a long time thereafter led a quiet, pious life; what befell the other two exorcists: all this shows us the dangers that are connected with the practice of exorcism. Aubin sees nothing in it but that the devil, whom they had painted on the wall, at last truly appeared to them.

From France we cross over to England once more, and there Hutchinson says: it is the land where the terrors of the witchcraft trials were felt the least, and ceased the earliest. There is not a true word in this assertion, neither with regard to the earlier times nor the present times of the uprising. On 20 February 1647, Howell wrote to Edward Spencer: "Since the beginning of these unnatural wars, clouds of witnesses attest to the existence of witchcraft; for in the short space of two years, nearly three hundred witches were brought before the courts, and most of them all executed, and that solely in Essex and Suffolk. Scotland now swarms with them more than ever, and seven persons of the better classes are executed daily." \[Page 415\]

The Long Parliament sent out into the land one of its own trackers in the person of Hopkins, who boasted of a special gift for finding them, and in one year alone brought sixty to the gallows. He usually employed the water test. Another method was to seat the poor, old, frail women, bound in their limbs in such a way that the entire weight of their bodies rested on their seat-flesh, in the middle of a room for 24 hours; until they, with the interruption of the blood circulation, could no longer endure it, and confessed what then cost them their lives. Others were kept awake continuously for four to five days and nights, until they fell into a kind of unconscious, half-visionary state, and then told things of which they afterward, in a calm state, could nevermore remember anything.

These tests were, beside their cruelty, no more rational than those devised by the Indians in Bengal. Branches of a certain tree are each inscribed with an equal number of the names of the village women, from twelve years upward, and in the morning planted in water; whichever branch then wilts within four and a half hours gives testimony that it belongs to a witch. Or small portions of rice, wrapped in cloth and similarly labeled, are placed into the heaps of white ants; she whose rice has been consumed has then drawn the lot of witchcraft. Finally, at lamplight, oil is poured drop by drop onto water, while the names are called out one after another; the shadow of a woman on the water then marks her as guilty.

The mischief of that Hopkins lasted so long, until one of the more respected men of the land had him himself subjected to the water test, and since he floated on top, he had to pay with his life. Z. Grey in his edition of Hudibras reports: he had seen a list of 3000 who in such a manner, during the rule of the Long Parliament, lost their lives. Especially Lancashire, in the north of England, was designated as the witches' land, and the impostor Robinson had played his game there. Toward the end of the century, only under the judgeship of Holt, did the fury of the persecution begin to abate. The testimonies against the old Munnings, in her trial of 1694, were very peremptory; but he knew how to persuade the jury that they, for the first time in a long while, pronounced her not guilty. Ten other similar trials, which were conducted before him from 1694--1701, had the same outcome.

In the case of Wenham, 1711 under Powell, the jury again pronounced her guilty; when questioned once more by the presiding judge as to whether their verdict went so far as to find that the defendant had consorted with the devil in the shape of a cat, the answer was: We find her guilty thereof. She was, however, pardoned. In the year 1716 the Hicks and her nine-year-old daughter were still hanged, because they had devoted themselves to the devil and raised a storm. With them ends the long series of the condemned; for in 1736 the penal law against sorcery was repealed, and offenses of that kind were punished with imprisonment and the pillory. \[Page 416\]

One may credit Barrington when, in his observations on the twentieth statute of Henry VI, he gives the total number of those executed in England since that statute---soon before the beginning of the Reformation up to the repeal---as 30,000; the same number that is given for those executed by the Inquisition, roughly in that same period but over the whole extent of its power, thus in the whole Romanic south and across to the New World, including the Spanish Jews and Muhammadans. One sees: clergy, judges, and the common people from whom the jury was drawn---all were in perfect agreement in their judgment; in place of the witch epidemic there had crept into judicial practice another one that infected all powers of judgment; and one does not know which of the two plagues was the more ruinous to the land.

This becomes especially visible in Germany during and after the Thirty Years' War. The ruin of the country in that accursed time was without measure or limit; the entire people had grown savage, been brought to ruin and despair; faith and trust in Providence had died out, while ignorance was universal. Thus one sought help from the powers that seemed to rule over the age; and with the vices and horrors that followed in the wake of the armies there also roamed all manner of evil arts. Thus sorcery was customary throughout the land, while on the other hand bloodshed had become a mere sport, human life dirt cheap; and a virtuosity in every kind of violence had soon developed. All these skills were now soon applied also to the witch trials; and between the state actions and the battles, the courts too delivered up their victims to the pyre, as bloody as the others.

When the war had passed, the princes had for the most part carried away from it an unlimited territorial sovereignty; and that modern relation between them and the people had developed, in that they had detached themselves from it and, clothed in their wholly abstract power, had set themselves high above it. The consequence of this exalted position was the substitution of officials, even into those affairs that had previously been wholly personal; from which there again arose a complete isolation of the princes, a total estrangement from the actual course of these affairs, a complete independence of those who burdened themselves with them within their own sphere, and soon a ruthless despotic sway, pressing down below and servile above, seeking to compensate for the loss of power through formality. Such were the governments to which the outcry over the witchcraft folly was addressed. All the misery of the time, all the people's need, all the country's devastation, men had prepared it for themselves; their base passions, their apostasy from religion and morality and from themselves, they had filled the witches' cauldron with mischief and abomination until it boiled over, and destruction seized the sorcerers themselves. Now all this was to be laid at the door of the unfortunate witch-women; what nature herself, imitating man, had at times brought forth strange and pernicious things, it was all their doing. \[Page 417\]

In the general barbarization and the crude superstition that had taken the place of faith, every accusation was eagerly seized upon; malice, envy, spite, and the lust for slander grasped with delight at the prey; and thus what had begun with a rumor here or there soon grew into a clamor that spread across all the lands; and it finally reached even the princes in the heights of their abstraction. "Thus it is said: This pest, which corrupts land and people, must be rooted out with all severity. The judges and councils are forthwith instructed to proceed against the sorcerous vermin. With this the princes have now done their part, the cancer is now cut out, all harm from Satan's folk is prevented, they have fulfilled their office, and have shown their zeal in protecting God's honor, and in raging against His enemies with fire and rope. They have now unburdened their conscience, and shifted the responsibility onto the shoulders of the officials; from their lofty height they cannot look more closely to see whether humanity, justice, and equity prevail in the proceedings. But the justice officials, for their part, are not inclined to take the responsibility onto their own shoulders; if innocents must sometimes bleed, that does not concern us, that is the prince's affair, he has his conscience, and must know what is incumbent upon him when he presses us; he may look to it, it is for us to obey."

\"The judges are thus to begin now; but they lack all indicia and proofs, and even, in a certain sense, the criminals themselves. Thus they do not know where to make a start, and they hesitate for a while. They are admonished a first, second, and third time. The people cry out: their laxity has good reasons. The same is made known to the princes; but to rail against these is a grave matter in Teutonia; for whatever they do is well done, so believes the servility of the age. Thus they finally yield, after having cut themselves a starting thread; or if they still hold out longer, an extraordinary commissioner is specially dispatched for the matter; perhaps an inexperienced novice, whose clumsy ineptitude, however, counts as zeal for justice, and whom the reward of 4--5 thalers per head, and other incidental benefits, spurs even further to the task. T \[Page 418\]

he word of a possessed person, or a malicious remark against some old woman, is reported to them; thus they begin with her. In the meantime, however, no process can be started on mere hearsay. Thus they spy into her past life, and it would have to go very ill if that were not found tainted with ill repute; for she has perhaps committed all sorts of evils, and it soon becomes clear that from evil to evil she has finally advanced to the very wellspring of all evils. Or her life was blameless, she went often to church and to the sacraments; that is an equally telling indicium as the former; for the witches, as is well known, are wont to hide behind a pretense of piety. Thus it is ordered that the rightfully suspected be arrested. In the process, new signs emerge again that point to her guilt. She shows herself fearful and startled, for instance, because she already knows what cruel torture awaits her: that is a wholly certain token of her criminality; for her conscience accuses her of the crimes. Or she shows herself undaunted, trusting in her innocence: once more an excellent indicium; for it is the way of the witches to display an iron brow, and to profess themselves entirely innocent. To gather further proofs, special sleuths are sent out; mostly godless folk, to whom it can scarcely fail to uncover something that can be interpreted as sorcery; all the easier if they already bear ill will toward the prisoner. Now it is said: strong indicia lie before us.\"

She is therefore taken into interrogation; no defender is permitted to her, for it is said: her crime is an exceptional case; and it is not easy to find such persons who might be willing to undertake the defense, because suspicion immediately attaches itself to them; just as all those who wish to speak in the matter, and admonish the judge to caution, are very readily branded as patrons of witches. She is therefore brought forward, and the indications of guilt are read to her. If she now completely clears herself of them, and justifies herself against all of them, that avails her nothing at all; the accusations remain in full force; she is merely led back to the dungeon, to reflect there more closely: whether she wishes to remain obstinate; for she is always obstinate if she seeks to clear herself of the accusation.

That is therefore a new indication of guilt; for she would never be so eloquent if she were not a witch. Another day is therefore appointed for her, and if she has truly considered the matter and remained stubborn, then the decree of torture is notified to her. "Thus is now the weak, powerless woman given over to this hellish instrument; after a most careful search of the entire body has previously been conducted, to see whether she might not be carrying some secret charm against the pain. And these pains, they would be unbearable even if they lasted only half a quarter-hour, indeed even only half of that space of time; and now, in defiance of the prohibition by Pope Paul the Third, the time of the still sharpened torture is extended beyond half an hour; indeed the torture is declared insufficient if it does not last a full hour. \[Page 419\]

The very strongest have confessed: the torment is so excessively great that, to be rid of it, they would without scruple confess the very worst crimes, even at the risk of their future salvation. Some, who are convinced that they would be eternally and irretrievably lost if they confessed to such infamy while innocent, struggle long against the monstrous pain, but ultimately succumb; and then, in the dungeon, they fall into the deepest sorrow and despair, because there is no one to raise them up and comfort them. Many are killed by it, others crippled for life: many were so torn and mangled that the executioner did not dare, at the execution, to bare their shoulders before the people; some had to be executed on the way to the court, so that they would not collapse. It is begun with what they call a mild torture, or rather no torture at all; a toothed iron press is placed over the shins, and the flesh is crushed flat with it until the blood spurts out.

The tormented one now perhaps confesses right away; and then she is lost by law. Or she denies it; then the torture is repeated, and doubled, tripled, quadrupled, until her stubbornness is overcome. To be sure, the laws forbid repetition upon the old indications; but for that they have found the expedient of determining the time of the torture at about five quarter-hours, and dividing this over three days. In her agonies the unfortunate one is sharply observed: if she rolls her eyes, then it is judged: See! she is seeking her paramour; but if the eyes remain rigidly open, then it is said: she has found him! If she is silent, then it is the maleficium of taciturnity; if convulsions run through her facial muscles, then it is said: she has laughed; if nature, in the excessive degree of pain, brings sleep over the unfortunate one, then her guilt is proven beyond all doubt; if she becomes clairvoyant, then they have what they wanted; if she dies, then Satan has broken her neck, so that his secret might not come out, and she is now buried under the gallows.

The judges must, for the office which they themselves cannot exercise, make use of other instruments, the executioners; a crude folk, full of malice and hardness of heart, to whom the unfortunate ones now find themselves delivered up as a prize.
